HEADLINE: Taiwan Voted for Status Quo, not One China;
A Stinging Defeat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Contrary to your Dec. 24 editorial on the Dec. 21 Taiwan election, the ruling Kuomintang Party "victory" was not "a vote for one China." How could it be? The Kuomintang-dominated Government banned the opposition party's platform of an independent "Republic of Taiwan" even from election posters. The Government arrested a score of pro-independence leaders on election eve. 
The Kuomintang spent millions of dollars buying votes throughout the island, as many election observers attested. The Government subdivided Taiwan into myriad tiny districts tailored for Kuomintang candidates.
 The Kuomintang also controls the electronic media. The triumph of its propaganda can be seen in your acceptance of the Kuomintang line on the election outcome.
 The election was a stinging defeat for the Kuomintang's policy of reunification with the mainland. In 1990, using the same districting tactics, the ruling party was able to garner more than 90 percent of the vote in elections for local officials. This time, despite control of the airwaves, vote buying, gerrymandering, crackdowns and propaganda, it came up with only 70 percent of the vote.
 The 24 percent of the population that voted for the Democratic Progressive Party also gave the lie to the Government claim that only 6 percent of the people support independence. The figure is far higher. On an island where advocating "one China, one Taiwan" can bring charges of sedition and a stiff jail sentence, pollsters are unlikely to get the truth to questions about independence.
 The "One China" policy is a fantasy the Kuomintang uses to justify its a grip on Taiwan maintained by a vast security network and the ever-present threat of detention and imprisonment. It is also the policy of the totalitarian government on the mainland, whose claim to Taiwan is dubious at best.
 Forty-five years after the Nationalist Party massacred 20,000 people and a generation of the island's leaders in a 1947 revolt, the Taiwanese still hunger for compensation and justice. The delight with which the Taiwanese evade taxes and regulations, and the enormous underground economy are expressions of the contempt in which the Kuomintang is held across the island.
 With a Government that permits the islanders little say in their national affairs, and the electoral cheating the Kuomintang uses to stay in power, it is only a matter of time until the ruling party itself brings about the result it is trying to forestall: Taiwan independence.
 
DAVID W. TSAI
President, Center for
Taiwan International Relations
Washington, Dec. 30, 1991

LENGTH: 784 words

HEADLINE: New York Needs Three Heroes, Not One

BYLINE: Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton; Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton are, respectively, director of research and president of the Citizens Budget Commission.

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins, Gov. Mario Cuomo and Felix Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, are likely to strike a deal soon that will shape the health of New York City's economy and the fiscal viability of its government. Its elements may be outlined by Jan. 16, when the Mayor submits his four-year financial plan to the State Financial Control Board. This plan should be examined to determine whether it addresses the city's underlying problems or merely papers over them.
The crux of the problem is that in the 1980's the government grew too large to be sustained by the economic base that remained after the Wall Street crash of October 1987 and the 1991 recession. The first fiscal adjustment to this harsh problem was the budget adopted last June. To close a $2.3 billion gap projected for the current fiscal year, the city adopted a "tax and slash" program. 
 To avoid a repeat performance, new arrangements for delivering and financing municipal services must be devised.
Mayor Dinkins must commit himself to change the way the city does business. This means pruning nonessential activities and revising work rules that determine how basic services are delivered. For example, the city could sell its AM and FM radio stations and its television station; they might fetch as much as $40 million. It might consider a Charter referendum on eliminating the five borough presidents, who are served by more than 500 political appointees. And it may have to oblige sanitation workers to collect trash on extended routes that require more than four or five hours' work per day, and may have to redeploy police officers from desk to patrol duties.
Through such reforms, which protect services by improving productivity, a minimum of 25,000 jobs should be eliminated over the next four years by attrition without layoffs.
Mayor Dinkins voiced a commitment to such changes in a speech in the summer, but the modification of his financial plan presented in November did not fulfill the promise: it proposed to cut only 11,100 positions over four years, with most of the reduction postponed until fiscal years 1995 and 1996. The January plan should schedule more productivity savings sooner and begin to specify the means of achieving them.
Governor Cuomo must commit himself to change the way the state finances welfare and Medicaid programs. The state requires the city and counties to pay nearly half the non-Federal portion of these programs -- a greater local share than in any other state. The result is high local taxes in New York City and Erie County, which have relatively large numbers of poor residents. Wealthier areas with fewer poor residents, such as Nassau and Westchester counties, do not pay a fair share of the costs of helping the state's impoverished.
The long-run solution is for the state to assume the non-Federal share of welfare and Medicaid costs. Using its broader tax base to finance welfare and Medicaid would permit local governments to reduce their levies. This would permit New York City local taxes to be reduced by about $2.4 billion.
In September, Governor Cuomo endorsed this policy for Medicaid. But the details of his subsequent plan didn't match his rhetoric. His plan for state assumption of Medicaid is inadequate because it is stretched over eight years, with little financial impact in the near future. It requires the city to earmark personal income tax revenues for Medicaid, and other counties to do so with sales tax revenues. The plan is predicated on the success of unspecified cost-control measures.
The Governor says this plan is the best he can hope to get through the Legislature, especially the Republican-dominated Senate. Both can do better. The January financial plan should contemplate significant fiscal relief from state assumption of Medicaid in the fiscal 1993-96 period.
The Mayor's and Governor's desire to gain relief from the Municipal Assistance Corporation puts Mr. Rohatyn in a difficult position. The agency can refinance about $1 billion of bonds that will mature in 1992, 1993, 1994 and 1995. This would save the city an equal sum in that period because the bonds would not have to be repaid until later. But by providing short-run fiscal relief, Mr. Rohatyn would reduce the pressure on Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo to produce the needed changes. Without these changes, Municipal Assistance Corporation help transfers today's cost to tomorrow's New Yorkers.
Mr. Rohatyn should protect the city's future. Before mortgaging it, he should insist that Mayor Dinkins agree to seek a smaller, more productive municipal government and that Governor Cuomo commit himself to meaningful Medicaid reform.

HEADLINE: Trade Discord Persists as Bush Arrives in Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 7

 BODY:
President Bush began his visit to Japan today in an atmosphere of contention and confusion, with negotiators for the United States and Japan in sharp disagreement over an American demand for Japan to buy more American automobiles and parts.
At issue are both the amount of cars and parts that Japanese auto makers and dealers would purchase and how the commitment would be described in light of Tokyo's insistence that purchases should be left up to Japanese businesses and not to the Government, officials on both sides said. 
"There is no agreement, and we're still skirmishing," a Japanese official said, speaking with some exasperation. He said the disputes could not be resolved until after negotiations with Mr. Bush, his top advisers and 18 corporate leaders on the final and most important leg of his four-nation Asia trip.
Nevertheless, the White House has expressed confidence that in four days of trade talks the President will be successful in achieving his goal of winning concessions from Tokyo that will appear, at least, to prop up America's slumping economy. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa is said to be eager to give Mr. Bush some of what he seeks. [Page A8.]
Mr. Bush came to Japan, the final country in his Asian tour, from Seoul, South Korea. The Government there canceled annual military maneuvers it was due to hold with United States forces, after receiving indications that North Korea was ready to allow inspections of secret nuclear installations. The President said during his Korean visit that the end of the 40-year-old division of the Korean peninsula was finally within reach. [Page A8.]
A principal area of disagreement with Japan concerned earlier announcements by Japanese auto manufacturers that they would raise American purchases to about $17 billion by 1994 from the current $9 billion.
A Japanese official said on Monday that the United States was demanding that this target be doubled or tripled. An American official denied that American demands were so sweeping, but he added, "We're shooting for Japan to up the ante a little bit more."
There was considerable confusion about whether Japan would agree to any kind of target or quota on automobile parts. Early in the day, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, Kozo Watanabe, said Japan would set specific targets for imports of American-made autos and auto parts.
But later, the deputy minister, Yuji Tanahashi, contradicted him, saying the Government was not asking the automobile industry for targets, but only to consider "various forms of cooperation." He added, "I guess the minister's remarks are a sort of wishful thinking."
The Japanese were said to be especially resistant to demands that targets be set for the purchase of American cars, since they would ultimately have to be purchased by consumers, who are free to buy what they want. American models now account for less than one-half of 1 percent of the 5.1 million cars sold annually in Japan.
Japan was, however, reportedly preparing some incentives to get dealers to handle American cars, although there was widespread skepticism that this would ease consumer distaste for American cars.
American cars are widely perceived here as being inferior in quality, too big and with too few concessions to Japan's narrow roads and to the fact that the Japanese drive on the left side of the road. European cars are much more popular in Japan than American cars.
 
Resentment and Concern
 Japan's accessions in part to the American demands are being carried out in an atmosphere of some resentment, coupled with concern that something be done for Mr. Bush to head off even worse trade pressures or threats of sanctions from Congress or the President's Democratic rivals.
"This is crazy," a Japanese official said. "If consumers don't buy the final products, are all these cars and parts going to end up being dumped in the gutter? But we just have to do something."
In a separate development reflecting the deepening sense of urgency over Mr. Bush's trip, it was announced that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady would fly to Japan to be with the President. That fueled speculation that broader financial issues and policies would be discussed.
All the American demands are viewed in Japan as resulting from political pressures in the United States, prompting a desire in Japan to help President Bush, who is seen here as basically opposed to protectionism and to the anti-Japanese retaliation advocated by many Democrats.
Intense talks have taken place behind the scenes in recent days between the Government and auto industry leaders in particular, since automobiles and parts account for three-quarters of the $41 billion American trade deficit with Japan.
On Monday Prime Minister Miyazawa again called on Japanese auto manufacturers to show some flexibility and, in effect, to help bail out the American car industry -- and also President Bush -- at a time of deepening economic woes in the United States.
"Japanese auto manufacturers may have some difficulties in meeting the request of the Government to do more than they have been doing," he told a group of American reporters. "But I think they are understanding to the need to contribute to the solution of the American problems.
"I think I can persuade them that it is in their own interest in the longer term to do so," he added.
Sounding a familiar theme, Mr. Miyazawa said that the Japanese must act, not to open markets that are closed, but out of a sense of obligation for past American generosity to the nation it defeated in World War II.
"It's over 40 years that Japan has benefited from the friendship of the United States, and it's about time we reciprocate," he said. "We'd like to be a friend in need."
Mr. Miyazawa's comments, couching Japanese actions as acts of generosity or compassion, have left a bitter taste for some Americans and some Japanese. A commentator recently said it was as if Japan were being asked to make reparations payments 45 years after its war defeat.
 
Some Implicit Criticism
 While sounding a basically conciliatory note, Mr. Miyazawa also rejected recent comments by President Bush and others that Japanese trade practices had contributed to the American recession.
"External trade is contributing positively, not negatively, to your growth," he said, explaining that Japanese imports of American products had grown by 70 percent since 1987, a far higher growth rate than exports to the United States.
The Prime Minister, who is a former finance minister, also implicitly criticized American economic policies, saying that the recession was attributable to indebtedness by consumers and businesses, weakness of banks and high interest rates resulting from the American budget deficit.
Spokesmen for the Japanese automobile manufacturers and dealers said that they were ready to cooperate with Mr. Miyazawa and other Government leaders, but they criticized the United States, saying it had not done its part to sell its cars in Japan or cater to Japanese consumer tastes.
"Japanese auto dealers are ready to sell U.S.-made cars if they meet Japanese consumers' preferences and if dealers are guaranteed appropriate profits," said Kenichiro Ueno, president of the Japan Automobile Dealers Association.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Schools Vie in a Marketplace: More 'Choice' Can Mean Less

SERIES: Lessons From Britain: First of two articles.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
More than three years after Britain applied a free-market cure to its ailing schools, using the same ideas President Bush endorses for American education, its schools relish their growing authority but parents find they still do not have enough good schools to choose from.
The measures that President Bush prescribes for American educational ills are now the law in Britain: national curriculum standards, national tests and "choice," a voucher-like system in which money goes not to parents but to schools, based on the number of students they attract. 
 The British system aims at forcing schools to compete for students. Bad schools will go under, the theory runs, and good schools will thrive. Giving individual schools control over their own budgets and decisions, the Government reasons, will also give schools the tools to compete.
Although results are still being debated and there are no data yet on whether students are learning more, some conclusions are being drawn. School officials say they manage far better with less bureaucracy. But parents find they have less of a choice than they want, because good schools fill up quickly and bad schools sink slowly.
There is no proof that choice actually improves bad schools. And some schools are trying to insure good results by screening out less desirable students, whether they are handicapped, troubled or slow learners, a form of discrimination that American critics fear would occur if choice were adopted in the United States.
 
Impacts Appear to Be Muted
 Schools across Britain are feeling the changes. "We're using words like 'market forces' and 'consumer-oriented,' words I've never heard in all my years of teaching," said Jane Traies, the head teacher, or principal, of Swakeleys School, a girls' high school in West London.
In the county of Warwickshire, in central England, one school even offered a discount on shower units as an incentive for parents to enroll their children.
Over all, however, choice appears to have had neither the catastrophic effects its critics feared nor the rejuvenating impact its advocates predicted. The debate now is whether this means that choice has gone too far or not far enough.
What no one disputes is that Britain's Education Reform Act, passed in June 1988, ushered in the most sweeping changes since World War II.
The act was a response to longstanding dissatisfaction with British education: for years, students had scored lower than those in other countries, employers had complained of their workers' poor skills, and bloated educational bureaucracies seemed impervious to pressures for change.
 
National Curriculum
 For the first time in modern British history the law required a national curriculum and national examinations based on that curriculum. In Britain, the national Government pays 80 percent of all education costs, as against 6 percent in the United States. The new law used this leverage to enact choice, declaring that most of the money schools receive would be based on how many students they attracted.
And, to allow competition, students can choose any publicly supported school, even one outside the normal geographic boundaries. Unlike President Bush's proposals to extend choice to private and religious schools, in Britain choice applies only to publicly financed schools.
Local education authorities, the equivalent of American school districts, must now hand over to individual schools 85 percent of their budgets, rather than deducting central administrative costs first, so that schools themselves can decide when to repair windows or how many teachers to hire. Schools that want complete autonomy can even "opt out" of the district altogether, receiving money and guidance only from the national Government. The law applies to England and Wales.
 
Selling Schools
Traditions Meet New Pressures
 The law has made schools across Britain newly market-conscious, for good and ill. Many schools now produce brochures describing their philosophies, extracurricular activities, and any rules, such as requiring uniforms -- a big draw for parents fond of tradition. Many have actually hired market consultants. Most districts issue pamphlets for parents listing all the schools in their area and explaining procedures for appeals if children do not get into the school they want. Such appeals more than doubled in the first year after the law went into effect.
"There is enormous pressure on schools to market themselves," Ms. Traies said.
Indeed, some schools, like the one offering shower units, have gone to extremes. But such pressures can be constructive, said David Hart, president of the National Association of Head Teachers, which offered marketing advice to its 32,000 members.
"Schools have got to produce something that sells their school to prospective parents," he said. "They must start writing down what's their ethos, their approach. That has forced schools to think more deeply about what they are trying to achieve."
It is less clear, however, whether choice is actually improving schools.
The Government has not conducted any national studies of the results of choice. But several scholars and school district officials say that for the most part, good schools fill up quickly and bad schools wither slowly. Sue Clark, press officer for the Department of Education and Science, said that very few schools had actually closed.
Instead, said Margaret Maden, director of education for Warwickshire, "the signs are of a slow, lingering death, damaging to children in that school and to teachers, whose morale and skill deteriorates."
 
Argument of Critics
 The problem, according to Ms. Maden and scholars studying the changes, is that choice is not explicitly linked to measures that would improve failing schools -- an argument also made by American critics. Instead, bad schools are stripped of the money they might need to turn themselves around.
"School improvement doesn't operate in a simple market way," said Peter Mortimore, deputy director of the University of London's Institute of Education and an authority on what traits make schools effective. "It operates by skilled help being provided to the failing school, by changing the principal, by giving special resources."
In Warwickshire, for example, Ms. Maden said, she had worked quietly to ease out 13 principals in the last few years and to help troubled schools draw up plans to improve. "If for a variety of reasons your child does go to the nearest school, you should know that the nearest school is good enough," she said. "We must act for those children not able to exercise their exit right, possibly because their parents are too busy instead trying to keep body and soul together."
Some failing schools have managed to turn themselves around, although it is not clear whether choice made the difference. The Kingsdale School in South London was on the verge of being closed down. Stephen Williams, who became principal just as choice was introduced, told The London Evening Standard that school test scores and enrollment had risen dramatically after he held students and teachers to higher standards and heeded parents' wishes to bring back school uniforms.
In the Wandsworth borough of London, the man known as former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's favorite educator is trying to create a model of what choice can achieve. Donald Naismith, Wandsworth's director of education, has begun to set up a wide range of schools offering different types of programs tailored to students with different levels of ability.
Yet even in Wandsworth, parents complain that their choices are limited. One parent who moved to Wandsworth, Carla Milner-Barry, said the best local elementary school had a long waiting list. The other school within walking distance is slated to be closed next year, and other local schools had bad reputations. Ms. Milner-Barry ended up enrolling her daughter in a private school, and said several other private schools had opened in Wandsworth in the last few years.
 
More Choice, Not Less
 Mr. Naismith acknowledges the problem, but says the answer is more choice, not less. He argues that to allow parents wider choices and to force schools to improve, the Government should remove bureaucratic obstacles so that bad schools would be forced to close quickly and new schools could spring up to meet demand. But because declining school enrollment has meant that many schools have empty places, the Government usually denies permission to open new ones.
There is also some evidence that competition has increased pressure on schools to screen potentially troublesome students, raising questions of equal opportunity.
Ms. Maden said that at least one school in Warwickshire had balked at the national policy of placing children with special educational needs in regular classrooms. "The school said, 'You must be joking,' " she said. " 'You'll make us into a dunces school.' "
Several school officials said they feared these tendencies would accelerate if a Government plan to publish nationwide school rankings based on examination scores passes Parliament, as expected. Many said a fairer measure would be how much progress children made on test scores.
Some scholars and politicians also worry that poor children may lose out because their parents do not have the money, time, or energy to get them into the best school.
"The evidence of all other markets is where there is limited supply, those who have the economic and cultural resources to get the most desirable products will get them," said Geoff J. Whittey, a professor of education policy and management at the University of London's Goldsmiths' College.
So far, no studies have examined which parents are the most aggressive and successful in choosing schools for their children. Tim Eggar, England's second-ranking education official, said the Government is considering measures aimed particularly at poor families. "But this isn't an argument for depriving everyone else of the benefits these reforms bring," he said.
 
'Opting Out'
A Few Schools Go It Alone
 Small Heath, a high school in a desolate section of Birmingham, was the first inner-city school in the country to "opt out" of any control by its district, after a bruising political battle with the Labor Party-controlled district.
These "grant-maintained" schools receive money directly from the national Government. They are freed from any regulation by the district, but must send financial reports, examination results, attendence and employment data to the government.
Grant-maintained schools are a potent form of competition for regular schools because they are freer to chart their own course, are very attractive to parents, and have received generous Government grants that have allowed most to buy equipment or fix buildings. The closest parallel in the United States is an experiment in Minnesota, where the legislature this year allowed the creation of schools run independently of the local school district.
Of the 26,000 schools in England and Wales, there are now about 150 grant-maintained schools, with another 150 waiting to be approved.
Of all the changes the education law has brought, grant-maintained schools have aroused the most opposition.
Since opting out in September 1989, Small Heath, which serves poor, predominantly Indian and Pakistani families, has been transformed, with the help of government grants for computers, color copiers, laboratories and maintenance. The school, which used to have four computers for more than 800 students, now has 150. In all, over the last few years, Small Heath has received about $395,000 in such grants, Mr. Knight said.
His teachers, many of whom were wary, are converts. "For so many years, we existed on a shoestring," said Noel O'Kane, the head of Small Heath's mathematics department. "Suddenly, all this money starts to flow. It made it possible to do our jobs."
Schools maintained by grants are given the same budgets they would have received from their school district, but are eligible for additional special grants. Opponents say the initial influx of cash has helped give the schools an edge on the competition and a certain cachet among parents.
"Grant-maintained schools were clearly designed to structure an education system to have elite schools and other schools," said Derek Fatchett, the deputy education spokesman for the Labor Party. "They have the dice loaded in their favor."
The borough of Hillingdon provides a vivid case study of the impact of choice. Hillingdon is the first school district in England where more than half the high schools have opted out, taking a big slice of the local district's budget with them. Kathleen Higgins, Hillingdon's director of education and community services, stands to lose $4 million from a $164 million budget next year. She has already cut one-third of her staff. Local school districts in the United States also stand to lose money under choice plans if students choose schools in other districts.
Swakeleys, however, does not plan to join the exodus. On balance, Ms. Traies believes her school, which is popular enough to have a long waiting list, gains more than it loses from remaining part of the school district. "Yes, there are bureaucratic nonsenses, but at the end of the day, there is also the support," she said.
 
Taking Charge
U.S. Educators Watch Closely
 Of all the changes, the move to place decision-making and budgetary power in the hands of local schools has been the most successful and most popular. The experience is particularly relevant to the United States because several studies of American schools have found that bureaucracies absorb a great deal of money before it reaches individual schools, and some scholars have suggested adopting English-style changes in the United States.
Local management of schools, as it is called in Britain, requires that a district hand over 85 percent of a school's budget to be spent by the school itself. All of Britain's high schools, and a growing number of its elementary schools, are now locally managed.
By 1994, all schools will manage their own finances, school meals, maintenance, and the hiring and recruiting of teachers and other staff. The districts are responsible for insurance, special programs for handicapped or learning-disabled children, libraries, and school psychologists and social workers.
If the experience of Bishopshalt School in Hillingdon is any guide, public schools can do without a great deal of bureaucracy. At Bishopshalt, which has opted out, two people -- Roland Parry, the deputy head, and one other teacher -- supervise a huge variety of activities once performed by the school district. These include cleaning, grounds maintenance, school meals, insurance, managaing and investing the school's $4 million budget, and deciding how many teachers to hire. They buy from the school district services that would be too expensive for an individual school to maintain, like teacher training or career programs.
Although the new responsibilities are considerable and at times overwhelming, most principals say they would never go back. "You have control over your own destiny," said Ms. Traies of Swakeleys. "You can make decisions, like let's paint the canteen, which the borough didn't paint for 15 years."
School districts have also felt the sting of competition. In Hillingdon, for example, Ms. Higgins told her staff to draw up a brochure of services, and set out selling them to many of the grant-maintained schools in the district. She is planning to hire a marketing expert, who will be expected to earn a salary through the revenue from extra sales.
Next: A national curriculum, with national tests.

HEADLINE: On Japan Leg of Journey, Bush's Stakes Are High

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Tuesday, Jan. 7

 BODY:
President Bush arrived in Japan today for four days of politically freighted trade talks, hoping to cap a four-nation sweep of the Western Pacific with concessions from Tokyo that will appear, at least, to prop up America's slumping economy.
Mr. Bush brings his top advisers on the region, his commerce secretary and a platoon of 18 American corporate leaders with him to Osaka and Tokyo. 
 The Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, was said to be eager to give Mr. Bush some of what he seeks. The White House expressed confidence that the public will judge the visit a success.
"I think we feel pretty good that they're going to be responsive," the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said of the Japanese.
 
Jobs, Jobs, Politics

 
 But the real stakes in Mr. Bush's visit are not the financial benefits to American companies, which appear comparatively small, but the political and public-relations gains or losses, which are potentially huge.
For weeks before he began his Western Pacific swing, the President cast his journey as a "relentless" personal quest to boost exports, and thus create more jobs for American companies mired in recession. Success would presumably help counter charges by Democratic rivals in the coming election that the White House has no domestic economic policy and no feel for the fiscal problems of the average person.
A good end to the Tokyo visit would also help defuse a challenge to Mr. Bush from the political right, where Patrick Buchanan, a Republican presidential candidate, has advocated an "America first" foreign policy that would retaliate against restrictive Japanese trade policies.
Mr. Bush has singled out Japanese trade barriers as his target, asserting that each $1 billion in American exports creates 20,000 new jobs at home.
Since Mr. Buchanan began his campaign, both he and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher have broadly hinted that Japanese trade barriers are at least partly to blame for the American recession, which has erased nearly 2 million jobs since July 1990.
By the Administration's reckoning, the nation could add more than 800,000 jobs if it wiped out the trade deficit solely by selling more to Japan, rather than by cutting American purchase of Japanese imports.
The President has refused to say how many jobs he hopes to create or to set any explicit goals for the visit to Japan. "I can guarantee you political opponents, no matter what is achieved, will be saying, 'Hey, you didn't jump quite high enough; you need to get over the bar; we just raised it another foot,' " he said at a news conference on Monday. "What is important is that we handle this relationship with a broad global sense, that we make progress on the economic front."
 
Hopes Exceed Expectations
 Perhaps sensing that it had raised hopes too high, Mr. Bush's aides have sought to play down public expectations. In interviews, they have stressed that the United States' economic problems cannot be remedied in a single meeting and that the answer to the trade deficit lies not just in persuading Tokyo to buy American goods, but in improving American quality and productivity.
After landing this morning, Mr. Bush flew by helicopter to nearby Kyoto, Japan's former capital, to tour the old Imperial Palace and to lunch with an old friend, former Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who was ousted by his own party in the fall.
Mr. Bush also engaged several men at the palace in a round of kemari, a 1,000-year-old game in which a stuffed ball is kicked from player to player.
The President's major activity today is a visit to a Toys "R" Us store near Osaka. The Administration is highlighting the store's success in entering the Japanese market under an agreement that lifted restrictions that favored "mom and pop" stores and prevented larger American chains from gaining a foothold in Japan.
Mr. Bush plans three meetings with his business delegation and Japanese business leaders during his stay.
Mr. Bush enjoys widespread support in his mission to Tokyo from allies in the Western Pacific, including all three nations he has visited in the last eight days. Leaders of those nations, some of whom recall Japan's sometimes brutal occupation of their homelands during World War II, now are openly fearful that they will soon be dominated not militarily, but by Japanese investment in their economies.
South Korea's president, Roh Tae Woo, was said to have discussed Japan with Mr. Bush at a private dinner on Sunday, a South Korean official said. South Korea runs an annual trade deficit with Japan totaling $8 billion.
That official, who refused to be named, said that Japan's refusal to apologize for its aggressive acts in World War II, as the Germans did, have denied it "moral strength" in the Pacific. Without another significant military and economic presence in the area, Mr. Roh is said to have told Mr. Bush, "it is bad news for all of us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush playing the traditional Japanese sport of kemari, a game similar to soccer, in the courtyard of the old Imperial Palace in Kyoto, Japan. At right was a former Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Fell 11.2% Last Year

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 6

 BODY:
United States auto sales ended 1991 on a positive note, but the upturn capped the weakest year since 1983 and one in which the industry performed far worse than many experts had predicted. In addition, the Big Three auto makers relinquished a larger share of the American market to the Japanese.
Retail sales of domestically made cars and trucks rose 7.7 percent in the Dec. 21-31 period, largely because of strong pickup truck sales by Ford and Chevrolet, a year-end surge stimulated by incentives for buyers and anticipated by analysts. That closed out a year in which sales of all vehicles sold in the United States dropped 11.2 percent from the year before. For all of December, car and truck sales, domestic and foreign, declined 2.5 percent. 
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for cars in the 10-day period was 7.1 million.
 
 
Pickups Sell the Best
 For the year, sales of all imported and domestic vehicles reached 12,326,772 -- 8,231,991 cars and 4,094,781 light trucks. That compared with a 1990 total of 13,877,259 -- 9,356,883 cars and 4,520,376 trucks. The top-selling vehicles in 1991 were Ford F-Series pickup trucks, followed by the Chevrolet C/K pickups, the Honda Accord and the Ford Taurus.
"It was a disappointing year," said Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Associaton. Mr. Webb had predicted in October 1990 that 1991 sales would run close to 13.5 million. But poor sales early this year, in part because of a drop in consumer confidence during the Persian Gulf crisis, prompted him to revise his expectations downward. A surge in late summer aroused analysts' optimism, but sales have slid steadily since.
For the coming year, analysts have estimated that the market will rise roughly 10 percent, to sales of 13.5 million vehicles. Mr. Webb said the market should turn up for a number of reasons, including the most recent cut in the prime lending rate by the Federal Reserve, which is expected to lower the costs of auto and other consumer loans.
The aging stock of cars on the road today also suggests pent-up demand for new vehicles; the average age of automobiles is now 7.6 years, with 42 percent of cars older than 8 years. In 1980, the average age of cars was 6.6 years, Mr. Webb said.
 
 
Dealers See More Interest
 Some dealers said their business had improved markedly since Christmas. Louis J. Fusz Jr., owner of the Lou Fusz Automotive Network in St. Louis, said his 14 foreign and domestic franchises sold 100 cars on Saturday. It was the first time his dealerships recorded a 100-sales Saturday in more than a year and a half. He attributed the improvement to the Dec. 20 drop in the prime rate, the strength of the stock market and President Bush's expressions of interest in redirecting the economy.
"Consumer confidence seems to be on the upswing," Mr. Fusz said.
Anthony P. Tremonte, general sales manager of Ekblade Oldsmobile-Cadillac-Pontiac in Hamden, Conn., also noted more people in the showroom in the days just after Christmas and New Year's Day. Some shoppers said they were encouraged by the drop in interest rates. Other industry watchers, however, are less optimistic about 1992. The WEFA Group, a financial consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., still expects sales to rise this year, but it recently reduced its 1992 estimate to 13.1 million, from 13.5 million. Edward J. Sullivan, vice president of automotive consulting, said that consistently low consumer confidence would result in flat or negative sales in the first quarter, rather than the gain he had predicted just weeks ago. He now thinks sales will not rebound until midway through the second quarter.
 Analysts estimated that the European car and truck market outperformed the American market in 1991 for the first time in recent memory. Although final European sales have not been tabulated, DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., estimated them at 13.5 million cars, up roughly 1.7 percent from 1990.
The General Motors Corporation, the industry leader, posted a 1.2 percent rise in domestic vehicle sales in late December. G.M.'s United States sales dropped 12.6 percent in 1991, to 4.34 million cars and trucks, including imports sold by G.M. Of all the G.M. divisions, only Buick scored a sales gain last year, of 1.4 percent.
The Ford Motor Company's domestic car and truck sales jumped 35.6 percent in late December, a gain achieved mostly by stronger sales of pickup trucks. G.M. posted a similar gain. Analysts had expected the higher truck sales in the period because of strong incentives on the trucks and reporting schedules of those sales. For 1991, Ford's total vehicle sales were 2.89 million, a 13.8 percent drop from the previous year.
The Chrysler Corporation's car and truck sales fell 13.6 percent in late December. For the year, Chrysler vehicle sales dropped 11.2 percent. Chrysler's best-selling vehicle for the year was the Dodge Caravan, of which 207,919 were sold.
 The sluggish year also took its toll on the two best-selling Japanese brands in the United States. The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales dropped 4.5 percent for the year, including the line of Lexus luxury cars, and the Honda Motor Company's sales dipped 6 percent, including the company's Acura models. But sales of the three luxury brands of Japanese car makers -- which also include Nissan's Infiniti -- rose during the year. By contrast, Cadillac's sales were down 17.4 percent.
Particularly hard hit in 1991 were United States sales of several European auto makers, including Volvo, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche, BMW and Jaguar. The share of the United States market of all non-Japanese imports dropped to 5.9 percent, from 6.6 percent in 1990.
The Big Three's share of the total American vehicle market declined to 68.4 percent in 1991, from 69.4 percent in 1990. The share of Japanese auto makers, including those with American operations, increased to 25.7 percent, from 24 percent last year.
Vehicles made in North America by Japanese car companies also increased their percentage of market share last year, to 10.6 percent, from 8.8 percent.

 Many Dominican grocery store owners have followed a quick but steep route to success, often planting their stores in tough neighborhoods where leading chains have pulled out. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Power Failure Darkens Much of Washington

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Much of the capital was plunged into darkness early this evening when a power cable failed, turning out most of the lights at the State Department and the Federal Reserve Board, and producing a flickering at the White House before emergency generators took over.
People were trapped in elevators, and rush-hour traffic was snarled when the power failure occurred about 5:15 P.M. Some power, including that on parts of Connecticut Avenue in the downtown area, began returning at 7 P.M. 
 A spokesman for the Potomac Electric Power Company said the blackout began with a failure in a 230,000-volt line running under the Potomac River from a generating atation in Alexandria, Va. The reason for the failure was not immediately clear, said the spokesman, Kevin Kase.
 
Power Out at 3 Station
 About 18,000 customers were out of service, another spokeswoman said, noting that one customer could be an entire office building.
An area from Georgetown east through the business district went dark. In addition, said Mr. Kase, there were reports of three stations on the Washington subway system losing power: Foggy Bottom, Smithsonian and National Archives.
Mr. Kase said the company's headquarters, at 1900 Pennsylvania Avenue, three blocks from the White House, had "phone service and flashlights," but no electricity.
The Potomac River power plant has a capacity of 480 megawatts, which is medium-sized, and runs on oil or natural gas.
The power failure did not appear to result in any loss of life or serious injures, a District of Columbia Fire Department official said. Some utility transformers shorted out underground in Washington's Chinatown district, but they were dealt with by the utility because they did not result in any fire above ground, the official said.
 
Thousands in Dark Streets
 Today's power failure sent thousands of Federal officials out of their offices into darkened streets lit by few lights and snarled by traffic signals that did not work.
Emergency generators kept the lights on at the State Department's operations center, but electricity failed in the rest of the building. The fax machines stopped working, forcing foreign embassies to communicate with American diplomats by phone, said Krassimir Kostov, a spokesman for the Bulgarian Embassy.
Joseph R. Coyne, an assistant to the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said he was working by the light of a candle on his desk. A back-up power supply would prevent the loss of any computer data on the nation's economy, he said.
Congress, which has its own power plant, was unaffected by the power failure, as was the Pentagon across the Potomac River in Virginia.
Emergency generators took over almost immediately at the White House, keeping offices lighted as well as computers running. "The lights flickered off and then they were on again; it's not like we were sitting here in the dark or anything," said a White House employee who insisted on anonymity.
John Cook, the shift supervisor at the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland Interconnection, an organization that coordinates power transfers among several large utilities, said the power failure did not spread outside the District of Columbia.
Office workers emptied into the streets when the lights went out, while some people were temporarily trapped in elevators.
"It reminds me of the war, when we had complete blackouts and I was a junior air raid warden," said Arthur I. Ross, owner of La Salle Liquors on Connecticut Avenue.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
MAYOR WORRIED OVER STEIN PARTY
City Council President Andrew J. Stein, gearing up to run for Mayor, is hosting a glittering political dinner with Frank Sinatra, Liza Minnelli and Shirley MacLaine to raise more than $2 million. David N. Dinkins, not on the list, was worried enough to call friends listed as committee members to ask if they were abandoning him. That put some of them where they least like to be -- in the spotlight in a public feud. B3. 

ROBBED JEWELER RETURNS TO STORE
A 71-year-old jewelry store owner said it was not easy to return to his Chinatown store one day after killing a 40-year-old man who had tried to rob him. The store owner, Herman Moser, said he found that he could not concentrate on his work and that his eyes kept flickering to the door to size up anyone who entered his store on Canal Street. B3.
 
BRONX ATTACK SEEN AS BIAS CRIME
Two black youngsters walking to school in the Bronx were beaten by a pair of white teen-agers and sprayed with a white substance, the police say. B3.
Prison term for lawyer who stole millions. B3.
 
REGION
 
NEW YORK CREDIT IS DOWNGRADED
In a stinging censure of New York State's fiscal condition and the political paralysis in Albany, a major Wall Street credit agency downgraded the rating on most of the state's debt, leaving New York with the second lowest rating of all states. The new rating, which affects only the portion of the state's debt backed by annual legislative appropriations, is the lowest in the state's history and could mean that New York would have to pay higher interest rates on future borrowing. Moody's Investors Service, which set the rating, was worried about the state budget deficit. A1.
 
PCB CONTAMINATION DELAYS CLASSES
Officials at State University of New York at New Paltz announced they would delay the spring semester two weeks and move 1,000 students out of dormitories where electrical transformers exploded or overheated last week, contaminating the buildings with PCB's. The dormitories, along with two academic buildings, were contaminated after a car struck a utility pole on Dec. 29, causing a power surge that damaged the transformers. A1.
 
A QUORUM, FINALLY. LESS TAXES, MAYBE.
After weeks of a Republican boycott that brought the legislative process to a halt in the New Jersey State Assembly, Democratic members finally managed a quorum and introduced two sets of bills that would repeal the $2.8-billion tax increase they rammed through the Legislature 18 months ago. But Republicans continued their stalling tactics. B6.
 
A TAX REVIEW FOR CONNECTICUT TOWNS
The Wilson place, a rambling array of gables and porches in genteel Fenwick, Conn., has become the unlikely centerpiece of a court battle that could force most Connecticut towns to review the way they assess property for real-estate taxes. It was there that John C. Wilson 3d declared war against the tax assessor for the town of Old Saybrook, of which Fenwick is a borough, after his tax bill rose to $14,000 a year, from $4,000. B6.

HEADLINE: Utilities Want Rates to Cover Health Costs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Public utility companies across the country are applying for substantial rate increases to finance the expensive medical benefits they have promised to their current and future retirees. The increases, if granted universally, would add more than $4 billion each year to the nation's electric, gas and telephone bills, according to Government economists.
The requested increases have drawn strong opposition from state officials and consumer groups, in part because utility employees and retirees typically receive far more generous medical benefits than most Americans. 
 The utilities contend that since active employees are earning their retirement benefits now, part of the cost should be added to current rates. Medical costs for current retirees are already included in the rates.
Southern New England Telephone and Public Service Electric and Gas of New Jersey are among the several large utilities that have requested these increases, and Consolidated Edison of New York plans to.
Consumer advocates are urging state regulators to reject such requests. They accuse the utilities of opportunism, arguing that ratepayers will receive little or no advantage in paying now for largely unpredictable obligations that are decades away.
"Obviously, 20 years from now there will be different ratepayers," said James Pretti, deputy director of the division of ratepayer advocates at the California Public Utility Commission. "It is cheaper for ratepayers to keep the money now, rather than put it up front."
Utilities' health plans have been generous in part because regulators allow the companies to pass along these costs to customers. According to a recent report by the A. Foster Higgins consulting firm, 53 percent of 66 utilites surveyed said they paid 100 percent of the medical costs for retirees and their dependents. But of the 1,189 employers of all types questioned in the same survey only 25 percent said they paid the entire bills.
The utility companies' efforts to add higher medical costs to their bills are fueling the broader political debate about rapid rises in these costs and the inequities between the insured and the uninsured.
Higher utility rates to cover retirees' future medical benefits would raise the cost of a broad variety of goods and services, affecting living standards and the international competitiveness of American factories.
The General Accounting Office recently estimated that as of 1993 all companies would face a total liability of $309 billion for health benefits for retirees, including $193 billion for active employees and $116 billion for those already retired.
Donald C. Snyder, assistant director in the G.A.O.'s human resources division, said the utilities' share for 1993 alone would be at least $4.5 billion. Covering that in full would add about 2.5 percent to the nation's total annual utility bills. And this amount would cover only future retirement benefits for active employees, not for those already retired.
Utility companies in at least a dozen states have applied for the increases. A few states, including Connecticut, Florida and North Carolina, have approved some rate increases to cover part of these medical costs. Others, including Georgia and Hawaii, have rejected the companies' requests, with regulators saying they need more time to study the issue.
Regulators are also examining the issue in New York and in California, where seven energy and telephone companies have asked for more than $450 million in higher rates. And in New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas, the state's largest utility, recently requested a $50 million increase to cover future health costs of retirees.
The utilities' actions are a response to a new reporting rule, affecting all large companies, that was adopted last year by the semi-official Financial Accounting Standards Board. Before the rule, most companies reported retirees' medical expenses on a pay-as-you-go basis.
Under the rule, each year beginning in 1993, companies must estimate and report a portion of their future medical expenses for retirees. The intention is to alert investors and corporate executives to liabilities that had been largely unnoticed.
The board did not require companies to set aside money for these future costs, but utilities are under special pressures to do so.
The Securities and Exchange Commission staff has questioned whether, in the distant future, state regulators will allow large enough rate increases to cover the potentially enormous obligations of utilities that have not put aside cash for retirees' medical expenses.
The rate requests raise important issues of fairness to current consumers and future generations. Accountants for the utilities say the promises to retirees are a current cost and should be paid now.
"People say, 'Let our grandchildren pay for them,' but this is a current cost of service provided today," said Ben McKnight, a partner with Arthur Andersen & Company and chairman of the public utilities committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.
Paul Menzel, a philosophy professor at Pacific Lutheran University in Tacoma, Wash., said that not to act now would be "downright exploitation of a future generation." , He is the author of "Strong Medicine" (Oxford University Press), a 1990 book that warns of unforeseen expenses as elderly Americans live longer.
 
A Matter of Timing
 Consumer advocates on the staffs of a number of state regulatory commissions say there should be no urgency about raising rates. They say it is impossible to forecast medical costs accurately, or estimate the interest earnings of money set aside to pay for them.
They also contend that the Government will eventually assume more responsibility for health insurance, shifting the costs for future retirees to taxpayers. The General Accounting Office said recently that the retiree health obligations of all private companies would be reduced by 30 percent if Congress approved a proposal by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, to expand Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.
The struggle over financing retiree costs has intensified pressures to cut back on health benefits and slow the rise in health costs, which have been growing at more than twice the general rate of inflation.
Medical benefits that many utilities provide their employees are often much more comprehensive than the health coverage of most of their customers. The public utilities, said Pat Wilson, a principal at the A. Foster Higgins consulting firm, "tend to lead the pack in offering more retiree benefits than other industries."
 
A Comparison to Taxes
 Arthur L. Caplan, director of the University of Minnesota's Center of Biomedical Ethics, compared utility bills to misdirected tax benefits. "The telephone, electricity and gas are essentials of life," he said. "The poor shouldn't be asked to subsidize the better-off and have to do it through a 'tax' that they can't avoid."
But union officials say their members should not be asked to surrender medical benefits, which they often got in lieu of larger wage increases over the years. They note that health care was the main issue in the 1989 telephone workers' strike against the Nynex Corporation.
"These are enormously productive industries," said George Kohl, research director with the Communications Workers of America. "If you start slashing benefits in the most productive industries, you would get a downward spiral in the standard of living of the rest of the country."
Each company can write off its entire liability at once, as General Electric and I.B.M. have done, or spread it over 20 years, which most utilities plan to do.
The calculation is different for every company, depending on the benefits, workers' ages, the number of retirees and active workers, and assumptions about medical inflation and interest rates.
 
Estimates for California
 Some California utility companies recently estimated that annual increases in health-care costs would start at 17 percent in 1993 and taper off to about 5 percent by 2015. To cover its future health costs for retirees, Pacific Bell Telephone is asking the California Public Utilities Commission for $204 million in higher rates in 1993. And the GTE Corporation in California is asking for a $61.3 million increase, which a commission aide said would add $1.46 to the average monthly residential bill of $42.33.
Some utilities, including Consolidated Edison and Brooklyn Union Gas in New York, Commonwealth Edison in Illinois and several regional telephone companies, are already using the new accounting method and putting money aside for retirees' medical costs.
Several states have granted rate increases to cover future health benefits for retirees. The Florida Public Service Commission recently approved a $2.9 million increase to cover such expenses for the Centel Corporation's employees in that state.
Connecticut has authorized $4.8 million for the Southern New England Telephone Company and smaller amounts for several water companies. North Carolina approved $1.2 million for a unit of the Virginia Electric and Power Company and is considering a similar request for $9.8 million by Duke Power.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Gulf States Utilities Names Key Manager to Top Posts

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Gulf States Utilities Company, the Texas-based power provider that has been in financial trouble since it finished a nuclear plant in 1986 in the midst of a regional recession, yesterday named Joseph L. Donnelly as chief executive.
Mr. Donnelly, senior executive vice president and a chief architect of the company's partial recovery, will also become chairman on March 1. 
 Mr. Donnelly, 62, who has been with the company since being hired in 1979 as senior vice president for finance, replaces E. Linn Draper, who is leaving as chairman, president and chief executive to become president of the American Electric Power Company, in Columbus, Ohio.
Gulf States, based in Beaumont, Tex., serves a 28,000-square-mile area between Houston and New Orleans with a population of 1.3 million. It was "tottering on the verge of bankruptcy" in 1986 and 1987, Mr. Donnelly said yesterday, because it completed its River Bend reactor, in St. Francisville, La., at a higher cost than planned, just as a recession was cutting power demand.
The recession made it harder to raise rates, he said. "We've been in rate proceedings for years and years and years," he said. "We had a mismatch of revenues and obligations."
The company cut stock dividends in 1986 and 1987 to conserve cash and sought a merger. By last year, its condition improved and it paid off $127 million of the $252 million it owed on back dividends on preferred and preference stock. Mr. Donnelly said Gulf States would like to pay off the rest in 1992.
Mr. Donnelly holds a bachelor's degree in political science from the University of Scranton and a doctor of jurisprudence degree from the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He was a deputy attorney general of Pennsylvania from 1955 to 1958, after which he joined the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company, where he held a variety of posts until coming to Gulf States.

HEADLINE: Fort St. John Journal;
For That Long Road to Alaska, a Long Birthday

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT ST. JOHN, British Columbia

 BODY:
Leslie Markham, a 79-year-old who lives in a trailer park here just off the Alaska Highway, recalls the day in 1942 during the road's construction when the muskeg "ate" one of the United States Army's Caterpillar tractors.
As the driver of a two-and-a-half-ton truck, Mr. Markham watched from more solid ground as "that Cat sank deeper and deeper and just got swallowed whole." The tractor's operator climbed out safely, and three other tractors sprouting cables and winches managed to extract the sunken machine many hours later. 
 Muskeg is an Algonguian term for grassy bog, and Canada probably has more of it than any other country. But muskeg, which melts treacherously in the summer, was only one of the hazards that thousands of workers like Mr. Markham faced in getting that road, now a nearly solid stretch of asphalt, across 100 rivers and five mountain ranges to Fairbanks, Alaska.
In 1992, Canada and the United States are planning a 50th-anniversary commemoration of their wartime collaboration in road-building to counter what was regarded in 1942 as a serious threat of a Japanese invasion through Alaska.
 
Old Road Warriors Returning
 Some of the old road warriors will return for the events, promoted as Rendezvous '92. Others will celebrate closer to where they live now, like a group of black veterans of the Army Corps of Engineers who plan a reunion on Jan. 18 to 20 at Florida A & M University in Tallahassee. A number of black engineering battalions commanded by white officers served in the segregated Army of that era.
Figures gathered by the University of Alaska in Fairbanks indicate that 10,607 American troops were involved in the project, among them 3,695 blacks. About 7,500 civilian construction workers took part, most of them Canadian.
Many others, from dog sledders and snowmobile operators to rally drivers and cyclists, are expected to help with the celebrations, and some organizers hope that President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney will stop by.
Although the two Governments formed a committee in 1930 to study the possibility of building a road through British Columbia and the Yukon territory to Alaska, it was the bombing of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, that provided the real incentive.
Construction of the 1,500-mile highway started just south of here at Dawson Creek in March 1942, and despite the hardships of cutting through rock, bog and bush at temperatures of 40 below zero for weeks at a time, the force of about 18,000 workers completed the highway in only eight months and 12 days, a remarkable feat of engineering.
Contemplating the highway that in some sections now bears as many as 3,000 vehicles a day, Mr. Markham, the son of a homesteader from Wisconsin, said, "In those days, it really seemed an impossible task."
The sense of urgency grew in June 1942, when Japanese bombers and fighters attacked the United States naval base at Dutch Harbor, Alaska. The next month several thousand Japanese troops invaded Attu and Kiska in the the Aleutian Island archipelago. American and Canadian troops later drove them out in what has come to be described as the Forgotten War.
The army of workers that poured into this sparsely settled region to help fight off the Japanese contributed to some military successes, and the road, also known as the Alcan Highway, has since helped to bring about economic development and other changes.
A driver heading north from Fort St. John will see a trail of Century 21 "For Sale" signs. Drivers of big 18-wheeler trucks, like Mel Mytron, 43, who carts oil equipment to Fort Nelson, hang out at Dodd's truck stop eating ham and eggs and drinking endlessly refilled cups of coffee.
Many historians say the road was been a mixed blessing at best because of its devastating effect on the northern Indians and Eskimos.
As the southerners flooded in, scores of indigenous people died in epidemics of new diseases against which they had no immunity, including measles, meningitis, dysentery, whooping cough, influenza, mumps, tonsillitis, bronchial pneumonia and tuberculosis.
And as members of the indigenous communities scrambled for highway jobs, they abandoned traditional means of subsistence like hunting and trapping, causing their food reserves to fall precariously.
Organizers of the Rendezvous '92 celebrations insist that they want this part of the Alaska Highway story forcefully told as well.
 
'Negative Effects, Too'
 "We want people to realize it did have negative effects, too," said Sandy Baker, an official on the Alaska Highway Rendezvous '92 committee. "This is a commemoration, not a celebration, of something that is a fact of history."
Indigenous people are themselves involved in the commemoration, using it as a vehicle to express their cultural views and to let visitors see their traditional ways.
As Win Baker, originally from Ontario, whose husband worked for a construction contractor in 1942, put it, "Everyone here came from somewhere else, and they came to do something."
She said the highway "sort of symbolizes the country -- huge, important for others needing work, but with something to show for it all."

HEADLINE: Overhaul of Dividend Tax Is Urged

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Challenging a fundamental feature of the nation's tax law, the Treasury contended today that the double taxation of dividends -- first at the corporate level and then at the shareholder level -- distorts decision-making throughout the economy and thereby reduces output as much as $25 billion a year.
The Treasury proposed to "integrate" corporate and shareholder levies so earnings would no longer be taxed two or more times and suggested options to do so. 
 Most European countries, as well as Canada and Australia, have adopted distribution-related systems of tax integration in which a separate corporate-level tax remains on retained earnings, but some or all of it is eliminated for earnings distributed to shareholders.
"Integration is beneficial, no matter how you do it," Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy, said at a news briefing. Noting that many of America's trading partners had already moved in this direction, Mr. Gideon added, "This is an issue we're going to have to deal with."
The issue is so far-reaching and complex that the Treasury study stopped short of recommending a particular solution. Its immediate aim was to open a debate that is expected to unfold over years rather than months.
Mr. Gideon, however, pointed to a preference in the study, which was mandated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, for either allowing investors to exclude dividends from taxable income or for adopting a comprehensive business income tax.
The idea of integrating the tax system has been discussed for two decades. Big business tended to oppose the idea, but Mr. Gideon said that for various reasons, including shifts in relative tax rates and heavier reliance on debt, there is now a "very different world" in which to debate and legislate.
The Treasury report concluded that the current "classical" system of tax law exacts a heavy toll.
For one thing, since those who operate as sole proprietors of a business or as partners, for example, are taxed only once on their earnings, the law "often perversely penalizes" the corporate organizational form, an odd thing for a capitalist country.
The current system, the report maintained, "also distorts corporate financial decisions -- in particular by encouraging debt and discouraging new equity financing of corporate investments." Moreover, the system prejudices corporate decisions on whether to pay dividends or retain profits and causes companies to maneuver distributions to help stockholders avoid double taxation.
 
Possible Benefits
 The report said the potential benefits of integration included raising the value of capital stock in the corporate sector by $125 billion to $500 billion, lowering the corporate debt-to-asset ratio from one to seven percentage points and increasing domestic product by $2.5 billion to $25 billion a year.
The study did not include estimates of revenue loss for any of the options.
One option -- a shareholder allocation system widely regarded as the fullest form of integration -- was analyzed and presented by the study but rejected by Mr. Gideon and his colleagues.
Under such a plan, a company's income would be apportioned to stockholders who would then include it in income and would get credits for paying corporate taxes. But this system would pose several policy problems involving the extension to shareholders of corporate tax preferences and the treatment of foreign-source income on which no United States tax had been paid.
 
Two Options Favored
 Of the two options favored by the Treasury, Mr. Gideon seemed to favor dividend exclusion, which he said "accomplishes a lot of the goals of integration" without the huge overhaul that would be required by a comprehensive business income tax.
The comprehensive business tax was thought to require a 10-year phasing in. In it, there would be no deductions for dividends or interest paid by companies, and stockholders and bondholders could exclude them from their income. "The result is that one -- but only one -- level of tax would be collected on capital income earned by businesses," the study said.
In framing the debate, the Treasury laid out four goals for designing a new system: greater uniformity of levies on investment across economic sectors; more uniformity in how debt and equity is taxed; minimum distortion of the choice between retaining profits and paying them out as dividends, and taxing investment once instead of two or even three times.

HEADLINE: Linking Arms Cuts to Taxes

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Senator Phil Gramm, one of the most influential Republican lawmakers on budget policy, called today for a 5 percent cut in military spending by 1993 to allow the Government to raise the personal income tax exemption for every taxpayer by $416.
The conservative Texas Republican said his plan would result in a $466-a-year tax cut for a family of four whose income is $35,000. Because Mr. Gramm's proposal would cut military spending by more than the 1990 budget agreement provided for, it would bend, if not break, the agreement, which he helped to negotiate.
 
Significance of Remarks
 Mr. Gramm's proposed cut in military spending from $291 billion this year to $276.5 billion in the 1994 fiscal year and $275.3 billion by the 1995 fiscal year is thought to be close to the kind of cut President Bush is thinking of proposing in his State of the Union Message later this month. By making his proposal first, Mr. Gramm could protect Mr. Bush from criticism by Congressional conservatives who warn that military spending has already been sliced enough. 
 Mr. Gramm's comments are all the more significant because his state benefits substantially from military spending and has numerous military installations. Given the choice between sustaining the personnel size of the military or modernizing its equipment, Mr. Gramm said that he believed in a modern military that included a missile shield in space.
Mr. Gramm, speaking at a news conference, also suggested that any cuts in military spending beyond what he has proposed be equally divided between reducing the Federal deficit and increasing the personal income tax exemption. He said that there was "nothing magic" about his 5 percent proposal and that the final figure ought to determined by the Defense Department.
"I believe that even in a world where the lion and lamb are about to lie down together, I want to be sure we're the lion," he said.
Mr. Gramm promoted his proposal as an alternative to several Democratic plans that would increase spending on social programs. One such plan, offered last week by Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee, and Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, would increase Federal spending by $55 billion to stimulate the economy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Spiegel to Close Honeybee Unit

 BODY:
Spiegel Inc. said yesterday that it plans to close its 17-store Honeybee division on Feb. 29, a move that will result in a pretax write-off of $9 million in the 1991 calendar year. The Honeybee stores had sales of $12 million in 1991, Spiegel said.
Honeybee, a retailer of women's apparel, will continue to sell clothes through Spiegel's catalogues. 
 "The Honeybee stores have been hard hit by the recession, especially in the Northeast, where they are concentrated," said John J. Shea, vice chairman of Spiegel Inc. Many of the current stores are in the downtown and smaller mall locations inherited when Spiegel bought the company in 1988 for $23 million, he said.
"The resources required to turn the stores' business around are out of proportion with their potential in the current and anticipated retail environment," Mr. Shea said.
Honeybee store division headquarters in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., will begin closing immediately. The retail distribution center, also in Huntingdon Valley, will close over the next six months.
The Honeybee catalogue division will continue to operate out of Spiegel plants in Chicago and Oak Brook, Ill.

HEADLINE: A Winning Year for Stock Funds

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
With a striking 8.7 percent price jump in the final 11 days of December, stock mutual funds posted a yearly gain of 36 percent in 1991, their best since 1967.
In contrast to 1990, when they lost 6.3 percent of their value, stock funds were brawny last year. They out-performed two traditional competitors for small investors' money: fixed-income funds, which were up 18 percent, and money-market funds, up 5.6 percent. 
 Falling interest rates increasingly drove investors to stock funds. By the end of the year, when the Federal Reserve slashed the discount rate to 3 1/2 percent, stock funds had become more popular than ever.
Many analysts caution that it may be hard in 1992 to repeat such a sparkling performance.
"There's still favorable momentum," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds. "But if there is disappointment in the economy, there is risk."
The biggest gainers of 1991 were stock funds made up of smaller, growth-oriented issues. High-growth funds studied by Mr. Lipper grew by an average 16.4 percent in the fourth quarter and a stunning 67 percent over the full year. Small-stock funds had lost 9.9 percent in 1990.
"Growth stocks are in vogue right now," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston, whose Special Equity Fund notched an 85 percent gain for the year.
Low inflation, low interest rates and a weak economy, Mr. Freedman noted, are favorable to growth-oriented, as opposed to larger, value-oriented stocks, which are generally bought because of their assets or prospective earnings.
Health and biotechnology funds surged 74 percent last year, extending an advance that began in early 1990; they rose by 16 percent in the fourth quarter alone. Biotechnology stocks, which led this group in the third quarter, dropped sharply in November, when medical equipment and technology stocks picked up.
Dragged down by disappointingly slow oil stocks, natural-resource funds performed the worst of any particular sector stock in the fourth quarter -- down 2.9 percent; they had an anemic 3.7 percent gain for the year. Gold funds also did poorly in 1991, declining by 4.5 percent.
Financial services funds, taking advantage of the flood of underwriting business and investment in the market in 1991, grew by a strong 60 percent in the year, and by 10.5 percent in the fourth quarter.
"It was a year where being an active manager worked," Mr. Lipper said.
Fund managers who carefully picked stocks outperformed ordinary indexes, like the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, which rose 26 percent for the year.
Some fund managers stressed the advantages of sticking with a stock, even if its price rose sharply, rather than taking a quick profit.
"When a stock is accelerating, why sell it?" asked James E. Stowers 3d, executive vice president of Twentieth Century Investors Inc., whose Vista Investors Fund was the fourth quarter's best performer, with a 22.9 percent gain.
"They get volatile, sure, but that's half the fun," he added.
Other managers found that fast-rising stocks were best sold early.
Heiko Thieme, manager of the American Heritage Fund, which grew by a nearly unbeatable 97 percent for the year, said he sold issues far sooner than he had planned because they rose faster than expected.
 
Tale of One Stock
 Mr. Thieme bought one biotechnology stock for his fund, Anergen Inc., when it fell to $8 a share and expected to hold on to it for some time. When it rose to $24 in only two weeks, however, he could not resist selling. The stock subsequently fell again, and yesterday closed at $12.25 a share.
Mr. Thieme said he ususally preferred to split his fund to about 60 percent big-name stocks and 40 percent smaller stocks. But this year he shifted the ratio, taking advantage of bargains -- and a faster rate of growth -- in small issues.
"It was a strange market," said David Dreman, who manages the Dreman High Return Fund. "On the one hand, there was almost mania in biotechs. No price was too high." Yet, he noted, stocks that follow cyclical trends in the market only began to excel in the final weeks of the year.
