HEADLINE: Tax Repeal Is Introduced In Assembly Tactics Duel

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
After weeks of a Republican boycott that brought legislating to a halt in the State Assembly, Democratic members finally managed a quorum today and introduced two sets of bills that would repeal the $2.8 billion tax increase they rammed through the Legislature 18 months ago.
But truculent Republicans, who showed up for the session only after the Democrats achieved a 42-member majority on their own, continued their stalling tactics. An Appropriations Committee hearing on the repeal package was delayed until late in the evening as wary Democrats refused to leave the Assembly floor for fear that a new Republican boycott would emerge and again deny a quorum if committee members left for a hearing. 
 When the committee finally met, its Democratic majority managed to approve a repeal package already passed in the Senate, setting the stage for a floor vote on Wednesday.
But two Democrats suggested that they could well vote against repeal when it gets there, which means the package is in trouble unless the Democrats can muster one or two Republican votes, which seems unlikely.
 
Democrat Is Doubtful
 One Democrat, Henry A. McEnroe of South Orange, abstained on the committee vote, and added, "While I never say never, I don't intend to support the repeal."
Another Democrat, William J. Pascrell Jr. of Paterson, is the author of the alternative package of repeal bills, which include a number of spending cuts. But he angrily vowed not to support any tax rollback unless his own repeal package was passed by the Senate, so it could be voted on by the Assembly. Mr. Pascrell also forced the committee to send his seven-bill package to the floor intact. When the committee at first tabled parts of it, he threatened to withhold his needed approval of the Senate-passed version.
The fledgling rebellion among its own members took the Democrats by surprise, although they had taken steps to avoid continuing parliamentary sabotage by the Republicans.
"We're holding the committee hearing in an upstairs room," said a Democratic staff member, "so we can go get them" if the Republicans call for a quorum.
 
Republican Rump Sessions
 Although the Democrats hold a 43-to-37 edge in the Assembly and only a bare majority of 41 members are required to conduct business, Democratic illnesses and absences, plus the Republican boycott, had kept attendance below that level until today.
For weeks the Republicans held rump sessions in a diner or a rented meeting hall, refusing to go onto the Assembly floor unless Democrats achieved a quorum on their own.
Today, they did it. But the sullen Republicans, who trooped into the Assembly chamber from the Contemporary Club, a meeting hall across the street, did not give up easily.
When Democratic committee members left the floor to begin their hearing, already three hours late, Republicans issued a quorum call and invoked a parliamentary rule that members could not leave the floor until the day's agenda was completed. And the agenda was swollen by a backlog of legislation bottled up during the monthlong boycott.
The committee hearing was recessed while the members returned to the floor.
 
Tax Gamesmanship
 At issue in the parliamentary gamesmanship were two sets of bills that would roll back $2.8 billion in tax increases that the Democrats pushed through the Legislature in 1990 over the strenuous objection of the Republicans, who occasionally wore gags to protest what they said was a Democratic effort to silence them.
But the legislative climate underwent a dramatic, virtually instant reversal after the elections on Nov. 5, when the Republicans won overwhelming, veto-proof majorities in both houses by lambasting the Democrats for the tax increases.
Republican jubilation quickly died when the Democrats, still in control until Jan. 14, announced that they would steal the Republican thunder by rolling back the taxes themselves, leaving the Republicans to decide how to replace the lost revenues and make up for a huge shortfall in a recession.
The Democrats managed to get their tax rollback legislation through the Senate, where they enjoy a 27-13 majority, but until today were unable to get a quorum in the lower house.
Gov. Jim Florio has not said whether he would sign or veto a package repealing the taxes, on which he staked his political career.

HEADLINE: Record-Setting Dow Rally Ends on 1.35 Loss

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market's mighty winning streak finally ended yesterday, but just barely. After 11 straight rises and 6 straight records, the Dow Jones industrial average inched downward for a change but hung on above 3,200. At 3,200.13 at the close, it was off 1.35 points.
Trading was heavy, and while there appeared to be some weakness in large issues, the broad market continued to make strong advances. The Nasdaq composite index rode to a new high of 597.90, up 5.25, and the American Stock Exchange's composite index also set a new record, up 0.44, to 399.27. 
 The Russell 2,000, an indicator of small-stock activity, jumped 2.24 points, to close at a record 194.34.
Philip H. Smythe, an analyst at Birinyi Associates, a market research firm, noted that the Dow's 11-day run, which lifted it 10.3 percent, was the longest in five years. In January 1987, the index posted gains on 13 straight days for an 11 percent gain.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy yesterday, at 251.2 million shares, up from 224.3 million shares on Friday. The Big Board's composite index slipped 0.50 points, to 229.85, as gainers outpaced losers by 1,059 to 787.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another blue-chip indicator, fell 1.38 points, to end at 417.96.
 
Some Taking Profits
 After the Dow fell below 3,200 early in the day, stocks rose across the board. Trading was volatile, with doses of program trading to make the day interesting. Birinyi Associates tracked four buying programs and two selling ones that, when combined, had a net effect of raising the Dow 4.68 points.
Gene J. Seagle, the director of technical research for Gruntal & Company, said he thought yesterday gave investors who felt the market had run too far, too fast, a chance to take profits. "And these will be the same investors who will be on the sides waiting to get back in," he said.
"Add those to the investors who have thus far missed the market's move and are waiting to get in, and it keeps building up a support level of potential cash infusion for the market to continue on its way," he added.
The market's move is not such a surprise if you look at January 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1991. The percentage moves in those months ran 17 percent, 27 percent, 26 percent and 22 percent, respectively. Applying the 23 percent average now, the Dow could hit 3,562 before any big drop comes, Mr. Seagle noted.
This market move has similarities to January 1987, which also followed a year when the market held mainly in a narrow range, he said.
"Many important things have come together at this time, like year-end factors, the large amount of sideline cash in money funds looking for a better return, a Presidential cycle and the January effect, where the revenue taken from the market for tax purposes finds its way back for reinvestment," Mr. Seagle said.
 
Heavy Secondary Activity
 Traders support Mr. Seagle's contention that the market is being led by individuals who have returned in a large way. "That's why we're seeing a lot of activity in secondary stocks, as well as the big blue-chip issues," he said.
Ricky Harrington, the director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities, said that judging by the heavy volume, one or two more days of consolidation could still take place, with nothing pointing to any more than normal.
He thought perhaps the President's trip to Japan could produce further news, but some profit taking in the meantime could be reasonable. "Later in the week we could get some economic news" that could affect the market, he said. "While the consolidation was relegated to a handful of Dow stocks, it could spill over into the over-the-counter market."
Auto stocks were steady or up slightly, as five Japanese car makers, Toyota, Nissan, Honda, Mitsubishi and Mazda, were reported to be ready to lift sales of American vehicles in Japan through their dealerships. Chrysler rose as high as 14 1/8, before closing at 13 5/8, up 1/8 for the day, while Ford Motor rose as high as 31 5/8, to 30 7/8, up 1/2. General Motors rose 1, to 33 1/2.
The stocks affected by the Food and Drug Administration's moratorium on silicone breast implants included Corning, which fell 2, to 77 3/8, and Dow Chemical, off 1 7/8, to 51 7/8. They own Dow Corning Wright, which markets silicone implants in the United States.
Bioplasty, which derives much of its revenues from implants sold outside the country, rose 1/4, to 5 5/8. It said that while the moratorium would not eliminate the commercial availability of the implants outside the United States, should it become permanent, it would hurt the company's future profits. Mentor, another marketer of implants, fell 2, to 12 1/4.

HEADLINE: The Analyst Behind the Lowering of New York's Rating

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
For months, George W. Leung, vice president of state debt ratings for Moody's Investors Service Inc., has been worried about New York State's mounting budget deficit. Yesterday, he acted on his concerns, recommending a lower rating for the state's appropriations-backed bonds, which represent about two-thirds of New York's $20.9 billion in debt.
After reviewing Mr. Leung's analysis, Moody's public finance department concurred, issuing the lower rating.
 
Aaa Rating for the Rater
 "This decision reflects the fact that time is running out because we are in the final quarter of the fiscal year," Mr. Leung, who lives in South Orange, N.J., said in a telephone interview yesterday. "Not only has the state not dealt with the problem, but the problem has grown." 
 It was a decision that Mr. Leung, (pronounced LONG) said that he made after months of detailed analysis and virtually daily discussions with state budget officials. "We had to weigh the ability of New York State against the scope of its problems," Mr. Leung said. "What was most disturbing was the lack of action."
New York State's deficit rose to $875 million in the third quarter of the 1992 fiscal year, which ends March 31.
Mr. Leung has worked in the state and municipal financing departments at Moody's for 15 years, where he has become known for his sharp analytical skills. Freda Johnson, who supervised Mr. Leung when she headed Moody's public finance department from 1979 to 1990, gave him a Aaa rating. "I have the highest regard for him," Ms. Johnson said.
A graduate of Rutgers, where he studied economics, Mr. Leung received a master's degree in city and regional planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
He described his job as "quite demanding," particularly as more and more states struggle to offset growing budget gaps.
Moody's, followed by Standard and Poor's, is one of two principal credit rating agencies for public debt. Because of the vast variety of municipal and state debt -- there are more municipal issues than stocks on the New York Stock Exchange -- it is virtually impossible for an investor to keep abreast of the financial health of every city and state. Thus, investors ely on debt-rating agencies.

HEADLINE: Delay Sought In Paying Tax On L.I. Homes

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 6

 BODY:
Here in the suburbs, where a home is a passport to the American dream, the Nassau County Executive declared today that the "American dream is dying" and called for emergency measures including a moratorium on foreclosures for homeowners who cannot pay their taxes.
The County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, who has a budget crisis that is forcing layoffs of up to a quarter of the county's workers, said the local economy was "closer to a depression" than a recession and was driving people out of the county. 
 The recession, he said, is aggravating the high cost of living, taxes and utilities, forcing the elderly to consider selling their homes and making homes unaffordable for young couples. To remedy that, he proposed freezing property taxes or even eliminating them altogether.
"The American dream is dying," he said. "We are gradually witnessing the New York City-fication of Nassau County. Property values are decreasing and the middle-income taxpayer is sustaining the largest portion of the burdens for all segments of society."
 
An Extra 2 Years to Pay
 In counties hard hit throughout the metropolitan area, more and more homeowners are falling behind in their taxes, officials say. In Nassau County, where the average property-tax bill is approaching $5,000 a year, delinquent taxes have almost doubled since 1985, to $86.6 million last year, from $43.7 million six years before.
Under Mr. Gulotta's plan, which is subject to the approval of the County Board of Supervisors, taxpayers who now have two years to pay back taxes before foreclosure proceedings begin would get an extra two years. In theory, that would tide them over until the end of the recession, officials said.
Lisa M. Burke, Deputy County Treasurer, said the moratorium was unlikely to encourage many residents to ignore their tax bills.
"There still would be a certain date by which most property taxes would have to be paid," she said, "and most people would want to honor that obligation as soon as they could."
The moratorium on foreclosures was proposed by Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, in a populist State of the County speech. It was preceded by weeks of budget wrangling with fellow Republicans, which has damaged his standing in the county and raised questions about his political survival.
In a dazzling reversal, Mr. Gulotta, who less than two months ago proposed a 25 percent property-tax increase, which was rejected by Republican legislators, backed the growing anti-tax movement.
He supported a freeze on all local taxes, but he went even further, calling for elimination of the property tax as "essential to the future health and vitality of our region." While some tax opponents want to replace it with an income tax, Mr. Gulotta did not propose an alternative, saying more study was needed.
In his speech in the Board of Supervisors chamber, Mr. Gulotta called for state legislation to bar tax assessors from raising taxes on houses that have undergone improvements, in order to spur the economy.
And he said that he said he would also push for establishing a sports authority that would consider a new sports stadium, perhaps on the site of the defunct Roosevelt Raceway.
Mr. Gulotta also said that he planned to sue New York State to prevent the imposition of state mandates on local government and reverse the loss of state aid to school districts.
 
House Lost on $92.07 Debt
 Edwin L. Crawford, the director of the New York State Association of Counties, said that two upstate counties, Montgomery and Saratoga, have already begun researching such a lawsuit. He said that counties were most concerned about state budget cuts imposed in the middle of a county's fiscal year.
Asked about the lawsuit, Tom Conroy, a spokesman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, noted that the Governor favors reducing mandates on local governments, and said, "I can't imagine what the basis could be of any suit."
Under a tax system set up in Nassau County during the 1930's, when many county residents fell behind in their property-tax payments, Nassau County auctions unpaid tax debts to speculators. The speculators pay the taxes, charge the homeowners interest and can foreclose on the properties.
In the mid-1980's, after one unsuspecting homeowner lost her home for a $92.07 debt she knew nothing about, the county tightened its rules. Since then, officials said, no homes have been foreclosed upon, although some foreclosure actions are pending.
 
'Single Most Important Asset'
 The new proposal was born out of fear that the recession would bring a new wave of foreclosures, they said.
"A home is the single most important asset owned by most of our residents, representing the investment of a lifetime," Mr. Gulotta said. "No one in Nassau County will lose his or her home due to the inability to pay taxes during this recessionary period."
Though the overall tone of Mr. Gulotta's speech was pessimistic, he said that the American dream could be restored if officials would rise above partisanship and "return to basic beliefs."
"We must be willing to explore every alternative to cut costs and to open the doors of opportunities for all of our citizens," he said.
 
'Feel Our Heartache'
 But some of the specifics he cited seem likely to do more to fuel conflict than to solve problems, especially his conflict with the majority leader of the county legislature, Joseph N. Mondello, the presiding supervisor from the Town of Hempstead and the Republican County Chairman.
In his speech, Mr. Gulotta criticized Mr. Mondello's budget cuts for hurting the elderly and damaging the county highway department. And in a call for consolidating services, he proposed that Hempstead do away with several agencies known in Republican circles as conduits for patronage, from the Civil Service Commission to the security department, which protects public buildings.
To support his theme that the American dream was dying, Mr. Gulotta read a Christmas card he received from Gail and Charlie Kinnison in North Massapequa.
"Dear Tom," it read, "Enclosed is a picture of our darling Kayla. She's our granddaughter, the fifth generation to live in Nassau County. But she and her Mommy and Daddy are leaving here because they can't afford the taxes on a home in Nassau. I wish you could feel our heartache. Merry Christmas."

HEADLINE: Brady, on Bush Trip, Expected to Press Tokyo

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Minister made a surprise announcement today that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady would accompany President Bush on his visit here, which begins Tuesday. The announcement caused speculation that he might press Japan for financial measures to bolster the ailing American economy and to help American companies doing business in Japan.
Japanese and American officials were unusually tight-lipped about Mr. Brady's visit and its purpose, other than acknowledging that he was coming, and that added to the speculative fervor. A senior Treasury official has been here since the weekend negotiating with the Japanese, but officials would say only that a range of macroeconomic issues have been discussed. 
 Undoubtedly, Mr. Brady's presence will add to the pressure that the United States is applying to Japan to make trade concessions. American negotiators are trying persuade the Japanese to establish targets for the import of American autos and auto parts, officials have said. The pressure has created some confusion and rancor, as the Americans work to tie up a deal before President Bush arrives.
 
Topics of Speculation
 Speculation on the specific purpose of Mr. Brady's visit ranged from an agreement to see the dollar weaken further against the yen to an agreement to lower interest rates jointly, the adoption of a more stimulative fiscal policy by the Japanese or some form of financial assistance to help American companies doing business in Japan.
The dollar weakened against the yen in Tokyo today, falling to 124 yen from 125.50 yen a week ago and about 128 yen a month ago.
Both countries have been encouraging a weaker dollar to reduce Japan's yawning trade surplus with the United States. The lower dollar makes it more expensive for Americans to buy foreign-made goods, thus inhibiting imports. It also makes it cheaper for those holding yen and other currencies to buy American goods, aiding exports.
Japan has taken two macroeconomic steps recently in response to American demands that the Government try to reduce the growing trade surplus. In a surprise move, the Bank of Japan lowered its official discount rate in the final week of last year. That makes it easier for the United States to reduce interest rates and stimulates growth in Japan, which will tend to raise imports here.
In addition, Japan announced a budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1, that includes heavy public works spending, as the United States has requested, because it would stimulate domestic demand.
Japanese officials have said that they are willing to help President Bush, who is facing an election later this year when the American economy is in recession. But the Japanese have also said there are limits to what they can do.

HEADLINE: Thriving Where Others Won't Go

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Mariano Diaz stood, hands on hips, in the front of a Ctown grocery store where Harlem meets Central Park. He looked as if he owned the place, which he does. "How many Dominicans do you know in the supermarket business?" he asked his friend Teodoro Cortes.
Mr. Cortes, a builder for many of these stores in the New York area, knew the right answer: "How many supermarkets are there?" he asked. 
 Mr. Cortes was only slightly exaggerating. The Ctown group alone reports that about half its 167 stores, mostly in the New York area, are owned by Dominicans. The owners of the 37 new Bravo stores are almost entirely Dominican. All told, the region's Dominicans sell more than a billion dollars worth of groceries a year.
The Dominican grocery store owners who succeed as well as Mr. Diaz have have followed a quick but steep route to six-figure incomes. Often, they plant their stores in tough neighborhoods where major chains have pulled out or seldom ventured.
New York remains a city where ethnic neighborhoods are often matched by ethnic industries, where Greeks own many of the diners, many diamond merchants are Jewish and greengrocers are often Korean.
The success of the Dominicans in the supermarket business has been less visible, because it has been fairly recent and because store owners, unlike Korean greengrocers, wait on few of their customers themselves.
New York's Dominicans -- about 400,000, according to official estimates -- are the city's largest group of recent immigrants. Behind the statistics about the low incomes in the Hispanic population lie hundreds of stories like Mr. Diaz's.
The Dominican store owners have recently taken a higher profile in the face of reports by city officials that grocers in poor neighborhoods gouge customers who often have no place else to shop. Some of the owners see an attack on the grocers as an attack on Dominicans.
Ctown appears to be the largest New York chain in which Dominicans figure so prominently. It has more than $1 billion in annual sales, according to the Modern Grocer trade publication. Other chains, including Associated and Met Food, also have dozens, perhaps hundreds, of Dominican owners.
These chains are what grocers call voluntary associations, as distinct from companies like Pathmark and A.& P., which own the stores themselves. Under the Ctown agreement, the privately held Krasdale Foods Inc. provides independent store owners with advertising services, legal advice and packaged foods, and often helps arrange financing. Krasdale's profits from the Ctown arrangement come primarily from supplying groceries to the stores.
Ask the Dominican owners and the Krasdale executives what brought them together, and they sketch a story of traditional immigrant virtues, of 14-hour workdays in poor neighborhoods. "They are very industrious," said Charles A. Krasne, president of Krasdale Foods. "And they stick their necks out. They came to New York to get rich, and they succeeded."
 
Changing Neighborhoods
 But they were also united by their economic needs. By the 1970's, several major grocery chains were retreating from the city. Krasdale, then primarily a grocery distributor, saw its market shriveling.
Krasdale also saw that many owners of bodegas -- the small, walk-in stores that are to New York what the auto-oriented 7-Eleven's are to Dallas -- were Dominicans. They often lacked education, but this ready-made minor league had trained them in the grocery business.
The company established the Ktown organization with 12 stores in 1975. When the K Mart Corporation objected, Krasdale changed the name to Ctown. Ctown's structure was suited to a diverse city. Independently owned groceries, Krasdale executives decided, could cater to neighborhood tastes more readily than stores run from some distant headquarters.
"Each store has to have its own flavor, its own personality," Mr. Diaz said.
And having a store owned, not just operated, by the manager improved performance, often doubling profit margins to about 2 percent -- in a high-volume business where margins tend to be as thin as Saran Wrap.
 
Another Immigrant's Tale
 Mr. Krasne's knack for promoting Dominican ambitions in the grocery business takes him back to his family roots. His father was an immigrant, from Russia, and a grocer who founded the family business in 1908.
Mr. Krasne, 61 years old, is a graduate of Yale College and Harvard Business School, a former International Business Machines salesman and an erstwhile computer entrepeneur. But once he saw how readily he could apply his business skills to making the grocery distribution business far more profitable -- ultimately turning it into as much of a consulting and marketing as a distribution company -- he was hooked.
Like other ethnic groups, the Dominicans began with small stores serving their own communities, then branched out. Their stores usually have labor costs much lower than chain-owned competitors, where even the managers might belong to unions. Many Dominican owners put their relatives on the job, recruit other Dominicans at near-minimum wages and work endless hours themselves.
Often, employees go on to run their own businesses. Luis E. Guarnizo, a doctoral candidate in sociology at Johns Hopkins University, said that more than a third of the Dominican business owners he surveyed had begun their careers as employees in other businesses owned by Dominicans. "They learn the ropes, get the skills, and move up," he said.
 
Protecting the Cash
 Such was the course that brought Mr. Diaz to 110th Street and Central Park West. There, at the Ctown grocery store on the ground floor of an apartment building, Mr. Diaz and his wife, Iris, sit caged behind three steel doors, with a band of narrow one-way mirrors looking out on the store, a bank of 10 video monitors displaying every aisle and cash register.
Even with all this security, Mr. Diaz said, a band of intruders could create a distraction that drew him away from his office, break in and be off with thousands of dollars by the time he returned. It is a high-volume cash business, so keeping money around and getting it safely to the bank requires stealth and cunning.
To foil robbers who might be staking out the store, he tries to avoid having the same employees, or the same car, carry the cash to the bank. Armored cars? Too conspicuous, Mr. Diaz said.
Still, just a few weeks ago, $9,000 was taken from his employees on a Monday at noon. He himself was held up at gunpoint in 1990. "When you start getting older, you think about those things," he said, adding that he has four children.
 
Well Lighted and Clean
 His store has little in common with the often cramped, worn bodegas. Bright fluorescent lighting bounces off floors and fixtures buffed to a shine worthy of household-cleanser commercials. Customers often linger, sometimes to trade neighborhood news with Mr. Diaz.
His keychain jangling from a belt loop, Mr. Diaz pops out of his office to run a cash register when he sees the lines getting long.
Mr. Diaz joined other Dominican supermarket owners who filed into the office of Mark Green, the New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, last spring to protest what they asserted were his ethnic assaults. Mr. Green's department reported that stores in poor neighborhoods tended to charge more for the same items than did stores in wealthier areas. To increase variety and competition, he has urged the major chains to return.
Dominican store owners loudly derided Mr. Green's views. "Why is a can of Del Monte beans that a Dominican sells different from a can that an Anglo sells?" Mr. Diaz asked. "In the past these stores were called supermarkets when they were owned by A.& P. Now that they are owned by Dominicans, why are they called bodegas?"
In an interview, Mr. Green responded sharply. "Are these owners really saying that their Latino customers are not entitled to larger stores that may have more choices and lower prices?" he asked, adding that he has also challenged some practices of Korean greengrocers and Israeli electronics merchants in the city.
Mr. Diaz, 36 years old, developed his own skills by working at bodegas. After he arrived in the United States about 15 years ago, his retailing education began at a store an uncle owned in Jamaica, Queens. He saved enough, and learned enough, to buy another store with two relatives before he bought his own, on 100th Street in Manhattan, in about 1982.
Soon, he began scouting the neighborhood for a larger store. When he saw new apartment buildings rising on 110th Street, about half a mile north of his bodega and several steep blocks from the nearest supermarket, he noticed that the ground floor had room for several narrow shops.
The neighborhood's need for a store was confirmed a few years ago by Mr. Green, who cited reports that the D'Agostino grocery chain's store at 110th Street and Broadway would not deliver as far east as Harlem (the store now delivers as far as Central Park West).
In 1987, Mr. Diaz talked to the Krasdale company about becoming a Ctown owner himself. He took a 15-year lease on the 110th Street space, sold his bodega for $350,000 and began installing coolers and cash registers.
After his store opened in December 1988, Mr. Diaz worked months without a day off. Now he rests on Sundays, working the other days from about 10 A.M. to 8 or 10 P.M.
For this, he says, he reaps annual sales of about $4 million and profits of about $100,000. But already, he is looking for new, young partners, perhaps to run other stores. "Hopefully," he said, "if my kids pursue this kind of work, we will do something together."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Economist Post Filled By Salomon Brothers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers yesterday announced the appointment of John P. Lipsky as its first chief economist since the 1988 departure of Henry Kaufman, whose economic insights dominated Wall Street for years.
The firm also named David G. Shulman to the new job of United States equity strategist. 
 Mr. Lipsky, who has been Salomon's chief economist for Europe, based in London, said his appointment was a sign of the growth and globalization of Salomon's research capabilities since Mr. Kaufman, who hired Mr. Lipsky, left the firm.
"Henry Kaufman became Henry Kaufman," Mr. Lipsky said in an interview yesterday, "because he was almost uniquely right about the inflationary consequences of the economic policies of the late 70's. But I will be happy just to be right."
Mr. Shulman is adding his new job to that of manager of the real estate research group. The new job, he suggested, might give him the opportunity, finally, to be a little upbeat.
The two appointments come as Salomon continues to restructure itself in the wake of the Government securitities scandal that became known in August and resulted in the resignation of much of the top management of the firm, with Warren E. Buffett taking on the job of acting chairman.
Mr. Lipsky, 44, said the new management of Salomon includes people "I have respected and worked with for a long time." He added, "I feel comfortable with the direction that they are moving in."
Mr. Lipsky will bring an international bent to the resurrected chief economist job. He said that while he did not intend to be Salomon's sole economic spokesman, there was a feeling in the firm and among clients "that there be a spokesman for the firms's global market view."
Mr. Kaufman, who spent 26 years at Salomon and now heads his own New York-based economic consulting firm, Henry Kaufman & Company, said yesterday that Mr. Lipsky's appointment was "recognizing the in-house talent that I hoped one day would be recognized."
Mr. Shulman, 48, joined Salomon Brothers in 1986. He is a managing director and was appointed to head the real estate research group in January 1990. Before joining Salomon, he was vice president at TCW Realty Advisors in Los Angeles and an associate professor of management and economics at the University of California at Riverside. He has a bachelor's degree from Baruch College in New York City and master's and doctorate degrees from the U.C.L.A. Graduate School of Management.
Mr. Lipsky joined Salomon it 1984, after working for the International Monetary Fund on exchange rate surveillance and on negotiations of economic programs for countries in Latin America and Asia. He earned his bachelor's degree in economics at Wesleyan University in Connecticut and his master's and doctorate in economics from Stanford Unitversity. He will return from London to New York soon.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Companies' Costs: How Much Is Fair?

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
LARGE employers, especially manufacturers, are telling Congress they have been saddled with an unfair share of the nation's health-care spending. A new study for the National Association of Manufacturers contends that hospitals overcharged employers by $10.8 billion in 1991 to make up for losses on unpaid bills.
The study by Lewin/ICF, a Washington-based health-care consulting firm, also said that hospitals charged an additional $10.6 billion because Medicaid and Medicare payments did not fully cover hospital costs. The association estimated that employees and their employers -- including Federal, state and local governments -- spent $171 billion on health care last year. 
 The National Association of Manufacturers gave a copy of the study to Steve Kelmer, an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Welfare, who said he hoped it would provide background for White House aides preparing the President's State of the Union address.
But the issue is clouded by a dearth of reliable numbers. Hospitals often calculate "uncompensated care" by using nominal, undiscounted prices, which insurers do not pay. And, insurers note, many local governments reimburse hospitals for losses on charity care. They add that some hospitals have managed to set aside reserves, purchase securities and invest in new buildings and equipment even as they were reporting financial difficulties because of razor-thin operating margins.
There are few Government statistics on how the costs are shifted, and what information there is does not seem to show a significant shift from public to private payers. An analysis by Katherine Levit, an economist, and Cathy Cowan, a program analyst with the Health Care Financing Administration, said that throughout the 1980's, business and Government each paid about a third of health-care costs, with an equal share from patients.
Making the manufacturers' case, Terrell Womack, vice president for benefits at Champion International, the paper company based in Stamford, Conn., said that 15 to 25 percent of the "typical" $10,000 hospital tab paid by Champion could be traced to charges that the hospital had added to make up for money owed on other patients' bills.
"You're asking the manufacturing sectors of the economy, which is under intense international competition, to subsidize all these people who aren't providing health-care benefits," he said. "That's not good national policy. It's a type of hidden tax."
The manufacturers add that they have also been hit from another quarter -- by charges for their employees' spouses and other dependents, who often work in service industries or for smaller companies, where health benefits are often skimpy or nonexistent. Donald W. Moran, a vice president of Lewin/ICF, said 17 million employed people received health coverage from an employer other than their own.
Manufacturing companies, which often have strong unions and many older workers, typically offer excellent health coverage. Sharon Canner, an assistant vice president with the manufacturers' association, said 98 percent of the group's members helped pay for employees' medical care. "Manufacturing is by far the highest provider of benefits," she said.
Dr. Donald A. Young, executive director of the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, a Government body that advises Congress on Medicare payments to hospitals, said the average hospital lost $3.2 million in 1989, the most recent year for which information is available. The losses included $1.4 million on charity cases, $1 million on Medicare, $745,000 on Medicaid and $33,000 on other underfinanced Government programs. The losses were handsomely assuaged by private payers, who were charged 128 percent of costs, plus nonoperating and "other" revenues, for a net average surplus for the hospital of $1.2 million, Dr. Young said.
But, he said, these numbers did not prove that the Government squeeze on hospitals had actually caused the increased charges to private payers. "The literature and other things suggest that hospitals would have charged more anyhow, to maximize revenues, even if Medicare and Medicaid were paying 100 percent of hospital costs," Dr. Young contended.
"We could argue that the Government is paying an appropriate amount, and the private sector is paying too much," Dr. Young said. "We are all bothered by the continued significant increases in hospital cost-producing services." Thus, he said, "continuing to put pressure on hospitals is the correct policy."
Not surprisingly, in view of their role as buyers of health care, large employers also do their share of pressing for hospital cost concessions. John Glaudemans, an assistant vice president for public policy issues at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, noted that many large employers and their insurers were also squeezing hospitals by insisting on discounts; on outpatient treatment, which is less expensive, and on shorter hospital stays.

HEADLINE: Energy Companies to Curb Drilling

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Dismayed by low prices for oil and natural gas, many energy companies are concluding that it makes more sense to buy than to drill.
This finding -- from an annual survey by Salomon Brothers of the spending plans of 241 energy companies -- is more bad news for the battered oilfield services industry, the worst-performing sector of the stock market in 1991. 
 The survey found that 68 percent of the companies are looking to buy proven reserves, which suggests they will spend less on oilfield services as long as crude and natural-gas prices remain depressed, said James D. Crandell, a managing director and oil-services analyst at Salomon Brothers, who directed the survey.
"This really represents a sharp turnaround," Mr. Crandell said. A year ago, three of four energy companies were more committed to drilling than buying reserves.
"Even back in 1985 and '86, when oil was on its way to $10 a barrel, more companies thought the economics of drilling were more favorable than the economics of purchasing reserves," Mr. Crandell said.
Among leading indendepent producers, 71 percent said they wanted to buy reserves this year, he said, the highest level since the Salomon survey was started in 1982.
Over all, the money that worldwide energy companies intend to spend for finding and producing oil and natural gas will be little changed this year, rising by 1.3 percent, to $53.7 billion, from the $53.1 billion projected at the start of 1991.
 
Shift From North America
 But the amount of that budgeted for projects in North America is continuing to decline. Dozens of large companies, including virtually all global giants like Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and Chevron, as well as companies whose efforts used to be mainly in the United States, like Pennzoil, said they would spend more on projects outside North America.
The survey showed that 80 companies collectively planned to increase their budgets for foreign exploration and production by 9.1 percent over a year ago. Also, 157 companies plan to pare spending in the United States by a combined 10.7 percent from the level projected a year ago.
The decline in actual spending for domestic projects this year could be even lower, Mr. Crandell said. Budget projections made at the start of 1991 were cut during the year, as natural gas prices plunged to nearly $1 per 1,000 cubic feet in July and oil prices slumped below $20 a barrel after the end of the Persian Gulf war.
 
Fewer Exploring Rigs
 In turn, drilling activity plunged in the United States to an average weekly rig count for the year of 860, the lowest level since 1942. Many analysts expect a further decline, perhaps below an average of 750 rigs exploring for oil and gas, this year. The rig count for the first week of 1992 was 764, down from 1,108 the corresponding week a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc., the oilfield-services company in Houston, said Friday.
Oil executives as a group expect the average price for domestic crude to be $20.40 a barrel this year, down from their projection a year ago of $22.05, Mr. Crandell said. The February futures contract for domestic crude traded at $19.21 today on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The projection for average natural gas prices this year was $1.62 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Most companies said the surplus of natural gas would continue for the next few years. For that reason, twice as many companies plan to spend more money drilling for oil than for natural gas, Mr. Crandell said. And more companies will direct their drilling expenditures on trying to produce bigger quantities of oil and natural gas from proven fields than on searching for new ones.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Speculation About Pact on Stronger Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against other major currencies yesterday as traders theorized that American and Japanese officials would push the currency lower to reduce the United States trade deficit.
Gold prices also fell, losing $1.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to close at $349.30 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $349.40, off $1.10. 
 The dollar began its slide overseas. Tokyo traders bid the dollar down after an unidentified Finance Ministry official was quoted as saying that the Japanese Government could accept the dollar falling below 124 yen.
The dollar slumped further on speculation that President Bush and Japanese officials meeting today would agree to allow the yen to rise further against the dollar.
A higher yen would help reduce Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which totaled $41 billion in 1990. American products are cheaper in Japan and Japanese goods more expensive in the United States when the yen moves higher and the dollar falls.
 
Dollar Falls in New York
 The dollar fell to 123.40 yen in New York, from 124.65 late Friday. In earlier London trading, the dollar was quoted at 124.05 yen.
In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.85 yen, to 124.40 yen, from its previous close there last Tuesday. Japanese currency markets were closed from Wednesday through Sunday for the New Year's holiday.
Analysts said the dollar also fell victim to profit taking after it rallied higher last week. With the United States economy still stumbling and fresh economic indicators out this week, many traders decided to take their profits while they could.
The British pound surged nearly 3 1/2 cents higher, to $1.8830, in New York trading, from $1.8485 on Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.8785, from $1.8445 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.51575 German marks, down from 1.5435; 1.3435 Swiss francs, down from 1.3730; 5.1730 French francs, down from 5.2675; 1,144.00 Italian lire, down from 1,165.00, and 1.14255 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14655.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $348.50, from $352.00 late Friday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $349.50, from $352.00 late Friday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.03 to close at $352.22.
Silver fell 0.4 cent and closed at $3.941 on the Comex. Silver also fell in London to a late bid of $3.92, from $3.98 late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Real Estate May Require New Skills

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
IN spite of a recession that has been devastating to real estate, good job opportunities may eventually appear in real estate, said Lynn K. Cherney, a managing director of Ferguson Partners Ltd., a Chicago consulting firm that specializes in advising the real estate industry.
A recent study by the firm documents many changes in the industry and calls for finding a new approach to educate people going into real estate by the year 2000. This education, the study says, should shift the emphasis away from finance and law in many real estate programs at the degree level of master of business administration. "For the study we talked to real estate executives around the country as well as professors of real estate at many universities," she said. 
 The pendulum has swung back toward the need for a broad general education, before training in the specifics.
Tomorrow's real estate leaders, the study found, must be capable of dealing with global issues, complex financing that might involve foreign currencies, environmental obstacles, a political process that moves slowly, and the ever-present requirement for more sophisticated marketing.
Formal undergraduate training should involve the liberal arts, foreign languages, communications skills, computer skills, along with marketing courses and knowledge gained on the job, the study showed. In addition, there should be graduate training in general management and finance.
The study indicates why the change is needed in educational focus. Real estate companies will be much larger, as evidenced by consolidations like the one that involved Coldwell Banker, acquired by Sears, Roebuck, which expanded further by acquiring Schlott, a large real estate firm in New Jersey.
Many of the enlarged real estate companies will have international operations and must be staffed with managers who can deal with broader operations. This will give the companies more stability during economic downturns.
"The bigger firms will provide more services such as development of projects and the management of the projects," she explained. She pointed out that many more real estate firms would be part of giant companies like Prudential Insurance and Equitable Life Assurance. Also, there will be more control of real estate companies in this country by foreign owners.
All this, Miss Cherney said, will lead to a new type of career opportunity in real estate.
Since the companies will have international divisions or possibly be owned by a foreign company, there will be a need for executives who are bilingual or multilingual and who understand how to deal with foreign culutres and foreign economic and political issues.
And since environmental problems will affect real estate even more in the future, the real estate executives of the year 2000 must understand issues like waste disposal, urban land use, recycling, waste, air and noise pollution, to mention some, as well as use of fuel sources like nuclear and solar energy.
In the realm of public affairs, the problems of today will be magnified by the year 2000 because of the growing population and accompanying urban sprawl. These problems include taxation, already a major issue, traffic congestion, new roads and public transit, municipal needs like additional water sources and more sewage plants.
Institutional investors with large amounts of pension fund money to invest will be reassessing their investment strategy in real esate companies and putting more focus on sound performing real estate assets.
This will put an emphasis on improved financial management of real estate firms and the need for their treasurers to have broader relationships with banks, pension funds, foreign investors and other capital sources.
At the same time, corporate real estate departments, Miss Cherney believes, will shrink as the big companies continue to slim down their managements. That indicates the need for more help and consultations with the outside real estate firms.
Miss Cherney points out that professors of real estate at various universities around the nation are well aware of these changes in the industry. "While other industries are looking for more specialized preparation for their field, real estate is bucking that trend, seeking managers who will have a well-rounded advanced education, she said."
She cited Peter T. Allen, an adjunct professor at the University of Michigan's graduate business school, who believes that a liberal arts background, customer experience, plus a graduate degree in an area like urban planning would be a good background for tomorrow's real estate executive.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Brits in High Places
It is the beginning of a new chapter in fashion history, and we don't mean Chapter 11. Liz Tilberis, the highly regarded editor of British Vogue, was named editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar magazine yesterday, ending months of speculation.
The new editor is soft-spoken, silver-haired and British. And she wears Chanel. (Note: With Anna Wintour at Vogue, this puts British editors at the top of two of America's most venerable fashion magazines.) 
 "I'm coming, but I'm not sure when," Ms. Tilberis said yesterday by telephone from London, where she lives with her husband and two children. "It's a question of sorting everything out."
D. Claeys Bahrenburg, the president of Hearst Magazines, which publishes Harper's Bazaar, confirmed yesterday that Ms. Tilberis would become editor in chief of the magazine, at a date to be announced later. The editors and staff of Harper's Bazaar have been in limbo for weeks, since the retirement announcement of the editor in chief, Anthony T. Mazzola, who has run the magazine since 1972.
"Everyone is terribly nervous," said a veteran Bazaar editor who insisted on anonymity. "In this economy nobody wants to be out of a job."
Mr. Mazzola is to stay at Hearst to edit a 125th-anniversary edition of Harper's Bazaar. His wife, Michele, who has been the special projects editor of the magazine, said she would probably join him, at least temporarily, in that project.
Ms. Tilberis, for her part, would not reveal what kind of makeover she planned for the magazine.
"It's a dark secret," she said. "I know exactly what I'm going to do, but I'm not telling anybody."
Ms. Tilberis, who is 44 years old, has been at British Vogue for her entire career, since winning the Vogue Talent Contest, an essay writing competition, in 1969. She is well known and well liked on Seventh Avenue, and was considered a protege of Ms. Wintour in England.
Ms. Tilberis served as fashion editor under Ms. Wintour at British Vogue in the mid-1980's. She became editor in chief in 1987.
"The more British editors, the better," Ms. Wintour said.
 
Armani Goes Shopping
 Giorgio Armani, whose A/X shop has been attracting crowds in SoHo, stopped off to do a little shopping of his own last week -- at Brooks Brothers, according to store executives.
The Italian designer, who recently revived the American sack suit popularized by Brooks, dropped about $2,300 in two visits to the Brooks Brothers store on Madison Avenue. He stocked up on shirts, braces and ties, proving that designers sometimes choose to buy something other than their own merchandise.
Brooks Brothers executives pointed out that soon Mr. Armani wouldn't need to fly to New York to purchase their goods: the store plans to begin selling its clothes in Italian specialty stores this year.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Nemchinov Finds Net, And Words

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
Sergei Nemchinov scored a goal, set up two others and then conducted his first postgame interview in English.
On a night when the humdrum Winnipeg Jets were at Madison Square Garden to absorb a methodical 4-2 licking by the Rangers, Nemchinov's stickhandling and linguistic grand slam provided the only real excitement in the house. 
 "In the Russian league I don't score as many goals, usually 20 goals in 44 games," the Ranger center said after considerable pause. "Here, there are smaller rinks, so there are more shots taken."
Nemchinov, a Muscovite who was drafted in the 12th round by the Rangers in 1990, scored his 20th goal of the season last night in the first period. His second-period assist represented his seventh point in four games.
There is an economy of motion, and words, here. Nemchinov went one-for-three again on his shots, continuing his league-leading shooting percentage of 33.3. He also continued to impress with his strong hands, his two-way hockey and his improving linguistic skills.
"I don't understand a thing he says," Coach Roger Neilson said. "But he understands everything, and his teammates seem to know what he's saying all the time.
"When I watched him play four games last year in Finland, I wrote in my report he was a good defensive player and that I thought he'd score 15 to 20 goals," Neilson said. "I guess I was talking about the first half of the season."
The Rangers built a three-goal lead last night in the first period, a formidable advantage not easily gained or lost against the meticulous Jets.
From then on, the game at Madison Square Garden served its homely purpose. The Rangers ground out a victory that again lifted them into a tie with Washington for first place in the Patrick Division standings, where victories continue to count two more points than esthetics.
The Jets, arguably the National Hockey League's most boring team, managed few dangerous shots at goaltender Mike Richter. The Rangers knocked them off their rhythm, and the Jets clearly did not battle back.
 
Three Quick Goals
 The game was decided early, on a flurry of three Ranger goals within an eight-minute period of the first period. First, James Patrick swept the puck from behind the Winnipeg net, into a crowd of players. From in front of the crease, John Ogrodnick poked the puck under Jet goaltender Bob Essensa for his 13th goal and a 1-0 lead at 4 minutes 48 seconds.
Essensa was screened on that play, but he had no such alibi on a standard slap shot by Ranger defenseman Jeff Beukeboom from straight on near the blue line. The puck went through Essensa's pads at 12:06, and the Rangers were clearly in control.
Nemchinov scored just 38 seconds later, fanning on a backhander as he skated by the crease on the right side, then flipping the puck high over Essensa from a nearly impossible angle for a 3-0 bulge.
"He's been an unbelievable surprise," Mark Messier said of his Russian teammate. "For a guy to come over here like that, with the culture and getting settled in, and to do everything so smoothly. He's a real leader in his own way.
"He's not able to talk a lot, but he plays, game in and out."
Messier might have been talking about himself -- high praise indeed.

 
 
SLAP SHOTS
 ALEKSEI KOVALEV, the Rangers' first-round draft choice from Moscow, was selected as the All-Star right wing at the world junior championships completed last weekend at Fussen, Germany. Kovalev had five goals and five assists in seven games, leading the Commonwealth of Independent States to the championship. . . . Ranger General Manager NEIL SMITH expects to bring Kovalev to New York by next season, and hasn't ruled out the outside possibility of Rangerizing the Russian in time for this spring's playoffs.

HEADLINE: Randy Warshaw Taking Next Step, at the Joyce

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Randy Warshaw would seem to be in an enviable position. A former dancer with the popular and influential modern-dance choreographer Trisha Brown, he is now much in demand himself as a teacher of modern dance. He has a vibrant seven-member company of his own that has performed at some of the major dance theaters in New York City and in Europe, and is establishing a second home in Miami, where he grew up. And tonight, Mr. Warshaw and his company open the three-week Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater, where the choreographer will present four new dances.
But at the age of 32, Mr. Warshaw is also at a difficult point in his career. He does not fit into the categories of hot new choreographic Wunderkind or acknowledged older master. How do you sell a "middle-aged" choreographer? Without the resources to hire a manager, he must devote a large chunk of time to the business of dance, losing the time and energy to focus on and create the new work that will help him develop both his audiences and an individual voice. Paradoxically, too, there are fewer places in New York for him to perform. His company has grown beyond the intimate loft theaters that dot Manhattan, but it is not ready for larger, more formal theaters. All of which makes him just right for the Altogether Different festival. 
 Six other choreographers and their companies will present work in the festival: Mark Dendy tomorrow, Friday and Sunday; Elizabeth Streb, on Thursday and Jan. 17; Peter Pucci, on Saturday and Jan. 18, 19 and 22; Doug Varone next Tuesday and on Jan. 19 and 25; Sally Silvers on Jan. 15, 24 and 26, and Molissa Fenley, on Jan. 18, 21, 23, 25 and 26. (Mr. Warshaw's program will be repeated on Sunday and on Jan. 16.) Each has made a mark on the New York dance scene. But all are at midpoints in their careers, in hard economic times and in the post-dance boom era.
"I'm thankful the Joyce has stepped in," Mr. Warshaw said. "Here was this gorgeous space sitting in downtown Manhattan. It was an appropriate place to present choreographers at this point in their careers and they started doing it. This is a step out of the loft, but not a situation like the Brooklyn Academy of Music or City Center, which would just have been pretentious."
Mr. Warshaw found his way into dance almost accidentally. An athletic child, he was interested in studying dance in college, as his brother was doing. He enrolled in a class in contact improvisation, a highly physical form of improvisatory movement, and worked with Steve Paxton, a contact guru who had danced with Ms. Brown.
"I dropped everything else," he recalled. He left college after his junior year to dance with Ms. Brown. "I called my mother when I joined Trisha's company and said, 'Well, I guess I'm a dancer.' "
He was drawn by the "rich physical camaraderie" of Ms. Brown's company. "Moving to New York and studying and working with Trisha gave me a fantastic model," he said. "I saw someone in her mid to late 40's just hitting their stride." He was able to study the ways an experienced choreographer worked. And he began to realize that he wanted to create his own dances, leading him to withdraw from the company in 1987, after seven years.
"What I gained from working with Trisha was a sense that you could give shape choreographically to deep physicality without losing the inner spirit of it," Mr. Warshaw said. His first piece, created in 1985, was "Fragile Anchor," a work filled with swirling, slithery dance. "I was dealing with the tenuousness of things that seemed solid and grounded, and that in some sense continues to be a concern of mine."
 
Life's Thicket of Choices
 That first piece was longer than Mr. Warshaw's entire Joyce program of four dances, which is called "Fictions of Relationship" and explores "the fact that relationships are simply what we create," Mr. Warshaw said, "and that we have an infinite variety of choices.
"The dances start from sensations, vague suspicions, really intangible feelings. The intangible state of your nervous system. So the process of making work is a process of giving form to things inside of me that have no form. I remember very clearly the confusion of adolescence, when I thought that if only I could get everything out in front of me, I could put it on a table and organize it. I think I am still motivated by that desire to give form to something inside me so I can begin to come to terms with it. That is the art of communication, what we attempt to do with the people closest to us. I'm only looking for that satisfaction. I'm trying to become a better choreographer so I can do that in a more compelling way and perhaps with more consistency."
Mr. Warshaw is also trying for distillation in the shorter new pieces. "I've been reading a lot of short stories," he said. "One, by Joyce Carol Oates, was only a paragraph long. 'Fictions of Relationship' is also about exploring the shorter form. One of the things I thought about when I was trying to make sense of shortness was what I wanted to leave the viewer with, as opposed to how much time to take to develop things."
Over the past year, Mr. Warshaw has tried to focus on his creative work, which he felt was slipping away as the demands of running a company became greater. He has learned to be more open with his dancers about business matters, letting them choose to continue or quit rehearsals when money runs out or a grant is uncertain. He has also learned to ask them to help occasionally with company work -- guiltily, he said. "The dancers subsidize the company," he said. "They are the ones who go to work all night in restaurants after rehearsal.
"There are incredible pressures placed on choreographers today. You're a one-man band. That tends to isolate you. I used to hear Trisha talking about earlier times, when everyone knew everyone. But there are so many people working in dance now. The demands of the profession are hitting people earlier and earlier.
"The emphasis has been on the importance of each season. Your next season is determined by the success of this year's season. What a ridiculous demand to place on people who are just beginning to speak!"
For that is what, in the end, Mr. Warshaw considers to be his place in dance today. "I feel like I'm just starting. By working, you realize what it is you need to learn. It becomes more and more rich. I feel I've just barely gotten my feet on the ground." He smiled. "It's very frightening."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Randy Warshaw, fourth from left, rehearsing with members of his dance company for their forthcoming performance at the Joyce Theater. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Throwing Back Undersize Fish Is Said to Encourage Smaller Fry

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

 BODY:
WHAT would happen to the human race if tall people were hunted down and killed en masse while short people lived and reproduced freely?
"Eventually I could play in the National Basketball Association," said Dr. James A. Bohnsack, a biologist with the National Marine Fisheries Service whose dream of dunking professionally was dashed by his 5-feet 6-inch stature. "What's now considered short would soon be tall." 
 That is exactly what is happening to fish, Dr. Bohnsack and other biologists say. Amateur anglers have long released puny fish and kept their bigger cousins for display over the mantle. But now, these biologists say, regulations are requiring commercial fishing operators to do the same thing on a grand scale. So the fittest fish -- that is, the fish most likely to pass on its genes -- now is the small fish.
This theory has led Dr. Bohnsack to propose protecting big fish and their genes by placing thousands of square miles of coastal waters off limits to fishing altogether, a radical revision of the country's marine conservation programs. The proposed reserves, encompassing perhaps 20 percent of all coastal waters, would serve as genetic refuges and seed banks for restocking nearby areas.
 
'We're in Trouble'
 Many biologists dismiss the idea that overfishing has caused rapid genetic changes. Nevertheless, Dr. Bohnsack's proposal has gained wide support from marine biologists. And there is a consensus that current marine conservation regulations, which rely on species' size, limited seasons and restrictions on fishing gear, have failed. The list of depopulated fish reads like a dictionary of coastal marine life. Some species like Atlantic herring and haddock show little evidence of recovery despite 15 years of conservation efforts.
"If we leave things the way they are, we're in trouble," said Dr. Greg Waugh, deputy executive director of the South Atlantic Fisheries Management Council, which regulates Federal waters from Florida to North Carolina. "Just going with size limits and bag limits isn't sufficient."
In an accelerating spiral, the failure of one species often leads to the collapse of others. California's abalone industry, developed in the 19th century, relied after World War II on pink abalone. But as stocks were depleted, fishermen switched to red abalone, then to green and finally to black. A few years ago the entire industry failed. So the fishermen turned to sea urchins. Now that catch is threatened.
Coastal fisheries, the researchers argue, probably survived years of increasingly intense harvesting because they were maintained by natural refuges -- areas too deep and too remote to harvest. But these reserves were moved to the front lines by armies of fishermen equipped with sophisticated gear, including satellite navigation systems, sonar, refrigeration and powerful engines.
The catch has plummeted all along the country's coasts. Fish thrown back as Lilliputians just a few years ago now are considered Brobdingnagians of the deep. Researchers at the Southeast Fisheries Science Center in Beaufort, N.C., a division of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, say large Warsaw grouper and other marine giants disappeared with frightening speed after a party boat fleet began plying the waters off the Carolina coasts in 1972.
 
Red Snapper Decline
 "It used to be we'd hook one almost every trip," Dr. Gene Huntsman, leader of the laboratory's reef fish and coastal pelagic team, recalled in describing the 300-plus pounders that once dominated the area's waters. "We haven't seen one in years."
Between 1972 and 1985, he noted, the weight of most of the 275 species tracked by the team plunged about 75 percent on average: red porgies went from 2.6 pounds to 1.3 pounds, red snapper from 18.0 to 4.4, snowy grouper from 17.6 to 4.4, speckled hind from 19.1 to 6.6, scamp from 10.1 to 3.3 and gag from 18.0 to 4.4. Dr. Huntsman noted that the trend, which has continued, was similar if less dramatic for the commercial catch.
The commercial catch of red snapper in waters along the south Florida coast, once considered among the richest in the world, has also plummeted, dropping from 253,000 pounds in 1983 to 8,177 pounds in 1989, according to statistics compiled by the South Atlantic Fisheries Management Council, a Federal agency that regulates ocean waters from North Carolina to Florida. The decline for the entire Gulf of Mexico was only slightly less precipitous, falling from 14 million pounds in 1965 to 4.1 million pounds in 1985.
While many biologists note that evolutionary changes usually take hundreds of years, evidence is growing that fishing pressure compresses generations and can accelerate the rate of such change. One study concluded that Atlantic salmon spawned earlier after fewer than two decades of heavy fishing; another that the average size of chinook salmon declined by more than 50 percent in 60 years and that the average age of maturity dropped by about two years. "Nets stop the big ones while the little ones get through," Dr. Bohnsack said.
"The result is a race of miniatures."
More recently, a New Zealand study of three orange-roughy spawning sites in the Pacific found that heavy fishing had a significant genetic impact. More alarmingly, the study, published in the journal Fisheries Research last year, also concluded that the genetic impact could occur before the species was threatened by extinction.
But Dr. John Gold, a professor of genetics at Texas A & M University, said it was almost impossible to demonstrate empirically that excessive fishing caused genetic changes like a diminution in size. While the simplicity and logic of the theory makes it compelling, he noted that the supposed changes involved several genes whose individual effect was small, cumulative and independent.
"Bohnsack's head and heart are in the right place," said Dr. Gold, whose specialty is molecular genetics. "But the idea, although a good one, is very difficult to test."
Proponents acknowledge that marine reserves may at first increase pressure on stocks in the remaining open waters and economic hardship for nearby coastal communities. But the biologists note that tourism and scuba diving can help mitigate the loss of revenue and that, unlike bag and size limits, refuges are easy to police. The reserves' negative impact will be more than offset within a few years, they argue.
That, at least, is what happened in the Philippines, which in 1974 closed a 820-yard sliver of reef off Sumilon Island. Within two years, the mean harvest rate of 1.76 pounds per man day had tripled, according to a study cited by Dr. Gary E. Davis, a marine biologist with the United States National Park Service.
And after five years the sustained yield on adjacent areas had climbed to between 18.2 and 26.4 tons per square kilometer per year, among the highest reported for any coral reef in the world. Then poachers started invading the reserve. Within two years yields plummeted by 50 percent over the entire area, according to the study, published two years ago by the California Cooperative of Oceanic Fisheries Investigations, a consortium of marine institutions.
 
Improvement With Age
 The underlying reason for the success of the reserves, which have been set up in half a dozen countries around the world, is that most reef fish rarely venture far from their home bases. And while juvenile fish channel their energy into growing, adults are disproportionately fecund.
"Unlike humans, fish get bigger and better as they get older," Dr. Bohnsack said. "It's exponential." The gonads of a single 23.8-inch female red snapper, he noted, weigh as much as those of 212 females of 16.4 inches and produce as many eggs, about 9.3 million. "A few older organisms may be more important to total reproductive output than many younger ones," he noted in a recent paper delivered at a meeting of the Gulf and Caribbean Fisheries Institute.
So current conservation methods, which spare juveniles but allow the harvest of larger fish, are counterproductive, the biologists argue. And by shortening the average lifespan, they increase vulnerability to mismanagement and catastrophes. "What happens if you have a natural disaster that prevents reproduction for a while?" Dr. Waugh asked.
Dr. Bohnsack said he was greeted with ridicule when he first broached the idea of a network of marine preserves three years ago in a paper for the American Fisherman's Society. "When people first heard the idea, the visceral response was 'Are you out of your mind?' " he recalled. "But after thinking about it, looking at the problem, they realize it's the only thing that makes sense."
Increasingly, a consensus is forming in support of the idea among marine conservationists. Dr. Davis said researchers at a symposium on marine fisheries in San Antonio were surprised by suggestions that the idea needed more testing, even though there remains vigorous debate over reserves' preferred size and location.
"We need to take the bull by the horns and create some of those refuges," he said.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Let the Commercials Begin. And They Have.

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
The assault of the Olympic commercials has begun, as CBS pitches its February broadcast of the Winter Olympics from Albertville and NBC hawks its July 26-Aug. 9 pay-per-view cable package of the Summer Olympics from Barcelona, Spain.
The goals of both are divergent. The intent of CBS's "Share a Moment With the World" campaign is to remind viewers to tune in from Feb. 8-23 -- a conventional promotional strategy. 
 The aim of NBC's "Catch the Fire Behind the Flame" campaign is to educate the public about the first Olympics to appear both on network television and a pay-per-view basis and to sell packages ranging in price from $95 to $170 -- a difficult task made even worse by the recession and the novelty of the effort.
Thus far, CBS is executing its strategy more effectively, with a series of sophisticated, goose-bumpy spots like one that links viewers and the story of a young girl rising early to train for the Olympic dream and uses the line, "Remember, that's not just America's team out there. That's somebody's kid."
Or this one about a bobsled team, with a camera mounted on a speeding sled: "They are four who must function as one. For one breakneck minute, they will hurtle down a swerving tunnel of sheer ice. . . . They call it fun."
The series of spots, which include some that focus on an actual athletes, feature the soothing and authoritative voice of Fritz Weaver, the actor. An additional 15 spots are ready to come out of CBS's chute over the next few weeks.
CBS's job is easier than NBC's. Viewers don't have to pay to watch the 116 hours of Albertville coverage. They just have to be excited enough to resist the lure of the competing programs planned by ABC and NBC. CBS's main challenge is to instill the desire to watch despite the relative paucity of winter events and the anonymous status of most winter athletes.
NBC's Triplecast promotional strategy is different from CBS's and, so far, it hasn't looked quite as enticing. Yes, it is still in its early stages, six months away from the Barcelona Games, but it hasn't packed the impact one would expect from this joint venture between NBC and Cablevision.
The main idea of the Triplecast is choice. While NBC will broadcast 161 hours of Olympic programming on its normal broadcast network, the Triplecast offers three cable channels, with certain sports dedicated to each one running simultaneously and without commercials. Each channel will broadcast 12 hours of live events, which will then be repeated in the following 12 hours.
"If you could be the executive producer, would you choose to watch this great athlete, this one, this rider fulfill his dream, or a team sport like basketball?" asks one spot. Says another: "You can catch every punch, every stroke and every dash of the Olympics. You have the power to choose."
If the intent of the Triplecast promotion so far has been to get viewers to start abandoning the last-minute pay-per-view buying habits that characterize the purchase of boxing events, it needs the oomph that comes with swaddling them in the arms of a Jackie Joyner-Kersee.
But asking, "Would you choose to watch this great athlete?" obscures the strategy of letting the stars sell the product. The great athletes have names.
The campaign correctly, if deceptively, does not give the prices of the packages, giving the viewer the incentive to want to know more. So the spots ask that prospective buyers call an 800 number (1-800-OLYMPIC).
The Triplecast management's stated goal is to sign up at least 2 million viewers and as many as 3.5 million. Those are lofty hopes, particularly in light of the fact that the Triplecast will compete against NBC.
The biggest question of all is whether there are enough Olympic junkies willing to be guinea pigs for this pay-per-view experiment, or will 161 hours delivered the old-fashioned way, on NBC, be enough?
Right now, the commercial campaign, the engine of education and excitement, does not deliver a strong enough message for viewers to pull out their Visa cards.

 
 
AIRWAVES
 Some observations on the weekend's National Football League divisional playoff games: CBS's VERNE LUNDQUIST exercised creative word usage, saying that Redskin JUMPY GEATHERS had "put the forklift" on Falcons running back ERRIC PEGRAM and that Redskins' DANNY COPELAND "counterpunches to the 46" after an interception. . . . NBC's TODD CHRISTENSEN rightly ripped bad time management by the Oilers in the fourth quarter, including a timeout that gave the Broncos more time on their winning drive.
NBC's BILL WALSH gave his usual football clinic during the Chiefs-Bills game, hammering at the Chiefs' "stereotyped" run-run-pass offensive scheme, suggesting the Chiefs abandon caution and start the second half in the shotgun. . . . CBS's PAT SUMMERALL and JOHN MADDEN frolicked verbally during the Lions-Cowboys blowout and Madden scored with a comment on how difficult it had to be for quarterbacks to pass when both teams' helmets were silver-colored. Of course, Lions quarterback ERIK KRAMER didn't seem to notice.
Top shots of the weekend: Close-ups by NBC of the grimace on injured Chiefs quarterback STEVE DeBERG's face and by CBS of two fumbled snaps by Cowboys' quarterback TROY AIKMAN.
