HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Presenting Hypocrisy Inc.

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
President Bush lands in Tokyo with 21 top American business executives and a full cargo of economic evasion, self-delusion, bombast and prefabricated "agreements" that cleverly avoid the realities of the problems between the United States and Japan.
 But that's all right -- it will be fair trade at its best. The Japanese will meet him with their own complete product line of economic hypocrisy, including that new and fast-growing specialty, contempt lightly camouflaged as compassion. 
 So the mission will leave the United States and Japan in exactly their present positions -- the Japanese using their skills, social strengths, history and every trick in the trade to remain powerful and growing, the Americans wasting their own rich talents and national heritage, looking up now and then for a good cry.
 The reason for the failure will be that neither the U.S. nor Japan talk candidly to each other or to their own people about the core reasons for the problems and what can be done to solve them.
 And, just as important, both sides do not acknowledge that not everything can be solved. Some problems between them are deep in national social contracts that neither intends to change -- so we might as well get on with the struggle where there is no way out.
 Experience, I keep learning, does not necessarily mean wisdom, but I did wind up my tour as a foreign correspondent in Japan knowing one thing about the Japanese mystery: There was none. The country, like every other, is scrutable, on its own terms.
 Japan is a social, political and economic whole -- a cartel if you don't like it, a cooperative community if you do. The Japanese have shown that within that sense of community they can argue, adapt and change. But government, business, politicians, the bureaucracy and the unions regard themselves as members of a national economics team, not adversaries.
 The idea that they are opponents to be separated by antitrust laws or conflict of interest concepts -- a basis of American society -- is to them foreign and foolish. Every day businessmen and government officials cooperate with each other -- Americans would call it conspire -- and against the outside world in ways that in the U.S. would put them all in jail.
 The contract is for loyalty up, loyalty down. Japanese unions have a way of staging work stoppages during lunch breaks. But their members know they will not wake up one morning to find out that 70,000 of them have been fired. Before that would happen, executives would resign, other companies would pitch in and the banks would come through with loans, on government orders.
 The Japanese are simply not going to change that system. It has made them one of the most prosperous countries on earth and, thanks to the U.S., all accomplished peacefully under parliamentary democracy.
 Americans would not like to be Japanese. The Japanese system does promote conformity, obsequiousness, rigidity. It suits neither American law nor American tradition. And let's never forget that it has been American history, law and culture that inspired the world and still does -- hardly the Japanese.
 But once our politicians recognize the differences between the countries instead of pretending there are really none, the U.S. can face reality. One essential is to examine our own laws and traditions, to see if some should be changed to permit more of the industry cooperation, combined research, shared capital investment and encouragement of savings that have helped Japan. We don't have to become Japanese; neither do we have to remain ostriches.
 Second step: In those defined cases where the U.S., calmly and patiently, decides that the Japanese system is being used deliberately against us we should calmly and patiently sock it to them.
 An American President should have the courage to say all that. Then he has to go one hard step further and say that what the whole world says about us is true. We spend too much, invest too little, allow our schools to be dominated by the limits of dullards. He should tell us that if we do not change we will wind up really deserving what the Japanese now just pretend to have for us -- compassion. And how would we like that?
 Then he can accomplish something in Tokyo, not before.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Neither Party Offering a Good Economic Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The failure of economists to expect much uplift to the economy from the Democratic Party plan to give middle-income families a tax cut of about $8 a week is easy to understand. People concerned about losing their jobs would be slow to spend the extra money, even if they noticed it in their paychecks. 
 Not so easy to understand is the absence of unanimous pessimism among economists about the Republican Party plan, with its orientation toward stimulating investment. Office buildings and shopping malls have been heavily overbuilt, the average age of automobiles is lower than it was five years ago, square feet of residential stock is historically high in relation to population, computer manufacturers are cutting prices. It is hard to see where capacities could be profitably expanded.
Since no program at all is better than a program that only serves to increase the deficit (and the onerous interest burden on it), a stalemate between the Democratic Congress and the White House might be the best attainable outcome for the next 12 months. Then a new administration, with four years in front of it, could undertake to stimulate the economy by increasing grants to state and local governments.
This money would be spent. Much of it would be investment spending in areas such as education and infrastructure, where additional investment is very clearly in the national interest. If and when there is another period of inflationary overheating, the deficit should be increased.
We are, after all, among the least heavily taxed among developed countries. This too is a reason for doubting that our salvation lies in reducing taxes.
 
JETSON E. LINCOLN
Montclair, N.J., Dec. 21, 1991

LENGTH: 979 words

HEADLINE: RATING FOR CREDIT OF NEW YORK STATE DOWNGRADED AGAIN

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Strongly censuring New York State's fiscal condition and the political paralysis in Albany, a major Wall Street credit agency today downgraded the rating on most of the state's debt, leaving New York with the second lowest rating of all states.
The new rating from Moody's Investors Service, which affects only the portion of the state's debt backed by annual legislative appropriations, is the lowest in the state's history and could mean that New York would have to pay higher interest rates when it borrows money in the future. The lower rating places New York in a tie with Louisiana for the nation's second lowest credit rating, ahead of only Massachusetts. 
 New York's credit rating has now been downgraded twice in less than two years. After being lowered from A1 to A by Moody's in June 1990, today's action, which lowered the state's rating to Baa1, left the state one step above the lowest investment-grade rating and two steps above the rating accorded many junk bonds.
 
Flurry of Finger-Pointing
 A statement released by Moody's late this afternoon attributed the downgrading to "the state's inability to exercise budgetary control and address the midyear deficit on a timely basis." The announcement set off a flurry of finger-pointing by the state's political leaders, with Democrats and Republicans blaming each other for failing to break a two-month impasse over closing the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget.
The action by Moody's did not affect the state's general-obligation bonds, which continue to be rated A by Moody's. But the downgrading brought Moody's into line with the two-tiered rating system used by the other major credit rating agency, Standard & Poor's, which previously rated the state's general-obligation bonds higher than its appropriation-backed debt.
In what many state officials viewed as a last-chance warning, the Moody's statement said the agency would review the rating on New York's general-obligation bonds at a later date.
"We must act now to insure that we give the raters no cause to take this action again," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in a statement.
State budget officials and credit analysts said it was not immediately clear how much the downgrading might cost the state in its coming bond sales. Bonds with lower ratings are considered greater risks and their issuers usually have to pay higher interest rates to sell them.
The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said last week that the state and its public authorities were planning to sell nearly $3 billion in bonds in the first quarter of 1992.
State budget officials said they were concerned not only that the downgrading would divert taxpayer money to debt service from needs like road building and health care but also that it would have long-lingering effects on market psychology.
Moody's lowered the credit rating on New York's appropriation-backed debt -- which is distinguished from the state's general-obligation debt -- after the vice president for state debt ratings at Moody's, George W. Leung, recommended the downgrading. The appropriation-backed debt currently accounts for about two-thirds of the state's debt and is its fastest-growing component.
Under the State Constitution, general-obligation bonds can only be issued with voter approval. They are backed by the full faith and credit of the state, meaning that bondholders have the first claim on each year's tax revenues.
Appropriation-backed debt, by contrast, does not require voter approval and is backed by annual appropriations passed by the Legislature. It includes the state's certificates of participation and debt issued by a host of state authorities, including the Dormitory Authority, the Urban Development Corporation and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Because the servicing of appropriation-backed debt must compete for resources each year with the state's other fiscal demands, it is considered a less secure investment than general-obligation bonds.
Vladimir Stadnyk, a managing partner at Standard & Poor's, said his firm's decision on whether to downgrade the state's ratings would not be affected by the Moody's announcement. But, he said, "as far as the general-obligation rating, we continue to be concerned with the lack of action on the part of the state."
"As time dwindles by, the less comfortable we would be with the current rating," he said.
 
Trying to Break Logjam
 Officials with both Moody's and Standard & Poor's have been warning for weeks that the budget impasse in Albany could generate a downgrading. Mr. Cuomo has tried unsuccessfully to use their alarms as leverage to break the logjam.
But with the March 31 end of the fiscal year fast approaching, each passing day has left less cash in the state's treasury. That has narrowed the options for closing the $875 million gap without borrowing heavily, and credit raters have consistently criticized the growth of the state's accumulated deficit. It is now nearly $6.3 billion, up from $4 billion in 1983, when Mr. Cuomo took office.
The Moody's statement said the state's inability to solve its midyear budget problem "is a legacy of this year's delayed budget," which was passed a record 65 days after the start of the fiscal year. It said that budget compromises of recent years had "exhausted one-shot resources and marginal solutions" and it called for "fundamental" restructuring of the state's finances.
Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, both Queens Democrats, attributed the downgrading to what the Governor said was "the State Senate's failure to recognize the critical need to close the current-year deficit."
But the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., said the Moody's call for fundamental restructuring supported his call for deep cuts in the state's Medicaid and welfare budgets.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 9, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A map on Tuesday showing bond ratings for each state misstated New York's rating. Moody's Investors Services gives New York's general obligation bonds a rating of A; it is the state's appropriation-backed debt that was lowered on Monday to Baa1.

HEADLINE: As Bonn Talks Louder, Some in the U.S. Wince

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
United States policy makers concerned with eastern and western Europe say they have become disturbed during the last six months by what they regard as new assertiveness on the part of the German Government and its willingness to flex its muscles in international relations.
Some of these officials -- at the White House below the level of President Bush, and at the State Department below the level of Secretary James A. Baker 3d -- say they are worried about this issue. Their response for the time being is to discuss their feelings among themselves but not to convey them to the Germans. 
 The main cause of disquiet is Bonn's decision to push ahead in the Yugoslav crisis with separate recognition of Croatia and Slovenia, rebuffing pleas of the United States, the United Nations and other European governments to remain in the previous framework of European Community peace efforts. It was the most striking display of German assertiveness on foreign policy since German reunification in October 1990.
 
Joint European Effort
 The 12-member European Community's previous approach to Yugoslavia consisted of negotiations among the leaders of the six Yugoslav republics under the auspices of the community, augmented by the United Nations mission headed by Cyrus R. Vance seeking a general cease-fire and the deployment of peacekeeping troops.
But the German approach, started in the early autumn by Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, focused solely on diplomatic recognition of Croatia and Slovenia, both of which had declared their intention to secede from the Yugoslav federation last June.
While most of Germany's European Community colleagues opposed recognition throughout the fall, in December at a meeting in Brussels, Mr. Genscher's 11 fellow foreign ministers in the European Community bowed to his adamant insistence that they approve Germany's demand to proceed with early diplomatic recognition of the two breakaway republics, which is to take place formally on Jan. 15.
 
'Unilateral Action'
 Describing this, Der Spiegel, the newsmagazine, said "It was the first time since 1949 that Bonn took a unilateral action in foreign policy." The German Federal Republic was founded in that year.
A senior state Department official, who said he had been "uneasy" about the new German stance for the last six months, said, "I really am bothered about it, personally." He said that Germany's new assertiveness "is going to be difficult for us to stomach," and that, "There is no question that we have to take the Germans more seriously than they have been."
He and other Administration officials concerned with Germany said they were worried less about the fact of the German initiative on Yugoslavia than about "the strong-arm tactics," as one put it. A second official said he was disturbed by "the style -- that we are right and the rest of you should follow us" -- displayed by Mr. Genscher in the Brussels deliberations.
These officials say they are concerned that Germany, with its economic might and new tougher diplomatic tone, will become a dominant power in the new Europe, and perhaps beyond, that will not necessarily be in harmony with American policies.
 
'A Great Victory'
 These officials were also disturbed by Chancellor Kohl's statement, after the Brussels meeting, that the decision there was "a great victory for German foreign policy."
A State Department official official, noting that the chancellor used the German word "Sieg," for victory, commented, "Kohl may have proclaimed the first German Sieg since 1945."
After the word "Sieg" became associated with Nazi propaganda, including Hitler's repeated predictions of an "Endsieg," or final victory, right up until his suicide in April 1945, Germans in general and politicians in particular tended to shun proclamations of "victory" except in sports. In place of Sieg they employed the more anodyne expression, "Erfolg," which means "success."
Robert Gerald Livingston, a retired American diplomat who specialized in German affairs for the last four decades, remarked, "Speaking of 'Sieg' would bother me if it became a constant in German politics."
But Mr. Livingston, director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies at the Johns Hopkins University, said of the Kohl Government's assertiveness: "I think it is less muscle-flexing than the consequence of passion, even an obsession, for order. What they see in Eastern Europe and beyond is chaos and anarchy. It disturbs them on the political level and on the emotional level, the fear that unwashed and unwanted immigrants are going to pour in."
Administration officials contend that Bonn has also become more muscular on trade and financial issues, notably by sidestepping a United States request to help in persuading France to agree to reduce Europe's high agricultural subsidies and by raising German interest rates last month without regard to effects on Bonn's partners.
Several officials recalled that they had expected the tone in United States-German relations to be set by President Bush's invitation in a speech in May 1989 in Mainz to the Kohl Government to join "a partnership in leadership." That was less than six months before the fall of the Berlin wall.
 
'Partnership a la Carte'
 "We saw it as a matter of working side by side," one Administration official recalled. "The Germans have something else in mind, more a division of labor, a partnership a la carte." He noted that except for contributing to the costs of supporting the allied forces in the Gulf War, the Bonn Government stayed aloof.
The new Bonn stance is acknowledged somewhat gingerly by German officials, who talk of unified Germany, with its population of 78 million, as having "larger responsibilities." Those responsibilities clearly involve speaking out more forcefully when it appears that German interests are affected.
Thus when the United States sent a note to Germany and the other European Community members warning them against the consequences of early recognition of Croatia and Slovenia, Bonn officials complained sharply to American diplomats that they were being singled out for criticism.
The note went out over the signature of Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who said that selective, premature recognition could "lead to greater bloodshed" in Yugoslavia.
 
A Charge Is Rebutted
 Last month, reacting to press reports suggesting that Germany had been less than scrupulous in trying to prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction, Jurgen Ruhfus, Ambassador to the United States, pointedly rejected the criticism in an Op-Ed article in The Washington Post. Such a public defense by a German diplomat would have been scarcely thinkable here a few years ago.
German diplomats, strongly defending their Government's actions in all fields, said this week that no one in the Administration had indicated concerns to them about either the style or the substance of Bonn Government actions in international affairs.
At home, the Kohl-Genscher approach to the Yugoslav crisis and other international issues has drawn considerable support in the German press, with the exception of the Suddeutsche Zeitung of Munich and Der Spiegel.
The newsmagazine reported recently that President Richard von Weizsacker also had misgivings about the Government policy toward Yugoslavia. In his New Year's address to the nation, Mr. von Weizsacker said there were "some concerns abroad about new German might," and he cautioned against seeking "a special role for us."
 Contrary to that report, Chancellor Kohl actually used the word "Erfolg" and not "Sieg." The Times should have checked the original text of Mr. Kohl's remarks, and not relied on a secondhand account of them.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 10, 1992, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about Germany's new assertiveness in its policy toward Croatia placed great stress on an assertion by an unidentified State Department official that Chancellor Helmut Kohl had used the German word "Sieg," instead of "Erfolg," to mean "success." As the article explained, the word "Sieg" has come to be associated with declarations of the Nazi Government.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 4.70 In Resuming Its Advance

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
After a one-day pause, the stock market resumed its daily record-setting yesterday, as investors, unable to find better returns elsewhere, continued to beat a path to equities. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.70 points, to 3,204.83, its seventh record in eight sessions.
Don Hays, director of investment strategy for Wheat, First Securities in Richmond, said he was amazed at the amount of money pouring out of bank certificates of deposit and money market funds that has found its way into this market. "There are people who have never invested in stocks before, sticking their toes in," he said. 
 Action on the New York Stock Exchange was choppy and the volume heavy, as 252.8 million shares were traded, up from 251.2 million on Monday. Gaining issues narrowly outpaced losers, 916 to 881.
 
Small Issues Lead the Way
 For the most part, lower interest rates and belief that the economy will recover continue to buoy the market, with smaller issues leading the march.
Other indexes achieving highs included the Nasdaq composite, which rose 4.39 points to close at 602.29, and the American Stock Exchange composite, up 2.44 points, to 401.71.
The Russell 2,000, another barometer of small stocks, also finished at a high of 195.77, up 1.40 points.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell short yesterday and slipped 0.56 point to end the session at 417.40.
While Monday's downside close on the Dow, its first since mid-December, and weak stock performances in the London and Japanese markets injected a note of caution at the beginning of yesterday's session, the stock market managed to erase its early losses by late morning.
For most of day the market gained, then lost, then gained again in a late flurry to carry it to new highs.
Mr. Hays called the market very fragmented. "If you were in the right stocks, you made money, but some stocks have already started their correction. Technical factors in the market tell us that we may have from a one-to-10-week correction taking place."
While there is indeed a lot of money coming in from small investors, Mr. Hays said there was another side to the coin. Many investors who made large profits last year and cashed in, large investors nervous over corporate earnings and a still-weak economy are pulling at the market from the other direction.
Analysts expect some investors to move to the sidelines ahead of economic news expected out later this week. On Thursday the December Producer Price Index figures will be released, and on Friday, employment numbers.
Elsewhere in the market, Dow Chemical, which fell in Monday trading after the Food and Drug Administration urged a moratorium on the use and shipments of silicone breast implants, rebounded smartly yesterday, moving up 2 3/4, to 54 5/8, as James H. Wilbur, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham, repeated a buy recommendation based on the stock's price decline following the F.D.A.'s announcement. Dow Chemical and Corning Inc. jointly own Dow Corning Wright, which makes implants.
 
Retailing Is Weak
 Among the actively traded issues was the Gap, which is one of the few retailers that analysts have recommended. The stock fell 2 1/4, to 56 3/4, and served as a reminder of the weakness in the retail sector, traders said.
DNA Plant Technology nearly doubled, rising 4, to 8 1/2, after it announced that its joint venture with Du Pont, Intermountain Canola, was producing a brand of canola oil with only 6 percent saturated fat. Cooking oils represent a $3 billion market.
Borland InternationalBORL.O fell 1 3/4, to 78 1/4, as Christopher Mortenson, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, lowered his third- and fourth-quarter earnings estimates for the computer software products manufacturer. Traders, however, said he had reiterated his buy recommendation.
I.B.M., one of the bluest of the blue- chip issues, was up 2 1/4, to 94 5/8, yesterday. Many analysts noted that the stock had been overly beaten up at the end of last year, and that the price might have dropped low enough to become attractive.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The Japanese Government announced a host of incentives to make it easier for American companies to export their goods, seeking to demonstrate its willingness to take concrete steps to reduce its growing trade surplus with the U.S. The move, parts of which had been announced earlier and some of whose measures merely expanded on existing programs, came on the first day of President Bush's visit. [Page A1.]
 
Markets
A torrent of new corporate debt securities flooded the credit markets, as companies began to react to the drop in rates. [D1.] 
 The stock market resumed its daily record-setting, as the Dow rose 4.70, to 3,204.83, its seventh record in eight sessions. [D6.]
The dollar settled lower against most currencies but was mixed against the yen. [D14.]
Oil prices fell sharply on anticipation that Iraq would escape from a U.N. embargo and resume exports soon. [D14.]
 
Companies
Bristol-Myers Squibb said it was reducing its prices by $20 million to Federal programs for veterans, the military and the Public Health Service, and by $60 million for Medicaid. [D1.]
Hartmarx said it would merge the operations of two of its retail divisions, in yet another effort to curb costs as the recession continues to chip away at sales. [D1.]
Ford will begin building right-hand-drive Ford Probe sporty coupes for export to Japan and Britain. It is trying to increase the appeal of its vehicles to the Japanese. [D1.]
Nearly $100 billion of G.M. and Chrysler debt was downgraded by Moody's and S.&P. just a day after auto makers reported their worst sales year since 1983. [D2.]
Macmillan's chairman said he had strong hopes that American-based Maxwell assets would remain intact. [D2.]
The Air Force asked that a billion-dollar computer contract it awarded last month be canceled. [D3.]
Paramount Communications reported profits that were less than half the prior year's level, despite higher revenues. [D4.]
American Express Publishing reorganized its magazines, with Travel & Leisure standing alone and the other five grouped together. [D4.]
Alcoa said it was taking a $217 million after-tax charge, primarily to cover the cost of environmental cleanups. [D3.]
 
The Economy
The 6.8 percent unemployment number understates the real number considerably, economists say. They warn that the figure provides a false sense of the economy's strength and its potential for rebounding. [D1.]
 
Business Technology
A new generation of nationwide data networks is making it possible for both large and small companies to extend their office computer systems to workers on the road. [D5.]
A carpenter's level with a computer chip has been called the first major advance in levels since 1666. [D5.]

Today's Columns
Last year was a strong one for bond funds, particularly for those invested in junk bonds. But in the fourth quarter, the best-performing funds were those that invested in the mark and in long-term domestic securities. Market Place. [D1.]
The temptation to buy condos at auction is probably worth resisting, two economists say. The only real winners seem to be buyers who wait until the auction is completed. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Edward H. Vick is changing fields. He was the last president and chief executive of Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver before it closed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bristol-Myers's Drug Prices Are Cut for Health Programs

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Acting at a time when Congressional drug-industry critics are demanding Government regulation of pharmaceutical prices, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company announced yesterday that it was reducing its prices by $20 million to Federal programs for veterans, the military and the Public Health Service, and by $60 million for the Federal-state Medicaid program for the poor.
Bristol-Myers Squibb said it was the first drug company to make reductions for the Federal programs that were as low as, or lower than, rebates that all drug companies are now required to give to state-run Medicaid programs. 
 The announcement followed general pledges by Merck & Company and Pfizer Inc. to restrain drug price increases.
About 32 million people, including military dependents, are eligible under the veterans and military programs; 25 million under Medicaid, and 11.6 million in public health programs for American Indians and other medically underserved groups.
Analysts estimated that the company had about $290 million in Medicaid sales in 1991 and worldwide pharmaceutical sales of $5.8 billion. The company said it provided $55 million in Medicaid rebates last year, under the 1990 law requiring the cuts.
Bruce R. Ross, president of the Bristol-Myers Squibb U.S. Pharmaceutical Group, said, "The Federal Government has been and is our single largest customer in the United States." The company declined to disclose its total business in the Federal and state programs.
Mr. Ross noted that the new discounts and the prices of Bristol-Myers's newest drugs to treat AIDS, cholesterol levels and high blood pressure were determined amid growing anger over medical costs.
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said that "the issue of drug prices becomes political because it hurts about one-third of the U.S. population," people who have to pay prices that have been rising at about double the general inflation rate.
Marc O. Mayer, a drug securities analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said the Bristol-Myers announcement was "basically an upfront concession" in an election year during a "tremendous buildup in political pressure" for price regulation.
 
 
Criticized in the Senate
 Bristol-Myers was criticized at a Senate hearing last year for charging a Federal purchasing program $75.64 for a three-week supply of its antipsychotic drug Prolixen. The company said yesterday that it was lowering the price of Prolixen to $44.85.
It said the price of Capoten, a heart and blood pressure treatment that is its largest-selling drug, would drop 11 percent, to $34.05 for a three-month supply, from $38.22, in the same Federal program.
Mr. Ross said the company had raised prices to some of these Federal programs last year when five-year contracts came up for renewal. The company was unable to say last night if the new cuts would cancel out the 1991 increases.
Congressional reaction was mixed. Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who has urged drug companies to reduce prices voluntarily, said the Bristol-Myers announcement was "the first step" in that direction.
Representative Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat, said he would not change his proposal to establish a "pool" of Government programs that would jointly demand price concessions. But Mr. Wyden added that "if other companies follow up on what Bristol-Myers Squibb is doing" with voluntary price reductions, "it might help hold off stronger governmental approaches and have a real impact on the national health debate."

HEADLINE: Hardships the Job Numbers Miss

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The United States unemployment rate is officially 6.8 percent today. But economists are now saying that this figure considerably underestimates the real number. They warn that the current unemployment figure, influential in gauging the nation's economic health and determining what policies should be adopted to improve it, provides a false sense of the economy's strength and its potential for rebounding.
The problem: changes in the work force over the last 15 years that are not accounted for in calculating the rate. One such change is the growing number of people on the edge of unemployment, counted as working but facing the hardships and insecurity of the jobless. These people, probably numbering more than three million, include many temporary and freelance workers, older men pushed into lower-paying jobs, consultants and single mothers who cannot work as many hours as they would like. 
 Workers like these often have no company-sponsored health insurance -- or even assurance from one day to the next that they will not be terminated. People in that predicament, though listed as employed, often behave as if they are not. They are afraid to buy a new home and hesitant to spend money on a new car, gifts or even dinner out and an evening at the movies.
The other important and growing category not captured by traditional employment data is an unknown number of people, perhaps more than a million, who have given up looking for a job or even admitting that they would like one. These include teen-agers, former factory workers and an unknown number of people unwilling to seek jobs that pay less than about $7 an hour. The monthly employment statistics, which will next be released on Friday, cover only people who have work or say they are actively hunting for it.
"It is quite clear that our employment statistics no longer fully explain what is going on out there," said Thomas Plewes, associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, which gathers the monthly employment data.
Only lately have policy makers begun to agree, recognizing as the recession drags on that a 6.8 percent unemployment rate -- mild by the standards of past recessions -- may be a misleading indicator of the economy's problems. Just last month, the Bush Administration, which had been forecasting a recovery by Christmas, acknowledged that Americans were suffering more hardship than the official data indicated and that the recession that began 18 months ago still gripped the nation.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, took note of the shortcomings in the employment numbers during recent Congressional testimony. "Don't look at these data and say that everyone is in good shape," he said in reply to a question, "because clearly they are not."
The Bureau of Labor Statistics derives the nation's unemployment rate from a monthly Census Bureau survey of 65,000 representative American households. The department bases its unemployment rate on those who report, in effect, that they did not work during the week before the survey, but did hunt actively for a job. Such responses produced 8.5 million unemployed in November -- a 6.8 percent jobless rate that is well below the 10.8 percent rate in the 1981-82 recession.
But an examination of Labor Department data and interviews with labor economists suggest that the November number would probably have been more than 12 million, or nearly 10 percent of the labor force, if the definition of joblessness was broadened to include those who wanted jobs but were not job hunting and those who held jobs but nevertheless suffered the concerns usually associated with unemployment.
The Labor Department is beginning to consider changes that might broaden the concept of who is considered unemployed, although Mr. Plewes cautioned that gathering the additional information needed to make the rate more accurate would require more questions about Americans' behavior that might violate their privacy.
"More penetrating questions in the monthly employment surveys would yield different answers," said John T. Dunlop, a Harvard labor economist and Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration.
 
A Matter of Classification
 That is evident from the way the bureau classifies the employed. The statistics, for example, listed 116.8 million people as holding jobs in November; that is, they met the bureau's criteria of having worked for pay in the week before the survey.
Such a blanket classification fails to capture the experiences of the proliferating number of Americans who work and draw pay but are carried on corporate rolls as freelancers, contract workers, consultants or temporaries.
Most of these people presumably show up in a subcategory of 12 million jobholders whom the bureau describes as temporary workers or self-employed. It is a substantial subcategory, one that has risen to 10 percent of the labor force from 8 percent in 1980. It covers the owner of a prosperous store or law firm. But the subcategory also covers the more precariously employed: the consultant, the freelancer, or the contract worker who hires out day-to-day as a clerk, engineer or gardener.
"There are probably more than five million freelancers and temps," said Mitchell Fromstein, chairman of Manpower Inc., which recruits and supplies such people at an hourly fee. "All the major corporations have them in what they call a supplemental work force," he said, "and the practice is growing."
Some freelancers prefer to work this way. But Mr. Fromstein said the majority wanted regular jobs and took temporary work because they could not get permanent employment. Among those who sign on with Manpower, a third acknowledge on their applications that they are hunting for a permanent job.
 Then there is the phenomenon of the part-time worker. Again, the Labor Department groups some jobholders as "part timers for economic reasons" -- people who tell the surveyors they would like to work full time, but can get only part-time hours. Their numbers jumped to 6.5 million last month, 5.2 percent of the work force, from 5 million in July 1990, at the start of the recession.
Clearly, these part timers suffer from partial unemployment, many economists say, and the Labor Department agrees, although this circumstance is not reflected in the national unemployment rate.
Neither is the hidden unemployment that exists among the 14.9 million people who were listed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in November as working part time voluntarily. Most in fact do not want more hours. But while this group has not changed over the years as a percentage of the labor force (roughly 12 percent), the composition may have shifted to include more people who, in easier circumstances, would have sought full-time work.
Specifically, economists point to an unknown number of single mothers who tell the surveyors that they work part time and prefer it that way, but in fact need more money and would work more hours if they could afford child care.
A decade ago, the Labor Department's definitions of employment and unemployment worked much better. Then, layoffs occurred en masse among blue-collar workers in manufacturing whose union affiliations, benefits and wages of more than $12 an hour gave them a strong attachment to the work force. During the 1981-82 recession, 2.3 million such jobs disappeared, and the people who held them joined the ranks of the unemployed as they sought work to replace their middle-class wages -- or waited to be recalled.
The current recession also features blue-collar job losses: 824,000 in the first 16 months. But whereas a decade ago job losses among white-collar workers in retailing, insurance, banking and real estate were virtually nil, 570,000 such jobs have disappeared in the first 16 months of this recession.
These are the white-collar equivalent of factory workers -- sales clerks, computer operators, restaurant workers, office personnel. They are more likely than factory workers to slide from full-time to part-time work, or to leave the labor force altogether, and therefore not be counted as unemployed.
 
$7.12 an Hour for Clerks
 "If you are a sales clerk earning $7.12 an hour, which is the average in the retail industry today, you are not as attached to the labor force as an auto worker or a steelworker who is still earning more than $15 an hour on average," Mr. Plewes said. "With less at stake, you are more likely to drop out and stay home. Or avoid layoff by agreeing to work fewer hours, a common practice in retailing."
The downgrading phenomenon has spread beyond retailing, to factory workers who have given up hope of re-entering factories and now retrain for office jobs; to executives who have become self-employed consultants with sporadic incomes, and to commercial pilots who become painting contractors or open other small businesses.
Other trends also distort the employment data. A rising number of people have dropped out of the labor force who in another age would have described themselves as unemployed and job-hunting. Some are among the Labor Department's 1.2 million discouraged workers, a growing contingent of people who in many cases have been laid off and have stopped job-hunting on the ground that a suitable job is not available.
Others are women. For the first time since the 1960's, the flow of women into the job market has stopped rising and has begun to fall. Still others are men and women 16 to 20 years old, who in the past would have hunted actively for a job and listed themselves as unemployed until they found one, but now stay quietly at home or extend their schooling. In addition, there are men over 55, whose participation in the labor force has been falling for years.
 
Variety of Reasons
 The question in all of these cases is why these people have dropped out, lowering the potential unemployment rate.
Katherine Newman, a Columbia University anthropologist, points to the rising incidence of women who leave the labor force to rear children. Improved pension benefits have lured many men in their late 50's into a welcome retirement. And college enrollment is at record levels among young people who see long-term earning power tied to education.
But negative forces also play a role. Rather than commute long distances to another factory, some "discouraged" blue-collar workers stay home or live on their spouses' pay.
Buyouts and severance pay have pushed some men into retirement prematurely, idling them against their wishes, often with adequate incomes. Women have been heavily represented in retailing, banking, real estate, computers and other service jobs hit with layoffs in the last two years.
"There is a group among them who said, 'I am just going to cool it, outside the labor force, until things get better,' " said Mr. Plewes of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

HEADLINE: Maxwell Official Sees Hope for U.S. Holdings

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
David H. Shaffer, chairman of the publishing company Macmillan Inc. and managing director of its parent, Maxwell Communication, said in an interview yesterday that he had strong hopes that Maxwell's American-based assets would remain intact, despite the turmoil in the publishing empire of the late Robert Maxwell.
The Maxwell board, which filed for bankrutpcy court protection in the United States hoping to avoid a liquidiation of its main American-bassed assets -- Macmillan and the Official Airlines Guide -- saw most of its power transferred last week to a British-appointed administrator and an American examiner. 
 While the British system leads readily to liquidation in bankruptcy cases, the American system is more prone to reorganization; in this case, representatives of the two countries will negotiate the outcome. Thus, despite Mr. Shaffer's enthusiasm, the companies' fate is by no means clear.
 
Negotiating a Plan
 The administrator, Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, must hammer out a reorganization plan with the consent of Mr. Shaffer and the examiner, Richard Gitlin, for submission to the bankruptcy court.
The team has 120 days from Dec. 16 to prepare a plan to present to creditors, which are a group of international banks that are owed about $2.4 billion. The plan will then be subject to their approval within 60 days, although a compromise is possible, as are deadline extensions.
One bankrutpcy expert not involved in the case said a plan could provide for some assets to be sold, with the creditors becoming owners of those that remain.
Yesterday, however, Mr. Shaffer listed a variety of reasons that he expected the company might be held together.
"The economy is going in the wrong direction," he said. With the values of media properties at a low, a fire sale of such properites would diminish the sale price, he said.
Also, "the structure has a low tax basis," he said, "so 35 percent of any gain would go to the Government."
 
Contribution to Income
 The American operations of Maxwell accounted for about 75 percent of its operating income of 200 million last year. During the 1991 fiscal year, when Mr. Maxwell was still alive, assets that accounted for about a third of the United States income of 150 million were sold, leaving the company with American businesses that generated 100 million, according to executives with knowledge of the company's finances.
Mr. Shaffer said Macmillan expected a decline this year, partly as a result of the soft advertising environment but also because of problems created by a breach of credibility with buyers of Maxwell products. He would not say just how great the drop was expected to be, but said it would come from the company's information businesses, rather than the publishing businesses.
Mr. Shaffer said that basically the company was in good shape and that Mr. Maxwell had not kept Macmillan from making necessary capital investments. He added that there were no plans for layoffs because the company was already relatively lean.

HEADLINE: Message to Albany: Baa1-Humbug

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
It is a symptom of the times that New York State's credit rating has become not only a financial benchmark but a significant political one as well.
In the last two years, the state's credit rating has twice been downgraded because of the inability of its leaders to balance the budget. In both cases, Wall Street rating agencies have made it clear that the dismal grades were given primarily for the state's political failure, not the sluggishness of its economy. 
 That was certainly so on Monday when Moody's Investors Service lowered the rating on the state's appropriation-backed debt from A to Baa1, the second-lowest rating of any state. In a three-page statement, Moody's dedicated only a fraction of a sentence to what it called "protracted weakness in the economy."
The rest of the statement focused on the state's failure to close its $875 million budget gap, the anticipated growth of the state's accumulated deficit, and the inability to restructure budget priorities in any fundamental way. All, it suggested, were failures of political will.
 
Partisan Blame Avoided
 What the rating agency avoided, both in its statement and in interviews, was the apportionment of blame to either the Republicans who control the State Senate or the Democrats who control the Assembly and sit in the governor's office.
"There's plenty of culpability," said George W. Leung, the vice president and managing director for state debt ratings at Moody's. "The issue of paralysis is what we're concerned about."
But what the state's politicians seem most concerned about, particularly in an election year, is how to shift the onus for the downgrading to the opposition. Indeed, some political leaders -- including the state Democratic chairman, John A. Marino, and the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., a Norwich Republican -- have suggested that the other party deliberately instigated the downgrading in order to use it later as a political club.
On the eve of his State of the State address, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo reiterated in a news conference today the argument he had made in the weeks leading to the downgrading.
 
Welfare Stereotype
 The Senate Republicans, he said, had deliberately refused to reach a budget compromise because they believe that their unbending insistence on deep cuts in welfare and Medicaid programs will help them in the November election.
Mr. Cuomo said that in demanding cuts in welfare grants and limits on Medicaid benefits for some welfare recipients, the Republicans were playing on the stereotype of welfare as a benefit to "a big minority swigging a can of beer who could work and says: 'No, I don't want to. I want to spend your money.' "
"I don't see any justification for that except you can sell it to people," Mr. Cuomo said. "You can con them."
The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, who is no relation to John A. Marino, responded that the Moody's statement made it clear that the raters were looking for structural reforms in the state budget, meaning cuts in social services that the Democrats are unwilling to make.
 
'Structural' vs. 'Silly'
 "They now openly taunt the raters by continuing to insist on a deficit plan that contains no structural reforms," Mr. Marino said in a statement.
Vincent Tese, the state's economic development commissioner, said that Mr. Marino's argument was "silly."
"The market and the raters know there are philosophical differences between the way Democrats view things and the way Republicans view things," he said. "But they expect you to be able to bridge that for the good of the state. What they want to see is a balanced budget."
Whoever is right, the cost of the downgrading to the state is undeniable. Although Mr. Cuomo said his budget analysts had not determined how much the downgrading would cost in extra interest on future bond sales, bond traders reported an immediate impact today on the state's appropriation-backed debt.
Several Wall Street traders said the yields on such bonds had risen today anywhere from 8 to 20 basis points, meaning that sellers suffered from declining bond prices. Duncan K. Smith, the senior managing director of Lebenthal & Company, said, however, that the full impact of the downgrading would not be known until the state sells a new bond issue.
Moody's intended its downgrading to spur the state into action, warning that the rating on the state's general obligation bonds would be threatened by a continued impasse. That downgrading would send an even more severe signal to the credit markets.
Instead, the paralysis deplored by Mr. Leung only seemed to deepen. Mr. Cuomo said today that he had finally given up hope of negotiating a multiyear financial plan aimed at closing both the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and the $4 billion gap projected for the fiscal year beginning on April 1.
The Senate Republicans said they continued to hold out hope for such a plan, even though Moody's said in its statement that "references to a 15-month plan are no longer realistic."
Mr. Cuomo also seemed to hold out little optimism for patching together a more traditional deficit reduction plan that would close this year's gap through spending cuts and other emergency measures. He said the state could eliminate about $400 million of this year's $875 million gap through spending freezes and other administrative actions, but that it would have to borrow to close the rest of the gap.
That would mark the fourth consecutive year that the state has had to borrow significantly to close an end-of-the-year deficit, a record that the credit raters have criticized loudly.

(David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hartmarx Will Merge 2 Retail Units

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
The Hartmarx Corporation announced yesterday that it would merge the operations of two of its retail divisions in yet another effort to curb costs as the recession continues to chip away at its sales.
The manufacturer and retailer, based in Chicago, said it would combine its Hartmarx Specialty Stores Inc., the troubled parent of Wallach's, Baskin, Field Brothers and 26 others, with its Kuppenheimer Men's Clothiers, a discount chain. 
 The consolidation, Hartmarx said, would help it reduce expenses and costs by eliminating redundant functions. In addition, without doing away with the specialty stores, the combination places greater emphasis on a business that has greater appeal in hard times.
 
Layoffs Are Expected
 Harvey A. Weinberg, chairman and chief executive of Hartmarx, said a number of employees in Chicago and Dallas, where most of the operations for the specialty stores are based, would be laid off when the company merges the accounting, data processing and distibution operations of the two divisions, but that the total had not yet been determined.
The accounting and data processing operations will be based in Atlanta, where Kuppenheimer has its headquarters, and distribution for Kuppenheimer's merchandise will move to the company's distribution center in Columbus, Ohio.
"I started Dallas," Mr. Weinberg said in an interview. "I remember walking around in the mud when they were building the Dallas offices. This is very hard for all of us."
He said merchandising and marketing for the new combined unit, to be called the Hartmarx Retail Group, would remain distinct. Many of the company's specialty stores stock stylish tailored clothing, with an average price of about $500 for a man's suit, while Kuppenheimer's 162 stores sell private-label men's clothing for significantly less. Hartmarx makes most of the clothing sold in its stores, though more than 75 percent of that apparel is sold through other outlets.
 
Staying in Specialty Business
 Mr. Weinberg said the internal merger was not intended as a signal that Hartmarx intended to abandon the specialty store business. As a way of cutting costs, it has been closing about 100 unprofitable stores over the last two years, and a few analysts have suggested that it do away with the specialty stores business altogether.
"As a provider of real value, Kuppenheimer is at the moment a very important channel for us, a good growth channel," Mr. Weinberg said. "The specialty stores have been hurt by the recession and by the recession in men's clothing."
Josie Esquivel, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said the consolidation would give the company "enormous" cost savings but was not a significant enough restructuring of the stores division.
"They've got to revitalize the stores, revitalize the assortment of merchandise," she said. "They've got to do something drastic -- Pow! -- because they've taken too long turning this thing around."
Ms. Esquivel said she was in the process of lowering her fourth-quarter earnings estimate, currently at a loss of 15 cents a share. She expects the company's earnings for its fiscal year ended Nov. 30, which should be announced sometime in February, to be down by at least $1.22 a share.
David R. McMahon, who was president and chief executive of Kuppenheimer, was named president of the new Hartmarx Retail Group. The company said John Eyler, chairman and chief executive of the specialty stores division, had resigned. Mr. Eyler could not be reached for comment yesterday.
"John made a great contribution to this company, but we really just needed one C.E.O., and we needed someone with an operational bent," Mr. Weinberg said.
Mr. McMahon, 54, gained praise for resuscitating and repositioning Kuppenheimer after Hartmarx bought it in 1983. Although its sales have declined, they have not dropped as markedly as sales in its specialty stores, which have eroded as the tailored men's wear business has dwindled.
When Hartmarx acquired Kuppenheimer it was a "pipe rack" men's apparel store, selling odd lots and manufacturers' overruns at bargain-basement prices. Hartmarx upgraded the product mix with clothes made in its factories and gave the sparsely fixtured stores some ambience. And when Sears, Roebuck & Company eliminated its tailored men's wear business about two years ago, Hartmarx persuaded it to open Kuppenheimer boutiques in its stores.
Mr. Weinberg said Hartmarx's retail stores had generally had a tough time in the holiday sales season, mostly because there were fewer selling days between Thanksgiving and Christmas. He said the company's Country Miss division, which sells women's apparel, was up slightly, but the specialty stores, Hartmarx's albatross in the current recession, were "down substantially." The company told analysts that sales in December plunged 16 percent at its specialty stores open at least a year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Zale, Under Pressure, Revamps Management

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Zale Corporation, a Dallas-based jewelry retailer whose creditors are seeking to force it into bankruptcy, has announced a new management arrangement aimed at making the troubled chain more responsive to its customers.
Irving R. Gerstein, the company's chairman, also said yesterday that Zale was meeting with its banks and bondholders "to discuss the company's business plans." Several large bondholders have already sought to force the company into bankruptcy court, but Zale has not yet indicated if it will seek to resist that process in court. 
 The new management structure calls for less centralized oversight and returns more autonomy to each of the company's four divisions, according to Dean Kehler of Argosy Group in New York, a small investment banking firm that is advising the company on its restructuring. "The arguments for doing this are that the division managers are closer to their customers," Mr. Kehler said. "That is especially important in a situation like this, where the target audiences are very different and the division identities need to be more distinct."
In addition to stores operated under the Zale name and catering to mid-market consumers, the parent company also operates the upscale Bailey, Banks & Biddle and Corrigans stores, through its Guild division, and the more modestly priced Gordon's chain.
Until now, the operation of those divisions has been largely centralized at the corporate level -- an arrangement that may have blurred the distinctions and hurt Zale's overall marketing effort, according to Randolph Lively, a senior vice president with the company and the new designated manager for the Guild division.
Under the new structure, the Zale division will be overseen by Joseph Keifer, who joined Zale in 1971 and was most recently in charge of store operations at the central staff level. Ed Jaben, who began his career at Gordon's and joined Zale when it acquired Gordon's in 1989, will return to familiar territory as general manager of that division. And Max Brown will continue to oversee Diamond Park Fine Jewelry, which operates leased space in department stores.
The jewelry chain, hurt by the recession and dismal Christmas sales, has already announced that it will close 400 of its 2,000 stores and lay off some 2,500 employees, or about 20 percent of its work force. It has also halted payments on its publicly traded bonds, part of its $850 million debt burden, and stopped paying suppliers and other creditors.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds and C.D.'s Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit continued to decline sharply in the week ended yesterday, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication that watches interest rates.
The lowering of interest rates by the Federal Reserve to help spur the economy has hurt consumers who rely on income from savings accounts and other relatively safe investments. Banks are much slower to reduce interest they charge on loans and much faster in cutting the interest they offer depositors.
 
'Grim Picture'
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday: "Unfortunately for the consumer, although bank yields are dropping like rocks, borrowing rates still remain stubbornly high. For example, the prime rate has come down two percentage points in the past four months, from 8.50 percent to 6.50 percent, and average certificate of deposit yields have fallen by more than one percentage point, to the 3 percent to 4 percent range. But personal loan rates have declined by only one-half of 1 percent. 
 "This grim picture," he added, "is not helping consumers to spend their way out of the recession as has been hoped."
In the last week, New York commercial banks reduced yields on money market accounts by an average 6 basis points, to 3.71 percent, while cutting the three-month certificate by 3 basis points, to 3.61 percent, and a six-month certificate by 2 basis points, to 3.69 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Among the savings institutions, the reductions tended to be sharper, with money market accounts down 10 basis points, to 4.44 percent; a three-month certificate off 12 basis points, to 4.29 percent, and a six-month certificate down 14 basis points, to 4.44 percent.
For money market accounts, the steepest cut among area institutions was by Marine Midland, which lowered its rate by 56 basis points. First Nationwide dropped the yield on three-month certicates by 25 points, and it and Howard Savings Bank cut 25 points from their six-month certificate rates.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area also showed significant declines in savings products, with the average yield on a money market account and six-month certificate of deposit both down 13 basis points, to 3.88 percent and 3.98 percent, respectively.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the average rate at auction was 3.85 percent and 3.86 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Junk-Bond and Mark Funds Excel

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Last year was a strong one for bond funds, particularly for those invested in high-yield junk bonds. In the fourth quarter, however, the best-performing funds were those that invested in the Deutsche mark and in long-term domestic securities.
Figures compiled by Lipper Analytical Services showed that the year's top-performing bond funds had annual returns exceeding 60 percent. The best-performing fund was the Dean Witter High Yield Fund, with a 67.21 percent return, followed by the Liberty High Income Bond Fund, which returned 60.5 percent. 
 "Some of the high-yield funds actually did better than the average equity fund," said A. Michael Lipper, president of the rating firm.
Mr. Lipper said that high-yield funds benefited from lower interest rates, which allowed many issuers to refinance their balance sheets, and from the scarcity of new issues of junk debt, limiting the available supply and raising the prices of some bonds.
In the fourth quarter, a falling dollar and a rising mark pushed up returns on funds that were fully invested in the German currency. The top performer in the quarter was the Fidelity D-Mark Performance Portfolio, which had a quarterly return of 11.6 percent. It was followed by the Shearson Currency: D-Mark fund. Both of these are unmanaged funds based on indexes of German Treasury securities that acted as a surrogate for the Deutsche mark itself.
During the fourth quarter, the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, raised interest rates when those in the United States were falling. That caused the dollar to fall relative to the Deutsche mark, pushing up the value of German currency funds.
But Deutsche mark funds were not the only ones to benefit from a falling dollar. Of the quarter's top 25 performers, 18 were world income funds, which were invested in single foreign currencies or baskets of foreign currencies.
On average, general taxable bond funds rose by 18.7 percent for the year and 4.84 percent for the quarter. Among tax-exempt securities, general municipal bond funds rose by 11.9 percent for the year and 3.36 percent for the quarter. By comparison, general equity funds, which invested in a broad range of stocks, rose by 35.57 percent for the year and 8.31 percent for the quarter.
In the fourth quarter, sharply falling American interest rates resulted in sharply rising bond prices, particularly benefiting funds that invested in long-term securities, which have greater price fluctations than securities with shorter maturities.
Over all, Mr. Lipper said, investors during the quarter earned more of their returns from changes in bond prices than from interest rate yields. Typically, the opposite is the case, with most of the returns in bond funds generally coming from coupon yields.
With prices of long-term bonds rising the most, target maturity funds, which invest in securities that mature far into the future, were strong performers. These funds as a group rose by 17.67 percent in the year and 6.65 percent in the quarter, rising in December alone, on average, by 7.33 percent.
Of the groups of bond funds, long-term funds were the second-best performers after high-yield funds and slightly outperformed world income funds.
In the municipal securities market, the most notable trend was a narrowing of the yield spread between tax-exempt securities and Treasuries. This trend began early in the year and continued as interest rates fell. On an after-tax basis, however, funds investing in tax-exempt securities, on average, still returned slightly more than those investing in Treasuries.
Mr. Lipper attributed the improved performance of municipal bonds to a general belief among investors that taxes will increase, particularly on the state level. Also, he said, there was an increased demand for these securities from investors whose certificates of deposits were maturing and who were unwilling to reinvest in certificates at their current low rates.
Mark Durbiano, portfolio manager of the Pittsburgh-based Liberty High Income Bond Fund, attributed the performance of his $170 million fund, which came in second among all funds for the year, to being "in the right asset at the right time."
He said he doubted that he could duplicate the 60.5 percent his fund returned in 1991, but that he believed there was "still money to be made" in junk securities. He expects that in 1992, investors disatisfied with low coupon rates will begin to put more money into high-yield funds.
In fact, Mr. Durbiano continued, in the last three to four years, he has seen the high-yield bond market begin to trade more like the equity market, with prices rising and falling because of factors other than simply interest rates.
Judy Pagliuca, manager of the Fidelity D-Mark Performance Portfolio, the top performer for the quarter with an 11.6 percent return, said that the $22 million fund's strong performance reflected the "wide interest rate difference between the U.S. and Germany, particularly in December."
Ms. Pagliuca said that the market would probably continue to focus on this difference unless there were indications that the German economy was beginning to fall or that the American economy had bottomed out, which would mean that domestic rates should begin to rise again. If either happens, Ms. Pagliuca said, she would advise clients to move out of her fund.

LENGTH: 448 words

HEADLINE: Ratings Are Cut on $100 Billion of G.M. and Chrysler Debt

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Just a day after Detroit's auto makers reported their worst sales year since 1983, Wall Street debt-rating agencies downgraded nearly $100 billion of General Motors and Chrysler debt.
Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it had cut the rating on $75 billion of borrowings by the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest car maker, from A1, its fourth-highest rating, to A2, its fifth-highest. 
 The Standard & Poor's Corporation cut ratings on $20 billion of Chrysler Corporation debt, moving the nation's No. 3 auto maker even deeper into junk-bond territory. It is the only Big Three auto maker with bonds rated below investment grade.
The auto makers reported on Monday that total sales of cars and trucks fell 11.2 percent last year, to about 12.3 million units. General Motors, Chrysler and the Ford Motor Company are expected to post more than $6 billion in operating losses for 1991.
The ratings agencies essentially said that investing in the auto makers was now more risky than in the past because of the effects of the severe slump on the companies' finances.
The move, serving as a gentle warning to investors, could raise borrowing costs for the auto makers.
G.M.'s stock dropped 50 cents a share, to $33, on the New York Stock Exchange; Chrysler closed at $13.125, also off 50 cents.
Chrysler said it was "extremely disappointed" by the downgrading. G.M. officials were not immediately available for comment.
But Chrysler's president, Robert Lutz, said the move would have no effect on the auto maker's operations or financial standing. "It's a relatively minor change that's of no financial or operational significance," Mr. Lutz told reporters at the Detroit Auto Show. "Going from BB-minus to B-plus doesn't mean we're crossing a horrible threshold."
The action provides little solace to the Big Three, whose top executives are currently visiting Japan with President Bush to push for measures to open the Japanese market.
The ratings agencies painted a bleak picture for Detroit, even as the auto makers lay off thousands of workers, close plants and struggle to reshape their business in the face of a competitive onslaught.
Moody's said its downgrade of G.M. was based on its "belief that G.M.'s long-term competitive position may continue to weaken." The ratings agency also said it expected the recession in the North American auto industry to be deeper and more protracted than previously thought.
Standard & Poor's said, "More difficult than anticipated automotive market conditions or lack of success with new products could cause further erosion in credit quality at Chrysler and Chrysler Financial within the next two years."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of MBIA Adds Duties of Chief

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
MBIA Inc., the leading insurer of municipal securities, said yesterday that its president, David H. Elliott, had been named the chief executive. Mr. Elliott, who is 50 years old, will remain as president. He is also president of the MBIA Corporation, the operating subsidiary.
He succeeds William O. Bailey, 65, who has served as chairman and chief executive since MBIA was formed in 1986 and who will continue as chairman. 
 The deterioration in the financial condition of state and local governments across the country has been a boon for MBIA and other insurers of tax-exempt municipal bonds, and Mr. Elliott and Wall Street analysts said they expect the trend to continue.
"Several things are going on," Mr. Elliott said in a telephone interview from MBIA's headquarters in Armonk, N.Y.
"First, the municipal bond market is growing," Mr. Elliott said. "New-issue volume was up 26 percent last year, and with the gigantic infrastructure needs facing the country, that is likely to continue."
In addition, since the 1986 tax act the municipal bond market has become dominated by individual investors, Mr. Elliott noted, "and it is individuals who demand the protection offered by insurance."
"We guarantee principal and interest payments," he said. "For a small sacrifice in yield, it is a good bargain."
Typically, yields on AAA-rated insured municipal bonds are about 15 to 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, lower than on uninsured municipal securities, Mr. Elliott said.
The risks to the company's bright outlook are minimal, analysts said.
"The big downside risk is that if the economy does not recover and we go into a prolonged recessionary period, there might be some municipal defaults," said Michael A. Smith, a first vice president at Lehman Brothers.
"But MBIA has built-in strengths to counteract that. We recommend the stock to investors and are looking for earnings growth of 12 percent to 15 percent over the next few years," Mr. Smith said.
A graduate of Yale and the Boston University Law School, Mr. Elliott began his career in the insurance industry in 1969 with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, where he held a number of different posts in a 17-year stint.
When he left Aetna to join MBIA, Mr. Elliott was vice president of the financial guarantee department, a post he had held since 1983.
Mr. Elliott, who is married with three children, lives in South Salem, N.Y.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Lower, But Is Mixed Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower against most leading currencies yesterday, but its performance against the Japanese yen was split ahead of today's meeting between President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.40 yen to close at 123 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 124.35 yen. But in New York, the dollar settled at 123.95 yen, up from 123.40 yen on Monday. 
 Gold prices were narrowly mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $349.50 an ounce, up 20 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained 10 cents an ounce to a late bid price of $349.40. Gold rose more strongly in London to a late bid price of $349.70 an ounce, from $348.50 late Monday, but in Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $349.40, from $349.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.41 to close at a bid of $350.81.
The dollar declined in overseas trading, then seesawed when activity shifted to domestic markets. But a late flurry of selling pushed the dollar lower against all leading currencies except the yen.
"People are concerned that the U.S. is seeking a lower dollar to help boost exports" and make foreign goods more expensive to American consumers, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, an advisory firm.
A lower dollar makes United States products cheaper for foreigners and foreign goods more expensive for Americans.
Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said traders were concerned that Mr. Bush and his entourage of American business executives might try to "turn up the heat on Japan" to depress the dollar.
"It's time to sit back and wait a bit on the yen until after the meetings" between the leaders, Mr. Donney said.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8720, from $1.8785 late Monday, but in New York it rose to $1.8855, from $1.8830 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Monday rates, included: 1.5070 German marks, down from 1.5158; 1.3390 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435; 5.1435 French francs, down from 5.1730; 1,139.00 Italian lire, down from 1,144.00, and 1.1427 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1426.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Condo Auctions: Who Really Wins

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SEARCHING for that ultimate bargain in the depressed market for condos? Chances are you may have been tempted by the auction extravaganzas, in which dozens of apartments in half-empty developments are offered to the highest bidders.
But the temptation, suggest Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton and David Genesove of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is probably worth resisting. For the only real winners seem to be buyers who wait until the auction is completed, and then scavenge the remains. 
 In a paper presented last week at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association in New Orleans, the two economists analyzed the results of the auction of 83 units in a New Jersey apartment complex. They were looking for -- and found -- evidence of what economic theorists call a price anomaly. Buyers early in the auction paid considerably more for equivalent apartments than those who waited until late in the day.
But to their surprise, they discovered that the auction also failed to define a true market price: The best deals by far were made in private negotiations after the auction was over.
Auctions interest economists because they can provide insights into the nuts-and-bolts workings of larger, more anonymous markets for everything from currencies to common stocks. Professor Ashenfelter, a wine buff who writes a newsletter on the economics of the wine market, has been struck by seemingly irrational behavior of bidders at wine auctions. When identical cases of wine are sold in a single auction, he noted, the ones sold first generally fetched higher prices.
Wine auctioneers are apparently aware of the phenomenon, he says, and generally take care to package wines in lots that are not precisely identical. Otherwise, bidders would catch on and avoid the early lots, driving down the total proceeds from the auction.
Professor Ashenfelter wondered whether this price anomaly was at work in the market for housing. He and Professor Genesove used a condo auction that took place in April 1990 in Princeton to find out.
Prices in the early sales were indeed higher: On average, the winning bid on units from the same line fell by about a quarter of a percent in each sequential sale. But the way this (and most other) condo auctions are structured forced the economists to look further to see whether the decline was really the result of a price anomaly.
Under the auction rules, all the units in a specific line were put up for bids together. The first winner got his pick of any of 30 apartments; the next winner chose among the remaining 29, and so forth. Thus the observed decline in winning bids might also be due to quality differences -- some, for example, were on higher floors while some had better views.
So the economists assigned an assistant to check local records for resales of apartments that had been purchased at the auction as investments. These secondary sales, they figured, would provide a statistical benchmark for separating price differences associated with quality differences from any anomaly caused solely by the order of the auction sale.
This task proved easier than expected. It seems that 37 percent of the auction sales fell through -- buyers got cold feet, or could not come up with the financing. And these apartments were all quickly resold by the developer at negotiated prices.
Matching first and second selling prices, the two economists found that no more than a quarter of the price decline observed during the auction was related to lesser quality; when it was sold during the auction remained important.
Thus the bizarre and not easily explained price anomaly effect holds for $100,000 condos as much as it does for $30 vintage Bordeaux. What really flummoxed Professor Ashenfelter, though, was the dramatic decline in condo prices after the auction was finished.
The intuitive appeal of a condo auction (apart from the irrational hope of getting something for nothing) is that the open bidding will provide a realistic sense of what the real estate is worth in the market. But this auction -- and, Professor Ashenfelter suspects, most condo auctions -- did anything but: By waiting a few days, buyers could have had the same units for an average of 13 percent less.
The economists conclude that condo auctions may be suckers' bait. But they do offer a fail-safe way to even the odds, a strategy that takes advantage of the fact that most states give buyers of real estate a grace period in which to back out. "The optimal strategy for a bidder," they write, "would have been to tie up a condominium with a high bid, and then renege on its sale and renegotiate a lower price."
The alternative, of course, is to buy the old-fashioned way -- through face-to-face negotiation.
