HEADLINE: Helping to Mate 2 Arts That Seemed as One

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
John Duffy has two favorite stories. Each has a great deal to say about Meet the Composer, which Mr. Duffy helped found in 1974 and which he now directs, and the Composer-Choreographer Collaboration Project, one of the organization's most popular programs.
The first story is about a little boy who stood up at a session in which a composer discussed his work with schoolchildren. When had the composer been born? the child asked. "And when did he die?" The second anecdote comes from a newspaper interview in which the composer Aaron Copland was asked why he never created dance music after "Appalachian Spring," the score for Martha Graham's work of the same name. No one had asked him, the composer answered. "That was kind of a jolt," Mr. Duffy said. 
 One of Meet the Composer's most important missions is to convince the general population that composers are not creatures from another world who necessarily lived and died a century or so ago. Another aim is to help living American composers find outlets for their music. Coincidentally, a third, to help composers and choreographers find each other and work together through the collaboration project, does both.
The success stories Mr. Duffy cites include recent collaborations between Eiko and Koma and the composer Robert Mirabal, Susan Marshall and Pauline Oliveiros, David Gordon and Philip Glass, and Peter Martins and Charles Wuorinen.
 
Search for Quality
 "This program grew out of my sense that the quality of music for dance had become very paltry," Mr. Duffy, a composer who has created scores for dance and theater, said the other day. "When I thought back to the fact that we live in a century when great orchestral collaborations came from works for dance. Works by Stravinsky, Shostakovich radiated in the dance world, then were transferred to the concert stage. And suddenly we were just getting drum machines."
The three-year-old project offers grants, generally $15,000 to $50,000, to be shared equally by choreographer and composer. "We had to fight for that," Mr. Duffy recalled. A representative of one major source of money for dance balked at that. "He felt there might be an economic eruption. We were warned that choreographers didn't make as much as composers, and that dancers did it for love. The fact is that dancers and choreographers have in a sense accepted that. But of course it turned out that choreographers loved to get paid.
"One of the things about Meet the Composers is that we wanted to focus just on fees and income and leave the esthetics to the individual. Even some of the most eminent choreographers who've gotten grants through our program are quite amazed to get a check for $25,000 when they're used to doing something for $3,000. They've been subsidizing their work for a long time."
The organization, which has a $3.3 million budget and is supported by the government, foundations and private sources, gets about 80 to 90 applications a year for the project. It commissions about 20 works, the number depending on the scope of the collaborations, which are selected by a panel of staff members, choreographers, composers and producers after scrutiny of videotapes and audiotapes submitted by the applicants.
"The application comes from the dance company," Mr. Duffy said. "We don't match composers and choreographers. People generally know the composer they want. And as long as they are professionals, we make no judgments. The criteria are first of all inventiveness, and professionalism. And the composers and choreographers have to be equal partners, the composers creating work that is as strong and filled with imagination and consummate craft as the choreographers'."
Money goes to ballet, modern dance, ethnic, jazz and tap projects, to be created by choreographers whom Mr. Duffy describes as "well-known, in mid-career or just starting out." Choreographers and companies who need information about contemporary music are eligible for small "pre-commissioning awards" to explore the field.
Meet the Composer is also a clearing house for information on choreographers and composers. "Choreographers call us for advice," Mr. Duffy said. "I tell them: 'Here is where you can hear music, pick up records, go to a music festival. The best thing is to listen to the music and get in touch with a composer who moves you.' There are many realms to music."
Plans are being studied for establishing library centers throughout the country, possibly run by the eight national affiliates. The libraries would make tapes and background information available to those seeking collaborators.
Through the project, Mr. Duffy said, composers get new audiences for their music, as well as income. The scorn traditionally expressed by musicians toward music created for dance has become pretty much a thing of the past, Mr. Duffy said. "And the other thing about dance," he said, "is that you get to know people like choreographers and lighting designers and you get excited. You carry that back to your studio and you're fired by it."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Loss of a Job Summons The Specter of Poverty

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Tonight Bill Moyers focuses on people who do not have the luxury of seeing the big picture when it comes to global economics. For these workers in Milwaukee, the flight of factories to other countries has meant unemployment or jobs that do not pay enough to support a family. "Minimum Wages," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, captures anxieties that are spreading across America.
This sober report notes that although 85,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost in Milwaukee in the last few years, the city's unemployment rate remains relatively low. But the sorts of jobs available do not pay enough to keep up installments on the house or the car or to plan ahead. Since many of them do not offer health benefits, a serious illness can be devastating. 
 "Minimum wage will not pay the bills," says a 38-year-old industrial worker who lost his job two years ago when Briggs & Stratton, Milwaukee's biggest employer, moved a factory to Mexico, where workers make in a day what American workers make in an hour. Steve was reduced to being a security guard, at $4.50 an hour and no benefits.
The other stories are cast from the same die. After a year of unemployment, Tony and Terry, parents of three young children, are in danger of losing their house. Mr. Moyers observes that they represent the "first generation of Americans expected to do worse than their parents." The camera catches the emotional as well as the financial strains as unemployment stretches on.
All these people are struggling against going on welfare. "I could not stand on that line," says one man. "I said this is not me; this is not me." Terry is embarrassed about having to accept donated food. But what a company executive interviewed here calls "the realities of the marketplace" are forcing many onto the dole. Even workers who have managed to get into a retraining course at a local technical school face a shrinking job market with shrinking wages.
As usual, black workers have been the hardest hit, but the interviews make plain that white-collar workers are being battered along with those they once supervised. A middle manager who has been out of work for eight months, although he is ready to accept a fraction of his former salary, remarks wryly, "The only thing I could recommend is going into top management."
Except for an unexceptionable wind-up statement or two -- "Our society requires the simple justice that rewards hard work" -- Mr. Moyers sensibly resists sermonizing this time around. The hour, filled with the clouded faces and cloudy prospects of people who want only to earn enough, as Terry says, to "get in the car, go grocery shopping and have a normal life again," speaks for itself.
Along with other television reports, "Minimum Wages" adds to the pressure on the Administration to act on a condition that it has been reluctant to acknowledge.
 
Moyers
Minimum Wages: The New Economy
 
Produced and directed by Tom Casciato; Kathleen Hughes, co-producer; Donna Marino, editor; Kelly Venardos, researcher; Judith Davidson Moyers, executive producer. At 9 tonight on Channels 13 and 49.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Bill of Rights, Stretching and Growing

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

A People's Charter
The Pursuit of Rights in America
By James MacGregor Burns
and Stewart Burns
577 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.
In a majestic chronicle that covers history, political science and the philosophy behind the social contract between citizen and government, "A People's Charter" celebrates and extends the Bill of Rights toward the dawn of the next century. It's a bold and path-breaking book that brings the first 10 Amendments down to earth and, at the same time, reaches for the moon in its idealism. 
 The authors, a father and son -- James MacGregor Burns, political scientist, historian and professor emeritus of government at Williams College, and Stewart Burns, social historian and associate editor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Papers at Stanford University -- subtitle their book "The Pursuit of Rights in America." If they had their way with American and world leaders, that brilliant Jeffersonian phrase in the Declaration -- "the pursuit of happiness" -- would come closer to reality for people everywhere.
After declaring the people's historic rights to life and liberty, Jefferson substituted the word happiness for the traditional word property. "But happiness was not for Jefferson merely some kind of pleasant sensation," the authors write. "Rather this further end of mankind was grounded solidly in people's daily lives and welfare."
This dramatically written book unearths facts to advance a liberal-rights agenda. Jefferson had advised young American friends traveling in Europe to do what he had done while serving as Minister to France: visit the homes of laborers, see what they eat, how they are clothed, if they are overworked, whether the Government or their employers take an unjust proportion of their labor, how much property they are allowed to keep for themselves, and if they are allowed to exercise personal liberty.
Building on Jefferson's interests and principles as a "philosophical radical," the authors follow a straight course to Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation and the three reconstruction amendments (ending slavery, granting the right to vote and due process of law for all citizens). They proceed to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, who created the New Deal revolution. During his third term, Roosevelt proposed an economic Bill of Rights to give "security and prosperity" to all, "regardless of station, race or creed."
President Roosevelt's "second Bill of Rights" ranged beyond anything conceived by the framers of the Declaration. Among these desired "rights" were remunerative jobs; food, clothing and recreation; a decent financial return for farmers; freedom for businessmen from unfair competition and monopolies; decent homes; adequate medical care; economic protection in case of unemployment or old age; good education.
The authors comment: "In 15 minutes Franklin Roosevelt had coupled the expansion of traditional civil liberties and protections to eight explicit social and economic freedoms. In these few minutes he had set the economic and social agenda for the Democratic Party and for American liberalism for at least the next half-century."
"A People's Charter" is outspoken in declaring that Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush are the enemies of these ideals:
"No more extensive and effective campaign against the Bill of Rights of liberal orthodoxy has been mounted in this century, save perhaps during the Red Fear, than by the Reagan initiatives of the 1980's, renewed by George Bush at the end of that decade. While many liberals by the 1980's were defensive, self-doubting, even guilt-ridden, the Reaganites were confident and aggressive. So abundant and vulnerable were their targets that they had no need to mount a single grand counteroffensive but produced a multitude of sorties on the different fronts. Only in retrospect did the sheer breadth and force of the attack become evident."
The authors make it clear that it was not simply social goals that came under assault in the 1980's; the Bill of Rights itself became a target of opportunity. "The Reaganite campaign against the First Amendment was reinforced from the grass roots, by private New Right organizations and by an amalgam of fundamentalists, right-wing evangelicals and other religious conservatives that touted itself as the 'moral majority,' " they write.
What makes "A People's Charter" distinctive is its emphasis on the centuries-old roots and meaning of the rights of women and minorities. In a chapter titled "Everybody Sing Freedom," Dr. King's words and accomplishments in raising hopes and broadening rights for blacks are traced in detail. Similarly, a chapter called "Women at the Cutting Edge" describes how the National Organization for Women and other groups initiated a wave of feminist activism and contributed to the effort for an equal rights amendment. The authors attribute the failure of the amendment to its "abstract nature and indeterminate language."
Looking ahead, the authors say that a new rights program in the United States would depend on extraordinary leadership in Washington as well as at the grass-roots level, with women leading the way. They also envision a time, they write, when there will be a global bill of rights.
Some remedies for change through collective leadership and action offered in "A People's Charter" may sound starry-eyed, but the ideas are well intentioned. The authors conclude that we will never know for sure what Jefferson had in mind when he inserted the word happiness in the Declaration, but they want the pursuit to continue in the third American century.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Honorary committees can be an eclectic lot. Take, for example, the the list for the national campaign of the National Museum of the American Indian. They include PRESIDENT BUSH, the four living former Presidents and their wives, KEVIN COSTNER, PAUL NEWMAN, ARNOLD PALMER, SARGENT SHRIVER, BARRY GOLDWATER, the writer OCTAVIO PAZ, Chancellor W. ANN REYNOLDS of the City University of New York, the Navajo Indian artist R. C. GORMAN and such Indian leaders as WILMA MANKILLER, chief of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, and LaDONNA HARRIS, president of Americans for Indian Opportunity.
"We went down a list of people in elected office, people who are active in the national Indian community and those in entertainment," said Representative BEN NIGHTHORSE CAMPBELL, Democrat of Colorado, the only American Indian in Congress. "We wanted high-profile people whose support would make it easier for us to raise money, and we chose them for their interest and sensitivity to Indian issues. My gosh, it's pretty hard to find a group with five living Presidents!" 
 The museum, now in upper Manhattan, is to have its main collection in a new Smithsonian Institution building in Washington. While the campaign will seek to raise $60 million for that building, Mr. Campbell said he was not worried about the dampening effects of the economy.
"I always believe there is money out there," he said. "It changes hands, and we simply must find out who has it."

HEADLINE: Japan's Consumers Are Proud to Buy Japanese;
Showroom Showdown

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There in our driveway sits a testament to unpatriotism. Gleaming garnet color, moon roof, leather, compact disk player. Everything about it says "made in Japan." We set out to buy another Ford. We had two last week. We really do hate the trade deficit. We really do want to buy American (and did so three years ago with the Fords after years of Volvos, Volkswagens, even some beaten up but great old Jaguars). 
 But the Ford dealer offered us less on our used Taurus than the dealer representing Japan offered. It was also simple math. We were able to buy a car stickered at about $30,000 for payments that would be equal to a $20,000 car made in the United States.
Those who control the money dictate the terms by which they lend. The Japanese figured that by lending at a lower interest rate, they would snag even patriots like ourselves, who have to make payments for four years and want a car least likely to break down. We also couldn't resist the offer of a free car, equal to our new one, lent every time we brought ours in and an 800 number that would bring us a repair van anywhere in the United States if we needed it.
Before President Bush beats up on the Japanese for their success, he should try to remember what it's like when you have to pay for your own car. When your payments are higher, they're higher, no matter what your politics. When your transportation stalls or quits, you're out in the cold.
 
JANET WEINER, MICHAEL WEINER
Tiburon, Calif., Dec. 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Japanese Visit, on the Surface: Jovial Bush, Friendly Crowds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8

 BODY:
He is about to engage the Japanese Government in a titanic struggle over his nation's economic future. But on Tuesday, opening a four-day state visit to Japan to discuss trade and security issues, President Bush was trying his utmost to build bridges, not wreck them.
He played tourist at an ancient palace. He engaged an astonished circle of middle-aged Japanese men in a slightly goofy, highly telegenic game in which a leather ball is kicked around. He waxed enthusiastic to college students about brotherhood and understanding. He undertook that most American of political tasks -- a ribbon cutting at a new store. 
 In all of this, often over a din of brass bands and lusty cheers, Mr. Bush sought to improve the unflattering image that his visit has taken on in Japan, that of a strong-arm raid on the mercantile system and even the national treasury.
"I will do my level best as President of the United States to preserve and strengthen the important relationship between Japan and my country," he said at one point. "It has a lot to do with world peace. It has a lot to do with world economic stability. It has a lot to do with two great economic and democratic countries working together, setting an example for other countries around the world."
This morning, Mr. Bush and Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, dropped in on business and government officials of both their countries and conducted a brief colloquy to underscore their mutual interest in seeing the trade talks go well.
"President Bush and I are working hard to advance our bilateral relationship, including its economic relationship," Mr. Miyazawa said "not only for the sake of our two countries, but for the world.".
The President, in his trademark stacatto, replied: "We've got to be specific; we've got to get as much as we can -- set tables, times, let's do it by then. And I think we can do it."
Because of the enormous financial influence of both nations, he said, "world leadership is at stake."
Despite these remarks, it was not clear how long Tuesday's veneer of hospitality that preceded today's serious business, or their optimistic tone, might last.
Aides to Mr. Miyazawa were reported to remain deadlocked with American officials over demands that Japanese automakers sharply increase purchases of American-made components, even beyond a commitment to buy an additional $8 billion in American-made parts by 1994.
 
Auto Magnates Weigh In
 Automobiles and related products are responsible for three-fourths of the $41 billion yearly trade deficit that Washington runs with Tokyo.
The tension over the visit was further heightened by the heads of Detroit's Big Three automakers, who stepped off Air Force One after a flight here from Osaka on Tuesday night and promptly struck a frosty tone toward their Japanese hosts.
The chairman of Ford, Harold Poling, told reporters that Japanese consumers buy so few American cars because they are too fond of luxury makes like Mercedes and BMW, not because American cars are poorly made.
Japanese bought more than 130,000 German-made automobiles in 1990, but only about 30,000 American-made ones -- and 9,500 of those were Hondas assembled in the United States.
Mr. Poling's counterpart at Chrysler, Lee A. Iacocca, was contemptuous of suggestions by some Japanese officials that problems of quality in American cars, not Japanese trade barriers, were at the root of the Big Three's poor sales in this country.
"We're not that stupid," Mr. Iacocca said. "We know our problems. They don't have to preach to us."
Mr. Iacocca, Mr. Poling and the General Motors chairman, Robert Stempel, are among 18 corporate leaders accompanying Mr. Bush on his visit.
Behind the scenes, the President's aides toiled to bury any expectations of major trade concessions from his talks with Mr. Miyazawa..
Instead, they played up the international security aspects of the visit. These include the signing of a so-called "Tokyo Declaration" that acknowledges the growing global influence of Japan and sets out ways it can work with the United States in addressing both world problems and regional crises.
Bush Administration officials said that Mr. Miyazawa's Government may also agree to foot more of the cost of American military forces in the Pacific region.
When Mr. Bush left Washington for the Pacific 10 days ago, he said that his primary purpose was to "relentlessly pursue our mission to create jobs and restore prosperity for all Americans."
On Tuesday, an Administration official took a different tack, saying, "You've got to look at this in the broader historical perspective of what just happened to the Soviet Union, and the end of the cold war."
This broader perspective did not appear to be of much concern to the touring President, who spent Tuesday playing the role of good-will ambassador and stressing his trade message, perhaps as much for the benefit of audiences back in the United States as here.
Mr. Bush may have had his domestic political opponents on both the left and right in mind when he argued that "free and open commerce is not a zero-sum game. Free trade on a level playing field creates jobs and lifts standards in both of our countries."
On arriving from South Korea early Tuesday, Mr. and Mrs. Bush visited Kyoto, Japan's ancient capital, to tour the restored Shishinden palace, once home to Japan's emperor. His guide was former Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who spent much of the day as the Bushes' unofficial host.
Outside the palace, the President saw several men in brightly colored ceremonial garb engaged in a round of kemari, a game in which players kick a deerskin ball to each other, taking care to keep it from touching the ground.
As cameras whirred, Mr. Bush leapt into the circle of astonished men, attacking the horsehair-stuffed ball with obvious relish in soccer style, giving it several bounches off his head.
Not until he was told that that was not allowed under the rules did Mr. Bush relent, and he shortly left, saying to no one in particular, "We won."
Later at a nearby hotel, Mr. Bush briefly met about 200 American and Japanese students who are looking into each other's cultures under university exchange programs.
Noting that Mr. Miyazawa once joined in a student exchange with the United States, Mr. Bush said: "I want the people of our countries to have a better understanding of one another. We need more Americans who can speak Japanese and who understand the workings of the Japanese marketplace."
Then he sped off by helicopter to nearby Kashihara, where he opened an American-owned Toys "R" Us discount store.

HEADLINE: JAPAN ANNOUNCES A HOST OF STEPS TO AID U.S. TRADE

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to demonstrate its willingness to take concrete steps to reduce its growing trade surplus with the United States, the Japanese Government late on Tuesday announced a host of incentives to make it easier for American companies to export their goods. The move came on the first day of President Bush's visit here.
Some measures had been announced earlier, while some merely expanded on existing programs. 
 But in spite of Japan's move, the difficult talks on what could amount to a new approach to managing trade between Japan and the United States appeared to bog down as negotiators worked late into the night but were unable to resolve tough American demands for increased Japanese imports.
"We are waiting to see what the Government of Japan comes forward with as a concrete, tangible set of actions," said a senior Administration official at a news briefing as the talks continued today.
 
Array of Incentives
 The Japanese package announced Tuesday night included an array of subsidized loans and voluntary targets for imports by Japanese corporations. It even included expansion of a program under which the Government offers low-cost financing to promote the export of American goods to developing countries receiving Japanese foreign aid.
Nuboru Hatakeyama, Vice Minister for International Trade and Industry, told foreign reporters at a news conference that the measures would increase Japanese imports over two years by more than $10 billion on products ranging from electronics components to automobiles.
 
More Action Is Sought
 Mr. Hatakeyama said it was not certain how much of the imports would come from the United States, and officials said it could also include products shipped by Japanese-owned factories abroad back to Japan. But officials also indicated that they expected the majority of the imports to come from American-owned companies.
The United States did not officially respond to the announcements. Officials said they were pleased that the Trade Ministry was taking the initiative but said more action was required. "An individual action plan from MITI certainly is not going to take care of the much deeper problem within the Japanese economy, which makes it very resistant to imports," said one American official.
What has struck many here is that the effect of all these measures and those still under negotiation will be a large increase in Government intervention in the market to try to help American-made goods sell here. Both sides have gone out of their way to express their conviction that markets must remain free, but the trade package emerging under heavy political pressure from President Bush's visit will amount to managed trade, many Japanese and some Americans acknowledge.
American officials have said that if successful, these discussions could mark a significant new direction. "I think this could have some long-term profound effects on the trade relationship," the Administration official said.
A key issue still being negotiated, officials on both sides indicated, is the dollar value of American autos and auto parts the Japanese will promise to acquire. Under a voluntary program, Japanese auto companies have said they will increase their purchases of American-made autos and parts to about $17 billion by 1994, from $9 billion now. The United States is said to be asking for a higher figure.
 
Easier Rules Expected
 Japan is also expected to ease some pollution-control regulations and testing standards for imported cars, to offer tax breaks for buyers of imported cars and to encourage Japanese auto companies to sell American-made cars through their extensive sales networks.
Officials on both sides have avoided referring to the import goals under discussion as targets. The Bush Administration has insisted that its only aim is to remove barriers to the free flow of goods and to halt exclusionary business practices in Japan.
"We want agreements that produce permanent improvement in access and in U.S. sales to Japanese markets and permanent improvement in the lives of Japanese consumers," President Bush said on Tuesday in western Japan, where he attended the opening of a Toys "R" Us store.
"We didn't ask them to make concessions," insisted Robert C. Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, who is one of 18 senior American executives accompanying the President. "We're not asking that they give us anything. We're just asking to compete." That, however, does not appear to be the case.
In the mid-1980's, the Reagan Administration negotiated an agreement with Japan to increase America's share of Japan's market for semiconductors to 20 percent, declaring that American manufacturers had been unfairly excluded from the market. Later, however, President Bush's trade negotiators insisted that they were opposed to setting such targets. The series of tense negotiations taking shape here this week on a range of manufactured goods appears to mark a step toward reversing course yet again.
"We are facing a dilemma," Mr. Hatakeyama said. "Theoretically speaking, this type of thing would be better not to exist. But we are experiencing a large trade imbalance with the rest of the world and we think it would be good for the Japanese Government to try everything she can."
He insisted that in Japan the Government could not dictate to private companies, since it has an open economy. He thus described the programs as "a kind of moral campaign" to persuade Japanese companies to import more. As he pointed out, some 88 Japanese corporations have complied so far.
Mr. Hatekeyama also insisted that the figures being discussed were not import "targets" but "estimates."
So far, the Trade Ministry reported, Japanese companies that account for more than 50 percent of Japan's imports and exports have said they will participate in the program to increase imports and links with foreign suppliers.
These range from agreements by Japan's big auto makers to sell American cars through their sales networks -- for instance, Toyota will sell G.M. cars -- to programs to permit more American auto-parts concerns to participate in the design of key parts and components for Japanese autos.
A series of "foreign access zones" will be opened near airports and ports to help imports. The Government will offer more low-cost loans to importers.
Tax breaks and subsidized loans will be offered to help foreign companies seeking to locate in Japan, a means of attracting more foreign direct investment into Japan from the current trickle. The Government will also establish a company to help foreign companies recruit Japanese staff. Under certain conditions foreign companies entering Japan will be offered Government loan guarantees to help them obtain needed bank loans, too.
The Japanese Government said it would also expand a program under which it offers trade financing to promote American exports to projects in developing countries underwritten by Japan. Under this program, which is being carried out in cooperation with the Export-Import Bank in the United States, the Japanese Government said it was likely to finance more than $10 billion in projects over several years, and that the greater part of the imports for these development projects would come from the United States.
That still leaves the negotiators wrestling with the politically sensitive issue of setting goals for sales of American automobiles and parts. It also does not include measures that are expected to be announced by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday.
An unusual level of secrecy has been maintained around Mr. Brady's visit, but there has been widespread speculation that he will be trying to work out financial measures to lift American exports.

HEADLINE: A National Curriculum: Seeking Fairness for All

SERIES: Lessons From Britain: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The 11-year-olds in Richard Nokes's history class are not having an easy time. They are trying to figure out how ancient Roman roads were built, and their only sources are translations of descriptions by writers of the time.
It is a sophisticated lesson in how to read primary documents, a skill expected of every child now that Britain has a required national curriculum. 
 Just last month, an advisory panel to President Bush recommended that the United States adopt voluntary national curriculum standards and national tests. As the debate begins in the United States, Britain's experience holds several revealing lessons.
 
The Debates Go On
 The British national curriculum has won wide acceptance as a way to raise standards and insure equal educational opportunity, although many teachers and scholars believe it is far too detailed and was rushed into the classroom. The curriculum exposed the need for much more extensive teacher training, particularly in math and science.
New required national tests have proved far trickier. Debates continue on whether they are fair, what form they should take, and whether they discriminate.
Britain is using the same kinds of tests that would be introduced in the United States, ones that avoid formulaic multiple-choice questions and are instead designed to test children's abilities more thoroughly. Yet teachers have criticized them as too time-consuming, and opinions remain divided on whether the tests were simply impractical or whether teachers were not given enough training or time to administer them.
In June 1988, a new education law required a national curriculum for the first time, along with identical national tests for every schoolchild at ages 7, 11 and 14. But minimum levels are not set for specific ages; the idea is to mandate what must be taught, not what must be learned in each grade. The law applies to England and Wales.
For Donald Naismith, a sometime adviser to former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and now director of education for the London borough of Wandsworth, the national curriculum is a way to enforce higher academic standards and prevent dilution of Britain's national identity. For Jane Traies, the principal of the Swakeleys School, a girls' high school in West London, the national curriculum means that her students will not be allowed to blight their futures by dropping such traditionally "male" courses as math and science.
That these educators, who consider themselves far apart ideologically, both support a national curriculum testifies to the popularity of an idea that not so long ago was heretical.
"I had a lot of anxiety about the national curriculum being a straitjacket," said Kathleen Higgins, director of education and community services for Hillingdon, a West London borough. "But we use it as an entitlement for education for all children. It's like an oyster with grit. We've managed to turn it into something wonderful."
Because Britain has long given national tests at ages 16 and 18 that help determine whether students advance to college, a de facto national curriculum existed for a relatively small, elite group. But only 20 percent of British students attend college, and in many cases poor or working-class students chose or were shunted into less demanding academic tracks.
Now all students through age 14 must study English, science and math, technology, history, geography, art, music, a modern foreign language and physical education. The Government is proposing to make art and music optional after age 14, and to require either history or geography through age 16. The Government has spent almost $1 billion developing the curriculum and tests.
The curriculum, which was drawn up by experts in specific fields but reviewed by Government officials, lists the factual knowledge and the analytical skills children should have at different ages. It breaks down each subject into "attainment targets," areas like genetics and evolution in science, and then describes levels of achievement within those, from basic to advanced.
There are no minimum levels children must achieve by certain a age, although each subject's curriculum outlines a range of levels most children will probably achieve at ages 7, 11, 14 and 16. For example, in science and math, most children would be expected to achieve level 6 or 7 by age 16. Level 10 would be achieved by the brightest college-bound students.
The law does not require specific textbooks or teaching methods. Rather than listing books, the curriculum says students should read "a range of fiction, poetry, literary nonfiction and drama, including pre-20th century literature." Students are required to read Shakespeare and other classic works (for example, the curriculum suggests, but does not require, the Bible and Jane Austen's novels).
Partly because the British curriculum leaves enough room to add whatever books teachers want, the battles over reading classics or including works by women and minorities now raging in the United States have been largely absent in Britain. But the issue of multiculturalism also seems to be less important in Britain, where, despite an increasing immigrant population, minorities do not have as much political power as in the United States.
 
Teachers Must Bear Heavy New Burdens
 For most teachers, however, the biggest problems have not been ideological, but logistical. Teachers have had to endure several dizzying years, studying the new curriculum, overhauling their lesson plans and adjusting to rapid-fire revisions.
Ian Host, head of the science department at the Small Heath High School in Birmingham, spent most of last year figuring out how to plan lessons that matched the 17 attainment targets and 10 levels of achievement in the curriculum. Meanwhile, the Government, responding to complaints that the curriculum was too unwieldy, reduced the number of attainment targets first from 17 to 5, and then to 4.
Lord Griffiths, who heads the Schools Examinations and Assessment Council, charged with overseeing the testing process, said that two-thirds of the attainment targets were still measured by teachers, not tests.
The hardest-hit teachers are in elementary schools, where many of the national curriculum subjects are being taught for the first time and teachers are especially unfamiliar with math and science requirements. Five-year-olds, for example, are supposed to be introduced to the concept of probability. David Hart, president of the National Association of Head Teachers, says teachers in "infant schools," for children from 5 to 7, are reeling. "The poor old infant teachers are so overloaded there is a danger the basics are being neglected," he said.
Indeed, introducing the curriculum has shown an urgent need for better teacher training, an issue the National Curriculum Council will examine, said its chairman, David Pascall.
Despite the frenetic pace, the neglect of teacher training, and what even Government officials agree is an unwieldy curriculum, surveys have consistently found that teachers welcomed the continuity, higher standards and sense of priorities the national curriculum brought.
"For very good schools, it is a dampener on innovation," said Margaret Maden, director of education for the county of Warwickshire, in central England. "But it has meant improvement for a lot of schools."
Testing is at the core of all the changes -- because it provides a way to check whether the high standards of the national curriculum are actually being met and a way to give parents adequate information so they can choose among schools.
But precisely because students, teachers and schools will all be judged by test results, the stakes are high and the debate contentious.
 
First Tests Create A Long Nightmare
 The first tests for 7-year-olds were just given last year. By all accounts, teachers found the experience a nightmare. They reported working an average of 58 hours a week giving the tests and struggling to figure out how to grade them. For teachers already strained by all the changes of the past few years, national tests worsened morale even further.
The tests were designed to be very different from the traditional exams familiar to generations of students, exams in which children facing a time limit wrote down answers. Instead, children were asked to guess in advance whether certain substances would sink or float, for example, or were given two magnets and asked to explain how to determine which one was stronger. They were also rated on longer-term projects, such as predicting and recording weather changes for several weeks.
 
Eye on the Workplace
 These "performance-based" tests are exactly the ones that testing experts in the United States want to see introduced as part of American national tests. They are better than traditional tests, experts argue, because they give children a fairer chance to demonstrate what they know and because they test skills needed in the workplace, such as reasoning ability.
Many British teachers, however, found the workload overwhelming, and the Government quickly issued a list of changes for this spring's round of tests. Half the tests for 7-year-olds will now be the "paper and pencil" variety, the science and math experiments were dropped, a spelling test was introduced, and teachers were given more time to conduct exams. Tim Eggar, the Government's second-ranking education official, said the initial tests for 7-year-olds were simply impractical. "There was a very commendable desire to assess as much of a child's different skills and knowledge base as possible," he said. "This inevitably resulted in a very elaborate system of testing. We've been dragging that back to reality. You've got to have a relatively simple testing system given in a reasonable time frame by an average classroom teacher dealing with an average class."
Lord Griffiths of the Schools Examinations and Assessment Council said the initial tests tried to serve too many purposes at once -- evaluating students and teachers, judging schools, communicating to parents. American tests now being drawn up also try to combine several purposes.
Yet support for the new "performance" style of tests remains strong, even among the same teachers who complained about the time such tests took to administer.
"The idea of written exams as the be-all and end-all belongs to the Victorian days of empire," said Ms. Traies. "Then they needed clerks to fill out forms in triplicate. What this country needs is people who can work cooperatively in groups."
Several educators said the tests themselves were good, but that teachers were not given enough training, time or aides to help watch the class while teachers gave the tests to small groups. Many hope not to see a return to paper-and-pencil tests because, they argue, these have tended to favor more privileged children.
"I am worried that the tests will be used to categorize and label pupils, and that the evidence on which they'll be labeled will not necessarily be reliable," said Peter Mortimore, deputy director of London University's Institute of Education, who helped draft some of the early tests. "This could be disastrous in a system which traditionally does well by the brightest and disastrously by the others."
Results from last year's tests showed that in one-third of the cases, teachers had underestimated their students' abilities -- particularly in the case of minority students. Professor Mortimore said that it was precisely because the tests were sophisticated that they were able to demonstrate the potential of so many students.
But Lord Griffiths and Mr. Eggar argued that this discrepancy showed just how much tests were needed to check teachers' assumptions. They say that the very labeling of children that critics fear the tests will bring about is already done by teachers.
Furthermore, said John Marks, who also serves on the testing council, tests can uncover problems and help children while there is still time. "You're not damaging their future by condemning them to some lower-ability rung, but saying here's some youngsters who need different treatment," he said. "If you've got a child who can't read, he can't get on. It's no good saying, 'I'm from a deprived background.' "

HEADLINE: AID PANEL STALLS ON FORMER SOVIETS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Just 15 days before the Washington Coordinating Conference on aid to the former Soviet republics is scheduled to begin, American and foreign diplomats are still trying to assemble a detailed agenda, a complete list of participants and even a consensus on what aid should be included.
Born of a last-moment insert in a speech on Dec. 12 by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the conference is seen by American officials as a way to prevent countries from duplicative efforts and insure that no region of the former Soviet Union is neglected. 
 But as diplomats arrived in Washington today to begin setting the conference's agenda, differences remained on whether broad economic and financial problems in the former Soviet republics should be included and on whether European nations would allow an American conference to guide their aid programs.
Some American officials say they hope the conference will end up guiding the billions of dollars in aid pledged by Western countries since the failed Soviet coup in August and allow the United States to seize the lead from the European Community on aid to the Soviet Union.
 
'Short Time Fuse'
 But those American officials and some European officials also say the conference might turn out to be a place for countries to do little more than exchange information on the scale of problems now facing the former Soviet republics.
"There's a lot of fluidity here," said one American official who insisted on not being identified. "There's a very short time fuse here as far as sorting out our own position."
Mr. Baker called for the conference in a speech at Princeton University after the barest consultation within the Administration and without first seeking the endorsement of American allies abroad, a State Department official said. Mr. Baker contended then that it was needed to organize a worldwide relief effort too large for any single nation to undertake.
The member countries of the European Community are still drafting their responses. They will be sending their foreign ministers to Brussels for a meeting on Friday to devise a common position on what issues should be addressed at the conference and the extent to which the coordination of European aid should be put on the table.
 
Wider Changes Urged
 Germany, Britain and Canada contend that the conference agenda, which is to be decided here on Wednesday, should at least allow discussion of issues like the Soviet Union's $63 billion foreign debt, the increasingly worthless ruble and the long-term economic recovery of Russia and 11 other former Soviet republics. A British official who insisted on not being identified said the success of humanitarian aid would depend on wider changes in the former Soviet republics.
"Our feeling is that you can't really look at all the subjects on the agenda without at least discussing the economic and financial situation," he said.
Mr. Baker mentioned in his speech on Dec. 12 the need for steps now to prevent a recurrence of shortages next winter, but the focus of American planning since then has been on short-term humanitarian relief.
The European eagerness to address other issues partly reflects concern by Western European governments and commercial banks that little of the nearly $60 billion they lent to the Soviet Union might be repaid. The United States is reluctant to help, contending that the Europeans won considerable political influence when they made the loans and knew the credit risks involved.
The United States and Japan want the two-day conference to focus exclusively on ways to provide food, shelter, medicine, fuel and advice to prevent social unrest. International task forces are being set up to review each of those five issues at the conference, and actual pledges of money and goods will not be sought.
"You sort of dilute the focus of this conference if you draw in a lot of other issues," an American official said.
Broader issues should be addressed by the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, some of whose officials will meet on Thursday in Bonn, said Hiroshi Hirabayashi, deputy chief of the Japanese Embassy in Washington.
The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund announced today that Russia and Azerbaijan had applied for full membership. The United States endorsed membership for Russia and five other former Soviet republics on Friday.

HEADLINE: U.N.'s Yugoslavia Envoy Says Rising War-Weariness Led to the Cease-Fire

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

 BODY:
Cyrus R. Vance, the special United Nations envoy for Yugoslavia, said yesterday that he believed that general war weariness was the primary factor leading to the cease-fire accord that took hold there under his supervision last Friday evening.
In an interview in New York, he said that while he was dismayed by the incident yesterday in which a Yugoslav Air Force jet shot down a helicopter, killing five European monitors, he did not think this could cause hostilities to resume between Serbs and Croats. 
 During the interview he received a call from Adm. Stane Brovet, the Yugoslav Deputy Defense Minister in Belgrade, who expressed sorrow over the incident and told Mr. Vance that the Air Force commander had been suspended and a full investigation begun.
Mr. Vance said he strongly suspected the incident was provoked by "hardliners" bent on discouraging intervention by the European Community or by the United Nations to bring an end to the still undeclared war that began last June in Yugoslavia.
 
'Growing Weariness'
 "There is growing weariness on all sides," the 74-year-old former Secretary of State said of the leaders of the warring factions in Yugoslavia. "Secondly the economy continues to deteriorate on all sides. The problem of displaced persons continues to grow. Desertions are also growing."
He was joined in the interview by his deputy, Herbert Okun, a retired Foreign Service officer who accompanied Mr. Vance on all five of his missions to Yugoslavia that began in mid-October.
"On the fourth mission I began to see light," Mr. Vance said of his shuttle diplomacy between Belgrade, the Serbian and federal capital, and Zagreb, the capital of Croatia. "You could see it and feel it when people began to talk about the feasibility of a peacekeeping plan."
Despite Mr. Vance's sense of optimism, the cease-fire agreement resulting from that trip, signed in Geneva on Nov. 23 by Presidents Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Yugoslavia's Defense Minister, Veljko Kadijevic, was broken immediately, like the 14 that preceded it. .
The November accord envisioned a cessation of hostilities and a simultaneous move by Croatian forces to unblock some 40 Yugoslav Army barracks where more than 25,000 federal troops were held hostage.
Mr. Vance said the Croatian and Serbian leaders were "disgusted" that the cease-fire did not take hold, but "very appreciative" that the blockades were gradually removed.
The difference between all the previous cease-fire agreements and the current one, Mr. Vance said, is that last Friday's agreement includes detailed mechanisms for separating the warring factions and preventing them from "shooting back" without first consulting international monitors.
Amplifying this, Mr. Okun said of the new agreement, "There will be military liaison officers from the United Nations, attached to the Army headquarters in Zagreb and Belgrade and to field headquarters down to the corps level, and contact between the liaison officers across the lines."
He said both Serb and Croat commanders had vowed to support United Nations liaison teams with their logistics.
 
Signed in Sarajevo
 All this is detailed in the "implementation accord" signed by Serb and Croat armed forces commanders on Jan. 2 in Sarajevo, the Bosnian city where World War I was ignited by the assassination of the Austrian archduke.
Mr. Okun and Mr. Vance had flown to Sarajevo after whirlwind stops in Belgrade and Zagreb, where they obtained the approval of both Serbian and Croatian leaderships. There, they drafted the accord over a period of four hours in the Konak, or official residence of the Bosnian-Hercegovinian Government, "on a 1914 Underwood typewriter," Mr. Okun recalled.
Sitting in the Konak, with Mr. Vance at the head of the table, Gojko Susak, Defense Minister of Croatia, signed for his side, while Col. Gen. Andrija Raseta signed for the federal forces. Then the two Americans dashed back to Belgrade for a "working dinner" with Serbia's President.
Mr. Okun said that of the 11 weeks he and Mr. Vance had spent on the negotiating task, "six or seven weeks were on the road, mostly in Yugoslavia."
Initially they flew among Yugoslavia's republican capitals on executive jets lent them by the Swiss Government, but on the last mission they used a small American Air Force jet.
Asked about the protests against the Sarajevo accord by Serbian minority leaders that took place this week in the Croatian region called Krajina, a scene of major fighting in the previous six months, Mr. Vance said he believed leaders in Belgrade would be able to bring them into line.
On another critical point he said he was convinced that the Serbian-led Yugoslav Army would "literally pull out of Croatia," where it holds about one-third of the republic's territory. "Literally and definitively," he said.
He said the first United Nations liaison officers were being chosen this week and that the initial team of 50 would "probably include an American." They are scheduled to be sent to Yugoslavia next week, to be followed -- if the cease-fire holds -- by about 10,000 blue-helmeted peacekeeping troops.
Mr. Vance said he was heartened that the European Community's peace conference on Yugoslavia, involving leaders of all six former republics, would resume work in Brussels on Thursday. Mr. Okun is leaving Wednesday for Brussels to attend that session.

HEADLINE: Imelda Marcos Back on Center Stage

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Jan. 7

 BODY:
With the announcement by Imelda Marcos that she will run for President in the Philippine elections, the widow of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos added further uncertainty today to an already chaotic and unpredictable campaign.
Mrs. Marcos, declaring that her candidacy was a reaction to the "sick and misdirected Government" of President Corazon C. Aquino, has undermined the presidential ambitions of several former Marcos family cronies and put new pressure on Mrs. Aquino to reconsider her refusal to seek a second term. 
 "Happy days are here again," said a beaming Mrs. Marcos, the 61-year-old former Filipino first lady whose entry into the race guarantees that, if nothing else, the rest of the presidential campaign will have the feel of theater. "If we are united, I am sure this nation will be great again."
While Mrs. Marcos scores low in opinion polls and is tainted by accusations that she and her husband looted the Philippine treasury during his 20-year rule, politicians and political analysts agree that her candidacy cannot be dismissed.
 
'The Best Demagogue'
 "People have discounted all those reports about the Marcos plunder," said Blas Ople, a newspaper columnist who was a Labor Minister under Mr. Marcos and who believes that Mrs. Marcos could win the May election. "In terms of stage appeal, no one comes close to Mrs. Marcos. She is the best demagogue in the country today."
But election victories in the Philippines are traditionally more dependent on money, intimidation and patronage than on public support.
In characteristically flamboyant style, Mrs. Marcos announced her candidacy on the steps of a Manila courthouse only minutes after she pleaded not guilty to new corruption charges.
The Government of Mrs. Aquino, swept to power in the popular uprising in 1986 that forced the Marcoses into exile in the United States, has accused the Marcos family of stealing nearly $5 billion from the Philippine treasury. Mrs. Marcos faces dozens of corruption-related criminal charges in Philippine courts.
 
Attacks Aquino Government
 "I have gone all over the country and seen so much suffering and economic chaos," said Mrs. Marcos, who returned home from exile last November insisting that she had no political plans. "After months of direct consultations with our poor and oppressed citizens, I have decided to run for office to seek the presidency."
Mrs. Marcos said the Aquino Government was "sick and misdirected" and that it "would rather spend hundreds of millions of dollars to persecute and vilify its own citizens while the poor and the destitute -- the victims of natural and man-made disasters -- languish in sickness and death caused by the failure to deliver basic services."
Mrs. Aquino's executive secretary, Franklin Drilon, did not respond directly to Mrs. Marcos' attack today on the President. But, in a one-sentence statement released to reporters, he said, "Imelda is entitled to chart her own political destiny, and nothing has changed the President's plans."
Mrs. Aquino has insisted that she will not seek a second term. But some of her political supporters are at work trying to convince her to reconsider her retirement from politics, and the entry of Mrs. Marcos into the race gives them a new and powerful argument. Mrs. Aquino's husband, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., was a leader of opposition to Mr. Marcos when he was assassinated in 1983, and Mrs. Aquino is known to believe that Mrs. Marcos played a role in the killing.
 
Seeks Opposition Endorsement
 Mrs. Marcos said today she would seek the endorsement of the Nacionalista Party, an anti-Aquino party that has fragmented in recent months as three of its most prominent members have announced their own plans to seek the presidency. Those candidates are Eduardo Cojuangco, Mrs. Aquino's first cousin who is also one of Mr. Marcos's closest friends, and two early supporters of Mrs. Aquino who have since turned against her -- Vice President Salvador Laurel and former Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile.
All three men had sought the support and financial backing of Mrs. Marcos but, with today's announcement, were rebuffed.

HEADLINE: Mr. Marino's Bad Budgeting

 BODY:
New York State's lowered credit rating hardly comes as a shock. Gov. Mario Cuomo has been warning about it and the rating agencies have been hinting at it. Despite these alarms Senate Republicans, led by Ralph Marino, the majority leader, accused Mr. Cuomo of crying wolf and refused to help resolve the state's latest budget impasse.
On Monday, Moody's Investors Service downgraded the rating on most of New York's debt, leaving the state with the second-lowest rating, Baa1, in the country. The least Mr. Marino can do now is limit the damage by negotiating in good faith on a plan to close a gap of $875 million in this year's $30 billion budget. 
 Mr. Cuomo said yesterday he could save $400 million through cuts in executive agencies. But that still leaves a $475 million hole to plug in just two months; Mr. Marino's intransigence is inevitably pushing the state to the irresponsible alternative of borrowing. That would add new debt to next year's anticipated deficit of $4 billion.
The lower credit rating on appropriation-backed bonds, which account for about two-thirds of the state's debt, no doubt means the state will have to pay higher interest rates on its bonds. Moody's has also warned that if Albany fails to approve a responsible budget for the next fiscal year, on time, it might downgrade its A rating on New York's general obligation bonds.
The other rating agency, Standard & Poor's, could lower its ratings at any time. So what is Mr. Marino waiting for? He continues to reject the Assembly's plan, which, though it relies too heavily on non-recurring revenues, makes fair spending cuts in services and administrative costs. Instead he calls for deep cuts in Medicaid and welfare, while keeping school aid cuts to a minimum.
But even his plan would not produce a balanced budget, raising the unavoidable suspicion that it is less a budget proposal than a campaign platform for Republican legislators facing re-election this year. New York deserves better.

HEADLINE: Wait Until the Soviet People Have Spoken

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Enough rhetoric about the failure of Soviet socialism ("The Soviet State, Born of a Dream, Dies," front page, Dec. 26). How about facts? 
 * The 1917 Bolshevik revolution that threw off the Czar was hardly an experiment by ivory tower idealists. It was a necessary revolt of workers and peasants led by women in bread lines whose families were starving.
* Lenin and Trotsky, leaders of the Russian Revolution, fought for democratic socialism (a planned economy to benefit society) under the control of workers, with full rights for women and national minorities.
* Many would have us believe that Stalinism was the logical outcome of the Bolshevik revolution. Not so. Stalin came to power after annihilating Trotskyist opposition. The Stalinist bureaucracy led an assault on democratic socialism and Communism to feed their coffers at the expense of the majority. That bureaucracy developed out of an impoverished and technologically backward Soviet Union, invaded and besieged for decades by Western capitalist countries.
* Stalin's 1930's reign of terror turned socialism on its head, with everything Lenin and Trotsky fought for and represented. Stalin had Trotsky assassinated while in exile in Mexico to kill his leadership role in Soviet and international socialism. The United States Government shed no tears.
Genuine democratic socialism in the Soviet Union hasn't been tried since Stalin's rise. Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin follow in Stalin's, not Lenin's or Trotsky's, footsteps. They will sell off the country and further impoverish the people for their own privileges like the bureaucrats before them.
Chances are, the workers, the women waiting in long bread lines, the poor who can't get housing and food will revolt against Mr. Yeltsin's market economy of big money and high living for a few and poverty for the rest. And though we hear little if anything about the protests of Soviet women, they will likely lead the resistance against capitalism and the fight for genuine socialism, just as they did in 1917. Yet this is a much brighter picture than what President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d have in store for the Soviet people.
 
MARY ANN CURTIS
Los Angeles, Dec. 30, 1991

HEADLINE: Bush Offers a Proposal to Battle Pollution in Asia

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7

 BODY:
Hoping to exploit American leadership in environmental protection in a part of the world where rapid population and economic growth is creating some of the worst industrial pollution and depletion of natural resources, the Bush Administration unveiled an environmental initiative for Asia today.
The program, involving 18 United States Government agencies working jointly with as many as 29 developing nations, territories or island groups in Asia and the Pacific, will attempt to match American expertise with the needs of nations where anti-pollution measures are not keeping pace with industrial development. 
 American consultants and companies will be assisted in marketing their skills and technologies to Asian and Pacific nations. Asians interested in learning more about environmental policy and technological advances will be offered places in a new United States Environmental Training Institute scheduled to open in April, jointly supported by the Government and private enterprise.
Several Asian cities, including Bangkok and New Delhi, are among the world's most polluted urban areas, without emissions controls or enforceable laws regulating industry. At the same time, some Asian nations are beginning to be more willing to spend money on cleaning the enviroment, American officials say. Taiwan and South Korea are planning anti-pollution programs that could cost up to $12 billion.
 
Problems Called Serious
 "The problems of urban Asia are terribly, terribly serious," said Tom Fox, director of the Center for International Development and Environment at the independent World Resources Institute here.
"There are all kinds of health-related environmental issues that grow from the confluence of population growth and poverty," Mr. Fox said in an interview. "Air quality, water, waste disposal, the whole range of sanitation issues are all susceptible to technology transfer. American technology leadership in these fields has been demonstrated in our cities."
"This program may not be the whole answer, but it's a good start," he added.
The United States-Asia Environmental Partnership, the first pan-Asian public policy effort to be undertaken by the Bush Administration, was first announced by President Bush in a speech Saturday in Singapore.
 
U.S. Warns Countries
 The United States has informed the following countries and territories that they are eligible for the new environmental program:
Bangladesh, Brunei, Cambodia, Cook Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, Fiji, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Kiribati, Laos, Malaysia, Maldives, Marshall Islands, Mongolia, Nepal, Niue, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Singapore, Solomon Islands, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand, Tonga, Vanuatu and Western Samoa.
Afghanistan, Myanmar, North Korea and Vietnam were not included because the United States refuses to deal with those countries. But neither was China, with which the Administration has tried to maintain ties.
A notable inclusion on the list was Pakistan, which is under an American aid embargo.

HEADLINE: Japanese Visit, on the Surface: Jovial Bush, Friendly Crowds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8

 BODY:
He is about to engage the Japanese Government in a titanic struggle over his nation's economic future. But on Tuesday, opening a four-day state visit to Japan to discuss trade and security issues, President Bush was trying his utmost to build bridges, not wreck them.
He played tourist at an ancient palace. He engaged an astonished circle of middle-aged Japanese men in a slightly goofy, highly telegenic game in which a leather ball is kicked around. He waxed enthusiastic to college students about brotherhood and understanding. He undertook that most American of political tasks -- a ribbon cutting at a new store. 
 In all of this, often over a din of brass bands and lusty cheers, Mr. Bush sought to improve the unflattering image that his visit has taken on in Japan, that of a strong-arm raid on the mercantile system and even the national treasury.
"I will do my level best as President of the United States to preserve and strengthen the important relationship between Japan and my country," he said at one point. "It has a lot to do with world peace. It has a lot to do with world economic stability. It has a lot to do with two great economic and democratic countries working together, setting an example for other countries around the world."
This morning, Mr. Bush and Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, dropped in on business and government officials of both their countries and conducted a brief colloquy to underscore their mutual interest in seeing the trade talks go well.
"President Bush and I are working hard to advance our bilateral relationship, including its economic relationship," Mr. Miyazawa said "not only for the sake of our two countries, but for the world.".
The President, in his trademark stacatto, replied: "We've got to be specific; we've got to get as much as we can -- set tables, times, let's do it by then. And I think we can do it."
Because of the enormous financial influence of both nations, he said, "world leadership is at stake."
Despite these remarks, it was not clear how long Tuesday's veneer of hospitality that preceded today's serious business, or their optimistic tone, might last.
Aides to Mr. Miyazawa were reported to remain deadlocked with American officials over demands that Japanese automakers sharply increase purchases of American-made components, even beyond a commitment to buy an additional $8 billion in American-made parts by 1994.
 
Auto Magnates Weigh In
 Automobiles and related products are responsible for three-fourths of the $41 billion yearly trade deficit that Washington runs with Tokyo.
The tension over the visit was further heightened by the heads of Detroit's Big Three automakers, who stepped off Air Force One after a flight here from Osaka on Tuesday night and promptly struck a frosty tone toward their Japanese hosts.
The chairman of Ford, Harold Poling, told reporters that Japanese consumers buy so few American cars because they are too fond of luxury makes like Mercedes and BMW, not because American cars are poorly made.
Japanese bought more than 130,000 German-made automobiles in 1990, but only about 30,000 American-made ones -- and 9,500 of those were Hondas assembled in the United States.
Mr. Poling's counterpart at Chrysler, Lee A. Iacocca, was contemptuous of suggestions by some Japanese officials that problems of quality in American cars, not Japanese trade barriers, were at the root of the Big Three's poor sales in this country.
"We're not that stupid," Mr. Iacocca said. "We know our problems. They don't have to preach to us."
Mr. Iacocca, Mr. Poling and the General Motors chairman, Robert Stempel, are among 18 corporate leaders accompanying Mr. Bush on his visit.
Behind the scenes, the President's aides toiled to bury any expectations of major trade concessions from his talks with Mr. Miyazawa..
Instead, they played up the international security aspects of the visit. These include the signing of a so-called "Tokyo Declaration" that acknowledges the growing global influence of Japan and sets out ways it can work with the United States in addressing both world problems and regional crises.
Bush Administration officials said that Mr. Miyazawa's Government may also agree to foot more of the cost of American military forces in the Pacific region.
When Mr. Bush left Washington for the Pacific 10 days ago, he said that his primary purpose was to "relentlessly pursue our mission to create jobs and restore prosperity for all Americans."
On Tuesday, an Administration official took a different tack, saying, "You've got to look at this in the broader historical perspective of what just happened to the Soviet Union, and the end of the cold war."
This broader perspective did not appear to be of much concern to the touring President, who spent Tuesday playing the role of good-will ambassador and stressing his trade message, perhaps as much for the benefit of audiences back in the United States as here.
Mr. Bush may have had his domestic political opponents on both the left and right in mind when he argued that "free and open commerce is not a zero-sum game. Free trade on a level playing field creates jobs and lifts standards in both of our countries."
On arriving from South Korea early Tuesday, Mr. and Mrs. Bush visited Kyoto, Japan's ancient capital, to tour the restored Shishinden palace, once home to Japan's emperor. His guide was former Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who spent much of the day as the Bushes' unofficial host.
Outside the palace, the President saw several men in brightly colored ceremonial garb engaged in a round of kemari, a game in which players kick a deerskin ball to each other, taking care to keep it from touching the ground.
As cameras whirred, Mr. Bush leapt into the circle of astonished men, attacking the horsehair-stuffed ball with obvious relish in soccer style, giving it several bounches off his head.
Not until he was told that that was not allowed under the rules did Mr. Bush relent, and he shortly left, saying to no one in particular, "We won."
Later at a nearby hotel, Mr. Bush briefly met about 200 American and Japanese students who are looking into each other's cultures under university exchange programs.
Noting that Mr. Miyazawa once joined in a student exchange with the United States, Mr. Bush said: "I want the people of our countries to have a better understanding of one another. We need more Americans who can speak Japanese and who understand the workings of the Japanese marketplace."
Then he sped off by helicopter to nearby Kashihara, where he opened an American-owned Toys "R" Us discount store.
