HEADLINE: JAPAN ANNOUNCES A HOST OF STEPS TO AID U.S. TRADE

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to demonstrate its willingness to take concrete steps to reduce its growing trade surplus with the United States, the Japanese Government late on Tuesday announced a host of incentives to make it easier for American companies to export their goods. The move came on the first day of President Bush's visit here.
Some measures had been announced earlier, while some merely expanded on existing programs. 
 But in spite of Japan's move, the difficult talks on what could amount to a new approach to managing trade between Japan and the United States appeared to bog down as negotiators worked late into the night but were unable to resolve tough American demands for increased Japanese imports.
"We are waiting to see what the Government of Japan comes forward with as a concrete, tangible set of actions," said a senior Administration official at a news briefing as the talks continued today.
 
Array of Incentives
 The Japanese package announced Tuesday night included an array of subsidized loans and voluntary targets for imports by Japanese corporations. It even included expansion of a program under which the Government offers low-cost financing to promote the export of American goods to developing countries receiving Japanese foreign aid.
Nuboru Hatakeyama, Vice Minister for International Trade and Industry, told foreign reporters at a news conference that the measures would increase Japanese imports over two years by more than $10 billion on products ranging from electronics components to automobiles.
 
More Action Is Sought
 Mr. Hatakeyama said it was not certain how much of the imports would come from the United States, and officials said it could also include products shipped by Japanese-owned factories abroad back to Japan. But officials also indicated that they expected the majority of the imports to come from American-owned companies.
The United States did not officially respond to the announcements. Officials said they were pleased that the Trade Ministry was taking the initiative but said more action was required. "An individual action plan from MITI certainly is not going to take care of the much deeper problem within the Japanese economy, which makes it very resistant to imports," said one American official.
What has struck many here is that the effect of all these measures and those still under negotiation will be a large increase in Government intervention in the market to try to help American-made goods sell here. Both sides have gone out of their way to express their conviction that markets must remain free, but the trade package emerging under heavy political pressure from President Bush's visit will amount to managed trade, many Japanese and some Americans acknowledge.
American officials have said that if successful, these discussions could mark a significant new direction. "I think this could have some long-term profound effects on the trade relationship," the Administration official said.
A key issue still being negotiated, officials on both sides indicated, is the dollar value of American autos and auto parts the Japanese will promise to acquire. Under a voluntary program, Japanese auto companies have said they will increase their purchases of American-made autos and parts to about $17 billion by 1994, from $9 billion now. The United States is said to be asking for a higher figure.
 
Easier Rules Expected
 Japan is also expected to ease some pollution-control regulations and testing standards for imported cars, to offer tax breaks for buyers of imported cars and to encourage Japanese auto companies to sell American-made cars through their extensive sales networks.
Officials on both sides have avoided referring to the import goals under discussion as targets. The Bush Administration has insisted that its only aim is to remove barriers to the free flow of goods and to halt exclusionary business practices in Japan.
"We want agreements that produce permanent improvement in access and in U.S. sales to Japanese markets and permanent improvement in the lives of Japanese consumers," President Bush said on Tuesday in western Japan, where he attended the opening of a Toys "R" Us store.
"We didn't ask them to make concessions," insisted Robert C. Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, who is one of 18 senior American executives accompanying the President. "We're not asking that they give us anything. We're just asking to compete." That, however, does not appear to be the case.
In the mid-1980's, the Reagan Administration negotiated an agreement with Japan to increase America's share of Japan's market for semiconductors to 20 percent, declaring that American manufacturers had been unfairly excluded from the market. Later, however, President Bush's trade negotiators insisted that they were opposed to setting such targets. The series of tense negotiations taking shape here this week on a range of manufactured goods appears to mark a step toward reversing course yet again.
"We are facing a dilemma," Mr. Hatakeyama said. "Theoretically speaking, this type of thing would be better not to exist. But we are experiencing a large trade imbalance with the rest of the world and we think it would be good for the Japanese Government to try everything she can."
He insisted that in Japan the Government could not dictate to private companies, since it has an open economy. He thus described the programs as "a kind of moral campaign" to persuade Japanese companies to import more. As he pointed out, some 88 Japanese corporations have complied so far.
Mr. Hatekeyama also insisted that the figures being discussed were not import "targets" but "estimates."
So far, the Trade Ministry reported, Japanese companies that account for more than 50 percent of Japan's imports and exports have said they will participate in the program to increase imports and links with foreign suppliers.
These range from agreements by Japan's big auto makers to sell American cars through their sales networks -- for instance, Toyota will sell G.M. cars -- to programs to permit more American auto-parts concerns to participate in the design of key parts and components for Japanese autos.
A series of "foreign access zones" will be opened near airports and ports to help imports. The Government will offer more low-cost loans to importers.
Tax breaks and subsidized loans will be offered to help foreign companies seeking to locate in Japan, a means of attracting more foreign direct investment into Japan from the current trickle. The Government will also establish a company to help foreign companies recruit Japanese staff. Under certain conditions foreign companies entering Japan will be offered Government loan guarantees to help them obtain needed bank loans, too.
The Japanese Government said it would also expand a program under which it offers trade financing to promote American exports to projects in developing countries underwritten by Japan. Under this program, which is being carried out in cooperation with the Export-Import Bank in the United States, the Japanese Government said it was likely to finance more than $10 billion in projects over several years, and that the greater part of the imports for these development projects would come from the United States.
That still leaves the negotiators wrestling with the politically sensitive issue of setting goals for sales of American automobiles and parts. It also does not include measures that are expected to be announced by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday.
An unusual level of secrecy has been maintained around Mr. Brady's visit, but there has been widespread speculation that he will be trying to work out financial measures to lift American exports.

HEADLINE: A National Curriculum: Seeking Fairness for All

SERIES: Lessons From Britain: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The 11-year-olds in Richard Nokes's history class are not having an easy time. They are trying to figure out how ancient Roman roads were built, and their only sources are translations of descriptions by writers of the time.
It is a sophisticated lesson in how to read primary documents, a skill expected of every child now that Britain has a required national curriculum. 
 Just last month, an advisory panel to President Bush recommended that the United States adopt voluntary national curriculum standards and national tests. As the debate begins in the United States, Britain's experience holds several revealing lessons.
 
The Debates Go On
 The British national curriculum has won wide acceptance as a way to raise standards and insure equal educational opportunity, although many teachers and scholars believe it is far too detailed and was rushed into the classroom. The curriculum exposed the need for much more extensive teacher training, particularly in math and science.
New required national tests have proved far trickier. Debates continue on whether they are fair, what form they should take, and whether they discriminate.
Britain is using the same kinds of tests that would be introduced in the United States, ones that avoid formulaic multiple-choice questions and are instead designed to test children's abilities more thoroughly. Yet teachers have criticized them as too time-consuming, and opinions remain divided on whether the tests were simply impractical or whether teachers were not given enough training or time to administer them.
In June 1988, a new education law required a national curriculum for the first time, along with identical national tests for every schoolchild at ages 7, 11 and 14. But minimum levels are not set for specific ages; the idea is to mandate what must be taught, not what must be learned in each grade. The law applies to England and Wales.
For Donald Naismith, a sometime adviser to former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and now director of education for the London borough of Wandsworth, the national curriculum is a way to enforce higher academic standards and prevent dilution of Britain's national identity. For Jane Traies, the principal of the Swakeleys School, a girls' high school in West London, the national curriculum means that her students will not be allowed to blight their futures by dropping such traditionally "male" courses as math and science.
That these educators, who consider themselves far apart ideologically, both support a national curriculum testifies to the popularity of an idea that not so long ago was heretical.
"I had a lot of anxiety about the national curriculum being a straitjacket," said Kathleen Higgins, director of education and community services for Hillingdon, a West London borough. "But we use it as an entitlement for education for all children. It's like an oyster with grit. We've managed to turn it into something wonderful."
Because Britain has long given national tests at ages 16 and 18 that help determine whether students advance to college, a de facto national curriculum existed for a relatively small, elite group. But only 20 percent of British students attend college, and in many cases poor or working-class students chose or were shunted into less demanding academic tracks.
Now all students through age 14 must study English, science and math, technology, history, geography, art, music, a modern foreign language and physical education. The Government is proposing to make art and music optional after age 14, and to require either history or geography through age 16. The Government has spent almost $1 billion developing the curriculum and tests.
The curriculum, which was drawn up by experts in specific fields but reviewed by Government officials, lists the factual knowledge and the analytical skills children should have at different ages. It breaks down each subject into "attainment targets," areas like genetics and evolution in science, and then describes levels of achievement within those, from basic to advanced.
There are no minimum levels children must achieve by certain a age, although each subject's curriculum outlines a range of levels most children will probably achieve at ages 7, 11, 14 and 16. For example, in science and math, most children would be expected to achieve level 6 or 7 by age 16. Level 10 would be achieved by the brightest college-bound students.
The law does not require specific textbooks or teaching methods. Rather than listing books, the curriculum says students should read "a range of fiction, poetry, literary nonfiction and drama, including pre-20th century literature." Students are required to read Shakespeare and other classic works (for example, the curriculum suggests, but does not require, the Bible and Jane Austen's novels).
Partly because the British curriculum leaves enough room to add whatever books teachers want, the battles over reading classics or including works by women and minorities now raging in the United States have been largely absent in Britain. But the issue of multiculturalism also seems to be less important in Britain, where, despite an increasing immigrant population, minorities do not have as much political power as in the United States.
 
Teachers Must Bear Heavy New Burdens
 For most teachers, however, the biggest problems have not been ideological, but logistical. Teachers have had to endure several dizzying years, studying the new curriculum, overhauling their lesson plans and adjusting to rapid-fire revisions.
Ian Host, head of the science department at the Small Heath High School in Birmingham, spent most of last year figuring out how to plan lessons that matched the 17 attainment targets and 10 levels of achievement in the curriculum. Meanwhile, the Government, responding to complaints that the curriculum was too unwieldy, reduced the number of attainment targets first from 17 to 5, and then to 4.
Lord Griffiths, who heads the Schools Examinations and Assessment Council, charged with overseeing the testing process, said that two-thirds of the attainment targets were still measured by teachers, not tests.
The hardest-hit teachers are in elementary schools, where many of the national curriculum subjects are being taught for the first time and teachers are especially unfamiliar with math and science requirements. Five-year-olds, for example, are supposed to be introduced to the concept of probability. David Hart, president of the National Association of Head Teachers, says teachers in "infant schools," for children from 5 to 7, are reeling. "The poor old infant teachers are so overloaded there is a danger the basics are being neglected," he said.
Indeed, introducing the curriculum has shown an urgent need for better teacher training, an issue the National Curriculum Council will examine, said its chairman, David Pascall.
Despite the frenetic pace, the neglect of teacher training, and what even Government officials agree is an unwieldy curriculum, surveys have consistently found that teachers welcomed the continuity, higher standards and sense of priorities the national curriculum brought.
"For very good schools, it is a dampener on innovation," said Margaret Maden, director of education for the county of Warwickshire, in central England. "But it has meant improvement for a lot of schools."
Testing is at the core of all the changes -- because it provides a way to check whether the high standards of the national curriculum are actually being met and a way to give parents adequate information so they can choose among schools.
But precisely because students, teachers and schools will all be judged by test results, the stakes are high and the debate contentious.
 
First Tests Create A Long Nightmare
 The first tests for 7-year-olds were just given last year. By all accounts, teachers found the experience a nightmare. They reported working an average of 58 hours a week giving the tests and struggling to figure out how to grade them. For teachers already strained by all the changes of the past few years, national tests worsened morale even further.
The tests were designed to be very different from the traditional exams familiar to generations of students, exams in which children facing a time limit wrote down answers. Instead, children were asked to guess in advance whether certain substances would sink or float, for example, or were given two magnets and asked to explain how to determine which one was stronger. They were also rated on longer-term projects, such as predicting and recording weather changes for several weeks.
 
Eye on the Workplace
 These "performance-based" tests are exactly the ones that testing experts in the United States want to see introduced as part of American national tests. They are better than traditional tests, experts argue, because they give children a fairer chance to demonstrate what they know and because they test skills needed in the workplace, such as reasoning ability.
Many British teachers, however, found the workload overwhelming, and the Government quickly issued a list of changes for this spring's round of tests. Half the tests for 7-year-olds will now be the "paper and pencil" variety, the science and math experiments were dropped, a spelling test was introduced, and teachers were given more time to conduct exams. Tim Eggar, the Government's second-ranking education official, said the initial tests for 7-year-olds were simply impractical. "There was a very commendable desire to assess as much of a child's different skills and knowledge base as possible," he said. "This inevitably resulted in a very elaborate system of testing. We've been dragging that back to reality. You've got to have a relatively simple testing system given in a reasonable time frame by an average classroom teacher dealing with an average class."
Lord Griffiths of the Schools Examinations and Assessment Council said the initial tests tried to serve too many purposes at once -- evaluating students and teachers, judging schools, communicating to parents. American tests now being drawn up also try to combine several purposes.
Yet support for the new "performance" style of tests remains strong, even among the same teachers who complained about the time such tests took to administer.
"The idea of written exams as the be-all and end-all belongs to the Victorian days of empire," said Ms. Traies. "Then they needed clerks to fill out forms in triplicate. What this country needs is people who can work cooperatively in groups."
Several educators said the tests themselves were good, but that teachers were not given enough training, time or aides to help watch the class while teachers gave the tests to small groups. Many hope not to see a return to paper-and-pencil tests because, they argue, these have tended to favor more privileged children.
"I am worried that the tests will be used to categorize and label pupils, and that the evidence on which they'll be labeled will not necessarily be reliable," said Peter Mortimore, deputy director of London University's Institute of Education, who helped draft some of the early tests. "This could be disastrous in a system which traditionally does well by the brightest and disastrously by the others."
Results from last year's tests showed that in one-third of the cases, teachers had underestimated their students' abilities -- particularly in the case of minority students. Professor Mortimore said that it was precisely because the tests were sophisticated that they were able to demonstrate the potential of so many students.
But Lord Griffiths and Mr. Eggar argued that this discrepancy showed just how much tests were needed to check teachers' assumptions. They say that the very labeling of children that critics fear the tests will bring about is already done by teachers.
Furthermore, said John Marks, who also serves on the testing council, tests can uncover problems and help children while there is still time. "You're not damaging their future by condemning them to some lower-ability rung, but saying here's some youngsters who need different treatment," he said. "If you've got a child who can't read, he can't get on. It's no good saying, 'I'm from a deprived background.' "

HEADLINE: Message to Albany: Bah-Humbug

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 7

 BODY:
It is a symptom of the times that New York State's credit rating has become not only a financial benchmark but a significant political one as well.
 In the last two years, the state's credit rating has twice been downgraded because of the inability of its leaders to balance the budget. In both cases, Wall Street rating agencies have made it clear that the dismal grades were given primarily for the state's political failure, not the sluggishness of its economy. 
That was certainly so on Monday when Moody's Investors Service lowered the rating on the state's appropriation-backed debt from A to Baa1, the second-lowest rating of any state. In a three-page statement, Moody's dedicated only a fraction of a sentence to what it called "protracted weakness in the economy."
 The rest of the statement focused on the state's failure to close its $875 million budget gap, the anticipated growth of the state's accumulated deficit, and the inability to restructure budget priorities in any fundamental way. All, it suggested, were failures of political will.
 
Partisan Blame Avoided
 What the rating agency avoided, both in its statement and in interviews, was the apportionment of blame to either the Republicans who control the State Senate or the Democrats who control the Assembly and sit in the governor's office.
 "There's plenty of culpability," said George W. Leung, the vice president and managing director for state debt ratings at Moody's. "The issue of paralysis is what we're concerned about."
 But what the state's politicians seem most concerned about, particularly in an election year, is how to shift the onus for the downgrading to the opposition. Indeed, some political leaders -- including the state Democratic chairman, John A. Marino, and the Assembly minority leader, Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., a Norwich Republican -- have suggested that the other party deliberately instigated the downgrading in order to use it later as a political club.
 On the eve of his State of the State address, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo reiterated in a news conference today the argument he had made in the weeks leading to the downgrading.
 
Welfare Stereotype
 The Senate Republicans, he said, had deliberately refused to reach a budget compromise because they believe that their unbending insistence on deep cuts in welfare and Medicaid programs will help them in the November election.
 Mr. Cuomo said that in demanding cuts in welfare grants and limits on Medicaid benefits for some welfare recipients, the Republicans were playing on the stereotype of welfare as a benefit to "a big minority swigging a can of beer who could work and says: 'No, I don't want to. I want to spend your money.' "
 "I don't see any justification for that except you can sell it to people," Mr. Cuomo said. "You can con them."
 The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, who is no relation to John A. Marino, responded that the Moody's statement made it clear that the raters were looking for structural reforms in the state budget, meaning cuts in social services that the Democrats are unwilling to make.
 
'Structural' vs. 'Silly' 
 "They now openly taunt the raters by continuing to insist on a deficit plan that contains no structural reforms," Mr. Marino said in a statement.
 Vincent Tese, the state's economic development commissioner, said that Mr. Marino's argument was "silly."
 "The market and the raters know there are philosophical differences between the way Democrats view things and the way Republicans view things," he said. "But they expect you to be able to bridge that for the good of the state. What they want to see is a balanced budget."
 Whoever is right, the cost of the downgrading to the state is undeniable. Although Mr. Cuomo said his budget analysts had not determined how much the downgrading would cost in extra interest on future bond sales, bond traders reported an immediate impact today on the state's appropriation-backed debt.
 Several Wall Street traders said the yields on such bonds had risen today anywhere from 8 to 20 basis points, meaning that sellers suffered from declining bond prices. Duncan K. Smith, the senior managing director of Lebenthal & Company, said, however, that the full impact of the downgrading would not be known until the state sells a new bond issue.
 Moody's intended its downgrading to spur the state into action, warning that the rating on the state's general obligation bonds would be threatened by a continued impasse. That downgrading would send an even more severe signal to the credit markets.
 Instead, the paralysis deplored by Mr. Leung only seemed to deepen. Mr. Cuomo said today that he had finally given up hope of negotiating a multiyear financial plan aimed at closing both the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and the $4 billion gap projected for the fiscal year beginning on April 1.
 The Senate Republicans said they continued to hold out hope for such a plan, even though Moody's said in its statement that "references to a 15-month plan are no longer realistic."
 Mr. Cuomo also seemed to hold out little optimism for patching together a more traditional deficit reduction plan that would close this year's gap through spending cuts and other emergency measures. He said the state could eliminate about $400 million of this year's $875 million gap through spending freezes and other administrative actions, but that it would have to borrow to close the rest of the gap.
 That would mark the fourth consecutive year that the state has had to borrow significantly to close an end-of-the-year deficit, a record that the credit raters have criticized loudly.

Cuomo addressed the state's credit rating at a news conference yesterday, saying that Senate Republicans' deliberate refusal to reach a budget compromise was caused by their unbending insistence on deep cuts in welfare and Medicaid programs, a stand that may help them in November. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
ACCORD ANNOUNCED BY U.S. AND JAPAN TO SPUR ECONOMIES

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In the first agreement to emerge from the summit meeting here between President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, the United States and Japan announced a broad commitment on Wednesday to try to lift the world economy from a looming slowdown by adopting budgetary and interest-rate policies that would promote faster growth.
The aim is to focus the domestic policies of the world's two largest economies clearly on expansion rather than on fighting inflation, with the hope that Europe's leading industrial economies will follow suit and create momentum for a period of healthier growth after an anemic 1991. 
 While the strategy was warmly supported by Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa, who held their first full day of talks on Wednesday, officials acknowledged that it was not a blueprint for definite policy measures.
 
Conforms to U.S. Policy
 Neither the United States nor Japan made specific promises on what steps it would take should it fall short of the growth projections. The announcement was a statement of intent -- but a potentially meaningful one because of the influence of the two countries involved, and one that it is hoped will have a positive psychological impact.
The agreement is in line with policy goals President Bush has already set, but it called for Japan, and later possibly some European countries, to put a greater emphasis on economic growth than they had been intending.
The two countries have already cut their interest rates sharply in recent weeks in steps that officials here said were taken in keeping with the desire for more rapid economic growth. The Japanese Government also announced a budget for the coming fiscal year that includes heavy spending on projects like new roads, sewers and bridges to stimulate quicker economic expansion.
 
Administration Expectations
 One Administration priority for the trip will not be fulfilled. Mr. Bush will return with no financial commitment from Japan for the giant $8.4 billion superconducting supercollider in Texas, raising new doubts about the project's future. [Page A9.]
And the American auto executives who accompanied Mr. Bush found few areas of agreement with the Japanese. Still, negotiators for the two governments appeared close to an agreement today on Japanese purchases of American-made autos and auto parts. The Japanese Foreign Ministry even said a basic agreement had been reached, but American official were not yet confirming that. [A10.]
The Bush Administration expects the American economy to begin rebounding by the middle of this year at the latest. In the meantime, Mr. Bush's options are limited by the huge Federal budget deficit, his ideological proclivities and a Congress controlled by the opposition party.
The expectation is that in his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, the President will propose a capital gains tax cut, a modest tax reduction for middle-class taxpayers and some new tax incentives for home building, savings and business investment. But he has promised to offset all his proposed tax cuts with spending reductions elsewhere in the budget, and he will not recommend big new public works projects. Moreover, in an election year, his proposals are likely to be debated vigorously in Congress, where passage is uncertain.
Coming during an election year, the accord announced here also creates an environment that may help the President restart the stalled American economy, if other countries, particularly Germany, can be persuaded to lower interest rates and adopt policies to stimulate their economies.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said a senior Treasury aide was already in Europe trying to organize this concerted economic campaign. A broader agreement to promote world growth may be announced when the finance ministers of the seven leading industrial nations meet later this month, American officials said.
"This action reflects recognition that the two countries have a special responsibility to pursue domestic policies that will strengthen the world economy," Mr. Brady said.
Like most of what is emerging at this unusual summit meeting, it was largely a political document, but one that underscored a new priority for Japan and the United States, which together account for 40 percent of the world economy.
"It is a confidence-building gesture, but an important one," insisted one official involved in the negotiations. "Psychologically, it will make a difference for businessmen to see that growth is a priority."
 
Commitment to Growth
 Yuichi Ezawa, a senior Finance Ministry official, said, "The important thing is that Japan and the United States expressed the same interest."
The announcement of "A Strategy for World Growth" came on Wednesday as extensive talks between the leaders and difficult trade negotiations that were marred when President Bush suddenly became ill. White House officials said Mr. Bush had the flu and would be able to resume a lighter schedule today.
The illness raised questions, however, over whether President Bush would return with the principal goal of this meeting, a significant trade agreement that the United States hopes will increase Japanese purchases of American autos, auto parts and other goods.
Those talks have been contentious, with the United States insisting that the Japanese make a detailed commitment on imports of American autos, auto parts and other goods in an effort to narrow Japan's yawning trade surplus.
There are reports that Japan is preparing to offer to increase such purchases by billions of dollars a year.
Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser and a participant in the meetings between the President and the Prime Minister, said Wednesday's discussions ranged from the American military presence in Asia to the changes taking place in the former Soviet Union and efforts to force North Korea to halt a nuclear weapons program. They also discussed the peace process in Cambodia.
President Bush urged Japan to push forward in various trade negotiations, Mr. Scowcroft said. Mr. Bush contended, Mr. Scowcroft said, that Japan's markets were not as open as they should be to imports, and he raised the issue of access to foreign-made automobiles, auto parts, computers, financial services, glass, paper and other products.
One area where the two leaders were in agreement was the new economic strategy to lift world growth. But officials said it was also the product of some difficult negotiations in which both sides had to make compromises.
Mr. Ezawa of the Finance Ministry said American officials had been urging Japan to take stronger measures to insure that it achieves its target of 3.5 percent growth in the coming fiscal year, which begins April 1.
The Japanese economy was projected to grow 3.8 percent in the current fiscal year, but is likely to have expanded by about 3 percent when the year closes at the end of March, economists say. The growth rate slowed sharply in the latter half of the year.
 
Economists' Reaction
 Economists welcomed Wednesday's agreement and said Japan should be able to meet its growth target.
"This is definitely achievable," said Yoshihisa Kitai, the senior economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank. "It depends on the willingness of the Japanese Government, and now they have said they have the will."

Mr. Stempel was among the 18-member delegation of American executives accompanying Mr. Bush. (Associated Press) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Wilder Ends Race for Presidency, Citing Virginia's Fiscal Troubles

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Unable to come up with a message or an organization that promised success in the 1992 Presidential race, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia came up tonight with the biggest surprise of the youthful campaign: he pulled out of the contest.
Mr. Wilder, the first black ever elected governor of an American state, said he did not have the time to seek the Democratic nomination for President and also to run the state of Virginia, which faces its worst budget crisis in half a century because of the current recession. 
 "Long before I announced for President," Mr. Wilder said in Richmond in his annual State of the Commonwealth address to the General Assembly, "I said that if it became too difficult for me to govern the Commonwealth and conduct a Presidential campaign, I would terminate one endeavor. I was left with a choice: either to devote all of my energies to delivering the message or to guiding Virginia through these difficult times. I have chosen the latter."
His explanation for getting out of the race was essentially the same that another Governor, Mario M. Cuomo of New York, recently gave when he announced that he would not enter the race. But unlike Mr. Wilder, Mr. Cuomo enjoyed universally high poll ratings, the promise of ample campaign financing and the prospect that with the help of numerous political allies he could put together a smoothly functioning campaign organization.
Mr. Wilder's announcement caught all but his closest advisers by surprise and injected a new element of suspense into the race for the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Wilder, a grandson of slaves who was born in poverty in Richmond and then struggled to become not only Governor but also a trial lawyer and a millionaire, had been angling for a major share of the nation's black vote. Now that vote, about one of every five Democrats, is more than ever up for grabs by the remaining five major Democratic candidates.
Black voters play an important role both in the March 3 primary in Maryland and the March 7 primary in South Carolina, as well as in the flurry of primaries in Southern and border states on March 10, Super Tuesday. His Democratic rivals had never ceded the black vote to the 60-year-old Governor the way Democrats ceded it to the Rev. Jesse Jackson in 1988, but he was still thought to have considerable strength there.
 
Help for Clinton
 At first glance, Mr. Wilder's withdrawal could be a particular boon to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the only Southerner among the remaining major candidates. Mr. Clinton is counting on a strong showing in the Super Tuesday primaries.
"I have known and respected Doug Wilder for years and I understand and respect his decision," Mr. Clinton said tonight in a statement released at a campaign stop in Oklahoma. "We haven't heard the last of Doug Wilder, and I look forward to the contributions he will continue to make this year and in the years ahead."
Still, other campaigns were eyeing the Wilder support. "We'll be moving aggressively to let Wilder supporters know that their support is welcome," said Lorraine Voles, press secretary to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska said: "No American can look at the personal and political courage of Virginia Gov. Doug Wilder without feeling a sense of pride for all that he has accomplished in his life."
The Wilder campaign was troubled almost from the day the Governor announced his candidacy on Sept. 13, standing on the steps of the Virginia Capitol. He said then that he was "the longest of long shots."
He had fairly high name recognition around the country, a factor that sometimes made him look good in polls. But there was no depth of support.
 
Less Than $1 Million Raised
 When questioned at length, prospective voters said they found the Wilder message lacking in substance, heavy on symbolism but short on detail about what the Governor intended to do about the flagging economy, soaring health care costs and other problems.
The latest Federal figures on campaign money raised by candidates showed Mr. Wilder trailing all major Democrats, with less than $1 million taken in, half of that in matching Government money. His campaign staff was little more than skeletal: seven paid workers in New Hampshire, the first primary state, and none in Maryland and South Carolina, where the next major tests will take place.
As late as 6 P.M. today, the Governor's staff was cranking out campaign schedules, and his advisers were laying plans to film television advertisements in New Hampshire. He was due to visit Baltimore on Thursday
"We're in it all the way, from New Hampshire on," Joe Trippi, the Wilder television advertising consultant, said in mid-afternoon when asked whether the Governor would make a major advertising push in New Hampshire.
In a statement released after the Governor's annual address to the General Assembly, in which he waited until the very end to discuss his Presidential plans, Mr. Wilder said he originally got into the 1992 race because "a job had to be done and a message spoken."
"I am concerned about the direction this country is headed and recognize the need for leadership," he continued. "I have the vision, experience and fortitude that is necessary to help reverse this dangerous trend and put this great nation of ours on the right track again."
Some polls, he noted, showed him doing well, particularly in Maryland and South Carolina. What he did not say was that the poll takers attributed much of his high standing in those states to name recognition.
Nor did Mr. Wilder mention in his speech to the General Assembly, some of whose members cheered his withdrawal, that polls in his home state showed his popularity steadily falling, to the point that his political future even there was more and more in doubt. Under state law, he cannot succeed himself as Governor, but he could run for another office, like a United States Senate seat.
In his campaign speeches, Mr. Wilder portrayed himself as "a fiscal conservative with a social conscience." Then he would point out that while other states were raising taxes in an effort to counter the national recession, he forced Virginia to make do by cutting its budget, not by imposing new taxes. Yet when pressed to say whether he was a conservative, a liberal or a moderate, he would insist he was none of them, which many political experts found difficult to comprehend.
In the 1989 Virginia Governor's race, Mr. Wilder had steered clear of race as an issue and had managed the considerable feat of putting together a winning coalition of blacks and moderate whites. He began his 1992 Presidential quest in the same manner but began to hammer upon the racial issue his campaign faltered. By today, the main thrust of his campaign was aimed at black voters.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2584 words

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
Excerpts From the White House Briefings on Bush's Condition

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from briefings by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, in Tokyo yesterday and today about President Bush's health:
 
OPENING STATEMENT YESTERDAY
President Bush is in his suite at the Akasaka Palace and is feeling fine following a bout with the flu. The President's personal physician, Dr. Burton Lee, said the President is in good shape and probably will feel okay tomorrow. 
 Before tonight's state dinner, at Prime Minister Miyazawa's official residence, President Bush told his physician that he felt somewhat ill. Dr. Lee examined the President and determined that he had a touch of the flu, but the President wanted to attend the state dinner. During the dinner tonight at approximately 8:20 P.M., the President slumped over in his chair, was feeling weak, and was helped to the floor by Secret Service agents.
The President recovered in a few minutes and remarked to his agents, "I just wanted to get a little attention."
Dr. Lee, who was also attending the dinner, was at the President's side immediately and determined there was no need for special assistance as the President left the dinner to return to his suite.
The President stood up, waved to the crowd, and walked to his car for the drive back to the residence here in Tokyo. Mrs. Bush stayed at the dinner, and Gen. Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security advisor, delivered the President's toast.
Dr. Lee reports tonight that the President has a case of gastroenteritis, commonly known as intestinal flu. The President was administered a dose of Tigan to control nausea and has gone to bed. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	When the President was asked how he felt by your pool upon leaving the dinner, he said, "I feel good."
The latest information is that the President is asleep at the hotel, and he was suffering from the flu.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. (inaudible)
A. He was in what we might call a faint condition, in the sense that he slumped over at the table, was conscious, however, and was helped to the floor by the leader of his Secret Service detail.
He remained on the floor for just a few minutes and then as I said, he got up on his own power and walked to the car.
Q. How do you know it's not a recurrence of the previous episode, that it's the flu that caused it, and not the previous heart condition?
A. Dr. Lee has examined the President and has determined that there's no connection whatsoever with the atrial fibrillation that the President experienced earlier.
A. Earlier today you said he had taken half a tablet of Halcion. Do you think -- did the doctor say that had any effect on him, that could have been a cause of it?
Q. I don't have any idea. I don't have any information on that.
Q. Are any further tests planned of the President?
A. The President of course is under the care and supervision of Dr. Lee and his medical staff. Dr. Roberts was also at the dinner, so there were two physicians there at the time. And they will remain with him at the palace and will watch his progress through the night and tomorrow. But they do not expect any difficulty.
Q. Do you have any special monitoring going on through the night as when he had his atrial fibrillation, he wore a portable device, anything extraordinary tonight?
A. Nothing extraordinary tonight. Dr. Lee does not feel there's any special monitoring required. All aspects of the examination indicate that it is a common case of the flu.
Q. Often in cases of intestinal flu there's nausea. Was the President nauseous when he slumped to the floor, or was there any vomiting or anything like that?
A. Yes, he was nauseous. He did vomit just before he slumped to the floor, and the medicine that he was given this evening was for his nausea.
Q. If the President was able to walk to his car under his own power, why was his departure obscured deliberately by security officers?
A. That precaution is always undertaken so that there's no impediment to efficient treatment of the President.
Q. Marlin, can you tell us what time the ambulance was called and why that was considered prudent at some point?
A. That also is a routine procedure if there's any kind of illness where the President's doctors determine that that could be necessary, and therefore certainly every precaution was taken.
But it was also quickly determined that that would not be necessary.
Q. Could you update us please, Marlin, on the medication that the President was taking for the atrial fibrillation, and whether in fact all of those medications are over, or is he still taking that?
A. All of that medication has been terminated several months ago.
Q. One follow up question, please. Where is Vice President Quayle and has he been notified of ----
A. The deputy chief of staff, Andrew Card, who was at the dinner also with the President, notified chief of staff Skinner in Washington, who in turn notified the Vice President and all other appropriate officials. But there was no need for any special alarm, there was no need for any special alerts to any aspect of the Government, and the notification was simply for information only so that when Government officials, including the Vice President saw these reports on television, that they would know that it's a case of the flu and there's no special concern. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. Is this the first time during his trip that the President has complained of feeling ill in some way? And is there any consideration of changing the way the President's hectic travel schedule is arranged?
A. It's the first time that I'm aware of that there's been any concern at all. The President's schedule is one that he has carried out in similar fashion for more than three years, one that he enjoys. He has a very rigorous schedule. He is a very physical and able man, and I don't expect any changes.
 
OPENING STATEMENT TODAY
 President Bush got a decent night's sleep last night. He awoke at about 6:30 this morning. He's up and about at the Akasaka Palace. He still is suffering from some weakness related to the flu, but the major symptoms have subsided.
All of the President's vital signs this morning are normal, as they were last night. There is no indication of any illness other than the common flu. No medication has been prescribed for today.
I spoke with the President this morning. He is in good spirits. He is concerned about the inconvenience caused to dinner guests last night. He joked he might have a large dry cleaning bill to deal with.
This morning, the President made a number of telephone calls, including to Vice President Quayle, chief of staff Skinner and members of his family.
Dr. Burton Lee, the President's physician, reports that the President is in overall excellent health and should recover from this bout with the flu in a normal period of time. In fact, the President expects to resume much of his schedule here in Tokyo this afternoon. . . .
The President feels the trip is going very well and hopes that this episode will not detract from the overall focus of the visit. He thanks Prime Minister Miyazawa for his many courtesies last night and looks forward to the business meeting with him this afternoon.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

 	 	 		. . .	 	The state dinner tonight is still on, the President plans to attend. There are no changes at this point.
 
Precautionary Tests
 Q. Have any precautionary tests been made, such as an electrocardiogram?
A. The doctors are certain that there is no other illness or any other problems related to this, that it's a simple case of the flu. The President is human, he gets sick, and I would refer you to last night's pool report that said that half the press corps has been sick with the flu since we left.
 
Lost Consciousness
 Q. Marlin, did the President at any point in fact lose consciousness?
A. I don't know. He fainted, fell down behind the table, and was up in just a few seconds. As you know, Dr. Lee was right there, noticed that he was looking pale earlier, so was right beside him. Dr. Lee said that he was just there on the floor. Dr. Lee asked him to stay motionless for a few minutes until he could be sure of his condition. So I think a fainted condition is the best description.
 
Types of Gastroenteritis
 Q. Gastroenteritis has a couple of different forms: one is viral, one is from an irritation. Can you tell us which this is?
A. I don't know that, no. I don't know.
 
On Contagion
 Q. Is he contagious, Marlin, do we know?
A. We don't believe he is, no.
 
Ambulance Refused
 A. Do we know who made the decision, whether it was the President's own decision to use the limousine rather than the ambulance?
A. It was the doctor and the security.
 
Tests Given to Bush
 Q. Can you tell us the tests that the President has undergone? Did he have an electrocardiogram? Was his heart rate checked?
A. No, I won't go into any of the tests, but suffice it to say that there is no indication of any illness other than the flu. He's under no medication of any kind today. He's recovering in an absolutely normal way, and it's a very common flu.
 
On Fainting
 Q. Last night you said that the President had not lost consciousness. Now you seem to be suggesting that he may have for a few seconds. Can you clarify that, please?
A. He fainted. All his vital signs were normal. That's all I'm willing to say about the tests, and that was the same last night and this morning.
 
Role of Halcion
 Q. Do you have any more information today about the President's taking Halcion?
A. No, I don't have any indication. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Bush's Next Appearance
 Q. When's the first time we're going to see the President today?
A. You will see him at the bilateral meeting with Prime Minister Miyazawa, which is about 1:30. . . .
 
Officials Telephoned
 Q. Did he talk to anyone else besides Skinner, his family and Quayle?
A. No, just the ones I mentioned. He was making other phone calls so by now he may have talked to more, but as of 8:00, those are who he'd talked to.
 
Schedule Changes
 Q. Marlin, so he's not -- he's canceling this morning? He's not participating in this morning bilat that he was going to do, the extended bilateral?
A. That's moved to this afternoon, the 1:30. All the meetings that were on the schedule are being retained on the schedule, but they're being -- they'll be put on this afternoon instead of this morning. . . .
 
Bush's Plans
 Q. What's President Bush going to be doing, just resting till this afternoon?
A. Yes, he's just resting.
 
Current Symptoms
 Q. Well, what symptoms does he now have? If he hasn't got a fever and he's normal, then what are the symptoms that tell you he still has the flu?
A. He's a little weak from the loss of fluids last night and is resting for that, and he has a little bit of nausea. He's sipping fluids at this point.
 
Solid Food
 Q. Has he had any solid food since last night?
A. Has not had solid foods.
Q. When will he have food again, do you know?
A. Don't know.
Q. Has he been sick to his stomach since last night?
A. No, he has not.
 
Medications Taken
 Q. Do you know what medication he has taken on this trip other than halcyon?
A. Tigan is the only thing, for nausea, taken last night.
Q. No heart medication? Nothing else?
A. No.
Q. How about his thyroid medicine?
A. All of that medication has been completed.
Q. Even the thyroid?
A. Well, the thyroid's a continuing thing, yes, but there's no connection. . . .
 
Back to Work?
 Q. Has he conducted any business this morning?
A. Just the phone calls that I've mentioned. One more question.
 
Miyazawa Meeting
 Q. The afternoon meeting with Miyazawa, is that going to be continuing negotiations on the trade stuff, or has this been pretty well buttoned up?
A. No, it will be across-the-board discussions. As you know, the meetings were going on last night and still this morning with the Foreign Ministry and the U.S. traveling officials on all the various sectoral questions. Those meetings are continuing again this morning. We feel progress has been made, but they have not buttoned up at this point.
 
Bush's Role in Talks
 Q. Is the President going to have to involve himself today in these negotiations to button up the action plan, or is he basically leaving that now to Mosbacher and Brady?
A. I don't expect any of them to be involved in the negotiations. Those are being handled by our State Department officials who've been working at the Foreign Ministry. The President's conversations with the Prime Minister relate to security matters as well as some general economic matters.
But the negotiations on sectoral changes are being conducted at the ministerial level.
 
Changing Routine
 Q. Last night you suggested that there wasn't any need to change the President's habit of a rigorous schedule on these trips. Isn't there an element of common sense if, for example, a 67-year-old man who has the flu doesn't play tennis, doesn't take sleeping pills and so on -- why not change?
A. Well, common sense would say there's a lot of 67-year-old people who play tennis and do those things, and it's quite normal for the President. There's not reason to not do it.
Q. (Inaudible)
A. And that's his normal routine -- he's a vigorous man, very healthy. There's no reason for him to change his schedule at all.
 
Doctor's Orders
 Q. Marlin, whose decision was it to cancel this morning's events? Did he make that decision or was he told by the doctor that he shouldn't ---- (inaudible)?
A. No, that's a collective decision by the staff.
 
Tone of Talks
 Q. You described those talks last night as severe and a lot of pressure being put on. Has the character of them changed in any way? Have any agreements been reached? Or have they continued to be hard-fought battles?
A. The sectoral discussions are all hard-fought battles. I would say there are very tough negotiations going on. Both sides have very strong positions and a lot at stake, and we're working those very hard.
 
Results of Meetings
 Q. Well, are you in a position to say whether there will be any specific substantive achievements, or will you leave here with nothing resolved?
A. We feel very encouraged by the whole process. We think we've already had a very successful trip, and it will be even more successful by the time we're ready to leave.
Q. That really doesn't answer the question whether there will be specific accomplishments.
A. There have already been specific accomplishments, and there will be more.
 
Points of Accord
 Q. On the trade talks, can you say that there have been, aside from the tough talks still continuing, several areas of agreement yet, or are they just all contentious?
A. There are several areas of agreement, there are several areas that are still being discussed.
 
Bush's Campaign
 Q. The President has said quite a few times that the only thing that might make him change his mind about running for re-election is health.
A. That doesn't include the flu.
Q. Well, that's the question. Can you tell us that this episode will have absolutely no effect on his re-election plans?
A. It will have absolutely no effect on his re-election plans. Thank you very much.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 582 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The U.S. and Japan announced a broad commitment to try to lift the world economy from a looming slowdown by adopting budgetary and interest-rate policies that will promote faster growth. The aim of the new strategy is to focus the domestic policies of the world's two largest economies clearly on expansion rather than on fighting inflation, with the hope that the leading industrial economies of Europe will follow suit. [Page A1.] 
 The heads of Detroit's Big Three came face to face for the first time with the powerful bureaucrats who run Japan Inc. And in a day of icy encounters, they discovered that they and the Japanese agree on virtually nothing. [A10.]
Israel's leading scientific university bought two supercomputers from a British maker after failing to buy a U.S. one. [D1.]
 
Companies
Woolworth said it planned to close, sell or reformat 900 of its 6,500 U.S. stores in the next 18 months. Fewer than half of the 10,000 workers at the stores will lose their jobs. [D1.]
American Airlines said it would begin offering business-class service on flights between New York and Los Angeles. [D1.]
Paine Webber was ordered by the Big Board to pay $900,000 in fines for numerous sales and trading violations. [D1.]
National Starch and Chemical introduced N-Lite, a line of six fake fats that can replace natural fat in processed foods. [D2.]
CSX said it would take a $755 million charge against earnings, largely to cover the costs of an employee reduction program. [D4.]
Intel said it would cut the price of its 386 microprocessors by up to 35 percent starting in April. [D4.]
The Princeton/Newport defendants will not be retried, a U.S. Attorney announced. [D5.]
Allowing callers abroad to phone the U.S. at the same low rates Americans pay to call overseas is the idea of International Discount Telecommunications, a tiny Bronx company. [D1.]
Hearst Magazines said it would merge Connoisseur into Town & Country after Connoisseur's February issue. [D22.]
El Paso Electric sought bankruptcy protection, unable to raise rates to pay for its investment in a nuclear plant. [D4.]
 
The Economy
Knot-tying between the lodging and fast-food industries is on the rise, though it is clearly a marriage of convenience. [D1.]
The consumer electronics industry, at a mammoth semiannual show, looks back on a year when it escaped the worst of the recession. [D5.]
Consumers kept a tight rein on their use of credit in November, the Fed said. [D17.]
Cuomo pledged to help lift New York out of recession, calling for an $800 million bond act. [A1.]
 
Markets

HEADLINE: Politics Reign at Spotted Owl Hearing

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 8

 BODY:
For only the third time in history the Cabinet-level committee known as the "God squad" began deliberations today on whether certain economic activities of man are more important than the potential extinction of an animal species.
But the hearings here by the panel, the Endangered Species Committee, concerning the northern spotted owl were only a few minutes old when it became dominated by internal conflicts of the Bush Administration over environmental policies. 
 Today, in a surprise move, the Environmental Protection Agency, which has harshly criticized Government policies that favor logging in the Pacific Northwest, abruptly withdrew from the hearings before Administrative Law Judge Harvey Sweitzer, taking with it some of the most crucial evidence on behalf of saving the owl.
 
'There Was a Deal'
 While the agency's lawyer, Tim Backstrom, offered no explanation for the withdrawal from the fact-finding hearings, critics said that political pressure had been brought against them.
"There was a deal struck here somewhere," said Victor Sher, a lawyer with the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. "To withdraw on the eve of a trial is wrong and inexplicable."
Gordon Bender, chief of staff to the agency's Administrator, William K. Reilly, said in Washington that the agency no longer needed to participate in the hearings because other administrative means had been developed for bringing information to the committee.
Ultimately, the decision on whether the Bureau of Land Management can be granted an exemption from the Endangered Species Act rests with the seven-member committee, which will vote in March. But that group, called "the God squad" because of its authority to let a species become extinct if it decides that saving jobs is more important, must make its decision based on the record developed in these hearings, which are expected to last about a month.
"After what happened this morning, we are concerned that the process is seriously flawed," said Melinda Bruce, a lawyer with the state of Oregon.
The withdrawal of the Government environmental advocate comes at a time when other Bush Administration leaders are attacking the Endangered Species Act.
The landmark 1973 law, one of the nation's most powerful pieces of environmental legislation, comes up for reauthorization by Congress this year. While the law has led to protection for 639 threatened or endangered species, critics, including the Secretary of Interior, whose job it is to enforce the act, say it has caused economic turmoil, particularly here in the northwest timber country, where logging on Federal land has been restricted to protect the owl.
"I have come to the conclusion in dealing with more than 25 endangered species that the way we do this thing is all wrong," said Manuel Lujan Jr., the Interior Secretary, in Washington. "My job is to protect these species, but by the same token I must make available to the American people these natural resources."
Mr. Lujan said he was in favor of changing the law so that, rather than saving individual species, it would give protection to whole ecosystems. "This law was meant to be used as a shield but instead it has been used as a sword," Mr. Lujan said. "It is not just the spotted owl. The Delta smelt, Colorado squaw fish, the desert tortoise. There is no end to it."
The Endangered Species Committee, which is headed by Mr. Lujan, can let logging proceed in the old growth forest that is home to the owl in Oregon if the group finds that economic considerations outweigh those of the owl's significance.
But the hearings today showed just how divided the Government's house is. Two agencies, both of them part of the Interior Department, are pitted against each other in the fact-finding proceedings here before Judge Sweitzer.
"It's like an inter-family feud," said Mr. Lujan. "I feel like two of my children are going at it." But critics say that because of his criticism of the Endangered Species Act, he is incapable of making an impartial decision.
 
Question of Logging
 One agency, the Bureau of Land Management, has asked that it be allowed to go ahead with logging on about 4,500 acres of Federal land in western Oregon on which fewer than 50 owls depend.
Fewer than 500 of the birds are left in existence. The owl was listed as a threatened species in 1990.
Another agency, the Fish and Wildlife Service, has said that logging would imperil the owl. It is that agency's role in these hearings to act as the protector and defender of the owl.
In opening statements today Government lawyers offered contrary views of what is at stake.
If the logging cannot proceed on the Federal land in question, "it is far more likely to result in homeless people rather than homeless owls," said Robert W. Nesbit, a lawyer with the Bureau of Land Management.
The timber industry has run into hard times, in part because of environmental restrictions and in part because the recession has caused homebuilding and demand for wood to slump. Because timber demand is down, no jobs would be lost by not cutting the 200- to 500-year-old trees in question, said Patrick Parenteau, a lawyer for the Fish and Wildlife Service.
"There's no need for this timber at this time," he said in his opening statement. "But because there is so little of this old growth left, the mere existence of it has economic benefits. Cutting down the last of the magnificent old growth forest in the Pacific Northwest does nothing to advance the economic vision of the region."
The question of economic value is crucial. Under normal circumstances, job or monetary loss is not considered in whether to grant endangered species designations. But it weighs heavily in the "God squad" deliberations.
Five members of the committee must vote to approve an exemption from the Endangered Species Act.

HEADLINE: Accord Reported to End Haiti Crisis

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Diplomats seeking a negotiated settlement of Haiti's three-month political crisis say that the country's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has endorsed the nomination of a leading political rival as Prime Minister in a compromise arrangement that would eventually bring about his return from exile.
Officials from the Organization of American States, which has sponsored negotiations for Father Aristide's return, said today that after two days of discussions with Haitian parliamentary leaders in Venezuela, the deposed President had accepted the nomination of Rene Theodore, one of two names put forward by the legislators, to be his Prime Minister. 
 Mr. Theodore, a founder of the Haitian Unified Communist Party whom American diplomats have described as a "moderate and urbane politician" had recently been one of Father Aristide's leading critics, suggesting forcefully that the deposed President had repeatedly violated the Constitution and encouraged class violence in his nearly eight months in office.
 
Overthrow of Aristide
 Father Aristide, a stirringly popular leftist priest who won 67 percent of the vote in Haiti's first democratic elections 13 months ago, was overthrown and forced into exile in Venezuela after a military coup last Sept. 30.
Almost immediately after his overthrow, the Organization of American States moved to impose a hemisphere-wide commercial embargo on Haiti to force his restoration. Warning that a successful military coup in Haiti could destabilize fragile democracies throughout the region, the O.A.S. has consistently demanded Father Aristide's negotiated return to power.
After today's announcement in Caracas that Father Aristide had accepted Mr. Theodore, the Colombian diplomat who has led the negotiations, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, other O.A.S. officials and diplomats expressed cautious optimism that the agreement would soon lead to the establishment of a new government in Haiti and the lifting of economic sanctions.
 
Preliminary Steps
 The details of Father Aristide's return, several diplomats said, was the subject of negotiations and, according to some, was unlikely to occur before several more months. These diplomats said that time was needed to restart a crippled economy, to iron out security arrangements for Father Aristide and to carry out major reforms of the Haitian police, army and judicial system under O.A.S. supervision.
The diplomats said that although he had been proposed by conservative leaders of the National Assembly, Mr. Theodore, 51 years old and the leader of a small party that still carried the Communist label, had not conclusively gathered enough support among the entire Parliament, Haiti's conservative economic elite, and most important, the army, to assure that his nomination would be approved.
 
Support of the Wealthy
 Before news of Mr. Theodore's selection began to circulate in the capital this afternoon, several Haitian legislators warned that support among the wealthy and the army for Father Aristide's return could only be assured if the deposed President were to endorse the nomination of Marc L. Bazin, the other candidate proposed by the legislators who traveled to Venezuela.
Mr. Bazin is a conservative former World Bank official who placed a distant second in the 1990 elections won by Father Aristide. An O.A.S. official who asked not to be identified said that Father Aristide had rejected Mr. Bazin, in part, because of what he felt was the conservative politician's endorsement of the coup d'etat against him.
Associates said that Mr. Theodore, who did not return several telephone calls, has been meeting with military and business leaders in recent weeks to reassure them and seek their support.
In recent statements, Mr. Theodore has also stressed the importance of the private sector and called for more domestic and foreign investment.
For years, a variety of underground political movements, some of them claiming Communism as their ideology led efforts to organize insurrections and invasions by small armed bands aimed at unseating the Duvalier family dictatorship that ruled Haiti for 29 years until its overthrow in 1986.
In its early years, Mr. Theodore's Unified Haitian Communist Party, was recognized and actively supported by Moscow. It was largely composed of educated young people.
The party suffered a major setback in 1969, the year it was formed, when many of its leading members were rounded up and killed.
Mr. Theodore was on a mission to Budapest at the time, and eventually made his way to Paris. In 1978, he became the party's leader in exile. In the 1990 election the party did poorly, winning just three seats in Parliament.

HEADLINE: F.B.I. to Shift From Cold War to Crime War

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
In a personnel shake-up that reflects the end of the cold war, the Federal Bureau of Investigation plans to reassign several hundred agents from internal security investigations to combat serious crime and gang violence, officials in the Bush Administration said today.
Although the move is expected to involved fewer than 300 agents in a force of about 10,000, the shift is symbolically dramatic, representing a downgrading of counter-espionage efforts in favor of a more intensive attack on violent crime, particularly gang violence. "Call it a peace dividend," one official said. 
 The reassignment comes as a result of the breakup of the Eastern bloc and the diminished threat of spying against the United States by the former Warsaw Pact nations, who in the past had vigorously collected intelligence in the United States.
Those changes have left the bureau's foreign counterintelligence section, which is responsible for investigating threats to national security by foreign agents operating in the United States, without a clearly defined purpose and facing the possibility of budget cuts.
The move also represents an effort by the Federal Government to marshal greater resources against serious street crime, areas in which state and local officials have historically played a greater role than have the Federal law-enforcement authorities.
 
Greater Federal Role Planned
 Attorney General William P. Barr said at his confirmation hearings last fall that he planned to make the effort to curb violent crime a top priority for the Justice Department. Since then, officials have been working on several proposals to increase the Federal role.
The scaling down of counterintelligence operations represents a major change for the F.B.I. In the past, internal security has ranked as one of the bureau's top priorities.In cities with a large foreign diplomatic presence, like Washington and New York, hundreds of agents have been assigned to surveillance and investigative work.
William S. Sessions, the Director of the F.B.I., has insisted in recent months that the demand for a strong counterintelligence presence remained high, despite the dismantling of the Soviet Union and toppling of Communist governments in Eastern Europe.
Some bureau officials justified the continued staffing levels by asserting that the newly emerging independent states had merely shifted their resources from military espionage to industrial spying in an effort to help their limping economies.
But the impending move appears to represent a changed environment in which domestic law-enforcement concerns now override the threat of overseas spying.
The expected changes will require scores of agents to move from their current jobs to cities like Chicagoo and Los Angeles, where gang-related violence has reached epidemic levels. Several dozen cities are expected to receive an infusion of new agents, but the precise locations remained unclear today.
 
Operation Triggerlock
 The Government has already taken several actions to step up its activites against violent crime. Last year the Justice Department initiated Operation Triggerlock, setting up task forces in several cities to enforce Federal laws that make it illegal for habitual felons to own weapons.
Last fall, in a speech in San Francisco, Mr. Barr outlined several proposals to attack Asian-American gangs that appear to dovetail with the reassignment of counterintelligence experts for a broader attack on gang violence.
Those proposals included the wider use of electronnic surveillance and long-term undercover operations against Asian criminal enterprises and a proposal to enact new laws enabling the authorities to shut down Asian crime groups as criminal enterprises.
In fighting gang violence, the F.B.I. has already sought to apply techniques developed in investigations of organized crime, including infiltration and the use of informers to file broad racketeering charges intended to dismantle the gang's leadership.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Connoisseur to Be Merged Into a Sister Publication

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Abandoning plans to remake Connoisseur magazine from a fine-arts publication into a chronicle of popular culture, Hearst Magazines announced yesterday that it would merge the monthly into another of its titles, Town & Country, after Connoisseur's February issue.
Gael Love, the editor in chief who was brought in to change the 91-year-old magazine, expressed surprise at the decision. 
 D. Claeys Bahrenburg, president of the Hearst Magazines division of the Hearst Corporation in New York, said, "We took a hard look at this and we thought it was best to reallocate our resources." Mr. Bahrenburg declined to discuss the potential losses, citing Hearst's status as a private company.
 
Experiment Ended
 The decision ended an experiment that began last January when Hearst dismissed Thomas Hoving, who had been editor in chief of Connoisseur since it was moved to America from Britain in 1982. During that time, Connoisseur specialized in articles on antiques, opera and art.
Replacing him was Ms. Love, a protege of Andy Warhol and the former top editor of Fame and Interview magazines. She moved quickly to change Connoisseur's editorial content, offering a mix of pop-culture topics like profiles of movie stars and reports on the British royal family.
But from the first issue published under Ms. Love, in June, the revamped Connoisseur drew criticism, particularly from fans of Vanity Fair, the monthly competitor from Conde Nast Publications.
Asked then about Ms. Love's debut issue, Tina Brown, editor in chief of Vanity Fair, said, "Oh, you mean the October 1985 issue of Vanity Fair." Both magazines had Diana, Princess of Wales, wearing the same tiara, on their covers.
Despite that, Mr. Bahrenburg said, he did not regret the decision to bring in Ms. Love.
"We needed to raise circulation and ad pages," he added, beyond what Connoisseur had attracted under Mr. Hoving. But, he continued, the drastic economic woes felt since the 1987 stock market crash by "affluent, young, free-spending" readers and advertisers of luxury goods doomed those efforts.
 
Falling Ad Pages
 In 1988, Connoisseur carried 1,083 advertising pages; the number fell to 925 in 1989, 759 in 1990 and 530 in 1991. Circulation, which Mr. Bahrenburg had hoped would rise at some point to 500,000, was at 328,453 for the six months that ended Dec. 31.
Effective in June, Hearst will raise Town & Country's rate base, the circulation guaranteed to advertisers, to reflect the absorption of Connoisseur; it will rise to 475,000 from 440,000. Connoisseur's most recent rate base had been 320,000.
Some editorial features and columns of Connoisseur will be added to Town & Country.
Connoisseur's publisher, Carole Ference, will be reassigned within Hearst Magazines, Mr. Bahrenburg said. As for Ms. Love, he added, "She and I are having dialogue" as to her future.
Ms. Love said yesterday that she had not been notified of Hearst's decision before the announcement. She declined further comment.
A publishing executive who insisted on anonymity described the period of time that Ms. Love edited Connoisseur as too short to make a decision like Hearst's to close the magazine.
"It's not like Conde Nast," the executive added, "where they nurse things till they happen."
This is the first time Hearst has closed one of its flagship monthly titles since July 1986, when it shut Science Digest and sold the subscription list to Time Inc.
