HEADLINE: Fast Food Fills Menu For Many Hotel Chains

BYLINE: By EDWIN MCDOWELL

 BODY:
Guests who feel the urge for pizza at many Marriott hotels now find their call for room service answered with a Pizza Hut pizza, made in the Marriott kitchen.
At the Day's Inn in downtown Atlanta, guests can satisfy their craving for a hamburger merely by stepping through a lobby door into the adjoining Wendy's. 
 Most of the 21 Homewood Suites have one-touch telephones in their guest rooms that connect with nearby restaurants, but phones at those hotels in Jacksonville, Fla., are connected to seven restaurants, including Pizza Hut and Domino's Pizza.
 
Benefits Are Mutual
 Such knot-tying between the lodging and fast-food industries is on the rise, though it is clearly a marriage of convenience. Faced with sluggish growth at its traditional properties, which just about blanket America, the fast-food industry is aggressively seeking new outlets.
Economy hotels seem to be targets ready made for fast food. They account for about 38 percent of the nation's 44,500 hotels and motels and are the fastest-growing segment of the lodging market. But few of them have restaurants -- or want them.
"Restaurants have always been money losers for hotels, unless they can attract other than just the hotel guest," said Betsy Bromberg O'Rourke, a spokeswoman for Choice Hotels International. Choice's 2,500 properties include Quality Inns and Hotels, Comfort Inns, Econo Lodges and Rodeway Inns. At its Sleep Inns, Choice's growing chain of economy hotels, telephones are connected to restaurants that promise to deliver in 30 minutes.
"The hotel industry generally makes a 15 to 20 percent departmental profit on food and beverage," said Bruce Baltin, a partner in Pannell Kerr Forster, the national accounting and consulting firm. "But if you add administration, marketing, occupancy costs and capital charges, they about break even."
For that reason, when all-suite hotels were conceived a decade or so ago, "the idea was that they wouldn't build restaurants because they weren't profitable," said Gary L. Carr, also of Pannell Kerr Forster. In two years, he said, "A lot of hotels have converted their restaurants into meeting rooms, at least as a stop-gap measure in this bad economy."
Not all the efforts involve telephoning. Virtually all 860 of the franchised Super 8 Motels are within a short walk of a family-style restaurant.
"Sometimes we'll even contact an Arby's or Denny's, and ask if anybody's interested in going into, say, Cedar Rapids, where a Super 8 is going up," said Joan Ganje-Fischer, a vice president of the Aberdeen, S.D., motel company.
 
A Full-Service Option
 What is different about the connection between the Marriott Corporation, based in Bethesda, Md., and Pizza Hut, a division of Pepsico Inc. based in Wichita, Kan., is that most Marriott properties already have restaurants and room service.
An executive of a small luxury chain, who insisted that neither she nor her company be identified, said it was "unseemly" for a full-service hotel to serve the food "that can be found on every street corner."
Yet name recognition was precisely what attracted Marriott, which once owned the Gino's and Roy Rogers restaurant chains.
"We had been doing our own room service pizza for some years," said Gordon Lambourne, a spokesman for the Marriott. "It was very popular, but we wanted to get a well-known, consistent product. We did some studies and found there's a brand preference for something like pizza."
After testing Pizza Hut in several company hotels last summer, including ones at the San Francisco International Airport and in Bethesda, Marriott gave the go-ahead. Its employees are trained in pizza-making by Pizza Hut, which supplies the ingredients, and the pizzas are made in special ovens in Marriott kitchens.
Now in about 40 Marriott hotels, Pizza Hut is scheduled to be on the room service menu of 25 more by July, Mr. Lambourne said, and could eventually be offered at 200 Marriott hotels. Depending on the size and ingredients, room-service pizzas -- identified by brand name -- cost about $1 more than those from a local Pizza Hut.
In addition to the licensing fee it collects from Marriott, Pizza Hut benefits in other ways from the partnership, which was eased by the fact that Steven S. Reinemund, the president of Pizza Hut, had been a Marriott executive.
"This gives us access to a potentially new audience of people," said Roger Rydell, the company's public affairs director. Pizza Hut has almost 7,000 stores in the United States.
Mr. Rydell said that Pizza Hut would like to talk to Radisson and Hyatt hotels, which now offer their own pizza on room-service menus. "We think their guests would prefer to have a brand product," he said. Partly in recognition of that marketing advantage, Radisson made up a brand name for its in-house product, Napolizza.
Many hotels let local managers to decide whether to make delivery arrangements with nearby restaurants, and some lodgings have long put leaflets or signs in rooms.
"If my restaurant is not open and a guest is hungry, I'll recommend restaurants in the neighborhood that will deliver," said Rich Bernhard, general manager of the Ramada Westport in Westport, Mo., near the St. Louis International Airport. It recommends three pizzarias, Domino's, Pizza Hut and Imo's, as well as a steak house that will deliver for a surcharge.
"About five years ago we tried putting in vending machines with apples and sandwiches, but it didn't go over," Mr. Bernhard said.
For security reasons, the Ramada Westport requires deliverers to report to the front desk. "They give us the room number," Mr. Bernhard said, "and we call and verify that the guest ordered."
The Homewood Suites in Jacksonville also requires deliverers to stop at the front desk.
Because Day's Inns are individually franchised, Carol Bivins, a Day's vice president, said each owner decides whether to provide food service, and what, if any, arrangements to make with nearby restaurants. "It's a rare hotelier that can turn a profit from sleeping service and food service," she said.
That's why the Day's Inn in downtown Atlanta has leased to Wendy's the space adjoining the hotel. "Before we became a Day's Inn," said Melinda Martin, the hotel manager, "another restaurant had been in that space."
Not only does Ms. Martin not mind guests bringing hamburgers and other fast food back to their rooms, "In the convention season, from January to March," she said, "we even offer room service from Wendy's."

HEADLINE: ALBANY NOTEBOOK;
At Feel-Good Event, Most Felt Rotten
BYL>By CALVIN SIMS

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
State of the State speeches are usually occasions when legislators smile, shake hands, applaud the Governor wildly or politely depending on their party and otherwise take a bath of good feelings, whether they feel good or not.
But it is a measure of the frayed mood of officials here that the pretense this year not only faded but gave way about 40 minutes into Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's speech to a shouting match between Mr. Cuomo and an Assemblyman from his own party and hometown. 
 Many legislators had been squirming in their seats as the Governor used his speech today to cast them as the enemy of widespread reforms. Specifically, Mr. Cuomo said, to avoid a repeat of last year's budget delay, elected officials should give up a day's pay for each day the budget is late. The budget was 65 days late last year.
Angered by this suggestion, Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, Democrat of Queens, interrupted Mr. Cuomo's speech, yelling: "It's good when you got a lot of dollars! It's good when you got a lot of dollars, Guv!"
Mr. Cuomo stopped in midsentence and asked Mr. Seminerio if he needed a loan. And the two men had heated words for about three minutes as the audience laughed and applauded. Mr. Coumo ended the exchange, saying he was glad that "at least everybody is awake," referring to Mr. Seminerio, who has been known to nap during sessions.
The exchange fit into the day's prevailing mood -- crabby. Like disgruntled students dragging back to class after a too-short recess, New York State's 211 legislators returned to the Capitol today to listen to the Governor's message and start a new session that is universally expected to prove the longest and most contentious in state history.
Weary Legislators
Yes, there was the normal opening-day camaraderie -- beaming grins, strong handshakes and lots of backslaps -- but there were visible signs of the contention to come.
The small talk among the crowd that crammed into the Assembly chamber for Mr. Cuomo's address was about the escalating battle between Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders over how to resolve the state's persistent budget crisis. With the end of the current fiscal year coming on March 31, the state has yet to close a budget gap of more than $875 million.
"You see a lot of smiling faces, but the truth is that most of us are not happy to be back here because we just barely left," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "The last session was so combative that I think most of us are very, very weary of the legislative process."
After Mr. Cuomo's speech, Mr. Seminerio said his comments were not intended to show disrespect for the Governor but to emphasize that state budget delays rest not with the rank-and-file members of the Legislature but with the Governor and the two top legislators leaders who have been at odds.
"I do love the Governor and he's a gentleman, and I would vote for him for President, but my mother did not raise no fools," the Assemblyman said. "I'm not going to be working for nothing."
Many legislators agreed with Mr. Seminerio. Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, called the Governor's plan to withhold legislators' salaries "coercion" and said that "many younger lawmakers who rely on their salaries to pay mortgages and bills simply could not afford it."
Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Nassau County, suggested that the Governor give up the many honorariums that he receives for speeches.
A Republican Response
In another example of the friction among politicians at the start of the new session, State Senate Republicans for the first time issued a televised response that was broadcast on the state-run system, NY-SCAN, immediately after Mr. Cuomo's speech.
The State Senate's majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Long Island Republican, attributed New York's economic problems to the "nearly two decades of Democratic control of the executive office and Assembly" in which, Mr. Marino said, "taxes, spending, fiscal mismanagement and regulatory control" spiraled out of control.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino, said the majority leader made a "special effort" to obtain television time for the response because "he sharply disagrees with the Governor over how to resolve this fiscal situation."
A Child's View
Following tradition, many legislators brought their families to the Assembly chamber to hear the Governor's address.
Six-year-old Terrance Grannis, the Assemblyman's son, said that he usually finds the speech "pretty boring" but that this year's was exciting because of the "strong man who yelled at the Governor."

HEADLINE: Grants Open Doors for Nuclear Waste

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Lured by lucrative grants, seven communities around the country have notified the Government that they are interested in becoming the site of a multibillion-dollar warehouse to store thousands of tons of high-level nuclear wastes, the Department of Energy said today.
But the notifications by the communities, among them five Indian tribes, have also stirred political dissension and raised questions about whether the Government is taking advantage of hard economic times and rural poverty to gain a site for some of the nation's most dangerous industrial wastes. 
 In Grant County, N.D., citizens opened a petition drive to recall three county commissioners who proposed studying the area as a potential nuclear waste site. Gov. George E. Sinner, a Democrat, has expressed reservations about putting such an installation in his state.
In New Mexico, where the Mescalero Apache Tribe has told the Government it would consider storing nuclear waste on its reservation, the Governor and Attorney General are the most vocal opponents. The criticism has become so fierce that Wendell Chino, the President of the tribe, declined in a short telephone interview today to discuss the project. "We've said just about all we want to say about it," he said.
 
Grants as a Carrot
 A Federal law enacted in 1987 required the Energy Department to build, by 1998, a network of concrete bunkers and buildings to temporarily store and package spent fuel rods from civilian nuclear power reactors before they are permanently entombed in the Government's high-level nuclear waste repository now under study in Nevada.
The law established an independent agency in Boise, Idaho, the Office of Nuclear Waste Negotiator, to scour the countryside for suitable sites and interested communities. A principal attraction the office can offer is the research grants that applicants can gain by considering the Monitored Retrievable Storage Facility.
Simply by applying to study the potential to build a nuclear waste installation, communities are eligible for up to $100,000 in grants from the Department of Energy. David Leroy, the United States Nuclear Waste Negotiator, said in an interview today that the communities were free to use the money almost any way they chose. Two of the seven communities have received the $100,000 grants and the rest are expected to, the Energy Department said today.
Communities that decide to pursue the idea further are eligible for a second phase of study that could provide several million dollars in grants, the Energy Department said today. In this second phase, the applicant must provide detailed scientific data to the Government. By 1993, the Energy Department hopes to have identified at least one firm site for the nuclear installation and to begin more rigorous environmental studies.
 
Former Foes Change Stance
 One of the tribes that indicated an interest is the Yakima Indian Nation in south central Washington state. Until now, the tribe was among the most vocal opponents of the Energy Department's management of nuclear waste at its Hanford nuclear weapons plant, which the Government built just east of the reservation on desert it seized from the tribe.
But last month, according to participants at the National Congress of American Indians convention in San Francisco, Russell Jim, a tribe leader, defended the decision to pursue the grants as a logical step for the 8,000-member tribe and their 1.3 million-acre reservation. Mr. Jim said the tribe's members had been living with nuclear wastes at Hanford since World War II and might be able to offer new solutions. He noted that the grants only required the tribe to study the potential for a nuclear waste installation and were not a commitment to allow the Government to begin construction.
Mr. Jim and Delano Saluskin, another tribe leader, did not return a reporter's telephone calls today.
Leaders from other tribes, including the Mescalero Apache, talked of the ambivalence toward the Government offers.
"Many of the tribes all over America are overwhelmingly dependent on Government programs and grants for basic services and jobs," said Robert T. Coulter, executive director of the Indian Law Resource Center in Helena, Mont., and a member of the Potawatomi Tribe. "When the Federal Government offers money without any obligation, it is tempting, and that is a regrettable fact of life."
 
Vulnerability of 'Colonization'
 Susan Shown Harjo, president of the Morning Star Foundation, an Indian rights advocacy group in Washington, added: "Five hundred years of colonization has done a real job on us. It makes us targets of cash and poverty politics."
John W. Bartlett, the director of the Energy Department's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management, said today the new nuclear waste installation would be large enough to temporarily store 10,000 metric tons of spent fuel from the country's more than 100 civilian nuclear power reactors. More than 22,000 metric tons of spent fuel are being stored in glowing blue pools and above-ground installations at nuclear plants across the country. By the middle of the 21st century, the amount of spent fuel is expected to grow to more than 84,000 metric tons, the Energy Department said today.
Mr. Bartlett said the technology to store and package the fuel for permanent disposal is well understood. Utilities in North Carolina, South Carolina and Virginia operate similar temporary storage installations, he said. He added that the temporary storage site was a vital nuclear installation to prepare the most dangerous radioactive wastes for permanent burial.
In 1986, the Energy Department estimated that it would take 500 people to build the waste installation, 300 to 400 people to operate it, and would cost $1.6 billion.
Along with Grant County, N.D., the Mescalero Apache tribe, and the Yakima Indian Nation, the other communities that have notified the Government of their interest are Fremont County, Wyo., the Prairie Island Indian Community fo Minnesota, the Sac and Fox Nation of Oklahoma and the Chickasaw Indian Nation of Oklahoma.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Offers Plan to Stimulate Recovery in New York Economy

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
In a State of the State address that mixed exhortation and confrontation, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo pledged today to help lift New York out of the grim hold of the recession and challenged lawmakers to undertake major improvements in the way the state manages its own finances.
The centerpiece of the Governor's recovery program was his call for an $800 million bond act that he said would spur construction projects across the state and create thousands of jobs. The proposal would not go before the voters until November, a fact bemoaned by some lawmakers today even as they praised the concept. 
 "We must pump confidence and capital and jobs into our own state economy," said the Governor, whose 55-minute address marked the 10th year he has presided over the traditional start of Albany's legislative season. "We must build a new New York with our own hands, without waiting for Washington." [Excerpts, page B9.]
 
Locked in Bitter Feud
 The Governor spoke against the stark backdrop of near-paralysis in the State Capitol, where he and lawmakers have been locked in a bitter and largely fruitless feud over how to close nearly $5 billion in budget deficits.
In an apparent bid to go over the heads of those legislators, the Governor proposed summoning a special constitutional convention to force changes in the way the state's budgets are put together. The Legislature would have to approve the convention, but it would then be run by popularly elected delegates.
Such a convention, which last met in 1967, would consider a measure that would allow the Governor's proposed budget to take effect temporarily in any year that the Legislature did not pass a budget on time, which has happened for the last seven years in a row.
Other measures advanced by Mr. Cuomo would dock the pay of the Governor and all the lawmakers for every day the budget remained late -- it was adopted 65 days past the April 1 deadline last year -- and institute a "limited initiative" ballot with which the public could force lawmakers to vote on specific bills, including the budget.
But while Mr. Cuomo characterized the convention as "one grand stroke of intelligent populism," many lawmakers derided it as demagoguery and said they were skeptical it would ever come about. And the confrontational aspect of the day was aptly symbolized by an unusual exchange between Mr. Cuomo and a Democratic Assemblyman, Anthony S. Seminerio of Queens, who interrupted the speech with an angry outburst from his seat.
"Don't tell me I won't get paid for my work -- that's political nonsense," Mr. Seminerio bellowed at the Governor. "We're here every day, 14 or 15 hours a day."
The economic proposals outlined by the Governor today combined his new call for the bond act with a package of major initiatives he has already announced, including such improvements in the infrastructure in the New York City area as a light-rail system to connect the region's airports with existing transportation lines and a huge office and housing development in Hunters Point, Queens.
And he offered several new proposals in the health and housing fields that touched on major problems but, in their relatively modest scope, illustrated the difficulties of finding financing for an all-out assault on social ills in the current economic climate. Among these were a health education campaign to counter the recent rise in tuberculosis and measles cases and a $40 million revolving-loan program to help out first-time home buyers.
 
Medical Programs
 The Governor said he would propose creation of six neighborhood emergency medical-treatment centers from Buffalo to Harlem and an "Early Care" medical program aimed at keeping infants and toddlers healthy, a move that he said might build the foundation for a universal health care program that has been shunted aside in recent years here as unaffordable.
And he pledged to consider privatization measures that ranged from the very small, like a pilot program to contract out laundry services for state mental wards, to the very large, including a proposal to sell the publicly owned World Trade Center.
Mr. Cuomo is expected to outline ways to pay for these new ideas when he presents his budget proposal for the 1992-93 fiscal year on Jan. 21. The Governor pledged today that there would be "no new taxes" in his plan.
For the first time, the State of the State address was followed by an offical Republican response that was carried on many of the same public-television stations that broadcast Mr. Cuomo's speech.
It was delivered by the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, who used it to reiterate his calls for reductions in Medicaid and welfare spending. "The growth in these programs has fueled tax increases, taken money away from road repairs and schools, and caused a structural imbalance in our budget that threatens our very ability to provide for people," he said.
Senator Marino said after the speech that his party had decided to "go on the offensive" in asking for the air time. "We thought the best way to do that is to enunciate our position, even though I don't enunciate well," he said.
 
An Interesting Contrast
 The speech today in the ornate Assembly chamber offered an interesting contrast to Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt's State of the State address in the same place 60 years ago, which offered a similar lament about Washington's inability to deal with harsh economic times.
"In any state of this union of states, the complete solving of those economic problems which are national in scope is an impossibility without leadership and a plan of action by our national government," Mr. Roosevelt said in 1932.
Today, Mr. Cuomo said, "The national Government, unable or unwilling to handle the challenge, gradually has shifted the burden to the states."
While Mr. Roosevelt's address was widely interpreted as a declaration that he would run for President, Mr. Cuomo's attack on Federal policies produced no similar speculation today because last month he firmly took himself out of the race. He cited New York's budget morass as the chief factor precluding a Presidential bid.
There was something vaguely wistful, then, about Mr. Cuomo's assault on Washington since it was coming from a man who portrayed himself today not as a potential President but as one of just dozens of governors struggling against a terrible national tide. Still, he sought to use the moment as an uplifting paean to his state, which he described as "an Empire State that has helped build this great nation from the very beginning."
Mr. Cuomo may well face an uphill struggle in securing approval of the major initiatives he outlined today. The last bond proposal, the $1.97 billion environmental bond act, was defeated by New York voters in 1990 amid concerns about adding to the state's long-term debt.
Even if the Governor gets his constitutional convention, there is no guarantee that it will change anything. The 1967 convention worked for months and proposed sweeping revisions in the organization of state agencies and the courts, only to have the entire plan rejected when it was put before the voters.
Mr. Cuomo certainly did not exempt himself from his general criticism of the way things have been run in Albany. "I'm not proud of what I have done," Mr. Cuomo said in a reference to the unresolved fight over the budget. "I'm the chief executive. I was supposed to produce a result. I failed, but so did you."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE KEY POINTS: State of the State"
 
These are some of the main proposals in Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address:

A series of measures to encourage the timely approval of a balanced budget, including temporary adoption of the Governor's proposed budget if the Legislature does not approve a fiscal plan on time.
 
Giving local school districts greater control over curriculum requirements, and changing the distribution of school aid to give more money to poor urban districts.
 
A state assumption of local Medicaid costs, as well as a series of measures to contain health-care costs and lay the foundation for universal health care. (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
Stunned Japanese Offer Sympathy As Some Are Struck by Symbolism

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 8

 BODY:
President Bush's sudden illness shook Japanese leaders today and spread shock and sympathy throughout a country that had been following his visit with great interest all week.
Television footage of Mr. Bush's collapse at the banquet at the official residence of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa was played over and over, sidelining the details of the agreements on economic cooperation and mutual security steps that were the focus of attention earlier. 
 Mr. Bush appeared to have made a highly favorable impression until now, with the Japanese enjoying scenes of his bouncing a ball on his head in Kyoto and, today, playing tennis with Emperor Akihito and his eldest son, Crown Prince Naruhito.
 
Prime Minister's Tears
 Prime Minister Miyazawa seemed to reflect the concerns of Japan as television cameras focused on him cradling Mr. Bush's head as the President sank to the floor supported by Secret Service aides and others at the banquet tonight.
At first, Mr. Miyazawa, who is 72 years old, looked dazed himself. Then, as Mr. Bush rose to his feet, he led the applause in the banquet hall. During his subsequent toast, Mr. Miyazawa's eyes filled with tears and his voice was choked with emotion, according to a person near him.
After the banquet, Mr. Miyazawa wrote by hand a letter to the President for delivery to the Akasaka Palace guest house. He especially noted the way Barbara Bush had introduced a note of relief and humor at the dinner by joking that Mr. Bush's illness was brought on by his defeat at tennis earlier in the day when the Emperor and the Crown Prince beat Mr. Bush and Michael Armacost, the American Ambassador to Japan.
"Thanks to Barbara's great help, as always, the dinner ended in great success," Mr. Miyazawa wrote, according to a Foreign Ministry official.
After the banquet, the Prime Minister left his official residence, a brown brick structure that dates from 1929, to be at his own home, a private house in the fashionable Harajuku section of the center of Tokyo.
This evening, the Prime Minister's top political adviser, Koichi Kato, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, visited the Akasaka guest house to convey Japan's concern. He met with Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser.
The Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, sent flowers to the guest house but told television reporters earlier not to worry. "It was nothing," he said on television tonight. "He was just tired."
Another dinner guest, Toshio Yamaguchi, a former Cabinet member who is a veteran member of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in Parliament, also sought to minimize the crisis atmosphere. "It was just like he had to lie down on a sofa for a while,' he told a television interviewer.
Emperor Akihito also sent a note to Mr. Bush expressing his hopes for a speedy recovery, officials said.
The vivid and dramatic image of Mr. Bush struggling in the arms of the Japanese Prime Minister seemed likely to make an indelible impression on the Japanese people, especially since it came after a trip in which the United States had been asking for steps to help its weakened economy.
 
Debate Over Symbolism
 The symbolism of the seemingly strong Mr. Bush collapsing was even compared by some to the widespread impression in Japan that the United States is reeling under the recession and is asking Japan to take steps to help it recover.
"It's so symbolic," said Naohiro Amaya, a former Deputy Minister of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, appearing on television tonight. "The superpower America is tired and everyone around it has to take care of it."
Whether such a conclusion was widespread was impossible to judge tonight, but some officials discounted the idea.
"Such symbolism is really far-fetched and I don't buy it," said Nobuaki Tanaka, director of the bureau that handles political relations with the United States. "I think what people really feel is warmth and fondness toward the President. They are relieved that he's not too ill."
Mr. Tanaka said he doubted that Mr. Bush's sickness would disrupt the array of negotiations and talks under way to deepen economic cooperation and solve a series of disputes on American demands that Tokyo buy more American-made cars and auto parts.
Senior Foreign Ministry spokesmen also came to the Okura Hotel tonight to hear the briefing of Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, and then to ask Mr. Fitzwater afterward if there was nothing more to Mr. Bush's illness. The Japanese officials said they were reassured that this was true.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Presidential Wars Behind Him, Cuomo Attacks His Legislative Foes

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo used his 10th State of the State address today to declare to both the Legislature and the state that he is no longer the political hostage of his Presidential ambitions.
Liberated of any need to position himself toward the right or to coax the Legislature into consensus, Mr. Cuomo cast himself as a strong protector of the social services safety net and as a populist crusader against legislative intransigence. 
 In a reflection of austere times, few of the initiatives Mr. Cuomo discussed today were either large or new. He focused instead on a spirited defense of social programs against recessionary budget-cutting pressures and on a package of reform proposals calculated to shame the Legislature for its inaction.
Some legislators speculated that if the Governor had chosen to run for President he would have been more wary about reinforcing his stereotype as a Northeastern liberal and about picking a fight with the Legislature.
"He seemed to be saying I can go out there now, I'm not a Presidential candidate, and I can beat you guys up anytime I want," said Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
 
A Diminished Figure
 Mr. Cuomo's decision not to run this year left him a diminished figure on the national stage, and to a certain extent within New York. But he made it clear today that he will make full use of the few political weapons still available to him -- the leverage provided by his veto power over reapportionment and the deep discontent of the public in a year when all legislators face re-election and the Governor does not.
Several legislators said the Governor may have found an effective and necessary tactic in his use of the Legislature as a foil, given the state's desperate fiscal condition and the nation's clear anti-incumbency sentiment. But they said it also could prove a risky strategy.
"It's one thing to declare a political war," said Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat. "It's another thing to declare an institutional war."
Just in case the image of a Governor unchained was not self-evident, Mr. Cuomo began his speech by paying homage to Terry Anderson, the favorite son of Batavia, N.Y., who was released last year after more than six years in captivity. Mr. Cuomo, the poet-politician, spun Mr. Anderson's story into a metaphor for New York State.
"With his fate in the hands of people he could not control, Terry Anderson resolved to do all that he could with his personal strengths," Mr. Cuomo said. "New York State, like other states, is struggling with a powerful force it cannot control, a national recession."
But by the time Mr. Cuomo concluded his 55-minute speech, listeners could wonder whether the hostage Mr. Cuomo was depicting was really the state or its Governor, and whether the oppressor was really the economy or the Legislature.
 
Blaming the Senate
 In the last three weeks, Mr. Cuomo has blamed the recalcitrance of the Republican-led State Senate for shackling his ability to run for President, for tying up the state budget and for encouraging the downgrading of the state's credit rating.
With today's speech, he seemed determined to break free of those bonds -- or at least to portray the Legislature as Albany's equivalent of the Hezbollah.
In vintage fashion, he said he would never agree to Republican proposals to reduce the size of the welfare grant and to restrict Medicaid coverage to 60 days for some recipients.
"We must change our ways, there is no doubt about that," said Mr. Cuomo, who has shown a new willingness to balance the budget with cuts in social programs. "But we must do it without losing our way, no matter how fiercely the political winds blow at the moment. We are not going to give up our integrity as a people to win an election."
Mr. Cuomo went on to highlight his reform initiatives -- few of which stand much chance of approval -- to dock the pay of elected officials who fail to pass timely budgets, to give voters the right to force legislative debate on various issues and to call a Constitutional convention to circumvent legislative resistance.
"Some of us are indignant at being accused of not functioning, but we haven't and you know it," he told the legislators, gesturing so energetically that a sign-language interpreter seemed superfluous. "And it's cost everybody money and in some cases it was as though we were doing it cavalierly."
 
A Democratic Heckler
 The defining moment of the speech, and potentially of the legislative session, came minutes later, when Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, a Queens Democrat, heckled Mr. Cuomo about his legislative pay-cut proposal.
A clear breach of legislative etiquette, Mr. Seminerio's angry outburst sent a signal across the Assembly chamber and across the airwaves that the Governor in his post-Presidential period will be just that, a Governor, and one who does not particularly intimidate the Legislature.
Even more telling was the Governor's response. Unlike two years ago, when an Act Up demonstrator interrupted Mr. Cuomo's State of the State speech with a protest against the state's AIDS policy, Mr. Cuomo did not listen politely and later commend the speaker for his cause.
Instead, he resorted to a favorite political device -- ridicule. "I'm glad that at least everybody is awake," Mr. Cuomo told Mr. Seminerio, who is known to nap at his desk occasionally. "Tony, you vote against it. At least this way we'll get a vote out of you."
Even before the speech was finished, the war against the Legislature was well under way. It was personal. And it was no holds barred.

Behind him, from the left, were the chaplain of the Assembly, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, Attorney General Robert Abrams, Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine, Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Excerpts from Address: A Plan to Fix the State

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State Address to the Legislature yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

 	 	 		. . .	 	New York State, like other states, is struggling with a powerful force it cannot control, a national recession. As a result of a decade of excesses and omissions and bad choices, the nation has lost its grip on the world economy and that is hurting us in the most fundamental ways. Businesses are closing. Millions of Americans have lost their jobs.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Reviving the Economy
 Together, the projects in that new New York plan will generate more than 100,000 jobs, more than $9 billion in economic opportunity for the state by the new millenium. 
 Now here are some of the pieces, only a few. Some of you are familiar with them already, but just to give you some sense of the dimensions and of the immense value that the new New York plan will add to the state's economic strength:
*An automatic billion-dollar people-mover, a light rail system that will connect New York's major airports to the rest of the transportation network. That's $1.6 billion, the funding already virtually guaranteed.
* The Freight Link America project that will connect New York City and Long Island to the rest of the nation.
* Queens West in Queens, overlooking Manhattan, one of the largest residential-commercial developments of its kind in the United States of America.
* The world's most extensive science, business and industry library, a library without walls -- unique, literally unique -- costs nearly $100 million, financed by private money, some Federal money, state money, etc., on its way, we've begun that project already. . . .
* Calverton Airport's conversion into a state-of-the-art transportation facility is on the list.
* Completion of the fourth lane of the Long Island Expressway, and other extensive highway work, is on the list.
* For the first time, a connection between Long Island and New England. . . . We're going to do with futuristic, high-speed ferries. This is really exciting and is going to lend a great deal of value to Long Island's economy.
* A 10-year, $300 million statewide capital improvement program for New York's unparalleled park system.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Call for Accountability
 . . . If taxpayers can be punished for failing to meet their obligations on time, then what happens when we elected officials, led by the Governor and you, are delinquent in meeting our obligations? Let's be honest. If we fail to pass timely budgets and send school districts and local governments to the brink of bankruptcy, why should we be allowed to continue enjoying our own considerable compensation, paid for by the taxpayers we punish with our delinquency, without paying some price ourselves? . . . I've given you a bill that would guarantee a timely budget by making the executive budget effective on April 1 if we fail to produce a different version before then. If you refuse that solution, I ask you please to show respect for the people we serve by passing another bill which I have given you which requires that we elected officials surrender our pay for every day that the budget is late, period.

 	 	 		. . .	 	. . . A constitutional convention could make it easier for people to run for public office. It's a disgrace how important wealth is. Everybody here knows that, that if you've got a lot of money, you have a tremendous advantage. You could be dumber, more venal, not as well intentioned and still have an advantage. Maybe we could change that. We haven't been able to do it in our system, maybe a constitutional convention could. The way you vote, the way you register, it could allow you to select judges the way these excellent judges were selected, on the merits, appoint them after they qualify on the merits. Merit selection for all judges. It could insure that Albany would never again make a late budget. It could insure a new fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Graduates March Down Aisle Into Job Nightmare

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 --
Lauren Bolfango, a recent law school graduate, works 37 1/2 hours a week researching cases, writing pleas and motions and doing other standard tasks of a new associate in a small law firm here.
What sets her apart is that she does the work without charge, after losing hope that her search for employment would ever produce a real job and deciding that volunteering in her chosen profession was better than being unemployed. 
 "I got tired of sitting around and watching soaps," said Ms. Bolfango, 27 years old, who graduated last spring from the University of California's Hastings College of Law here. She contacted 100 law firms in search of a job, without a glimmer of an offer. "I wanted to have something on my resume," she said. "I feel kind of lucky I'm doing anything at all."
Ms. Bolfango is one of thousands upon thousands of well-educated young professionals who have had the misfortune to begin their working lives in a deteriorating economy that has cut a mean swath through the white-collar work force. For some that has meant unemployment, lower wages or no wages at all. For others, it has meant deferred dreams, changed career plans or extended apprenticeships.
 
Ivy League Bartenders
 Some recent Ivy League graduates, for instance, are tending bar and driving taxicabs, and doctoral students are stalling completion of their dissertations because staying in a $20,000-a-year teaching assistantship is better than leaving a university and having no job at all. Internships that used to last for a few summer months are turning into year-round jobs at less than year-round salaries. And dean's list applicants who once preferred the riches of private industry are turning to government agencies that have entry-level slots to fill.
A turn from the private to the public sector can be costly.
Take R. David Powell, a recent graduate of Emory University Law School in Atlanta, where graduates have seen their average salaries fall to $45,000 from $48,000 in the space of the past year. Mr. Powell expected to practice real-estate law at a large firm in the city for a salary of about $50,000. Instead, he accepted a position as law clerk to Chief United States Magistrate Allen L. Chancey Jr. for $32,500 a year.
 
Blue-Collar Plight
 "I feel lucky I even have a job," Mr. Powell said. "Several people in my class who had jobs with large firms in New York got letters before their first day of work that they had been terminated."
These young people seem to understand that their hardship does not match that of their working-class peers, who are hungry for blue-collar positions that are even harder to find, who are without the blessing of advanced degrees and who, unlike Ms. Bolfango, are often without the help of credit cards, generous parents or a spouse's income. Over and over, they say they know they are lucky, although not as lucky as their friends and siblings who entered the work force in the booming 1980's.
And many are showing verve and enterprise in translating adversity into opportunity. That is the case with Andrew Yap, a recent graduate of Florida International University in Miami, who offered to intern without pay at a local business magazine, impressed his superiors and four months later wound up with exactly the marketing research job he wanted at the magazine's parent company.
But their voices still quaver with disappointment or resignation when they talk of what they are doing now versus what they expected, their prospects today versus those of friends just a few years ahead of them.
Typical is Ronald A. Sobala of Houston, a recent marketing graduate from Baylor University who has been looking for a job since graduating last December. He works part time as an electrician and lives with an uncle to save money.
"The job search has been a shock to me," said Mr. Sobala, 31, who earned $27,000 a year as a manager of a Zale's jewelery store before he returned to college in 1987. "I had high expectations of working as a country-music promoter, but I couldn't find the prestigious job I was looking for. I even tried car sales. Now I'm just making a living, trying to pay off my student loans."
Ed Funkhouser, who has a doctorate in economics from Harvard University, settled for a year-to-year teaching post at the University of California at Santa Barbara rather than a more prestigious, tenure-track job that a few years ago would have been his for the asking.
"I wish things were different, but they aren't," said Mr. Funkhouser, who earns about $5,000 less in a year then he had expected and has a heavier teaching load. "This is just the way it is. And now there are not just fewer jobs, there are more people like me who want to change."
Janet Byron, with a master's degree in journalism from the University of California at Berkeley, works as an intern at The Oakland Tribune, functioning as a full-time reporter but earning 75 percent of the regular starting salary.
"I assumed I wouldn't get a full-time job," Ms. Byron said. "I have a whole folder full of rejections. But this way I have a leg up. I have a regular byline."
Nancy Roche of LaVerne, Calif., a graduate of California Polytechnic University in Pomona, is looking for a position in marketing or personnel while working as a manicurist -- the very job that put her through college.
 
Still in Shock
 "There's zero openings in my fields now, and a few years ago people were getting hired," Ms. Roche said. "I've been hearing, 'That position is closed because we can't afford it anymore.' I'm shocked. I'm still in shock everyday."
Amy S. Redar of Chererville, Ind., a recent graduate of Indiana University who had hoped for work with the Federal or state Environmental Protection Agency, is headed instead for a Peace Corps assignment in Ecuador. "It was one of my few options," Ms. Redar said.
What distinguishes this recession from the last is the toll it is taking on white-collar jobs. In the 1981 recession, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington, 838,000 new white collar jobs were created while this time 209,000 have been lost.
"The number of options young people have is certainly narrowed," said Thomas J. Plewes, the bureau's associate commissioner for employment and unemployment statistics.
Mr. Plewes added that the contraction of opportunity in the private sector had produced an unusually high-qualified crop of young economists and statisticians for Government agencies like his own. The 20 people hired in his department last year, Mr. Plewes said, all had college grade-point averages of 3.5 or higher.
There is widespread disagreement among economists, employment agencies and college placement officials about whether the current dearth of jobs has actually forced reductions in salaries and benefits for the entry-level professionals who succeed in finding work in their chosen fields.
But experts concur that only the cream of the crop of young lawyers, bankers, engineers, professors, journalists and the like are finding the sort of jobs they expected while the rest are scaling down their aspirations, and thus their wages. And these experts say a growing number of companies, as they cut back their costly experienced work force, are expecting younger workers to do more for the same amount of money.
That threat hangs over the head of Martha Diaz, a legal secretary at a Miami law firm. "My boss said I should consider myself lucky," Ms. Diaz said, unwilling to identify her employer for fear of losing her job. "She told me that a lot of attorneys are sharing secretaries to lighten the financial burden but are not increasing their salaries. You could wind up doing double or triple the work for the same amount of money."
 
More Work for Less Pay
 Or double and triple the work for less, which is what has happened to Wendy Lamm, a photographer at The Oakland Tribune, which instituted a two-tier wage system last year as part of a plan to keep the sinking newspaper afloat. Ms. Lamm earns about $22,000 a year, 20 percent less then colleagues who were hired just weeks earlier.
Ms. Lamm is grateful for a job at a time of retrenchment in the newspaper industry, sympathetic about The Tribune's corporate plight, which has forced salary reductions for long-term employees as well, and aware that her assignments are better because she is one of only five photographers on a shrunken staff.
"I have mixed feeling, because I feel I kind of squeaked in," Ms. Lamm said. "But there's this sense that the ceiling has dropped. You can't live the way you thought you'd be able to live."

HEADLINE: Marino Says Reform Needed

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts of Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino's response to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State Address, as recorded by The New York Times.

 	 	 		. . .	 	New York State is in trouble, and we are at a crossroads. It is the opinion of Republicans that we cannot continue on the same track. The time to change direction is now. Since 1982, state spending has virtually doubled while our population has grown by only 3 percent. Spending growth has outpaced inflation by 56 percent.

 	 	 		. . .	 	New York's economic problems, fueled by taxes, spending, regulatory controls and fiscal mismanagement, spiraled out of control. . . . Today, it is the virtually automatic growth of New York's Medicaid and welfare programs that is the chief cause of our budget problems at both the state and local level. 
 Democrats have criticized Republicans for wanting to change and limit these programs. They say we are against helping the poor. That's nonsense. New York State spends almost twice what California does on Medicaid, to serve a million fewer people. . . . We must eliminate waste and duplication, we must make welfare benefits temporary, not permanent, for able-bodied people. And we must rely on lower-cost managed care programs to deliver health care to the needy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We need structural reform. The benefits we provide should be brought in line with what other states provide and there should be a residency requirement for welfare recipients, to end the practice of people coming to New York for our more generous benefits. . . . Last year, local school aid was cut by more than $700 million. The additional cuts that have been proposed would trigger property tax increases across our state. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	We can save this state, but only if we are willing to make the tough decisions to fix the budget, open the process, avoid taxes and commit ourselves to a program to re-energize New York's economy by creating jobs and opportunities to grow.
This is what Republicans will fight for.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Institutions Inject Cash Into Money Funds

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The inflow of cash into tax-exempt and taxable money market funds in the last week was huge, IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
Walter S. Frank, the publication's chief economist, said the amount of money flowing into the taxables was the highest been since the money funds were begun in the 1970's. 
 The increase in the assets came mainly from institutional investors. The seven-day compounded average yield for the tax-exempt funds dropped from 4.41 percent to 3.89, and the seven-day simple yield dropped from 4.32 percent this week to 3.82 because of seasonal factors.
During the same period, the 30-day compounded yield rose 2 basis points, to 4.01 perecent from 3.99 percent, and the simple yield rose by 2, to 3.93 from 3.91 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The top Connecticut fund was the Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.50 percent, down from 4.79 percent the previous week.
In New Jersey, the top fund was Calvert Tax Free Reserves, N.J., with a 4.40 yield, compared with 5.11 last week.
In New York, the top fund was Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund, with a yield of 4.47 percent, down from 5.20 percent.
The assets of the tax-exempt funds rose by $4.1 billion, to $95.1 billion.
IBC/Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios fell by one day, to 55.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund in Milwaukee, led the way with a 4.91 percent seven-day compound yield.
 
Taxable Assets Up
 The assets of the taxable funds were up by $26.9 billion, increasing assets to a total of $483.2 billion, from $456.3 billion the previous week. Of this, Mr. Frank said, about $21.3 billion came from institutional investors. At the beginning of the year, he said, there is traditionally a large inflow of funds.
The average days to maturity of the taxables this week fell by three days, to 56.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell to 4.49 percent, from 4.61 the previous week, with the simple yield at 4.40 percent, compared with 4.51 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was down four basis points, to 4.62 from 4.66 percent, and the simple yield to 4.52 from 4.56.
The taxable fund with the best return was Prudential Command Money Fund with a return of 5.69 percent, some of which could be attributed to realized capital gains.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 4.06 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Florio's Education Panel Offers Many Changes, at a Hefty Price

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
An educational study commission appointed by Gov. Jim Florio recommended a host of costly changes in the state's school system today, including adding 40 days to the school year and providing preschool to every 3- and 4-year-old in the state. But the panel offered no suggestions about how to pay for them.
The co-chairmen of the Governor's Quality Education Commission conceded that political and economic realities would make such changes extremely difficult, but dismissed suggestions that the recommendations were too visionary to come to pass. 
 "Can we afford some of these things?" asked James Cullen, the president and chief executive officer of New Jersey Bell and a co-chairman of the commission, which in the last year studied educational priorities at the behest of the Governor.
"We cannot afford not to," said Mr. Cullen. "We cannot afford not to deal with them."
The 29-member commission's 20 recommendations, which the panel said were intended to spur statewide discussion and debate, were handed to Governor Florio and the Board of Education today. They call for extending the school year to 220 days from the present 180 by the year 2000, lengthening the school day itself and providing "high-quality" preschool education to 3- and 4-year-olds.
 
A Shopping List of Ideas
 The panel also recommended a school refurbishment program that alone would cost $6 billion.
Mr. Cullen and the other co-chairman, P. Michael Timpane, president of Teachers College at Columbia University, said the commission made no attempt to assess costs of its recommendations, essentially creating a shopping list without price tags.
The ambitious proposals will certainly bring enormous costs to a state that already spends $10 billion, 40 percent of its total combined state and local revenue each year, on education, and has the nation's highest per-pupil expenditure, $9,410 in 1991.
The state's Education Commissioner, John Ellis, is laying plans to extend the school year, a move whose cost is an estimated $2 billion a year, mostly for increased teacher salaries and air-conditioning.
That means the recommendations will likely face tough sledding in a state already in the throes of a tax rebellion. Other commission proposals like consolidating some school districts to cuts administrative costs are likely to run into opposition because they threaten to dilute local control and raise the specter of combining urban and suburban school populations.
The commission co-chairmen emphasized that the recommendations for school consolidation were not intended to achieve racial integration, as has been suggested by the State's Public Advocate, Wilfredo Caraballo, and by Mr. Ellis. The idea has generated a storm of opposition.
Both the commission and Mr. Ellis said efforts at school consolidation were desirable not necessarily to achieve integration, but to improve educational quality and cut administrative costs.
Indeed, Mr. Ellis said in an interview that he did not want the question of consolidation to focus on racial balance and thus lead to emotional rather than rational debate. "If you introduce desegregation into consolidation, it is so polarizing you can't discuss the issue," Mr. Ellis said.
"Our society is unfortunately so race conscious" he said, "that introducing racial balance into the debate will probably be counterproductive."
 
Merger Proposals
 But New Jersey has about 600 school districts, and the commission recommends that any that do not provide a full kindergarten-through-12th-grade curriculum or that have an enrollment of fewer than 2,500 students be consolidated by the 1997-98 school year.
The commission recommended that a list of such schools be prepared, and that the list as a whole be either accepted or rejected by the Governor to avoid endless bargaining and revisions, and that it be automatically implemented unless rejected by the Legislature.
Some districts have fewer than 100 students -- one Hunterdon County district was said by the panel to have only 56 students -- and consolidation could pare the number of districts from 600 to about 250, Mr. Cullen said.
The panel's recommendations brought mixed reactions. The League of Women Voters, for example, was highly critical of a call for the state to continue to pay for all of teachers' pensions and social security costs.
 
Mixed Reactions
 Under the Governor's Quality Education Act, these costs were to be transferred to the local school districts, but the panel recommended full funding by the state.
But the League said full state funding would "undermine equal educational opportunity" because more affluent districts receive more money that poorer districts under state funding formulas.
The League maintained that state pension payments amount to $1,066 per pupil in Millburn and $1,037 in Ridgewood, compared with $522 in Camden and $617 in Irvington.
And while the current State Senate President, John A. Lynch, praised the recommendations as "insightful and well thought-out," the incoming chairman of the Assembly Education Committee, John A. Rocco, a Republican of Camden, criticized the committee for failing to recommend "fundamental changes in school finance"
The New Jersey School Boards Association, however, praised the recommendations as "forward-looking." While acknowledging that many of the proposed innovations, like expanding early childhood education, would require a substantial amount of money, the organization said the report should not be declared "dead on arrival simply because of today's difficult economic times."
The potential benefits are simply too great, the organization said.

Michael Timpane, co-chairmen of the Governor's Quality Education Commission, spoke to reporters in Trenton. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Broke Comptroller

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 8

 BODY:
As the head of an accounting firm here that bears his name, Michael J. Maunsell made it his business to oversee the financial affairs of others. His clients included individuals and more complicated accounts, like that of the neighboring town of Southbury.
Those were the credentials that swept the political newcomer to victory last November when he ran for city comptroller on the Democratic ticket, a ticket that pledged fiscal responsibility for this onetime manufacturing center, which has stumbled badly under the combined effects of municipal scandal and the recession. 
 Thus, it was a shock for residents to learn today that Mr. Maunsell had filed for personal bankruptcy on Dec. 31, one day before taking his oath of office. Citing liabilities of $6.9 million and assets of $261,739, Mr. Maunsell and his wife, Eleanore, declared personal bankruptcy in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Hartford.
His debts, largely a result of failed real-estate investments, are considerably more than the city's own $4 million deficit.
While Mr. Maunsell is not charged with any crime and other officials were quick to point out that his problems are personal, not professional, some residents were clearly fed up with their public officials.
 
'Par for the Course'
 "All of a sudden, now, it comes out?" said an incredulous Fred Ruscitto, who was walking down Grand Street, Waterbury's boulevard of government buildings, buttoned up against the chill wind this afternoon. "Oh, sure. Seven million dollars, and you don't know about it till now? It should be pretty obvious."
"This isn't new at all," Mr. Ruscitto said, adding that he had voted for an independent candidate, Josephine Mills, for mayor. "This is par for the course."
Mr. Maunsell responded to requests for comment with a prepared statement, in which said he had filed for bankruptcy "to provide a fresh start for both myself and my family." The statement continued: "The need to file bankruptcy arose from my inability to sell real-estate investments made in the 80's. I regret the need to file personal bankruptcy and hope that you will understand."
Mr. Maunsell is not alone among Waterbury officials with legal problems.
The city's former Mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, left office charged with an assortment of Federal crimes, among them receiving bribes, embezzlement and fraud. He is to go on trial next month. The current Mayor, Edward D. Bergin Jr., was acquitted in state court last April on charges of taking illegal payments from a towing company.
In his statement, Mr. Maunsell said he expected the bankruptcy filing "to have no adverse effect on my business or on my ability to manage the finances of the City of Waterbury."
 
'The Bottom Line'
 But some residents were not so sure. "This affects a lot of people in the city," said Joanne Silva, who works in a downtown stationery store, looking back at Waterbury's recent political history. "It's just a sad situation. The bottom line is greed, and deception, and it affects people's trust."
The Republican leader of the city's aldermen, Nicholas P. Augelli, said he declined to comment on Mr. Maunsell's situation "until all the facts are in." The chairman of the city's Democratic Party, Gary J. Reardon, said Mr. Maunsell's situation was, by and large, news to him. "I had heard a few things, that he may have been having trouble," Mr. Reardon said. "I was surprised at the extent of it. I wish him the best."
Among Mr. Maunsell's creditors is Citytrust, a Connecticut bank that was seized by Federal regulators last year. Mr. Maunsell was a partner in an investment group that took out a $5.6 million loan for a real-estate project. He also made investments in the Colonial Realty Company, a Hartford-based concern that went bankrupt in 1990, taking with it several banks and dozens of small investors.
 
Entire Amount of Loans
 Mayor Bergin said he had confidence in Mr. Maunsell's ability to do his job despite his personal problems. "He is at work today," said the Mayor, "and he will be at work tomorrow and the rest of the week." He added, "What he is going through, a great number of people are going through."
Mr. Maunsell was being pursued by creditors for the entire amount of loans taken out by an investment group in which he was a partner, Mr. Bergin said.
Colonial Realty figured prominently in the indictment of Mr. Santopietro, the former Mayor. Government prosecutors contend that he took bribes from Colonial officials in return for investing $1 million in city employees' pension funds with the company.

HEADLINE: Woolworth Cuts Back On Stores

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Facing a persistently weak economy, the Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close, sell or reformat 900 of its 6,500 stores in the United States during the next 18 months.
Woolworth, which over its 113 years turned to selling clothes, shoes and sporting equipment after starting out as a simple variety store, said that half the closed stores would be reopened as faster-growing types of Woolworth stores. The company said that less than half of the 10,000 workers at the stores would lose their jobs. 
 The stores to be closed include about 500 clothing stores, 300 Kinney Family Shoe stores and 90 Woolworth stores, which together lost $50 million from January last year through October.
 
Redeploying Assets
 "Unfavorable economic conditions, that contributed to these results, have greatly accelerated the urgency and magnitude of our store closing and redeployment program," said Harold E. Sells, Woolworth's chairman and chief executive. The company characterized the move as a part of a continuing program to funnel assets to its fastest-growing units, which include Champs Sport, a sports clothing and equipment chain, Lady Foot Locker, a women's athletic shoe store, and Northern Reflections, an outdoor clothing store for women.
"We are taking the losers and trying to turn them into winners," Mr. Sells said.
The closings will lead to a charge of $250 million, or $1.92 a share, against the company's fourth-quarter earnings.
Woolworth, which got its start in 1879, when Frank Woolworth opened the Great Five Cent Store in Lancaster, Pa., has been expanding since 1982 beyond its slow-growing variety store business. Unable to compete directly with the large discount department stores, like Wal-Mart Stores Inc., on price and selection, Woolworth has been emphasizing convenience by concentrating the variety business on small Woolworth Express stores, selling items from toothpaste to film, in urban locations. The Woolworth stores themselves have found it increasingly difficult to compete with the discount giants.
 
One Big Success
 The company's biggest success has been with its Foot Locker stores, which have more than $1 billion in annual sales in the United States, out of a total of about $5.5 billion.
For the year ended January 1991, Woolworth had worldwide sales of $9.8 billion and profits of $317 million. The company has 9,300 stores in 11 countries, including the 6,500 in the United States. Woolworth said that the stores to be closed employ 4,700 full-time and 5,300 part-time employees. Mr. Sells said more than half the workers would be offered other jobs within the company. Woolworth has 70,000 employees in the United States.
The closings are spread out throughout the United States and are not concentrated in any particular area, a company spokeswoman said. .
Woolworth's closings are part of a general post-Christmas upheaval among retailers. Since the third dismal holiday selling season in a row ended last month, Zale, the Dallas-based jewelry retailer, announced it was closing 400 outlets; Seaman's, the largest furniture retailer in the Northeast, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, and the apparel retailer Hartmarx said it was consolidating its specialty and discount stores.
Analysts said Woolworth was taking a positive step to improve its profits. "Because of the uncertain economy, they have to close some of their upprofitable operations," said Walter Loeb, a retail consultant in New York. "They will see an immediate payback."
 
Stores With Potential
 Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst with Salomon Brothers, said, "They are concentrating on those stores and business which have the most favorable long-term growth potential."
Woolworth's stock rose $1.50 yesterday, to $29 a share, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Of the clothing stores being closed, Woolworth is shutting 207 women's apparel boutiques that do business under the Susie's and Sportelle names, including the Susie's store that is in the landmark Woolworth Building in lower Manhattan.
The company plans to convert those locations into other formats. The struggling Susie's stores were unable to compete with more fashionable retailers.
Woolworth also said it planned to close its 268-store Richman Brothers/Anderson-Little men's and women's apparel shops, along with three manufacturing plants. Woolworth said it would try to sell the Richman Brothers/Anderson-Little unit as an operating company.
The 300 Kinney family shoe stores being closed represent one-quarter of the total Kinney stores. And 90 Woolworth general merchandise stores out of 1,000 are being shut.
In a recent report on Woolworth, a retail analyst for the investment firm of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, Richard N. Baum, called Kinney Family Shoe stores "a survior in a declining segment." Mr. Baum said Kinney profits had come under pressure because of competition from more focused sellers of athletic shoes and women's shoes.
 
Opening Up Locations
 Mr. Sells of Woolworth said the store closings "will give us an immediate inventory of good locations" for the company's faster-growing businesses.
Mr. Sells said 10 percent of the company's stores in the United States were in space formerly occupied by a different type of company store.
Many of the Susie's stores will be converted into Northern Reflections, an outdoor store developed in Canada that has been popular with consumers. There are 30 such stores in the United States, and Mr. Sells said there might be 500 within five years.
Mr. Feiner of Salomon Brothers said the stores had "demonstrated the ability to grow at very high rates businesses that they developed initially."
The company's fast-growing Lady Foot Locker division will also move into some of the Susie's locations.
But Mr. Loeb, the analyst, warned that the women's shoe business was becoming increasingly crowded and that the company's growth in that area might slow.
Woolworth also said yesterday that an accounting change related to pension issues would lead to a charge of $115 million, or 88 cents a share, in its current fiscal year.
The company also said it planned capital expenditures of $400 million in the year beginning Jan. 26, 1992, mostly for opening 850 stores worldwide. This amount includes expenditures for stores to be opened in space freed up by the closing of underperforming stores.

HEADLINE: Contributions To Neediest Aid Homeless

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
"The other day as our 4-year-old was festooning the living room, he suddenly stopped to ask, 'Do homeless people have any Christmas decorations?' " Anna Mayer of Dobbs Ferry wrote in a note with her family's $100 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
"When I told him I thought most homeless people didn't, he thought for a minute. Then he ran to the hallway where he had hung his favorite, most colorful ornament. 'Let's send them this one,' he said. He put it gently into a shoe box. Back in the living room he picked up another ornament to put into the shoe box. 'Maybe they would like to have two,' he said. Our family's donation is in honor of Daniel and his spirit of giving." 
 That spirit to help society's most public and persistent symbols of need has prompted scores of people to designate their Neediest Cases donations for the homeless.
Stanley Rosenfeld of Manhasset, L.I., said he was moved to give after a disturbing experience. After attending a performance at Lincoln Center, he said, he was "surprised to see homeless people sleeping outside this magnificent edifice." He said he hoped his $50 donation "can somehow help these unfortunate people particularly since the weather is turning cold."
 
More Than 'a Little Change'

 
 The daily frustration of seeing the homeless but not knowing how to help in a meaningful way led Sumiko Patrone of Manhattan to give $50. "I have never given money to homeless people when I pass by on the street even though I feel pain to look at them," he wrote. "I believe that we, as a society, should have some kind of program to place them in proper living condition instead of giving them a little change now and then."
Mr. Patrone's donation combined with thousands of others helps buy food and clothing to meet the immediate needs of homeless people. The seven charities supported by the Neediest Cases also the use the money to run programs that pull people out of homelessness. The Children's Aid Society, for example, uses money from the Neediest Cases to maintain 34 apartments for homeless families to live in while they are helped to find permanent housing.
The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies uses the money for the Open Door, a center on Ninth Avenue and 41st Street that provides up to 220 homeless people with food and shelter each day.
Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases Fund has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. The Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to the seven charities.
Last year the Fund raised $4.4 million. This year's appeal, conducted against a background of poverty and economic anxiety made even more pervasive by the recession, topped the $4 million mark yesterday, with two months to go.
Dan Margulis and Carole Kahrs of Princeton, N.J., who did not want the amount of their donation disclosed, wrote, "Those people who hesitate to give spare change to people begging on the streets for fear they that they don't really need it or will use the money unwisely, can, through your fund, do something to directly address the enormous problem of homelessness in this city."
Brenda Hilsberg of Manhattan, who gave $50, echoed their sentiments. "Thanks for making it possible for those of us who care to help ease the burden for those less fortunate than we."
