HEADLINE: Many Electronics Makers Avoid Recession's Brunt

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 8

 BODY:
As the consumer electronics industry meets today at a mammoth semiannual show here, the nation's purveyors of color television sets, videocassette recorders, car stereos and cellular telephones can look back at 1991 as a year in which they escaped the worst effects of the recession. Sales actually rose.
Figures released this week by the Electronic Industries Association, the consumer electronics trade group, show that factory sales totaled a record $33.9 billion, up 2.9 percent from the year before. Since electronics prices were virtually unchanged, or in some cases lower than a year earlier, inflation-adjusted sales rose by more than 3 percent. 
 That passes for success when retailers and most other consumer-products companies watched in dismay as Christmas shoppers, hands nowhere near their wallets and purses, hummed past holiday displays and said politely, "Just looking."
 
Ever-Optimistic Exhibitors
 Home computer and cellular phone sales were strong as entrepreneurs and small businesses looked for new ways to gain efficiency and sales. Color televisions remained the best-selling category, but sales were almost flat, while camcorders gained popularity as consumers sought to upgrade their video systems.
About 1,500 ever-optimistic exhibitors have gathered under the sunny, if slightly chilly, Nevada skies this week. They have rented a record 840,000 square feet -- about two-and-a-half times the area of the Great Pyramid of Cheops -- at the Las Vegas Convention Center and three hotels. About 75,000 people, mainly buyers from retail chains, will see the latest in new products.
Veterans of these shows complain that they see only permutations of some hardy perennial products, but nothing truly new. Among this year's permutations are televisions shaped more like movie screens so that wide-screen epics like "Lawrence of Arabia" are not chopped on the left and right, like the mythological Procrustes who shortened his victims to fit his iron bed.
The set, under the RCA label, is made by Thomson Consumer Electronics, a unit of the French giant that owns the RCA and General Electric television brands. It has proportions of 16 by 9 compared with the typical 4 by 3 and is scheduled for distribution to leading retailers this year.
Still, there are some genuine innovations. Just as the compact disk has eclipsed the long-playing vinyl record and is beginning to hurt tape cassette sales, the music industry will now attempt to interest listeners in two newer formats: the Sony Corporation's mini-disk, a recordable disk smaller than current compact disks; and Philips N.V.'s digital compact cassette, a tape that can carry and record digital music.
Many in the industry say Sony and Philips are being more cautious than expected about introducing these media, apparently fearing consumer confusion and resistance. But the sales of blank audio cassettes totaled $357 million last year, down about 5 percent, so the industry is interested in another recording medium to revive sales.
Some traditional big-ticket items fared poorly in 1991, according to the Electronic Industries Association figures. Color televisions and projection televisions, the biggest-selling category of consumer electronic products, with $7 billion of sales, were up about 1 percent; videocassette recorders, with $2.5 billion, were up by about the same percentage, and audio components, about $2 billion, were up even less than that.
Companies like Panasonic and Yamaha say sales of stereo receivers, which would seem to be postponable expenses, are flat over all. Mainly, the expensive units are selling well. Consumers are buying better equipment, said Steve C. Girod, vice president of marketing for the Yamaha Electronics Corporation of Buena Park, Calif.
 
'Surround Sound' Effect
 Many consumers are upgrading their color televisions and videocassette recorders by improving the sound with better speakers and receivers. New features give "surround sound" effects like those in a movie theater, so the Terminator's sawed-off shotgun sounds like it is roaring just behind the living-room rhododendrons.
Those big-ticket items used by business people, or newer to the market, sold especially strongly. Cellular telephones, which can cost up to $2,500 apiece, totaled about $1.4 billion in sales. That was a 9.3 percent gain for the year, the largest rise of any leading category of electronic products. Camcorders, the little video cameras that cost up to $1,000, were the second-strongest growth segment, with $2.4 billion in sales, up 5.8 percent.
Home computers were relatively popular, too. With 1991 sales of $4 billion, they grew about 6 percent. With the economy in such a poor state, the Tandy Corporation said, many of its units are being bought by small businesses or by professionals working feverishly at home. "The only difference these days between a home and an office computer is where it's located," said Edward Juge, director of market planning for Tandy, based in Fort Worth. "People are looking for computer horsepower wherever they are, and the recession just heightens that need."
Car stereos, especially the expensive ones, often costing around $800, grew 5.5 percent, with annual sales of $4.5 billion. Many drivers are buying fancy compact-disk changers that hold four or five CD's, or a whole traffic jam's worth of music. "They're putting the bigger changers in their trunk," said Jack De Basio, national product planning manager for the Clarion Corporation of America in Gardena, Calif., with a note of glee in his voice.
Sales of many little-ticket items were especially slow. Portable tape and compact-disk players, which cost from $25 to $300, had sales of about $1.6 billion, down 3 percent from the year before. Sales of telephones, both conventional and cordless, were flat at about $1.15 billion, although they usually cost well under $100 apiece.
As for the longer-term trends, a new study by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, a New York investment banking firm, found that Americans are spending less time on leisure activities, but more time listening to recordings and watching videocassettes.
The survey, comparing how adults spent their leisure time in 1985 and 1990, found that annual leisure activities declined from an average of 3,307 hours in 1985 to 3,262 hours in 1990, or by nearly two full days. Americans spent less time watching network television, listening to the radio and reading newspapers and magazines, according to the survey.
But the average American spent more time listening to recorded music (up 27 percent) and a lot more time watching recorded videocassettes (up 233 percent).

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Tandem Sees Cuts and Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CUPERTINO, Calif., Jan. 8

 BODY:
Citing the recession and changes in the industry, Tandem Computers Inc. said today that it would restructure operations and would likely post an operating loss for its first fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 31.
Tandem, known for computers with redundant parts to prevent breakdowns, said it would take a $90 million restructuring charge for the quarter. The company did not estimate the amount of the loss but said it would not be solely because of the restructuring. 
 "We believe the economic framework of the computer industry is changing," said James G. Treybig, Tandem's president and chief executive.
The restructuring -- including consolidation of offices and work force reductions -- should save $40 million to $50 million in the 1992 fiscal year and $90 million to $100 million in 1993.
Tandem has cut the number of employees by 3 percent since July, to slightly more than 11,000, and expects an additional 6 percent reduction during the 1992 fiscal year.
Tandem shares rose $1.25 a share today, closing at $12.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Borrowing Restrained

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8

 BODY:
Consumers kept a tight rein on their use of credit in November, the Federal Reserve Board said today, paying off more in car and bank loans than they took out.
As a result, outstanding credit balances expanded by a slight $27 million after revised growth of $1.67 billion in October and $43 million in September. 
 Originally, the Fed said October consumer credit expanded by $802 million.
Consumer reluctance to borrow and spend in the face of high unemployment is considered a key factor in the economy's difficulty in struggling out of recession.
Purchases of goods and services by consumers fuels about two-thirds of economic activity, so a spending slowdown quickly leads to production cuts.
The most obvious area of continuing slack credit demand was in loans for new cars, which fell in November by $952 million after contracting by $211 million in October and $1.68 billion in September.
Consumers paid off more in car loans than they took out in each of the first 11 months of 1991 as car dealers rang up their poorest sales year since 1983.
Credit charged on credit cards expanded in November by $1.01 billion, lower than the increases of $1.59 billion registered in October and $2.62 billion in September.
Other credit, including bank loans but not home mortgages, was cut back by $160 million in November after growing by $235 million in October but shrinking by $288 million in September.
Credit for the purchase of mobile homes grew in November by $125 million after a $51 million increase in October. This category was down by $603 million in September, the Fed said.
At the end of November, consumers owed a total of $733 billion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Minolta in U.S. Gives Up President's Job

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
After 22 years as the head of the American subsidiary of the Minolta Camera Company, Sadahei Kusumoto is finally going to be able to concentrate on the part of the job he likes best: representing Minolta to the outside world.
Mr. Kusumoto, who is currently president and chief executive of the Minolta Corporation, will become chairman and chief executive on Jan. 25, turning over the post of president to Osamu Kanaya, who will also be named chief operating officer. 
 "We were only selling cameras when I first came from Japan in 1954," Mr. Kusumoto said. "Now business equipment is bigger than cameras, and it's much more complicated."
Mr. Kusumoto, 63, has been among the most visible Japanese executives in the United States and, according to Minolta, he has now been here longer than any other Japanese manager of an American subsidiary. During his tenure, the Minolta Corporation's sales have risen to $780 million from $11 million.
In recent years, Mr. Kusumoto has been active in the United Way and has advised other Japanese executives on the importance of philanthropic activities in American corporate life. He has also organized contacts between Japanese and black executives to fight perceptions of Japanese racism.
The combination of those activities and a heavy travel schedule to maintain relations with Minolta's 500 equipment distributors has increasingly left his desk in Ramsey, N.J., stacked with work related to internal problems, Mr. Kusumoto said. Now such day-to-day problems will become the responsibility of Mr. Kanaya, 57, a Minolta Camera director who has held a number of financial, planning and administrative positions since joining the company at its Osaka headquarters in 1957.
Mr. Kusumoto said that Mr. Kanaya would be inheriting a tough assignment.
"The recession here is going to last longer than everyone expected," Mr. Kusumoto said. "It's important to organize the company to deal with it. On top of the recession, we have the problem that the yen is getting stronger. It will require great attention to detail."
What advice will he give Mr. Kanaya when he arrives from Japan? "Talking frankly," Mr. Kusumoto said, "is the key to success in the United States."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
G.P.U.'s Chief Started At the Ground Level

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
James R. Leva became president and chief executive of the General Public Utlities Corporation yesterday, 40 years after starting there as a ground hand digging holes for utility poles.
Mr. Leva, 59 years old, had been president and chief operating officer of Jersey Central Power and Light, a subsidiary company based in Morristown, N.J., since 1986. In taking the helm at the holding company, he succeeds William G. Kuhns, who was brought out of retirement last May to replace Standley H. Hoch. Mr. Hoch resigned because of a controversy over his personal relationship with a woman who was then G.P.U.'s vice president for corporate communications. 
 Mr. Leva, who came to Jersey Central Power in 1952 after serving two years with the Marines in Korea, later became a lineman. Then, as a night troubleman, he put himself through Fairleigh Dickinson University, where he earned an electrical engineering degree magna cum laude. He served as a union shop steward and later as vice president for personnel, safety and services, among other posts. He received a law degree from Seton Hall University in 1980 and served as mayor of Morris Township, N.J., for two terms, as well as in various other government posts.
Speaking of his rise from ground hand to the top of the corporate ladder, he said in a telephone interview: "There is less and less of an opportunity for that to happen. I really don't know why. But we seem to take more professionals out of college." He added that he did not know of any linemen working their way through college now.
The holding company, with 1991 revenues of about $3.2 billion, is one of the 20 largest investor-owned utilities, serving 1.9 million customers over an area comprising about half of Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
A key issue for G.P.U., which is based in Parsippany, N.J., is the national debate over transmission access. That involves the terms under which outsiders -- either independent generators or distant utilities -- are allowed to ship power over the lines of a company like G.P.U. to sell to customers who are far away, or even in G.P.U.'s service territory.
Opening up the system would increase competition, but Mr. Leva said: "It's really hard to put a handle on what this transmission access will bring. Our solution is not to be mean -- but lean and flexible."
The company's revenues have declined lately, and Mr. Leva said that if the weather stayed mild, they might not rebound, even though he expects the recession to ease in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: Orders Down At Airbus

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 8

 BODY:
The four-nation European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie said today that its new orders fell to about 100 last year, down sharply from 404 in 1990 and below the forecasts of 145 for 1991.
An Airbus spokesman also said the group delivered slightly fewer than the 170 jets it forecast for 1991. In 1990, it delivered 95 aircraft, with the number held down by a strike at one of its partners. 
 The spokesman declined to give exact 1991 order and delivery figures, saying those would be announced by Jean Pierson, an Airbus managing director, at a news conference Thursday.
"Everybody's orders are down this year," the spokesman said. "It was, as we expected, a lot worse than previous years."
All civil aircraft makers expected orders to plunge in 1991 because of the losses suffered by most world airlines and because a pause was likely after the buying binge in the late 1980's.
Airlines have been hurt by economic downturns in the United States and Western Europe and by the Persian Gulf crisis of late 1990 and early 1991, which caused world airline traffic to drop steeply.
Airbus is a consortium made up of Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace P.L.C., Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain and the Deutsche Airbus unit of Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany.
It booked a record 421 orders in 1989.

HEADLINE: A 1930's Visionary Who Looked Back And Saw Santa Fe

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
BEFORE the Range Rovers, the howling coyote sculptures and Santa Fe (the fragrance), there was an architect named John Gaw Meem, whose wildly romantic Spanish Pueblo revival houses, built primarily in the 1930's, set the stage for it all.
Mr. Meem arrived in this luminous landscape of pinon and juniper in 1920. From 1924 until his death in 1983, he designed houses and churches, municipal and university buildings that married the spirit of native pueblo architecture with the necessities of the modern world. 
 With deliberately battered corners and other atmospheric effects, he created what Chris Wilson, a cultural historian, calls "pueblo getaways from the modern world." Despite the recent preponderance of blue-corn gourmets and Anglos longing to be Navajos, Mr. Meem's imagery -- exotic fantasies of life in the Southwest -- endures.
His houses, which number around 150 in and around Santa Fe, were designed for wealthy, spirited clients, including East Coast sophisticates and women of opinion. In the early 1930's, Amelia Beard Hollenback, who was the first woman to photograph a Hopi snake dance, instructed Mr. Meem, "I want something extremely informal that will let us amuse ourselves with old ways and old things, but may Heaven preserve it from looking Arty!"
"Daddy was fortunate in having very paternalistic clients," said Nancy Wirth, Mr. Meem's daughter, who still lives where she grew up, in a two-story stone house designed by her father in 1937. "He used to say that the best clients were the ones who sat down with him, told him what they wanted and then went to Europe for the year."
Mr. Meem's influence is found in the portals of the Plaza in Santa Fe, which were added in 1969; in a 1929 renovation of La Fonda Hotel; in the Laboratory of Anthropology, and in the main campus of the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, which contains some 30 buildings designed by Mr. Meem.
But it extends to more than his architecture. As chairman of the city Planning Commission, he helped develop the city's first master plan in 1947, which helped protect the character of downtown Santa Fe.
As chairman of the New Mexico Society for the Restoration and Preservation of New Mexico Mission Churches, Meem the preservationist personally restored dozens of historic mission churches, including those at Acoma, Laguna and Zia pueblos.
Today, the cult of John Gaw Meem, who was an engineer by training and never completed his formal architectural training, flourishes among regional architects. Last summer, the Historic Santa Fe Foundation, a private preservation group, organized a special John Gaw Meem house tour. "He's arguably the single most important person in the way the city looks today," said Mr. Wilson, who is writing a book for the University of New Mexico Press called "The Myth of Santa Fe."
His buildings, Mr. Wilson added, "still serve as the ideal image of Santa Fe style."
In other words, John Gaw Meem made Santa Fe safe for Ralph Lauren.
Mr. Meem drew inspiration from regional architecture, but his designs were very much his own. In a 12-room summer house built in 1930 for Eleanor Brownell and Alice Howland near Bishop's Lodge, it is necessary to duck one's head and step high over the raised thresholds when passing through the antique doors. To simulate the earthen floors of early New Mexican houses, which were treated with ox blood to keep them free of dust, Mr. Meem used a dark-brown mastic covering somewhat like linoleum.
The house is arranged like a traditional hacienda, with a chain of rooms gathered around a placita, or open courtyard. The late architectural historian Bainbridge Bunting, who wrote a monograph on Mr. Meem, referred to such houses as "inscapes," a poetic meeting of pueblo spirit and the material world.
Laban Wingert, a Santa Fe architect, has the delicate task of helping a couple who remodeled the house unsympathetically bring it back to Mr. Meem's original plan. "Mr. Meem had such a wonderful sense of form," he observed. "Every corner and projection was thought out."
Each Meem house is a miniature world: quiet, comforting spaces with flickering fireplaces that keep the tumult of the modern world at bay. Like the houses of the California architects Greene & Greene, they seem both aged and ageless, appearing to have magically sprouted from the soil.
These days, cutesy shops overrrun the Plaza and the most authentic-feeling place downtown is Woolworth's. It is difficult to imagine that in 1920, the pueblo style, which now attracts tourists like flypaper, was on the decline.
When Mr. Meem first came to Santa Fe, to recuperate from tuberculosis, the vogue was not flat-roof adobe dwellings but pitched-roof houses with expanses of glass imported from St. Louis and Kansas City. Along with the artist and photographer Carlos Vierra and others, Mr. Meem advocated a return to vernacular styles, the more weathered-looking and beat-up, the better.
"Some old forms are so honest, so completely logical and native to the environment," he once wrote, "that one finds -- to one's delight and surprise -- that modern problems can be solved and are best solved by use of forms based on tradition."
Santa Fe was hardly the typical small town, even in 1920. It was the adventurous bohemian's alternative to Paris and Greenwich Village. During his stay at the Sunmount Sanatorium, Mr. Meem hobnobbed with other wealthy patients. As there is today, there was an unusual abundance of potential commissions for the right architect.
Mr. Meem's houses, photographed by Ansel Adams and Laura Gilpin, contemporaries he hired to record his work, physically embody the Santa Fe fantasy. They have mellowed beyond preciousness and are almost excruciatingly civilized. From chunky wooden chandeliers made from church beams to rustic plank flooring, they are distinctive for their understated but abundant use of ornament, much of it adapted from graphic pueblo and Spanish designs.
In one living room, for instance, Mr. Meem designed a herringbone-pattern ceiling using vigas (unmilled ceiling beams in the natural shape of a tree), and latillas (golden-colored aspen poles stripped of their bark). Lowly details like mirror frames and radiator covers were excuses for handcrafted stamped-tin motifs drawn from Indian and Spanish sources. Mr. Meem's sense of graciousness also led him to lavish attention on hallways and other forgotten household spaces.
A number of Mr. Meem's best clients were collectors who scoured the countryside for church beams and other antique architectural details. Amelia Hollenback, who spent the autumn months in Santa Fe to attend Indian ceremonial dances, was an astute and voracious collector.
"It's lots of fun," she wrote Mr. Meem of her shopping sprees while her house was being planned. "I wish we were building a village."
Completed in 1932, her house was the apotheosis of the genre, a "domestic cloisters for the Southwest," in Mr. Wilson's words. Like many of Mr. Meem's houses, it has intentionally wobbly silhouettes and rounded corners, giving the impression of having been eroded over time.
The size of the rooms was dictated by the dimensions of the old beams Miss Hollenback collected. Among her prizes, seamlessly incorporated into the architecture, are a large number of Spanish colonial doors, carved beams from Acoma and Gran Quivira, a historic pueblo site, and a rare carved portal beam from 1828 decorated with hex signs and archaic Spanish writing.
"Amelia was out collecting the things that everyone else was throwing away," said Mary Jean Cook, who now owns the 15-room house with her husband Dr. Edward S. Cook. "Meem listened to her ideas, and thank God he did."
The Cooks purchased the house, which was hardly used after its completion, in 1971. For the last 13 years, Mrs. Cook, a musician and historian, has been working on a book on Miss Hollenback, who has become something of an alter ego. Miss Hollenback left some 6,000 photographs in a trunk, and her ballgown still hangs in the closet. Mrs. Cook carries her briefcase; the Cooks' cat is named Amelia Hollenback.
Much to Mrs. Cook's delight, Miss Hollenback kept detailed records of both the building process and her collection, noting on a tag the date and origin of each piece. Mrs. Cook is so committed to retaining the original feeling of the house that she does the mud work on the portale walls and fireplaces herself, based on Mr. Meem's own "recipe."
Many owners of Meem houses seem to share this maternal, curatorial feeling. "My philosophy is, don't monkey with it," said Dr. Orville Linck, a retired English professor, who lives in a small Meem house on Delgado Lane. "It's the livability of the place. You get into it, and it's a part of you."

HEADLINE: Russian Actor Tells Of Chaotic Freedom In Russian Theater

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
There are easier things than being an actor in Russia these days, even if you're one of the country's superstars. Russian film makers go begging for financing. Theater companies can't locate the essentials for costumes and props. Finding even a loaf of bread can be difficult. Audiences dwindle as citizens become increasingly distracted by the hunt for necessities. And some of the best playwrights, shell-shocked by political and social upheaval, won't write new works until they regain their artistic bearings.
"But there is one wonderful thing -- we are free," said Vitaly Mefodiyevich Solomin, a Russian stage and film star who will perform at the Circle in the Square Theater on Broadway on Saturday night. "All the constraints and hardships have forced us to be more creative. And at the end of all of this, I think we will have reinvented our theater." 
 Mr. Solomin is a principal actor with the Maly Theater in Moscow, the 235-year-old national company that performs Russian and European classics. He may be remembered by American film buffs for his performances in two Soviet films, "Winter Cherry" and "Siberian Story." But he is known to nearly every Russian for his roles in more than 70 Soviet films, and is absolutely beloved for his portrayal of Dr. Watson in "Sherlock Holmes" on Russian television.
On Saturday evening, American audiences will have a chance to see Mr. Solomin for the first time in a solo performance that will be attended by the Russian Federation's Consul General, Ivan Kuznetsov, and other Russian political and cultural figures in New York.
 
Excerpts of Best-Known Roles
 In "An Evening With Vitaly Solomin," the 50-year-old actor will present excerpts, in Russian, from many of his best-known performances. They include the roles of Ivan Khlestakov from "The Inspector-General" by Nikolai Gogol; the octogenarian Firs in "The Cherry Orchard" by Anton Chekhov, and Laurence Shannon, the defrocked minister in Tennessee Williams's "Night of the Iguana," which is a permanent part of the Maly's repertory.
Mr. Solomin's performance "is a celebration of the Circle in the Square's relationship with Russia and the Maly Theater," said Theodore Mann, artistic director at the Circle in the Square. In 1989 Mr. Mann directed "Night of the Iguana" at the Maly, and last year Boris A. Morozov, the Moscow company's resident director, directed "Zoya's Apartment" here. Fifty acting students from Russia and the United States have thus far participated in an exchange program between the two theaters. "This is the first opportunity American audiences have had to see one of the greatest actors in the world," said Mr. Mann, who has worked with George C. Scott, Raul Julia, Colleen Dewhurst and James Earl Jones through the years.
Although some in New York's Russian community have dubbed Mr. Solomin the Paul Newman of Russia, the bearded, 6-foot-tall, hazel-eyed performer bears more of a resemblance in person to the actor Robert Shaw, projecting the same on-stage gravitas and rugged introspection. So heroic is his physique that he was the model for a colossal World War II Russian soldier in a bronze victory monument in Moscow.
"But really, I think Vitaly is sort of a cross between Kevin Kline and John Malkovich," said Mr. Mann, who has worked with both of them. "His physicality is like Kevin's, but he has the danger of Malkovich. He's a little scary on stage."
 
During the Coup Attempt
 He can be no less formidable off stage. In August he stood with the crowd of truculent Muscovites outside what was known as the Russian White House as they waited to do battle for Boris Yeltsin against troops supporting the abortive coup. The troops never arrived. And when Mr. Solomin returns to Moscow this month, he will star in a film, "Black Square," that seeks to expose the lords of the Russian mafia, the ringleaders of organized crime.
"The film is based on documented research about the ways in which the mafia operates, from the top down, in Russian society," Mr. Solomin said, modulating his big voice casually as his words were translated by Katya Obraztsova, who directed him in his last play, at the independent Actis Cultural Center in Moscow.
"The mafia may try to steal our equipment and sabotage the film," he added. "I suppose our own safety depends on how far 'Black Square' goes in exposing the mafia."
"Black Square" is breaking ground in another way, as a model of the new capitalism. "It's the first privately financed film I've ever acted in," said Mr. Solomin, who made his first film 30 years ago at the age of 20. "And the film will be exhibited outside of the traditional Soviet distribution system."
In his performance on Saturday, Mr. Solomin will also present selections from such contemporary Russian dramas as "The Cage" by Aleksandr Kastinsky, an allegorical play about imprisoned birds that created a sensation in Moscow when Mr. Solomin starred in it last fall.
 
Keeping Up With Chaos
 The play, which will tour America this spring, is still being rewritten to reflect the current political chaos. "But ever since the putsch, many of our best writers have been silent," said Mr. Solomin. "They don't know what to write, because they don't know what to think. They need to come to an understanding of what has happened. But eventually, they will make sense of all this, and they'll revolutionize our theater."
Mr. Solomin said Russian drama needed to break away from its "wholly political" tradition. He added: "In our country, even Shakespeare was seen as a vehicle for political comment, disguised though it was. Now all the plays about Stalin and Brezhnev are so dated, so insular and political. We need to go beyond that, to a theater about humanity, to create a theater of the world."
If the new artistic freedom is welcome, the new economic freedom is increasingly problematical, said Mr. Solomin. "A lot of uncultured money-grubbers are getting involved in film and theater, just to make a profit," he said, and laughed. "Just like here!"
While some theater companies, including the Maly in Moscow, continue to receive subsidies from the central Government, Mr. Solomin said, other troupes are being absorbed by local municipalities, which may not be able to finance them. Most are seeking private funds. Some companies eke out an existence by charging rent for office space in their buildings. And managing producers are agonizing that now, in an era when the state-subsidized theater ticket is no more, they may lose audiences by charging too much.
Mr. Solomin, who was born in Siberia, moved to Moscow at the age of 17 to attend the Maly Theater's school, and still lives in the city with his wife, Masha, the editor of a Russian fashion magazine, and their two daughters, who are 18 and 7 years old.
How can Russians in the arts survive in this time of chaos? "It's hard, but you must keep going your own way," he said. "You must not lose yourself." He smiled. "You must be very quiet in this unquiet time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We are free," said the star Russian actor Vitaly M. Solomin. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
N.C.A.A. Adopts Tougher Academic Standards for Eligibility

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 8

 BODY:
Delegates to the annual National Collegiate Athletic Association Convention continued adopting stronger academic standards on the aging heels of Proposition 48, including a significant and predictably controversial change today that will require incoming athletes to have a higher grade-point average in core academic classes.
Other changes include a toughened requirement that athletes make progress toward a degree and an increase in the number of core-course credits taken by high school students from 11 to 13. The additional subjects must be in English, mathematics or natural or physical science. 
 The passage of the proposals, over strong opposition from black educators, brought the most sweeping changes by the convention since the 1983 passage of Proposition 48, which allowed schools to accept academically deficient athletes but cost those students one year of eligibility so they could concentrate on their studies. That measure, like today's revisions, brought controversy because many believe the standardized tests that weigh heavily in the Proposition 48 formula are culturally and racially biased.
 
Presidents' Recommendations
 "It's going to have a detrimental impact upon access to higher education for African-American students," William DeLauder, president of Delaware State, said of the toughened requirements, which he said had not been well researched. "Any proposal that we bring forward that's going to have an impact on young people's lives ought to be based on sound reason and not on arbitrary reasons. Despite all the discussion, I have not seen anything that has a sound basis."
The more stringent rules follow the recommendations of the Presidents' Commission, a 44-member group of college presidents that has spent the last two years following an agenda of greater involvement in their athletic departments.
The revised measure, Proposition 16, passed easily, by a margin of 249 to 72, although it faced considerable debate and survived a motion by Frank Rienzo, the athletic director at Georgetown University, to refer it back to the academic requirements committee.
Proposition 16 and Proposition 14, which requires two additional course credits for high school athletes, do not take effect until Aug. 1, 1995.
Proposition 16 establishes freshman eligibility guidelines based on a sliding scale that takes into account an incoming freshman's grade-point average and test scores on either the Scholastic Aptitude Test or the American College Testing standardized test.
A student with a score of 700 on the S.A.T. or 17 on the A.C.T., for example, would be required to have a grade-point average of 2.5 on a scale of 4.0. The scale allows for students with lower grade-point averages to be eligible by testing higher in the standardized tests. A student with a 2.0, therefore, could be eligible by testing 900 on the S.A.T. or 21 in the A.C.T.
Proposition 16 essentially tightens the guidelines of Proposition 48, which was the first legislation toward tougher entrance standards for student-athletes. Under Proposition 48, a student could be eligible to compete as a freshman with a 700 S.A.T. score (or a 15 in the A.C.T.) and an overall 2.0 grade-point average. The theory has been that student-athletes who do not meet those standards may need their freshman year to adjust before the additional stress of competing in intercollegiate athletics.
"If we require a 1.5, that's what we'll get," said R. Gerald Turner of the University of Mississippi, the chairman of the Presidents' Commission. "But 90 percent of those who do 2.0 can do 2.5. Our goal is to establish standards that fairly and accurately communicate to young students that if they do these, they will get a degree."
Some delegates, however, said they believed that the new rule would severely affect athletes who are members of minority groups.
"There are going to be kids who will be denied access to education," Rienzo said. "I think the road to academic reform will be covered with the bodies of socio-economically disadvantaged individuals, and the Presidents' Commission is leading the way. Those individuals have no way of representing themselves."
 
Rule Called Unfair
 Backlash against Proposition 16 was immediate and not confined to academia. Representative Edolphus Towns, Democrat of Brooklyn, issued a statement that said: "The proposition is discriminatory, because student athletes are held to higher educational standards than the rest of the student population.
"It seems to me that this rule is unfair, and makes sense to individuals who do not have a solid perspective on the myriad challenges which confront black student athletes."
E. M. Jones, the faculty representative from Grambling State, a predominately black school, said the rules would eventually mean smarter athletes but also less money in the coffers of the universities.
"It's going to take us to a point in which we have A and B students on the football team, and I have no problem with that," he said. "At Grambling we graduate from 48 to 49 percent of scholarship student athletes. But perhaps they won't perform as well, won't be as exciting, and then the coffers are going to drop, because people won't pay to see a mediocre team."

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo's Sobering Speech

 BODY:
Even Gov. Mario Cuomo's soaring rhetorical skills were not enough to lift his State of the State address above the depths of a national recession. The New York Governor complained about weak national policies, restated his commitment to the needy and proposed limited programs to help the state. With the economy sagging and a state budget gap that could reach $4.5 billion in the next fiscal year, the speech was inevitably sobering.
Mr. Cuomo must fill in the blanks when he presents his budget later this month. He says he will cut Medicaid and welfare by $1 billion. How? He also wants to create jobs through an $800 million bond issue for construction. Would that add too much debt to deficit-ridden New York? 
 Also unclear is the status of the many public works projects the Governor cited yesterday. For example, Queens West, an ambitious plan for developing the Long Island City waterfront, hinges on private investors, and a state coordinating subsidiary has yet to be created.
The State of the State address is always more atmospheric than substantive. The Governor was strongest on defining a humane New York, one that will "look for solutions instead of scapegoats" and not cut welfare "simply to pander."
His remarks reflected the contentious fight in Albany over social service cuts. The Republican-controlled State Senate has made cutting welfare and Medicaid the centerpiece of its budget strategy, as the Senate's majority leader, Ralph Marino, outlined in his response to Mr. Cuomo. The Governor will need an intelligent plan to compete with Mr. Marino's, which cuts so deeply it would damage the safety net.
In sensible proposals, Mr. Cuomo once again cited the need for improving the school aid formula to channel more help to poor school districts, consolidating some school districts and boards and penalizing elected officials for every day they go past the April 1 deadline for a new budget. He also challenged the Legislature by calling for a constitutional convention to force budget reforms.
Judging from the sometimes combative tone of Mr. Cuomo's speech, he knows the April budget deadline is likely to be missed again this year.

HEADLINE: Aid, at Last, for the Republics

 BODY:
The republics of the former Soviet Union are struggling to turn decrepit Communism into vibrant capitalism. Even if successful, the transition will be traumatic. Ossified factories will close, throwing millions out of work; controls will be lifted, sending prices soaring. The entire fabric of society will have to be created anew.
The republics will need all the help they can get. So it is welcome news that the Bush Administration has finally endorsed membership for Russia and five other republics in the International Monetary Fund and World Bank. Membership allows the two institutions to provide billions of dollars of aid to support economic reform. 
 Until now the Bush Administration has rejected membership because the republics were not desperately poor and had promised but not yet delivered radical reform. All the republics have met the first condition by suffering economic implosion: output is plummeting, and millions face starvation. Russia and two other republics have now also met the second condition by launching sweeping price decontrol.
What type of aid is needed? The I.M.F. helps countries put together a disciplined program of economic stabilization, and provides aid only as long as the regimen is obeyed. The World Bank provides subsidized loans for investment in specific infrastructure projects.
By one estimate, Russia alone will need approximately $30 billion a year for five years, divided almost evenly among funds to stabilize the currency, import emergency food and import consumer goods during the initial burst of inflation. The funds would seek to ward off political backlash by cushioning the initial blow of harsh reform measures.
Even with membership, the republics will be hard pressed to stitch together capitalist institutions in time to make reform work. Without membership, the task would be nearly hopeless.

HEADLINE: ALBANY NOTEBOOK;
At Feel-Good Event, Most Felt Rotten

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 8

 BODY:
State of the State speeches are usually occasions when legislators smile, shake hands, applaud the Governor wildly or politely depending on their party and otherwise take a bath of good feelings, whether they feel good or not.
 But it is a measure of the frayed mood of officials here that the pretense this year not only faded but gave way about 40 minutes into Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's speech to a shouting match between Mr. Cuomo and an Assemblyman from his own party and hometown. 
Many legislators had been squirming in their seats as the Governor used his speech today to cast them as the enemy of widespread reforms. Specifically, Mr. Cuomo said, to avoid a repeat of last year's budget delay, elected officials should give up a day's pay for each day the budget is late. The budget was 65 days late last year.
 Angered by this suggestion, Assemblyman Anthony S. Seminerio, Democrat of Queens, interrupted Mr. Cuomo's speech, yelling: "It's good when you got a lot of dollars! It's good when you got a lot of dollars, Guv!"
 Mr. Cuomo stopped in midsentence and asked Mr. Seminerio if he needed a loan. And the two men had heated words for about three minutes as the audience laughed and applauded. Mr. Coumo ended the exchange, saying he was glad that "at least everybody is awake," referring to Mr. Seminerio, who has been known to nap during sessions.
 The exchange fit into the day's prevailing mood -- crabby. Like disgruntled students dragging back to class after a too-short recess, New York State's 211 legislators returned to the Capitol today to listen to the Governor's message and start a new session that is universally expected to prove the longest and most contentious in state history.
 Weary Legislators
 Yes, there was the normal opening-day camaraderie -- beaming grins, strong handshakes and lots of backslaps -- but there were visible signs of the contention to come.
 The small talk among the crowd that crammed into the Assembly chamber for Mr. Cuomo's address was about the escalating battle between Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders over how to resolve the state's persistent budget crisis. With the end of the current fiscal year coming on March 31, the state has yet to close a budget gap of more than $875 million.
 "You see a lot of smiling faces, but the truth is that most of us are not happy to be back here because we just barely left," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "The last session was so combative that I think most of us are very, very weary of the legislative process."
 After Mr. Cuomo's speech, Mr. Seminerio said his comments were not intended to show disrespect for the Governor but to emphasize that state budget delays rest not with the rank-and-file members of the Legislature but with the Governor and the two top legislators leaders who have been at odds.
 "I do love the Governor and he's a gentleman, and I would vote for him for President, but my mother did not raise no fools," the Assemblyman said. "I'm not going to be working for nothing."
 Many legislators agreed with Mr. Seminerio. Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, called the Governor's plan to withhold legislators' salaries "coercion" and said that "many younger lawmakers who rely on their salaries to pay mortgages and bills simply could not afford it."
 Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Nassau County, suggested that the Governor give up the many honorariums that he receives for speeches.
 A Republican Response
 In another example of the friction among politicians at the start of the new session, State Senate Republicans for the first time issued a televised response that was broadcast on the state-run system, NY-SCAN, immediately after Mr. Cuomo's speech.
 The State Senate's majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Long Island Republican, attributed New York's economic problems to the "nearly two decades of Democratic control of the executive office and Assembly" in which, Mr. Marino said, "taxes, spending, fiscal mismanagement and regulatory control" spiraled out of control.
 John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Mr. Marino, said the majority leader made a "special effort" to obtain television time for the response because "he sharply disagrees with the Governor over how to resolve this fiscal situation."
 A Child's View
 Following tradition, many legislators brought their families to the Assembly chamber to hear the Governor's address.
 Six-year-old Terrance Grannis, the Assemblyman's son, said that he usually finds the speech "pretty boring" but that this year's was exciting because of the "strong man who yelled at the Governor."

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
BUSH REACHES PACT WITH JAPAN, BUT AUTO MAKERS DENOUNCE IT

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 10

 BODY:
President Bush left for home today with a Japanese agreement to buy more American cars and $10 billion more in auto parts, but the car makers he brought with him denounced the Japanese pledges as woefully inadequate.
Even Bush Administration officials were saying the arrangements, worked out in the long and often bitter negotiations, fell far short of meeting the goals set by the White House for improving American exports to Japan and thus creating more jobs in the United States. 
 The Presidential party nonetheless contended that the talks were useful in drawing more attention to the continuing dispute over the trade in autos between the United States and Japan.
 
$19 Billion in Auto Parts
 Mr. Bush announced on Thursday the Japanese pledges to buy more American cars and $10 billion more in auto parts yearly by 1995, from $9 billion now to $19 billion in three years.
The results on the auto issues -- the core of American anger over Japan's trading system -- symbolized an economic summit meeting that appeared to throw cold water on Mr. Bush's election-year promises of new export markets and new jobs, and left his reputation for strength and vitality sapped by a dramatic physical collapse.
Administration officials sought in their subsequent briefings to portray the Japanese pledges in a sympathetic light, but the Big Three auto executives, who accompanied Mr. Bush here as part of a delegation of 18 business leaders, were quick to denigrate it, often in quite strong terms.
 
'There Is No Agreement'
 "There is no agreement," said Harold Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company.
He said the Japanese were unwilling to commit to a schedule to lower their $50 billion trade surplus with the United States, three-quarters of which comes from automobile trade. "The proposals on the table as far as the auto industry is concerned are inadequate."
Mr. Bush appeared slightly weary on Thursday, a day after he fainted and vomited at a private dinner held in his honor by Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. But he attended a state dinner on Thursday night, and insisted at a news conference that afternoon that he was fit.
 
A Superpower Summit
 The state dinner was the final event of a frenetic meeting of economic superpowers that bore earmarks of the vanished Moscow-Washington summits: tense all-night negotiations, carefully barbed remarks at news conferences, artery-clogging doses of diplomatic pomp and proclamations of success.
At the joint news conference on Thursday, the President called his trip to Japan "highly productive" and praised the 18 business leaders who accompanied him.
The heads of Detroit's Big Three automakers have long been vocal critics of Japan's trade practices. Many Japanese reacted angrily to their inclusion on a formal state visit by an American President.
Mr. Bush said, "I believe the U.S. Government and our business leaders have sent a strong message about the importance of fair access to markets." Japan's decisions to sign agreements and "action plans" that would open markets to American goods and services "make it clear that the message has been received," he said.
But other officials were not so sanguine. "The jury is still out," one Administration official said Thursday of the White House verdict on the Japanese summit.
The President's meetings with Mr. Miyazawa produced a stack of real and tentative agreements on trade and security issues.
 
Increase U.S. Share Seen
 They included specific proposals to increase American shares of Japanese markets for products and services like paper, Government-bought computers, glass, construction and legal assistance. The sides also agreed that Japan would take steps to remove hidden trade barriers, like the arcane safety and testing standards for autos, that raise the price of foreign cars being sold in the Japanese market.
Japan also agreed to change tax codes to make foreign investment less expensive and to expand a program that offers low-interest loans to companies seeking to enter or expand business here.
In some cases, however, what aides to Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa called "action plans" were closer to expressions of hope. A plan to expand the foreign presence in Japan's $65 billion-a-year paper industry, for instance, turned out on closer inspection to be a commitment by Japan to study the issue and a promise to "substantially expand" opportunities for foreign papermakers by the end of March.
Similarly, Japan agreed to "initiate measures with the goal of expanding" the business of foreign computer makers in selling their machines to Japanese Government agencies. That $3 billion-a-year market has been difficult for American computer makers to crack, but it is tiny compared with the $16 billion non-Government market, where foreign concerns already reap $4 of every $10 in sales.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa also released a largely symbolic document, called the Tokyo Declaration, that recognized Japan's growing global influence and pledged to harmonize Japanese and American policies on many world issues.
 
Focus on Auto Issues
 Of them all, however, the so-called action plans to promote Japanese purchases of American cars and auto parts were easily the most watched results of the summit and of Mr. Bush's 12-day Pacific journey.
In the weeks before, Mr. Bush billed the trip as a crusade to open Asian markets to American exports, thus creating new jobs that would help lift the economy out of recession. In Japan, where American trade deficits are concentrated, three-quarters of the imbalance is concentrated in auto-related products.
Along with the pledge by Japanese auto companies to increase the amount of American-made components that they buy for their factories $19 billion by 1995, Japanese car plants in the United States would increase the percentage of American parts in their cars to 70 percent, up from a current average of 50 percent
 
To Promote U.S. Cars
 Japan's Government also agreed to promote the sale of American cars at home, allowing existing car dealers to add American models to their product lines and staging more foreign auto shows in Tokyo and other Japanese cities. Japanese companies said they would try to sell as many as 20,000 American cars in a year, which would be in addition to the more than 16,000 American models sold now through American franchise dealers. That total of 36,000 cars would be about seven-tenths of one percent of the 5.1 million cars sold annually in Japan.
The President's negotiators sought to depict the accords on automobiles as a promising step toward opening Japan's huge markets to foreign companies of all stripes.
But the trade concessions that Japan offered appeared too meager and uncertain either to affect the economy much or to ease tensions caused by Japan's $41 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, its largest mercantile partner.
 
No Goal on More Imports
 Japan set no goal for increasing imports of American cars beyond a general pledge to seek new buyers for Detroit's products, and some makers suggested that American cars would be a tough sell in their country's quality-conscious market.
Tokyo's commitment to buy $19 billion in auto parts annually was but a fraction higher than an existing commitment to raise their purchases to about $18 billion a year.
American negotiators, who contend that American parts are well-made but unfairly excluded by the Japanese, had been demanding much larger increases in the purchases of American-made parts.
"We had a view of what we could reasonably ask for," said a senior Administration official, who insisted on anonymity. "I think they have taken a good step in that direction. If I assumed this were the end of it, then I might walk away disappointed."
In that arena and some others as well, Administration negotiators repeatedly acknowledged late Thursday, Japanese pledges of improvements in trade balances were either below White House expectations or were too murky and tentative to be readily measured.
On the one initiative that Mr. Bush had underscored daily on his Pacific tour -- the need for Washington and Japan to adopt a united front at crucial free-trade talks in Geneva -- a senior Administration official in Tokyo said simply, "We're not there yet."
Pressed to say whether or not Japan even supported Mr. Bush's call for a quick agreement to lower global trade barriers, the official twice replied, "I think you have to ask the Japanese Government that question."
Earlier, Mr. Bush maintained that Mr. Miyazawa had committed his nation to working with Washington on the talks, which are mired in an argument over free trade in farm goods.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa also declared late Thursday that their nations had established a "global partnership" aimed at harmonizing their policies to promote world economic growth, protect the environment and secure world peace.
The so-called Tokyo Declaration reaffirmed their commitment to an array of programs already conducted by the two nations, from counter-terrorism work to American and Japanese versions of the Peace Corps.
It also proposed establishing several new programs to improve the global quality of life, including a new joint commission on aging and further efforts to guard against the spread of nuclear arms and long-range missiles.
 
He Discusses His Illness
 In his news conference, the President offered new details of his illness on Wednesday, saying his doctors had "totally ruled out" any disorders other than the flu as a factor in his fainting and vomiting spell on Wednesday.
Tests that included an electrocardiogram and blood-pressure reading showed no abnormalities, he said.
Mr. Bush, who is 67 years old, brushed aside suggestions that the collapse, his second public medical emergency in eight months, might raise his age and condition as issues in the 1992 Presidential race.
"Do you think only old people get the flu?" he said to loud laughter, adding, "I think Democrats get the flu from time to time."
The White House said late Wednesday that Mr. Bush planned to return to a full schedule on Thursday morning after a full night's rest. But those plans were quietly dropped the next morning, when he continued to feel slightly ill, and Mr. Bush did not resume his full round of activities until Thursday afternoon.
He canceled a Thursday afternoon helicopter trip to an Eastman Kodak Corporation research center and morning meetings with business leaders, as well as a Friday morning call on American Embassy employees in Tokyo.
The White House also scrapped plans for the President to visit the Commerce Department and make a speech shortly after his return to Washington today. The events would have followed a nonstop 12 1/2-hour flight from Tokyo to Andrews Air Force Base outside the capital.
"It's not a big deal," an official traveling with Mr. Bush said of the cancellations. "It's been a long trip, and it'll be a long flight back. We thought it would be better if he got some rest when he gets home."

HEADLINE: Yelstin, in Rebuff to Ukraine, Lays Claim to Black Sea Fleet

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 9

 BODY:
In the latest twist in the dispute over the future of the Soviet military, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia flatly declared today that the Black Sea fleet belongs to Russia, not Ukraine. Disposition of the fleet is a crucial issue because it is one of the most valuable assets of the disintegrating Soviet military.
Mr. Yeltsin's assertion underscores Russian sensitivity about the legendary fleet, which was the core of the Russian Imperial Navy beginning in the 18th century, and about its home port, Sevastopol, a historically Russian city that was besieged by the Turks and their allies in the Crimean War in the 19th century. The Crimea was made part of the Ukrainian republic less than 40 years ago. 
 Only on Wednesday, the Russian President told another audience that "the Black Sea fleet cannot belong to any one republic" because it was the "indivisible" property of the Commonwealth of Independent States, the loose grouping that has replaced the old Soviet Union.
 
An Emphatic Claim
 "It has to be subordinate to the joint command," Mr. Yeltsin said in Saratov, a Russian city on the Volga River.
But today Mr. Yeltsin was emphatic about Russia's historical claim. "The Black Sea fleet was, is and will be Russia's," he told a gathering of workers at an airplane factory in the Russian town of Ulyanovsk, Lenin's birthplace, where he was greeted with applause.
Tass reported that Mr. Yeltsin had sent a message to Admiral Vladimir N. Chernavin, commander of the former Soviet Navy, saying that the fleet's commanders were under the protection of the Russian President and urging them not to swear allegiance to Ukraine.
 
Agreement, and Dispute
 On Dec. 30, the members of the new commonwealth agreed in Minsk that the strategic forces of the former Soviet Union would come under the joint commonwealth command. But the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, has since argued that the agreement does not cover the Black Sea fleet because its vessels do not carry strategic nuclear weapons, and has demanded that members of the fleet swear loyalty to Ukraine.
In a suggestion that he may be backing off from an immediate confrontation, Mr. Kravchuk told a group of American Congressmen today in Kiev that Ukraine would take control of the fleet by July 1, the deadline set by the republic for removal of all strategic weapons on its territory, Tass said.
Mr. Kravchuk had set Jan. 20 as the deadline for officers and soldiers serving in a future Ukrainian military, including Black Sea sailors, to take an oath of loyalty to the Ukrainian people.
Russian officials argue that such an oath runs counter to the spirit of the commonwealth, which wants units of the former Soviet military to profess dual loyalty to the organization as a whole and to the republics in which they serve.
With 3 carriers, 6 missile cruisers, about 30 submarines, 235 combat planes and helicopters and scores of support and supply ships, the Black Sea fleet is a crucial component of the former Soviet Navy.
 
A Counter to U.S. Fleet
 Although none of the fleet's submarines are armed with long-range nuclear missiles, Russian and military officials argue that the fleet is strategic by virtue of its position near the straits linking the Black Sea to the Mediterranean. Soviet naval forces have operated continuously in the Mediterranean since the mid-1960's to counter the United States Sixth Fleet.
In an interview published today in the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya, Admiral Chernavin criticized the Ukrainian leadership for its "hasty attempts" to lay claim to the Black Sea fleet and warned that the move would only bring "chaos, strife and destabilization." Politicians, he said, should beware of "playing jokes with the army."
Continuing his barnstorming in the city of Nizhny Novgorod, formerly Gorky, Mr. Yeltsin said today that Russia would be the last of the republics to create its own army, and then only if it was forced to.
"We do not want to be provocateurs," he said, "That is why we shall be as patient as we can."
 
Incompatible Claims
 But the arguments over oaths and the status of the fleet have exposed a fundamental crack in the accord on a new commonwealth reached by 11 former Soviet republics. As Russia advances its claim to be the inheritor state of the former Soviet Union, Ukraine is trying to assert equal rights. As one political commentator said recently, the two claims are not only incompatible but unrealistic, and must somehow be resolved for the new commonwealth to survive.
On a two-day tour of several Russian cities, Mr. Yeltsin has addressed the most painful issues now confronting Russia, starting with the removal of most state controls on consumer prices on Jan. 2.
The lifting of controls, which more than tripled the prices of basic foods like bread and milk, has brought wide dismay, particularly among old people and others on fixed incomes. Even before price liberalization, such citizens were having a hard time surviving in the shaky Russian economy.
Mr. Yeltsin has said repeatedly that he expects his own popularity to suffer from the economic shock therapy. He told the crowd in Saratov that it would take another six to eight months for the economy to pick up.
 
Facing Angry Crowds
 By going to cities like Ulyanovsk and Saratov, which have large military industries likely to be hit hard by unemployment, Mr. Yeltsin showed once again he is not hesitant to face hostile audiences. When angry shoppers swirled around him at one stop, he said: "What do you want? To chop me up in pieces and put me on the shelves?"
In Saratov, capital of the former German autonomous region that was dissolved by Stalin after Germany invaded the Soviet Union in 1941, Mr. Yeltsin tackled the painful question of re-establishing a German autonomous republic. Such a move is sought by local ethnic Germans and by the German Government, which wants to stem the flow of German emigrants.
Mr. Yeltsin said Wednesday that he would agree to a new autonomous republic, but only in an area where ethnic Germans made up more than 90 percent of the population and there was "free" land -- for instance, land used as a military testing ground in the Volgograd region, or other land near Saratov.
"Am I crazy to create another state on Russian territory?" he asked local Russians who were protesting Bonn's promises to help in the creation of a new German autonomous region.

HEADLINE: Fed by More Than Slump, Welfare Caseload Soars

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
After showing little growth for almost two decades, the nation's welfare rolls now surge to record levels with each passing month.
The initial hope was that the increase in the number of welfare recipients was merely a byproduct of the recession that would disappear when the economy improved. But analysts increasingly suspect that other factors, more enduring than the current economic slump, are adding to the sharp increase. 
 Many now say the nation may witness substantially more cases for the foreseeable future, a trend almost certain to provoke strong cultural and political reactions.
"A lot of people in the beginning were saying it's just due to the economy," said Jo Anne B. Barnhart, the assistant secretary for children and families in the Department of Health and Human Services who oversees the nation's welfare programs. "But this is a very different situation."
Virtually everyone agrees the sagging economy is a main cause of the welfare surge that began two years ago. But other factors also cited by many analysts include increases in the number of households headed by women, changes in the rules governing welfare programs, increased efforts by social workers to expand the Medicaid program and even the amnesty program for illegal immigrants, which has made some of them eligible to receive welfare.
Where experts disagree, often sharply, is over how much weight to give the various factors, and how much the trend can be expected to reverse with an economic recovery.
 
A National Index
 Welfare cases offer an index of national misery, but they are important for other reasons as well. While welfare payments account for only 3.4 percent of an average state's budget, the rise in cases does place financial pressure on state governments desperately seeking to cut deficits.
Welfare has figured prominently in recent elections of governors in Louisiana and Mississippi, as have other problems associated with long-term poverty, including crime, the breakdown of families and frequent failures in school.
The last large welfare increase ended in 1973 after cases tripled in seven years, and politicians have been pointing fingers and apportioning blame ever since.
Understanding a rise in cases is seldom as easy as it seems, since there is a swirl of factors constantly at work, from regional economics to sexual mores, and they often push the numbers in different directions at the same time. Demographics, economics, cultural values and the eligibility rules, which vary in every state, all play a role.
 
Rise Is Steep and Fast
 Those pessimistic about the future note that the number of families receiving welfare has increased more in the last 2 years than it did in the previous 16. And recent studies have found the welfare rolls rising much faster now than in previous recessions. Studies of past recessions have shown that welfare cases decline when the economy recovers, but not to the pre-recession levels.
The number of families receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children, which provides cash benefits to needy families, grew by almost half a million a year in the early 1970's, before leveling off in 1973 at about 3.1 million. Over the next 16 years, the rolls grew by only 600,000 families, to 3.7 million in July 1989.
Then the figures rocketed. By October 1991, the last count available, 4.6 million families were receiving welfare, an increase of 24 percent in a little more than two years. The October figures showed an increase of 57,000 families from September and was the 27th month in which a record was set. While 10.9 million Americans lived in families receiving assistance in 1989, by October that figure had risen to 13.2 million.
A small part of the increase can be explained by a law requiring every state to provide welfare to some two-parent families by the end of 1990. Such programs were previously offered only in some states, and since July 1989 the number of families receiving welfare under that program has risen to 297,000 from 184,000.
 
Trend in All Sections
 A study by the American Public Welfare Association, a professional group in Washington representing social workers and state welfare departments, found cases increasing in all areas of the country, led by a rise of 72 percent in New Hampshire, 41 percent in Arizona, 39 percent in North Carolina, and 37 percent in Kentucky, Florida, and Connecticut. Those figures covered the period from July 1989 to April 1991.
As cases have risen, so have costs. Total spending on the Aid for Families with Dependent Children program, which includes both benefits and administrative expenses and is shared by the state and Federal governments, rose to an estimated $23.1 billion in 1991, from $19.6 billion in 1989. Those costs were offset in small part by collections of delinquent child support payments from parents, which rose to an estimated $1.6 billion in 1991 from $1.3 billion in 1989. The estimates come from the Federal human services department.
These rises reversed what had been a long-term decrease in the welfare program's actual cost when adjusted for inflation. Using constant 1990 dollars and including the offsetting child support collections, the total cost of welfare benefits dropped to $16.7 billion in 1989, from $20.7 billion in 1973. That is mostly because inflation has eroded the average welfare benefit by about 42 percent over the past two decades.
The growth of cases is only one of many measures of the nation's reliance on welfare. A calculation by a staff economist for the House Ways and Means Committee estimated that the percentage of all Americans who receive welfare was 5.1 percent in October, down slightly from the 1975 record of 5.2 percent. Analysts say this is probably because children, who are eligible for the program, make up a smaller proportion of the population.
 
More Children in Poverty
 On the other hand, the estimated percentage of American children who receive welfare had risen to a record level of 13.5 percent, after previously peaking in 1976 at 11.9 percent. This reflects the increasing number of children in poverty.
While some might regard the current rise in cases as evidence that the country is taking care of its needy, most advocates for the poor argue the opposite: that the safety net has eroded. They note that the percentage of children living below the Federal poverty line who receive welfare is now estimated to be about 65 percent, down from its 1973 high of 81 percent.
Not everyone thinks the current case levels are likely to endure.
"If we have strong economic growth in the 1990's, there's no reason why caseloads might not go down even lower than they've been," said June O'Neill, an economist at Baruch College.
 
Rolls May Just Be Cut
 Noting that several states have proposed or enacted welfare cuts, Ms. O'Neill cited another way that cases might decline: states may simply remove people from the rolls.
Those who expect sharp declines in the future also emphasize that the current rise is being exaggerated by program changes in the 1980's that made it harder for working families to receive welfare. In the past, more of those families would have been on welfare before the recession; now they appear on the rolls only when an economic slump throws them from work.
"Presumably they'll be the folks who'll be rehired when the economy picks up," said Richard A. Ferreira, a policy associate at the public welfare association.
Some officials also say new education and training programs will work to reduce cases. Those programs were passed as part of the 1988 Family Support Act but have been implemented only in the past year.
But at least one analyst contends the opposite: that the new benefits provided under the law may be attracting people onto the rolls and keeping them there longer. In 1988, Charles Murray, now a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, wrote an article in The Wall Street Journal predicting the law would cause cases to increase by making the system more attractive.
 
'I Hit the Jackpot'
 "It's the only specific prediction I've ever made in my life, and by God, I hit the jackpot," Mr. Murray said this week in an interview, adding that he expected the higher levels to endure.
Others who are pessimistic about the future argue that the recession has lifted a veil that kept demographic trends from showing up in cases. They say the trends, which have been building for a decade, will continue to increase cases.
In the past decade, the number of households headed by women has continued to rise, as has the percentage of households headed by women who have never been married. Studies show families headed women who have never been married are particularly likely to receive welfare.
In 1980, there were 6.2 million families headed by single women, making up 19.4 percent of all families with children. By 1990, according to Census Bureau figures, the number had risen to 8.4 million families, representing 24.2 percent of the total. In 1980, 17 percent of households headed by women were led by women who had never been married; by 1990 the proportion had risen to 33 percent.
Analysts say those trends were obscured by the economic growth of the 1980's and by restrictions in welfare eligibilty, including those that dropped 300,000 families from the rolls in 1981.
"This leaves many people more vulnerable than they were before," said Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, which has done the most elaborate analysis of caseload growth.
The budget office report lists other reasons that may also be contributing to the rise in cases. These include changes making unemployment insurance harder to collect, leaving families increasingly reliant on welfare instead.
