HEADLINE: Poll Shows Price Bush Pays For Tough Economic Times

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Eight of 10 Americans say the economy is in bad shape, and President Bush is paying a clear political price for their discontent, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But voters know little about the Democrats who would challenge him.
The telephone survey, conducted Monday through Wednesday, shows an unpredictable terrain at the start of this election year: The President's approval rating is down to 48 percent, and voters are evenly divided when offered a choice between re-electing Mr. Bush or replacing him with a unspecified Democrat. But the real Democratic field has barely penetrated their consciousness, according to the telephone survey of 1,376 adults. 
 Still, the poll reflects the recession's toll on Mr. Bush. Only 18 percent said Mr. Bush cared "a great deal" about the needs and problems of people like themselves, down from 28 percent last March. Thirty-five percent said they thought Mr. Bush did not care much about them, according to the poll, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Skepticism Over Asian Trip
 Mindful of the dangers of seeming insensitive in a recession, the White House promoted Mr. Bush's Asian trip as an attempt to produce jobs. But even before Mr. Bush left Japan yesterday with trade pledges denounced by American car makers as woefully inadequate, the public was skeptical:Fewer than a third of those surveyed said they thought Mr. Bush's recent meetings with Asian leaders would increase employment in the United States; 53 percent said they thought the trip was "mainly for show."
About two-thirds, 67 percent, said that Mr. Bush was spending too much time on foreign policy and not enough on domestic affairs. That was up from the 58 percent who said that last October, and the 36 percent who expressed that view the previous year.
Mr. Bush's overall approval rating dropped below 50 percent for the first time in The New York Times/CBS News Poll, a matter of some symbolic note. But at 48 percent it was statistically indistinguishable from the 51 percent registered in November. Moreover, Presidents with similar approval ratings have won re-election.
President Ronald Reagan's approval rating dipped to 41 percent in his first term, and he went on to win 49 states against former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee. Still, Mr. Reagan's popularity had stabilized in the mid-50 percent range as he entered his re-election year.
William J. Feltus, deputy campaign manager for communications for the Bush organization, said: "On economic measures, this poll is not appreciably different from others we've seen. And until the Democrat is better known, polls are not going to tell you much about what's going to happen in November."
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, acknowledged that the Democratic candidates were still little known, but added: "A year ago, people were saying it doesn't matter what the Democrats do because Bush is invincible. We're not having that conversation anymore."
The poll indicates that the economy is at the heart of Mr. Bush's problems, and underscores the political challenge facing him as he seeks to allay concerns in his State of the Union Message and beyond. Eighty-one percent now say the economy is either "very" or "fairly" bad, up from 74 percent who took that view in November. Nothing came close to the economy when people were asked to cite the most important problem facing the country.
Moreover, Mr. Bush is clearly being held accountable for the current state of affairs: Only 23 percent said they approved of the way he handled the economy, a level last recorded in the Administration of President Jimmy Carter. Fifty-two percent said the recession was something that a President "can do a lot" about.
 
Attitudes Reflect Anxiety
 Economic anxiety is directly linked to current attitudes toward the election: 41 percent of registered voters said that if the election were held today, they would probably vote for Mr. Bush, while 38 percent said they would probably vote for an unspecified Democrat. Those who said the economy was bad were more than twice as likely to prefer the Democratic candidate as were those who said the economy was good.
Still, the election is 11 months off, and these attitudes could change dramatically by then. Moreover, as Republican strategists note, poll takers are now offering people a choice between Mr. Bush and an idealized Democrat. The real Democratic candidates are still struggling to introduce themselves.
Only Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had support in the double-digits among likely Democratic primary voters nationwide. And while Mr. Brown is the best known Democrat in the field, his critics outnumber his admirers by almost two-to-one in his own party.
 
Gains by Clinton
 Mr. Clinton has clearly made some strides in the past few months: 14 percent of the self-described Democratic primary voters now say they would prefer him as the Democratic nominee, up from 6 percent in November. Mr. Brown was preferred by 13 percent; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska by 7 percent, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa by 3 percent and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas by 2 percent. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who dropped out of the race Wednesday night, was the choice of 6 percent.
When all the respondents who said they were registered to vote -- Democrats, Republicans and independents -- were asked their views of the Democratic candidates, the cloudy image of the current field emerges. In the case of every candidate, the vast majority of the respondents said they were either undecided or did not know enough to have an opinion.
More than two-thirds of the respondents were interviewed before Mr. Bush's collapse from a stomach ailment in Japan, but those polled afterwards expressed views that were statistically indistinguishable from the earlier sample.
Those interviewed Wednesday night were asked whether they worried about whether Mr. Bush was healthy enough to serve effectively for a second term: Only 25 percent said they did feel that anxiety.
 
Worrying About Quayle
 Two-thirds of those interviewed Wednesday, however, said they would worry about whether Vice President Dan Quayle would be up to the job of President; this was about the same percentage who voiced those concerns soon after Mr. Bush's thyroid problem last May.
The latest poll indicates Mr. Bush remains the overwhelming favorite of Republicans nationally for renomination: 78 percent said they preferred Mr. Bush, 12 percent favored Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, and 3 percent backed David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader and unsuccessful gubernatorial candidate in Louisiana.
The margin of sampling error for smaller subgroups in the poll was larger than the 3 percentage points for the overall poll. For example, it was plus or minus five percentage points for either the Democratic primary voters or the Republican primary voters.

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
A Trade Mission Ends in Tension As the 'Big Eight' of Autos Meet

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
President Bush's hopes of returning home with what he called an "action plan" to help Detroit began to unwind late this afternoon, in one of the most unlikely business meetings in the history of Japanese-American industrial rivalries.
The chief executives of the world's eight largest auto makers -- three American, five Japanese -- gathered face to face in a hotel room in downtown Tokyo, with everyone in the room clearly understanding, and no one saying, that the American industry will probably never gain back the ground it has lost to Japanese imports and to Japanese cars made in American plants.
 
A Tense Hour
 It was apparently the first time executives of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler met directly with their counterparts at Toyota, Nissan, Honda, Mitsubishi, and Mazda, which together now control more than a third of the American auto market. After a tense hour, during which the Japanese told their guests that American industry needed to transform itself radically, and the Americans warned that the time was long past when "mere declarations of intent" to open markets would suffice, Lee A. Iacocca, the fiery head of the ailing Chrysler Corporation, finally spoke up. 
 "He said he wasn't satisfied with the figures," Yutaka Kume, the president of the Nissan Motor Company, recalled a few hours later, referring to Japan's plan to double the amount of American-made auto parts that it buys every year and to sell roughly 20,000 American-made cars each year in Japan.
Congress is just a step away from enacting limits on the import and production of Japanese cars in the United States, Mr. Iacocca warned, "and he was not certain he could convince fellow Americans" that that was a bad idea, Mr. Kume said.
Mr. Iacocca left the meeting visibly angry, and immediately flew back to Detroit, the city that has come to symbolize better than any other the enormous transfer of wealth that has taken place in the last decade between the American Midwest and Tokyo.
"Of course you have to remember," said Robert C. Stempel, the chairman of General Motors, trying to put the whole session into perspective a few hours later, "that Lee is always a little hot under the collar."
But the bottom line was that the plan, which Mr. Bush described only a few hours before as a "significant but interim step" in solving the worsening economic relations between the two countries, had already been shot down -- by the executives Mr. Bush brought along on his trip.
"There is no agreement," Harold Poling, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, said soon after he emerged from the meeting. The Japanese, he said, were willing to talk but unwilling to commit themselves to a schedule to lower their $50 billion trade surplus with the United States, three-quarters of which comes from automobile trade. "The proposals on the table as far as the auto industry is concerned are inadequate," he said.
The confrontation today at the Hotel Okura, for two decades the site of the trade talks that have left both sides increasingly exasperated, seemed to underscore the problem dogging Mr. Bush throughout his trip: Solving the fundamental difficulties on both the American and Japanese sides -- insufficient American investment in Japan, exclusive-sourcing arrangements among Japanese suppliers -- has only the most indirect effect in meeting Mr. Bush's goal of creating "jobs, jobs, jobs" in America.
"We can always buy more parts," a senior Nissan official said. "But that does not address the basic problem of how American cars can compete against Japanese cars, or American parts against Japanese parts." And until those problems are solved, he said, American industry "will not truly recover."
 
An Outspoken Approach
 If Mr. Bush's trip did bring about one big change, however, it is this: Japan seems far less shy than it did even a few months ago about telling America exactly what it thinks is wrong with America. In no sector is that clearer than in autos, an area where the Japanese think they have gained the right to do a little lecturing.
Soon after the meeting among the Big Eight broke up, the leaders of the Japanese companies said they thought the Americans had failed to learn some vital lessons about competitiveness that should have been obvious in the 1980's. And as a result, they said, the goals announced by President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa this afternoon could be met only if Detroit fundamentally changed its ways and learned how to suit Japanese tastes.
"We cannot lower the quality of our cars," said Nobuhiko Kawamoto, the president of the Honda Motor Company. "So to achieve the goals in the plan, we need to request the cooperation of American producers."
Throughout the trip, the American auto executives have complained that the Japanese have tended to treat them like sidewalk beggars, doling out commitments to buy American goods out of some sense of public duty and political self-interest rather than any conviction that Japan needs to buy what America is selling.
 
Concessions Rejected
 "We are not here asking for concessions," Mr. Poling said today. "We don't feel we've been defeated, and we didn't ask for any concessions."
It was Prime Minister Miyazawa himself who first used the word "defeated" the other day, talking about what happened when Detroit met Tokyo, and what kind of shock the United States was facing at the prospect of General Motors' eliminating 70,000 jobs. But today Mr. Kume, who heads Japan's leading organization of automobile manufacturers, said he did not regard American industry as a charity case. "We are not as arrogant as that," he said.
If Mr. Bush had hoped to alleviate some of these tensions, the hodge-podge accord announced today did not seem to do the trick. American executives said it was "the start of a process," and expressed a willingness to meet with their Japanese counterparts regularly.
Despite the flare-ups, Mr. Bush's traveling companions said the trip was a success -- though not because of any concessions wrung from Japan. "For the first time business and Government in the United States are joining together on a serious national problem," Mr. Poling said tonight. "The message has been transmitted to Japan that it must open its markets in the strongest language possible. From the standpoint of the Administration, it was a success."
Mr. Bush's aides, trying to put the best face on the President's accomplishments, pointed to more concrete agreements on specific trade issues, like the sale of computers, glass and paper. His presence also allowed breakthroughs on other nettlesome problems that have bothered American business here for more than a decade, including a cumbersome system of certifying and inspecting foreign cars.
But the most contentious issue, and the one the Bush Administration least wanted to discuss in detail tonight, involved automobile trade. Since long before the trip, Mr. Bush's aides have found themselves in an ideologically uncomfortable position. They are philosophically opposed to "managed trade" -- the setting of quantifiable goals and market shares for each nation's industries. But they also realize that, as recent experience shows, that is the only way to deal with Japan. The most successful trade agreement with Japan yet, the semiconductor accord that was renewed last year, clearly states that American companies are expected to hold at least 20 percent of the Japanese market.
"We knew we had to pattern this agreement after the semiconductor agreement," said an official in the Commerce Department. "But we could not appear to be agreeing to specific numbers."
The Japanese know that, too, and, eager to make Mr. Bush's trip a success, the Government here spent the last few weeks cajoling and arm-twisting to force Japanese auto makers to once again revise plans to increase their imports.
Because the announcements came from the companies, not the Government, the United States was able to argue that such "unilateral" proposals from Japanese companies did not amount to managed trade.
"In no way does it constitute an agreement," said a senior Administration official who briefed reporters this evening, even though President Bush had referred to "the agreements" on autos just hours before.
Whatever they are, the "action plans" adopted by Japan and the United States have a number of provisions and loopholes that may provide the grist for new tensions in months ahead.
For example, American companies hoping to take advantage of Japan's new commitment to import American parts may have to build factories or warehouses in Japan at a time when parts plants are being closed in the United States. Recognizing that few companies will be willing to make that investment, the Japanese said that nearly 80 percent of the parts they buy will be from their "transplant" factories in the United States.
 
Already in the Works
 Over the next two to three years the Japanese are planning to open new manufacturing lines that will increase their output at transplants by roughly 50 percent. That means that even without today's offer Japan's purchases of American parts seemed bound to rise. It is hard to measure whether Japan's commitment to purchase $10 billion more in American parts in 1995 will create new jobs or merely save some positions at American companies that might otherwise be forced into layoffs.
"It is something positive," said John P. Reilly, the president of Tenneco Automotive, who represented parts makers on Mr. Bush's trip, "but probably not enough."
Mr. Bush did little to change the basic attitudes of either side. The American auto executives left Japan convinced that it was still a closed society, barring foreign goods at the gate, offering tokens instead of real trade opportunities. The Japanese saw them off, convinced that the Big Three still don't get it. "We haven't done anything wrong," Mr. Kume said this evening, "so we don't have to rectify our conduct or deeds."

HEADLINE: In the New York Area, Businesses Are Stifled by Cash-Flow Worries

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Slowly and with little fanfare, many businesses in the New York City area are being strangled by a lack of cash, raising the prospect that still more companies could succumb to bankruptcy before this recession is over.
Although it is common in the business world for people to talk about profits and the infamous "bottom line," it is cash that dictates the fortunes of many small and medium-sized businesses.
 
Ripple Effect
 Companies can die for lack of sufficient demand for their services, as many in the New York area have discovered during this lengthy and painful recession. But even those that still have a reasonable amount of business can also expire if their customers do not pay promptly and they get caught in a cash stranglehold from which they cannot escape. That appears to be the more common problem now. 
 "For many people, there's enough business to sustain the company, but cash flow is so critical that they're having to go in with their personal money or close down," said Peter D. Colahan, vice president of Colahan-Saunders, a mid-sized printing company in Manhattan. This cash squeeze has forced many companies to search for more creative ways to raise cash or stretch out what they have.
In one example, Jansen & Rogan, a Manhattan-based engineering firm, recently put its employees on a four-day week -- even though the firm still has plenty of work coming across the transom. The move saved the firm 20 percent of its salaries.
Over the last 12 months, many companies have not only suffered a sharp decline in the volume of their business, but the customers they still have left are paying their bills at a much slower rate. That means that those on the receiving end of that slowdown have little choice but to turn around and pay their own creditors and suppliers more slowly. And that is causing a cash crunch to ripple its way through the local economy.
"It's a vicious cycle," said Mr. Colahan. "You're paid slower so you pay slower."
Representatives of small-business groups said although they had not specifically surveyed their members on this issue, they believe the problem is a national one. "Somebody gets squeezed and it's typically small businesses because they don't have the clout to respond," said Kenneth Yancey, executive director of the National Business Association, which is based in Dallas.
In normal times, a company could tide matters over by borrowing from a bank. But bank loans are extremely hard to get these days, even for well-heeled companies.
The recent drop in interest rates is likely to make it easier for more companies to qualify for loans. But many businesses that might be eligible do not want to borrow because that would just make them more of a de facto banker to their customers than they already are. Instead of just "lending" money to a late-paying customer, without charging any interest, they would also be paying a financing charge for the privilege.
Joseph Crapanzano, general manager of the Arzee Mid-state Supply Corporation in East Brunswick, N.J., said he has so many customers who are more than 120 days overdue that he occasionally forgets what business he is in. "Sometimes you think you're really not in the siding business any more, you're just a bank for your customers," he said.
 
If You Lag, I Lag
 The cash crunch has left few businesses or industries in the region untouched. Choice Courier Systems in Manhattan, for instance, used to expect about 65 to 70 percent of its customers to be current on their bills. Today that figure has dropped to 45 percent. And only 7 percent of its customers used to drag out their payments past 90 days, while those laggards now constitute 10 to 11 percent of the company's accounts.
Mike Beck, Choice's vice president of finance and administration, said that in reaction to this turn of events his company has chosen to lag some of its payments, too. Choice is paying its office supply and printing bills after 60 days, instead of the usual 30 to 45. And it is making its lawyers and accountants wait 60 to 75 days for payment, instead of the 30 to 45 days it used to.
"You have to borrow from Peter to pay Paul," said Mr. Beck. It has not helped, he added, that about a dozen of the company's customers have gone bankrupt, leaving unpaid debts to Choice of $150,000. "We can't afford to take it on the chin," he said. "We don't have deep pockets."
Indeed, business executives said this is one of the most worrisome aspects of the cash crunch. Because it affects those without financial staying power, it tends to hurt small businesses the most, and they have traditionally been one of the most dynamic sectors of the New York economy. From 1982 to 1987, small businesses generated 79 percent of all private sector employment growth in New York City.
 
Savings Are Exhausted
 While many small companies had set aside funds for emergency purposes, few expected their cash needs to be so severe for so long. "They can dip into their reserves, but after a year and a half of a depression, those reserves are depleted or just not there any more," said David A. Capodiece, regional coordinator in the Northeast for the National Office Products Association.
According to those in the office-supplies industry, one company that succumbed to these kind of cash-flow problems was Milton Goldhair Associates, which had sales of an estimated $4 million to $5 million and had been in business for about half a century. In early 1991, the company, which competitors said had about 30 employees, filed for bankruptcy protection. Although industry executives said the company got caught in a cash-flow squeeze, Richard Goldhair, the son of the founder, refused to discuss the reasons why the company went out of business.
"Lots of companies have gone out of business," Mr. Capodiece said, and if things continue as they have, "you could see a lot more."
In the first seven months of 1991, Dun & Bradstreet, the business information company, recorded 703 business failures in New York City, more than double the 327 that failed in 1990 and more than 8 times the 83 that failed in 1989. It is impossible to discern from the data what proportion of these failures were caused by cash-flow crises.
 
Creative Dunning
 Of course, anyone who starts a business and survives in New York City's competitive business environment has to be enterprising to begin with. But many owners of small companies now find themselves engaged in a battle that can tax their creative energies even more than their everyday business.
Business executives have had to learn how to dun customers without alienating them so much that they decide to take their business elsewhere, yet these same executives cannot bet so heavily on the value of a client relationship that they are left holding the bag if that client goes out of business. On the other side of the ledger-book, these executives have to try to slow their payments to their own suppliers without spooking them so much that they lose a valued source of inventory.
To arm themselves against deadbeats, executives at many companies said they now generate a list of late-paying customers every one or two weeks instead of once a month. And most said they had assigned members of their staff, or even hired new employees, to spend the day calling delinquent customers and pleading for payment. Many said they had also resorted to using more collection lawyers. One such, Michael Laufer, who is based in Manhattan, says the demand for his services has risen by about a third in the last year.
Harvey J. Krauser, the president of U.S. Coffee/Breaktime Concepts, which supplies offices in the New York area with beverages and snacks from its base in Westbury, L.I., has even taken to visiting some of his customers personally. His goal is to sound them out on their problems and to remind them of their obligations.
Although his approach seems to have worked, Mr. Krauser said, "We're spending a disproportionate amount of time worrying about getting money in, and that's very hard for a small business." It leaves precious little time to go after new customers.
In some extreme cases, executives said they felt they had no choice but to play hardball. With its most unreliable clients, for instance, Choice will refuse to send a messenger to deliver another package until the latest bill has been paid first. When it reaches a point like that, many business people said they had already accepted the likelihood of losing that customer's business.
It is for exactly that reason that Michael Collado, president of the Itex Corporation, an office products company in Stamford, Conn., says he is not accepting any new customer accounts. He figures that if they are coming to him, it is because they have just been cut off by one of his competitors for not paying. "You have to be wary of new business at this time, because, chances are, it won't be good business," said Mr. Collado. He will, however, accept customers who pay by credit card or check.
Surprisingly, several business executives said that some of the worst offenders are large companies. In one case, said Mr. Krauser, it was a bank that suddenly began asking for a second copy of a bill before paying, or suggesting that they call another department. "We're getting more creative excuses," he said, "even from the bigger companies."
Mr. Krauser's son, Steven, who is the company's executive vice president, identified perhaps the only bright side to this cash squeeze. There is at least one group of customers that has shown itself to be desirable in paying on time: Bankruptcy lawyers and "work-out" groups that help companies dig themselves out from debt.

HEADLINE: Coalition Rule in Ethiopia Is Facing Growing Fears of Collapse

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Six months after winning control of this war-weary, impoverished nation, the new Ethiopian Government is struggling to keep its people together despite ethnic conflicts, a rock-bottom economy and a dispirited bureaucracy.
There is growing apprehension here in the capital that an experiment to dismantle the traditionally autocratic central government into self-governing regions based on ethnicity will result in the disintegration of the country. This danger is accentuated, Ethiopians and Western donors say, as President Meles Zenawi refuses to shed the Marxist economic ideas of his insurgency movement and pushes the peasants and urban dwellers into even deeper poverty. 
 "I can see a scenario where it goes down the tubes," a Western diplomat said. "It's not hard to imagine a Yugoslavia. But everyone wants to avoid that."
One member of the new Government said, "I can see civil war ahead."
 
U.S. Backs Coalition
 After routing the army of the Marxist Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam last May, the insurgent group based in Tigre province in the north and led by Mr. Meles formed a coalition government at a national conference in July. In contrast to its hostile relations with Colonel Mengistu, the United States blessed the Meles Government by sending five State Department officials to the conference, including the Assistant Secretary for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen.
The main partnership in the Government is between Mr. Meles's Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front and the Oromo Liberation Front, based on the Oromo people of the southern region and the country's largest ethnic group. The Oromo of the south are largely Muslim and the Tigreans of the north are Christians of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church. And they speak different languages.
There have been increasing incidents of fighting between the armed forces of these two ethnic groups as Mr. Meles's forces move into the south as a national army and clash with a rising tide of Oromo nationalism, according to reports from both sides.
In the last several days, units of both forces have clashed in the string of towns from the city of Harar in the east to Awash, about 200 miles west of Addis Ababa. In the last several months, there has also been fighting in the Oromo regions of Arusi, to the south of the capital, and in Wallaga, to the west.
 
War Hurts Farming
 The southern region is agriculturally the most fertile of this chronically food-short country, but the area is now so chaotic that farming has been severely curtailed, agricultural experts said.
In an interview, Mr. Meles, who is 37 years old, acknowledged that while the ethnic clashes were worrisome, "Things have not gone too far, yet."
"Once we have new security in place with a new police force and all armed groups inside camps, there should be no reasons for armed conflicts," he said. Mr. Meles said he was confident that the election of regional assemblies, planned for three months from now, would undercut Oromo or other ethnic secessionist sentiments.
But members of his own Government concede that it will be exceedingly difficult to hold regional elections in a poorly educated country that has never known democracy and with the ethnic tensions that prevail in the south. To keep Ethiopia together, Mr. Meles must prevent in other regions what he has agreed to in Eritrea, the northernmost province, which is already functioning as a separate entity. In mid-1993, the Eritreans are planning a United Nations referendum that will most likely confirm and legalize Eritrean independence.
Here in the Ethiopian capital, a valley of ramshackle iron-roofed houses and some dilapidated high-rises, the most obvious difference since the fall of the Colonel Mengistu is Government-sanctioned debate in coffee shops, on television and in the newspapers. After a 17-year era of Stalinesque fear, people are talking and grumbling, often on ethnic grounds. The previously dormant university is abuzz with students.
 
Rise in Banditry
 But against this backdrop of new-found expression, there is increased banditry in the city and countryside, mostly by destitute members of the demobilized, 500,000-member Mengistu army.
This insecurity will be aggravated, several Ethiopian and Western economists said, by the Government's disappointing economic plan. Announced last month, the long-awaited plan allowed for the privatizing of trading that left the rest of the already barely functioning economy, including the state farms, in the hands of the bankrupt Government.
This failure to make any serious commitment to economic reform may jeopardize much of the promised two-year package of $500 million from the World Bank, an Ethiopian economist familiar with the plan said.
Mr. Meles's case with the World Bank was not helped, Western diplomats said, since his two chief economic advisers, Kasu Ilala and Wanwossen Kebede, two loyalists from the Tigrean insurgency, appeared to be unreconstructed Marxists. Mr. Kasu's professional background is plant science and not finance, they added.

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
Excerpts From Bush-Miyazawa Remarks: 'Promoting Prosperity' in Pacific

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of the joint declaration released yesterday by President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, provided by The Associated Press, and excerpts from their joint news conference, provided by Reuters:
 
Cooperation to Promote World Peace and Prosperity
 The U.S.-Japan alliance provides the foundation for our global partnership. Together both nations pledge to: work together to maintain world peace and security, promote development of the world economy, support the worldwide trend toward democratization and market-oriented economies and meet new transnational challenges. To achieve these goals, the two countries will cooperate to strengthen the GATT multilateral trading system, reinvigorate the U.N. organization, advance arms control and the nonproliferation of weapons of mass destruction, assist the developing world to promote growth and stability, and protect and improve the global environment. 
. . . The United States and Japan are committed to promoting prosperity, reducing tensions, and enhancing political cooperation in the region and to take steps to strengthen the bonds of the Asia-Pacific community while respecting its diversity. . . .
Japan and the United States will also broaden the scope of their cooperation in the rest of the world, including the Middle East, Central and South America, Africa, and Europe, with particular attention to supporting countries that are in transition to democracy and market economies. The two nations will strengthen cooperation in their respective economic assistance programs in the developing world to promote growth and stability, help reduce the developmental gap between industrialized and developing countries, enhance respect for democratic values and human rights, and ameliorate global problems, including environmental degradation, refugees, illicit narcotics, disease and aging.
 
Political and Security Relations
 The U.S. and Japan reaffirm their commitments to the 1960 Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security which is central to the U.S.-Japan alliance. . . .
As countries with vital interests in the Asia-Pacific region, Japan and the United States recognize the continuing importance of the defense relationship to the peace and stability of this vast and diverse region. The two governments will work closely with others to reduce tensions and instability in East Asia and build regional political cooperation in the post-cold war environment.
Aware of the need for continuing vigilance as we enter a new era now marked by instability and uncertainty, the United States will maintain the forward-deployed forces necessary to preserve peace and stability in the region.
 
Economic and Trade Relations
 Aware of the high degree of interdependence of their economies and mindful of the need to encourage closer cooperation to promote conditions of sustainable real growth with price stability and employment, the two Governments are resolved to enhance openness and oppose protectionism in their commercial, financial and investment markets. To this end, Japan and the United States will strengthen policy initiatives to reduce structural impediments.
Japan and the United States further pledge to make their economies the most open, productive and competitive in the world, thereby building a sustainable trade and investment relationship. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q: Mr. President, people all around the world yesterday saw some very disturbing video of you collapsing in apparently very severe distress, that many of us are not accustomed to when we see people with the flu.
Can you describe what you were experiencing there, and also, can you say that your doctors have conclusively ruled out anything other than the flu, or will there be further tests?
PRESIDENT BUSH: No further tests. Totally ruled out anything other than the 24-hour flu. I've had an EKG, perfectly normal. Had blood pressure taken and probing around in all kinds of ways, and it's all going very well indeed. . . . Nothing else to it. And somebody asked me earlier, am I going to slow down my schedule?
I don't think it has anything to do with speed or slowness of a schedule. One of the businessmen who's young and aggressive and eager this morning, a young guy on this trip got it. I understand some of the journalists have had flu, and people in our country have had it, so why isn't the President entitled to 24 hours?
 . . . They've done all the checking in the world, the heart is normal, the thyroid or whatever's left of it is going fine, and I really have no hesitancy or worry at all.
 
Effect on Campaign
 Q: Are you at all concerned that now that you've had two quite sort of public health episodes that your -- some of the Democratic political opponents who are a lot younger than you might make a subtle issue out of the fact that you're somewhat older and perhaps --
PRESIDENT BUSH: Do you think only old people get the flu. . .? . . . I think Democrats get the flu from time to time. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Results of Trade Talks
 Q: Mr. President, American leaders since Nixon have been engaging in trade talks with Japan, emerging claiming great success, and nothing seems to change too much. And some of that, in a more specific sense, has been related to the American auto industry, relief from competition from Japan. And yet they continue to lose market share.
Some Americans feel it's because of bloated salaries in Detroit, because of lack of responsiveness to consumers, and the fact that, or the claim that they make cars that are not competitive. What's different in this round of trade talks and previous ones?
BUSH: . . . I think when you look at the agreements you're going to see that both sides have agreed to more in the way of auto parts, more in the way of autos coming into this country from the United States, and in a couple of other areas as well.
So I think there is some specificity to go with the hope in this case.
Q: Do you feel that the American auto industry has to do more to --
BUSH: Yes. I think we've got to do more as well, and not just in autos. In both the public and the private sector. One of the things that we haven't focused on here today is this economic growth agenda. And there the United States must do something. Japan is growing more than we are. So they should say, well, hey, how about yourselves? And we're saying we're going to submit a growth package, we're going to fight for it, we're going to try to get our interest rates down.
And we've got to do a better job in all industries, on building quality, improving competitiveness, knowledge and understanding of the Japanese market, so we can be vigorous competitors, based on more cultural understanding and background.
 
Attitudes Toward U.S.
 Q: (Inaudible) in your press conference on New Years Day you said you were thinking of America as (inaudible). My dictionary says that these were the feeling of sympathy, feeling of compassion. Why do you feel sympathy for America?
MIYAZAWA (through interpreter): Well, you use the words sympathy or compassion, and I would not claim that these are inaccurate, but what I really tried to say was that we have to understand the other person's position. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	But for various reasons, U.S. society, and I might say I believe the U.S. society is a great society, but there are homeless people, there is a problem of AIDS, and so on, and for various reasons education is not as high as in the past. And U.S. industries are not as competitive in the past for various reasons. Americans are pointing to these problems.
And since Americans themselves are aware of these problems, I am convinced they will overcome these problems. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Remarks at Pearl Harbor
 Q: (through interpreter) A question for the Prime Minister, you mentioned that we are very much touched by the President's speech at Pearl Harbor. Now bearing that in mind, I wonder how you would respond to the question asked by the President yesterday, Mr. Prime Minister.

 	 	 		. . .	 	MIYAZAWA (through interpreter): In the speech delivered by the President in Honolulu, he said he holds no rancor against Japan or Germany. These former enemies have become best friends for democracy. This is what basically he said.
There are quite a few warships that are sunk in Pearl Harbor with the dead bodies of the soldiers and with veterans in front of him. So I believe it was not easy for the President to say all those things, and that is why I was especially moved by the friendship shown by the President, the sense of trust expressed by the President.
Japan was able to grow this much thanks to the continued support and help by the United States. This again we should not forget. . . .
Now, the President in Honolulu also mentioned that we must fight against, or fight off isolationism and protectionism. And I think these words were uttered with Japan in mind. Now, in discussing economic issues this time, there was concern expressed that the entire world might fall into protectionism, and what can we do in order to prevent that.

HEADLINE: Health Care Battle Flares, Now Over a Disputed Study

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Two members of President Bush's Cabinet held a news conference today intended to show conclusively, with a major new study, that Democratic efforts to revamp the nation's health care system would increase taxes and unemployment and saddle employers with huge new costs.
But the chief author of the study, which was performed under Government contract, accused the Secretary of Labor, Lynn Martin, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Louis W. Sullivan, of misrepresenting the results of her research. 
 The author, Sheila R. Zedlewski, who has worked for the last 19 years at the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan research center here, said in an interview: "We chose not to go to the press conference today because political officials of the Labor Department presented a very inaccurate, incomplete portrayal of our study and gave only one side of the story. They did not focus on the beneficial aspects of universal access to health care. Our study does not even address the effect of these proposals on jobs."
The clash reflected the way politics pervades the discussion of health care in this Presidential election year. And it provided a textbook example of how Government officials use research to support their policies and objectives.
 
'Devaestating Effect' Predicted
 Ms. Martin, a former United States Representative from Illinois with well-honed political instincts, and Dr. Sullivan, a hematologist with comparatively little political experience, acclaimed the study as proof of their contention that one set of Democratic health care proposals in particular would have "a devastating effect on workers and jobs," as the Labor Department said in a statement today.
The proposals are sponsored by such influential Democrats as George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, and Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who heads the House Ways and Means Committee. They would require all employers to provide private health insurance for their workers or pay an additional payroll tax to help the Government provide such care.
Steven Hofman, a spokesman for Ms. Martin, and Richard P. Hinz, who supervises health policy research at the Labor Department, denied that Federal officials were misrepresenting the results of the study. Mr. Hofman said Ms. Martin was setting forth the "logical implications" of the study.
At the news conference this morning, Dr. Sullivan praised the Urban Institute as "a well-respected organization." He said its research demonstrated that the Democrats' health care proposals "would result in lost jobs, higher employer costs, higher taxes and a huge new Government-run health program."
 
Higher Cost to Taxpayers
 Ms. Martin said the study showed that the Democratic plan "will cost employers an additional $30 billion annually and will also result in a large subsidy, which will cost taxpayers $36 billion a year more than what the Federal Government now spends on health care."
In the later interview, Ms. Zedlewski did not dispute the figures cited by Ms. Martin but said the Secretary had skewed the study's findings by failing to cite the proposals' advantages as well.
The Administration attack comes just five days before nearly 200 Democratic members of the House hold town meetings across the country to hear constituents' complaints about health insurance and health care, widely seen as a politically potent issue in this year's elections.
In the language of the health care debate, the Democratic proposals are known as a "play or pay" program, because employers would have to provide insurance or pay the tax, at rates ranging from 7 to 9 percent of payroll.
Ms. Martin said: "Pay or play is misnamed. It is really pay and pay and pay and pay, by the middle class."
 
Bush's Record Criticized
 Senator Mitchell said the criticism from Ms. Martin and Dr. Sullivan today was consistent with Mr. Bush's record over the last three years. "The Administration has criticized other proposals while offering none of its own," the Senator said.
The President plans to send Congress a package of health care proposals later this month. They include incentives for people to enroll in prepaid group health plans and tax credits for the purchase of health insurance.
The Urban Institute study is an assessment of costs and benefits, including coverage of the more than 34 million Americans who now have no health insurance. The study does not endorse or oppose any specific plan.
The report said "play or pay" proposals would increase insurance costs for many employers. But it also said that under such proposals "all Americans would have access to health care on a more equal basis," and that the burden of medical expenses would be reduced for many families.
Ms. Zedlewski explained: "Many people would have lower out-of-pocket medical costs. Many employers would save money under these proposals because the payroll tax would be less than their current health insurance premiums."
The study said that if the payroll tax rate was set at 7 percent, more than half the nation's nonelderly population -- 112 million people out of 216.6 million under 65 years of age -- would be enrolled by their employers in the Government health plan. The study said that 51.7 million people now insured through employer-sponsored health plans would shift to the public plan.
Dr. Sullivan said the Democratic proposals "would constitute a fatal first step down a slippery slope toward nationalized medicine."
The study did not analyze more sweeping Democratic proposals for national health insurance financed entirely by the Federal Government. Dr. Sullivan has denounced that approach even more forcefully than he criticized the pay or play proposals.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Lynn Martin, Secretary of Labor, discussed a new study on Democratic health care proposals at a news conference yesterday. The chief author of the study accused them of misrepresenting the results. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN: Bush's Painful Trip;
Japanese Feel the Talks Will Not Help U.S. Economy or Rapport With Tokyo

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 10

 BODY:
As President Bush's grueling trade mission in Asia ended this morning on a note of confusion and discord, perhaps the reason was that without realizing it, the participants in Japan had given birth to the first summit meeting between rival superpowers in the post-cold-war era.
All the old trappings of past confrontations between the Soviet Union and the United States were in Tokyo this week -- talks that churned past midnight, fact sheets, briefing sessions, dueling news conferences and a chorus of angry assertions and counterassertions of deception and bad faith. 
 But instead of negotiating missile silos and warheads, the disagreements focused on auto parts procurement practices and standards for dashboard warning lights.
"Arms-control negotiators always used to say that 'the devil is in the details,' " said a Japanese diplomat. "Now I know what they meant."
 
Little Gain Expected
 There was no specter of nuclear war, of course. But negotiators seemed to realize that if the huge and growing trade deficit between Japan and the United States was not brought under control, it could drive Tokyo and Washington apart, hurt their economies and damage Mr. Bush's re-election prospects.
It was too early to discern the American political effects of the Tokyo talks. But the widespread view in Japan was that the negotiators' efforts would not help the American economy or Mr. Bush's political fortunes, and indeed that they could lead to even deeper Japanese-American antagonism.
Mr. Bush's hopes for a clear signal of greater Japanese purchases of American automobiles, auto parts and other products were shattered when an accord hammered out on such purchases was criticized by Japanese and American manufacturers as having little force or meaning.
Japan, on the other hand, had hoped to transcend petty trade disputes and take note of Tokyo's leadership in aiding poor nations, refugees and the environment. But no new initiatives were announced in those areas, and trade issues were as prominent as ever and likely to become more bitter.
 
Talk of Insults
 The negative tone of Japanese commentary on the whole United States approach was scathing.
"Is there not a decent individual in the Bush Government who truly understands Japan?" a columnist, Takahiro Oda, said in the Asahi newspaper today, after listing what he said were insults to the Japanese leadership by the White House's hectoring demands for purchases of American products.
As for insults, Americans too chafed today, when Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's pledge to work on trade issues came with a distinct edge to it.
Mentioning AIDS, homelessness and declining education standards as the root of American trade problems, the Prime Minister said, "Since Americans themselves are aware of these problems, I am convinced they will overcome these problems because I believe that the United States is a great country."
 
Error of Summitry
 The scene of Mr. Bush's illness and gallant recovery the next day muted the images of hostility, especially for Mr. Miyazwa, who held the stricken President's head, comforted Mrs. Bush and encouraged her to reassure a dinner banquet frozen in fear over the spectacle Wednesday night.
Barbara Bush was such a hit with the Japanese audiences that her face was immediately spread all over the popular newspapers. The wives and widows of every recent Prime Minister were interviewed, commenting how admiring they were of her graceful and witty television performance.
But in pushing Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa into the arcane matters of trade negotiations, Japan and the United States seemed to have committed a cardinal error of summitry, in that they raised the stakes and involved the principal leaders before the time was ripe for an agreement.
"Japan and the United States should not have committed themselves to negotiating these topics until the talks have reached a more advanced stage," said Yukio Okamoto, a business consultant and former Japanese diplomat. "These are really complicated matters. What I fear now is a backlash."
 
Japan's Criticism
 As his news conference, Mr. Bush seemed uncomfortable with the details of the automobile accord and turned aside all questions about it, asking that they be directed to other specialists. But he said he was convinced that the deals on automobiles would produce jobs for Americans.
For Mr. Bush the whole trip in Asia started inauspiciously early last year, when it was first scheduled and canceled because of the Persian Gulf war. Then it was scheduled for November but canceled because of the President's need to attend to domestic politics.
By the time he got to Japan, he added major new demands for the automobile industry, whose troubles are major issues in the Presidential campaign. But that set off unsparing criticism among the Japanese. Newspapers seem to delight in traditional metaphors, like calling Mr. Bush's party an ominous return of the "black ships" of Commodore Perry in the 19th century that forced Japan to open its borders to trade.
Still others have noted that the anti-American mood in Japan extends to the latest Godzilla movie, in which the famous sea monster defends Japan against marauding foreigners who want the Japanese to adopt a foreign computer standard as a means of subjugation.
 
Sympathy and Symbolism
 The mood reached a crescendo as Mr. Bush arrived but was suddenly dissipated by the sympathy that Japanese showed when the President collapsed at dinner on Wednesday night. But even there some commentators said that it was symbolic that Mr. Bush, like the United States, had run out of energy and needed help from Japan and Mr. Miyazawa.
The summit meeting showed most of all that Japan might have taken a few steps to placate American demands, but Tokyo declined to see the problem as the United States did: a question of a "level playing field" in which outsiders could have more access.
Instead of opening up its markets, Japan simply responded by pledging to purchase enough new imports to defuse anti-Japanese anger in Washington. Aside from revising some of its standardization and inspection procedures, Japan left the basic rules of free trade unchanged, particularly in the case of the auto accords. That was, in fact, a major step in carrying out what the United States has said it opposes: managed trade.
All week, Mr. Miyazawa appealed to Japanese and to Japanese auto companies to make some sacrifice for the United States out of sympathy or compassion. At a news conference at the Shinto shrine of Ise, he tried to stir sympathy for the American condition but sounded, to some Americans, very patronizing.
 
Tokyo's Coming of Age
 "We must appreciate how seriously layoffs are in America," he said. "Imagine a family where the mother has to tell her children, 'Dad no longer goes to work tomorrow.' Layoffs are the kind of thing which throws many families into despair. The President is coming to Japan against the background of such economic and social worries."
What that reflected was itself a coming of age for Japan, in that the country was being asked to respond from a position of strength to help what the Prime Minister called "a friend in need."
The main thing that Japan wanted out of this week's summit meeting was a new burst of credibility for the concept of "global partnership." But Japanese officials had to admit that there was not much new in the extensive statements about all the initiatives between Japan and the United States.

QUESTION OF CASH
It is common in the business world for people to talk about profits and the infamous "bottom line." But slowly and with little fanfare, as customers fail to pay their bills on time, many small and medium-sized businesses in the New York City area are being strangled by a simple lack of cash, raising the prospect that still more companies could succumb to bankruptcy before this recession is over. A1.

WALL ST. PROJECT IN JEOPARDY

In the first punishment stemming from the nine deaths at a City College basketball game, the administrator responsible for overseeing the students staging the event has been stripped of such authority. B3.
 
GUILTY PLEA IN SON'S DEATH
In a calm, unemotional voice, Shulamis Riegler admitted in a Brooklyn courtroom that she had killed her 8-year-old mentally retarded son Yaakov, twisting his leg so violently that she heard the bone crack. She is to be sentenced to a term of 7 1/2 to 15 years in prison for the killing, which raised troubling questions about the city's system of protecting abused children. B3.

An internal struggle among the leaders of the 10 unions representing workers at The Daily News could be the first crisis in the effort to save the bankrupt paper. HEADLINE: NETWORKS TO SAVE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
The three major television networks and CNN have agreed on a money-saving innovation for covering the New Hampshire Presidential primary. Starting Jan. 27, each of them will start sharing some of its videotape with the rest.
"Each of us will donate a crew each day to contribute material to the pool," said Tom Hannon, the political director of CNN. "It's an experiment we're trying for the first time in a primary, although it's not any sort of radical departure. It's the same sort of pool arrangement that we routinely use for covering hearings and other events in Washington." 
 The four news outlets, all under pressure to cut costs this campaign, agreed last week to set up the pool coverage effort through the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18. Their assignment editors will confer daily to deploy four crews, whose producers and technicians will record candidates' speeches and other public events. Videotape will be gathered daily in Manchester, N.H., and fed to the four networks and any other news organization that decides to subscribe.
 
'Just Protective Coverage'
 "The idea is to save time, money and effort by having one camera doing the body watch for everyone," said Hal Bruno, the political director for ABC News. "It's really just protective coverage. We'll still be sending in our own crew with a correspondent when we want to do a piece on a candidate."
The pooling arrangement gives pause to some news-media critics, among them Marvin Kalb, a former network correspondent who is the director of the Joan Shorenstein Barone Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard University.
"There's certainly a potential for this kind of cut to have an impact on the quality of coverage," he said. "It's true that a pool is just as good for routine coverage of speeches, but any arrangement that diminishes the competitive fires of the networks worries me. This is yet another illustration of the power of economics to determine campaign coverage."
Network officials acknowledge that economics are the chief motive for the pooling, but they say the change might produce some benefits beyond cost savings. In the last campaign the networks were criticized for focusing too much effort on staged events, and for televising some less-than-newsworthy eventssimply to justify the money spent covering them.
 
Fewer Crews, More Film
 "This should free up money to spend on more focused coverage of the issues and the candidates' qualifications," said Bill Wheatley, the director of political coverage at NBC News. "And it should expand our reach. Even though individual networks will have fewer crews in New Hampshire than in 1988, each of us will have more overall footage available."
The pool experiment will last until at least the day after the New Hampshire primary. The networks' political directors said they might try a similar arrangements for future primaries and for the general election campaign in the fall. They have also been discussing a proposal to have an outside organization, the Election Satellite Network, provide videotape of all the candidates' daily activities.

HEADLINE: Big Exchange Withdraws From Joint Futures Project

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
The board of the New York Mercantile Exchange has withdrawn from a plan to build a joint headquarters with four other futures exchanges, a decision that has stunted the project and may kill it.
As a result, the city is reassessing its commitment to the project, while officials for the consortium of exchanges say they plan to proceed with a smaller building on the same site in TriBeCa. 
 All the exchanges -- the Mercantile, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange Inc., the Commodity Exchange Inc., the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange -- have indicated that they plan to stay in New York, said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
"We're assessing how best to accomplish that," he said.
The withdrawal of the Mercantile Exchange, by far the largest of the five exchanges, has dealt a serious blow to the project.
"We wanted the exchanges in a position where we can enter the 21st century," said Martin Greenberg, chairman of the Commodity Exchange, the second-largest exchange. The Merc's decision to go it alone, he said, "reduces your competitiveness globally."
 
Changing Conditions Cited
 The new building, originally proposed as a 47-story tower, was to be built on a city-owned lot bounded by Greenwich, Warren, Murray and West Streets.
In explaining his board members' unanimous decision to abandon the project, R. Patrick Thompson, president of the Mercantile Exchange, said that both premises on which the members had originally based their support had "evaporated."
The first was that the building would serve as an "industry center," with space not only for the five exchanges but also for some of their more than 1,000 members. But tumbling rents in lower Manhattan made offices in the new building unattractive to the members.
The second premise was that consolidation of some functions, like computer tracking of trades, would save the exchanges upward of $8 million annually. But the exchanges, which have a long history of squabbling among themselves, could not agree on a new, joint system.
Planning for the center began more than a year ago, when the five exchanges announced that they were unhappy with their cramped trading floor in the World Trade Center and would relocate to northern New Jersey, taking about $160 million in tax dollars and 11,700 jobs with them.
To keep the exchanges, New York City and state promised to pay $100 million toward building the commodities center, and later came up with an additional $42 million in tax breaks and rent subsidies.
From the beginning, the commodities center was dogged by community opposition.
"The fact that the Merc has pulled out really undermines the whole idea of the project," said Nancy Page, a member of Community Board One, which has been fighting the commodities center.
The building as originally proposed was to have two trading floors. The departure of the Merc will lead to a smaller structure, with one trading floor, said David Halperin, president of the Commodity Exchange.
One possibility, city officials said, is that the Merc is bluffing.
A letter dated May 6 from the chairman of the board of directors of the Merc, Z. Lou Guttman, to the board may support that view. Mr. Guttman wrote that he favored dropping out of the project because the move might lead to the merger of the exchanges' functions "that we all want." He said that if the Merc withdrew, the city and the other exchanges "would all be scrambling to put together a merger."
Mr. Thompson said it was "highly, highly, highly unlikely" that the Merc would reverse its decision.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Uncommon Effort Aids Quayle's Common Touch

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LACONIA, N.H., Jan. 9

 BODY:
He ate milk and cookies by the fire. He dropped his suit coat for a green high school varsity jacket. He ate breakfast at a diner. He shook hands with what seemed like every schoolchild between Littleton and Laconia.
Just in case anyone missed the point after two days of trying to make it, he even dropped into a restaurant called The Common Man this afternoon. 
 In more than three dozen events in 13 towns, Vice President Dan Quayle has offered what might almost have been a conservative Republican's version of a populist message: He said the poor as well as the rich should be given their choice of schools and railed against both the "stupidity" of banks that made bad loans in the 1980's and what he called the timidity of bankers who now put their money in Treasury bonds instead of business loans and mortgages.
For Mr. Quayle, the common touch often seems as elusive as it is for his boss, President Bush, but Mr. Quayle tried hard for it nevertheless on Wednesday and today as he campaigned through snowy mountain country and covered-bridge small towns in New Hampshire.
Do candidates believe they can convince the voters that politicians are just like them? Probably not, but the need to attain that aura of just-plain-folksiness seems to be an unwritten law of campaigning.
Especially when you are campaigning in a state like New Hampshire, which holds the first Presidential primary every four years and expects its candidates to visit them personally. And especially when you are under fire for being too aloof in the first place from the problems of everyday Americans.
So Mr. Quayle stayed overnight at Doc Hill's house in Littleton, telling audiences the next day how he sipped milk and nibbled chocolate chip cookies by the fire. When he appeared on the NBC program "Today" this morning, there he was in the Hill kitchen, a spotless and seemingly empty cup of coffee at his elbow and the good doctor and his wife behind him at another table, eating breakfast.
Mr. Quayle ate his breakfast at the Littleton Diner and he dropped in to places during the day like the Town Hall-cum-theater-cum-basketball court in Lisbon, where the town's entire school-age population screamed and squealed for him like he was a rock star.
In Woodsville, Mr. Quayle put on a team jacket presented by the high school student body president and waved a varsity letter over his head.
And in Ashland, he posed for cameras outside The Common Man, a restaurant whose fare is more nouvelle than homespun.
The theatricality of these touches does not seem to bother Mr. Quayle or his audiences. For Steven Huntington, an unemployed builder who "out of curiosity" attended a Littleton Elks Club breakfast at which Mr. Quayle spoke this morning, the common touches are all just part of politics.
"I'm not sure it accomplishes a heck of a lot, but people at least feel they have some contact with the powers that be," Mr. Huntington said as he patted his 2-week-old daughter, Eliza, as she slept against his shoulder.
Mr. Quayle spied the child as soon as he walked into the room and walked straight over. He did not kiss her. But he put his finger into her tiny fist and then 15 minutes later mentioned her by name as he spoke of the importance of education.
Mr. Huntington, a lifelong Democrat, laughed good-naturedly. "Oh, yeah," he said. "I'm voting for him now. He's locked up my vote."
 
On Liability and Credit
 While Mr. Quayle and Mr. Bush like to say they are aware that the President bears the responsibility when things go wrong (the economy, for instance), they are zealously looking for ways to avoid taking the blame.
For months, the Republican Administration has been blaming the Democratic Congress for not passing the President's legislation. But even Bush campaign advisers have had to admit that is not the best way to approach the re-election debate, and they have been casting about for new methods of framing the "it's not our fault" argument.
Confronted by residents of a state whose construction and real estate industries are, as Mr. Quayle put it today, "in the tank," the Vice President tried blaming the banks. He acknowledged that both private irresponsibility and Government inaction had led to the savings-and-loan crisis, and that some discretion was a good thing in making loans.
But Mr. Quayle said in several campaign appearances today that the time has come for banks to resume lending to home buyers and small-business men, and he insisted there was little the Government could do to compel them in that direction.
"How are you going to regulate stupidity?" he said. "How are you going to regulate mistakes? How are you going to regulate bad judgment?"
Mr. Quayle added: "Now they are going the other way, saying: 'Boy, let's not get risky here. Take the safe way. Take the safe course.' But we're saying, risk is part of the American way. Let's get out and do business."
 
Not All Congress's Fault
 Mr. Quayle concentrated in New Hampshire on countering the challenge to Mr. Bush from a Republican conservative, Patrick J. Buchanan. But he did not entirely forget about Democrats, and he did not entirely forget about Congress.
"I'm not going to say it's all Congress's fault," he said in Woodsville. "Most of it is."
Still trying to counter the notion that Mr. Bush is too engaged in foreign policy and not enough in domestic affairs, Mr. Quayle turned on Congress to explain what he said was the gap between the President's diplomatic prowess and his "frustration in domestic policy."
"In foreign affairs, the President decides what is in the best interests of this country, and he does it," Mr. Quayle said. He added: "He decided it was in the best interest of the country to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. He didn't have to ask Congress when to begin the air war. He didn't have to ask Congress when to begin the ground war."
But Mr. Quayle said, "In domestic policy he needs the total cooperation of the Congress." And Mr. Quayle noted, of course, that Congress is controlled by Democrats.

HEADLINE: December Producer Prices Fell

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
Prices received by American producers fell two-tenths of 1 percent in December, another sign that the economy remained weak, Labor Department figures showed today.
Prices also eased, although by the slenderest of margins -- one-tenth of 1 percent -- for 1991 as a whole, the first full-year decline in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods since 1986, when oil prices collapsed. 
 Inflation by this measure "is basically nonexistent," said Robert T. McGee, an economist at the Tokai Bank in New York, noting that only one category, tobacco products, posted double-digit price increases for the year.
Excluding food and energy, which swing erratically, producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, half the average of core inflation for October and November, and 3.1 percent for all of 1991.
In another report showing a sluggish economy, the department said new claims for state jobless benefits rose 22,000 in the week ended Dec. 28, to 458,000, with the biggest increases in Wisconsin, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania. [Page D2.]
 
Bonds Rise and Fall
 The two reports drove bond prices up and interest rates down, but the market subsequently slumped on various rumors involving the President's health, a possible rise in payroll jobs in Friday's labor-market report for December and diplomatic pressure for cuts in German rates. Such cuts would be politically difficult in Germany, where the Government reported inflation last year climbed to 3.5 percent, the highest level in a decade.
The producer-price report provided additional maneuvering room for the Federal Reserve if it is inclined to make another round of cuts in interest rates to spur economic recovery. But it appeared that most analysts thought the Fed, which made a sharp cut on Dec. 20, would await data to be published in the next few weeks.
In this view, the central bank already assumes a weak December job performance, with payrolls down perhaps 75,000 or more.
 
Stronger Profits Expected
 Companies find that the sluggish demand and intensified competition that characterize a poor economy generally act to prevent them from raising prices, even when they are experiencing higher costs. But many businesses have responded vigorously to this squeeze by cutting payroll and other costs, so that corporate profits are expected to rise substantially this year.
In addition to the lower prices for finished goods last month, companion Producer Price Indexes showed prices falling two-tenths of 1 percent at the intermediate stage of production and a hefty 2.2 percent for crude goods. Crude goods had not dropped this much since February and March, when the Iraqi-related run-up in oil prices was reversed.
As examples, a suit of clothes would be a finished product, a bolt of cloth an intermediate product and raw cotton a crude commodity.
Price changes at the producer -- sometimes called wholesale -- level tend to be reflected on store shelves within several months. At 3.1 percent for 1991, core inflation for the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was significantly less than the 4.5 percent core rate for the Consumer Price Index over the latest 12 months. However, most of this difference is accounted for by the fact that the the consumer price measure includes both imported goods and services while the producer price measures do not, so consumers cannot necessarily expect to see the same low level of inflation as reported at the producer level.
For December, the price of energy goods fell 1.4 percent, the first decline since July, even though the cost of residential electricity turned up and residential gas continued to rise. Food prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent as fresh and dried vegetables, paced by lettuce and tomatoes, tumbled 15.2 percent after jumping 23.6 percent in November. Egg prices rose sharply after falling for three straight months.
 
Tobacco Keeps Rising
 Tobacco rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, ending the year 13.1 percent higher, its fifth consecutive annual rise of over 10 percent
Capital equipment rose two-tenths of 1 percent for the month, despite a 1.2 percent decline for the computer sector.
In intermediate goods, prices turned down for energy, for nondurable factory goods like organic chemicals and wood pulp, and for foods and feeds. The price of flour rose substantially for the fifth straight month.
Durable factory goods, like refined copper and flat glass, were unchanged, the report showed, while construction materials turned up by two-tenths of 1 percent.
"We can expect conditions to remain soft in manufacturing," suggested Alan C. Lerner, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company.
 
Big Drop in Energy
 Among crude goods, energy accounted for most of the price drop although feeds also fell, slightly more than in November. Crude petroleum dropped 13.8 percent while coal prices turned down; natural gas rose 5.2 percent but this was somewhat less than in November.
Prices rose for aluminum base scrap and phosphates, while declines slowed for cotton, copper scrap and softwood logs. However, price declines accelerated for iron and steel scrap and for silver ores, while cattle hides and copper ores turned down following increases the month before.
The finished goods index now stands at 121.9, or 21.9 percent higher than its 1982 base. Updated weights, based on 1987 production patterns, will be introduced with the report for January, to be published Feb. 14.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Borg-Warner Names New Chief Executive

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The Borg-Warner Corporation has named Donald C. Trauscht as its chief executive, the company said yesterday.
Mr. Trauscht, 59 years old, ho had been president and chief operating officer since September, replaces James F. Bere, Borg-Warner's longtime leader, who died after a heart attack last Friday at age 69. 
 Mr. Trauscht said he was not planning large changes for the Chicago-based company's two divisions, automotive parts and protective services. Mr. Trauscht and Mr. Bere had worked closely together to develop strategies during many of Mr. Trauscht's 25 years at Borg-Warner. "Our minds, if you will, were almost joined together in strategy and how operations should be conducted," he said.
Those operations include the company's $800 million automotive parts division, which makes transmissions and drive-train components. Although its business has been hurt by slow sales in the recession-battered automobile industry, Borg-Warner is expanding its operations in Europe and the Far East. For example, it is investing in a $200 million plant in Japan, where Borg-Warner supplies all the auto makers. The company has operated in Japan since the 1950's.
Borg-Warner is also developing new technology, including continuously variable transmissions and variable camshaft timing, to help improve automotive gasoline mileage. Mr. Trauscht predicted that those products would be introduced in about four years.
The Borg-Warner protective services division is more diversified and includes Wells Fargo and Burns guards, Pony Express couriers and Wells Fargo armored car services.
In addition to Mr. Trauscht's appointment, the company named Neal F. Farrell executive vice president for administration. He continues to have responsibility for financial and legal issues.
Mr. Trauscht began his career with Borg-Warner in 1967 as director of corporate planning. In 1978, he was named vice president of business development and acquisitions. Four years later, he was appointed vice president for corporate planning, and in 1987, he was named corporate vice president for finance and strategy. In December 1990, he was also named president of Borg-Warner Automotive.
Mr. Trauscht has a bachelor's degree in physics from St. Mary's College in Winona, Minn., and a master's degree in business from the University of Chicago.
He and his wife, Arlene, have three children and live in Oak Brook, Ill.

HEADLINE: New Jobless-Benefit Claims Up 22,000 in Late December

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9

 BODY:
The number of Americans applying for unemployment benefits climbed by 22,000 in the last full week of December, ending a fourth quarter in which claims steadily crept higher, according to a Government report released today.
The Labor Department said 458,000 people filed new claims for state jobless benefits in the holiday-shortened week that ended Dec. 28, up from the previous week's level of 436,000, as layoffs continued to batter the economy. 
 "It reinforces what we know -- that the economy in the fourth quarter was weak," said Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation. "This just shows the continuation of the trend,"
The four-week moving average of weekly jobless claims, considered a more accurate gauge of the nation's employment picture than the more volatile weekly figure, rose to 463,500 from 452,500 for the previous four weeks.
"The data show a continuing movement upward in the moving average, which tends to smooth out the week-to-week variations," Mr. Logan said.
Fred Sturm, senior economist at Fuji Securities, said he expected the average weekly rate to "dig in its heels somewhere around 450,000" before possibly moving downward.
He said today's report served as mild evidence supporting his theory that new claims are peaking.
The number of Americans actually receiving unemployment benefits fell by 280,000, to 3.175 million, in the week that ended Dec. 21, the latest period for which data were available.
The latest figures will not be reflected in Friday's report on December unemployment. The data for that report were collected in the week that ended Dec. 12.
But analysts were not expecting the news to be any better. They anticipated a loss of 70,000 jobs in non-farm payrolls and an increase in the unemployment rate to 6.9 percent from 6.8 percent, according to a Reuters survey. That report will reflect conditions before the Federal Reserve slashed interest rates on Dec. 20.
