HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Expressway's Good Samaritan Loves His Work

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
Here's a job description for you: Up at 5 A.M. to drive off by 5:45. Spend four hours seeking trouble on the expressway. Inhabit traffic jams of grumpy motorists reading, telephoning, fuming, shaving or applying makeup. Find stubborn stalls, fires, accidents, hysterical drivers, women in labor, startled children, men in fistfights. With luck, crawl under a disabled car in the rain with a flashlight in your mouth. Fix a transmission leak. Accept no payments. Perhaps be thanked.
In spare time, monitor six radios and two telephones. Every 30 minutes go on the air to chat smoothly about traffic for miles around. 
 At 3:30 P.M., do it all over again for grumpy homebound commuters.
It's not easy being a good Samaritan these days, especially along the grimy multilane suburban maelstroms that are the modern American expressway. But Matt McGuy loves his work.
"I get to help people and fix things," he said, "and I don't have to get them to pay me."
The job of the 38-year-old Mr. McGuy is to repair disabled vehicles, which gets travelers on their ways quicker, clears the highways safely and sooner and -- who knows? -- maybe earns goodwill for his corporate sponsor, Texaco. "We love the response to Matt," said Joan Gilbert, community relations manager for Texaco's Westchester headquarters.
Mr. McGuy's territory is Interstate 287 in a 20-mile corridor of concrete across Westchester County from Port Chester to Tarrytown that then soars over the Hudson River on the Tappan Zee Bridge to Nyack. His transportation turf is not like the city expressways' crumbling rock walls seemingly held up by generations of graffiti, roving packs of wheeled bandits and burned hulks of yesterday's disabled cars.
But it does have its dangers. His roadway is a well-littered, often high-speed, no-holds-barred no-man's-land where deadly wheels whiz by just a few feet away. That explains why Mr. McGuy never turns his back to oncoming traffic.
Technically, Mr. McGuy works for Samaritania Inc., a Massachusetts company operating do-good vans in a dozen Northeast communities. For about $100,000 a year, a sponsor gets its name on a vehicle and an association with thousands of free favors. All drivers are trained in mechanics, emergency medical techniques, firefighting and a range of social skills to defuse many drivers' often-emotional encounters with cars that dare to fail them. "Some people can make the biggest deal out of a flat tire," Mr. McGuy said in wonder. "I fix it, ba-dee ba-dum, and they're outta here."
With his keen diagnostic eye and ear, Mr. McGuy translates grinding sounds into failed bearings, steam into thirsty radiators and silence into cracked distributor caps. His van carries fuels, oil, fluids, jacks, sprays, plugs, wires, fan belts, fire extinguishers, first-aid kits and even new teddy bears for frightened young passengers. "That was my daughter Paula's idea," he said.
For extra exposure, each van broadcasts regular traffic reports to a local radio station. Mr. McGuy, who doesn't mind the mild local fame accompanying his regular radio appearances, is heard on Westchester's WXPS-FM, billing itself as The Express 107.1.
With their thousands of self-important kilowatts, most of New York City's more powerful stations still seem to think that all roads, tunnels and bridges lead to Manhattan. Their traffic reports sometimes range as distant as Long Island or New Jersey's nearest counties.
But development of outlying office and industrial parks has created new economic, cultural, political and commuting orbits, meaning the one-time suburbs are no longer sub-anything. Thousands of drivers bustling from homes in, say, Rockland County to jobs in Westchester or Fairfield County in Connecticut have been left to fend for themselves anticipating tie-ups. Enter a squad of weak-voiced but aggressive suburban stations. "We're killing 'em with our local traffic reports," said Ira Kleinman, WXPS's general manager, who actually has two local traffic reporters interrupting music with urgent reports on things like "a backup at the 287 split."
Most of the time, however, Mr. McGuy is fixing cars or working the radios to spot traffic trouble. Many truckers, when they can interrupt their CB chatter, supplement Mr. McGuy's information. Many of 287's traffic problems have a familiar pattern: Friday afternoons are the heaviest, Monday mornings the worst for breakdowns and more midweek drivers get lost. "Where's Main?" asked one.
Mr. McGuy himself is fresh from a family trip. The McGuys saw Walt Disney World. The man who commutes 250 miles a day without ever arriving is asked how he traveled there. "Are you kidding?" he said. "Plane."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Matt McGuy, who repairs disabled vehicles and clears the highways along Interstate 287 in Westchester. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Dow Up 5.59; Small Issues Set the Pace

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks rose in choppy trading yesterday, with a number of indexes repeating their almost daily feat of reaching new highs. Shrinking interest rates still leave investors with few alternatives to shifting money into equities.l
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.59 points, to a new closing high of 3,209.53. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange remained heavy at 292.4 million shares, up from 290.8 million on Wednesday. 
 Gaining issues on the Big Board easily outpaced losers, 1,014 to 783, as the Big Board composite ended unchanged at 230.23.
 
Nasdaq Index at High
 While the market did finish higher, it was up even more earlier in the day. Stocks other than the larger blue- chip issues continued to attract the new money coming into the market, as the Nasdaq composite again closed at a new high of 619.80, up 9.48 points, and the Russell 2,000, a barometer of smaller issues, rose 2.48 points, to 200.58, also a high.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell short for the day and slipped 0.49 point, to 417.61, as the American Stock Exchange index posted a new closing high of 407.57, up 4.09 points.
David Chao, senior vice president for trading at County NatWest Securities, said the market was a little skittish, with the Dow running up and down, then up again. Large professional traders were ready to step out of the market on any kind of news, he said.
"At some point the market has to sell off, since volatility usually comes at the top and bottom of market moves," he said. "We've had good volatility over the past three days along with good volume, an indication that the market may be a little heavy."
The day's rally was assisted by a drop of two-tenths of a percent in producer prices for December and a firm bond market. The selloff in the afternoon may have been started by rumors that information had been leaked showing that employment numbers expected today would be stronger than expected and thus leave little room for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates further, analysts said.
Birinyi Associates, a research firm that also tracks program trading, said there was a fair amount of it yesterday with four buy and four sell programs, which had a net impact of a 0.45-point decline on the Dow.
Elsewhere in the market, JWP Inc. a technical services company, rose by as much as 1 to close up 3/8 at 18 1/4, as David Loeb, an analyst at Oppenmheimer & Company, upgraded his rating on the company to "buy," from "market performer" and raised his 1992 earnings estimates. Mr Loeb said the company's earnings propects for the second half were better than they had been.
Healthtrust Inc., a medical-hospital management and service company, rose by 3 3/4, to 22 1/4, as Lucy Olwell, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, initiated coverage of the company with a "buy" rating.
Adobe Systems , which was among the over-the-counter actives, fell 2 5/8, to 63. Traders said the software company's fourth-quarter earnings of 57 cents a share were below market expectations, as Alex. Brown & Sons lowered its 1992 earnings forecast.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Building a Consumer Economy Amid Communism's Ruins

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AN actor dressed as a dentist, complete with white coat, holds up a package of toothpaste and slowly explains how toothpaste works to make teeth stronger. An American television commercial of the 1950's? No. A 1992 Hungarian television commercial.
A stylishly dressed woman matter-of-factly discusses feminine hygiene. 
 An American television commercial of the 1990's? No. A 1992 Polish television commercial.
Those contrasting spots, for Blend A Med toothpaste and Always sanitary napkins, were both created by the same agency, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc. They typify what American shops are experiencing as part of their embryonic efforts to expand into Eastern Europe.
Preconceived notions about marketing to the former East bloc nations, particularly a belief that what worked in this country after World War II can serve as a primer to turn Eastern Europeans into Western-style consumers, are being disproved almost daily.
"Even calling it 'Eastern Europe,' to the Czechs, Hungarians and Poles, is talking down to them," said Andy Bielanski, D.M.B.& B.'s managing director for Central and Eastern Europe, who supervises the agency's operations in those countries from an office in Budapest. "They'd much rather it be called 'Central Europe.' "
In an interview the other day at D.M.B.& B.'s midtown Manhattan headquarters, Mr. Bielanski, who had returned to this country for the holidays, spoke about the trial-and-error process, sometimes humorous, always instructive, by which the agency is learning about a part of the world where it was thought a primary duty of an advertising agency was, as in Czechoslovakia, to supply mannequins to department stores.
Unlike postwar America, which embraced consumerism with a zeal never before seen, in Eastern Europe "you're dealing with skepticism right from the start," Mr. Bielanski said. "Under Communism, if a product was advertised, it was in oversupply and of poor quality."
That skepticism even extends to something as simple as using percentages in advertisements, he added, because of their previous association with quotas under multiyear centrally planned economies.
"We tested using percentages of cavity reduction in our toothpaste ads," said Arthur Selkowitz, the agency's New York-based executive vice president, international, who joined Mr. Bielanski for the interview. "But it was not credible."
And a disdain for authority figures, intensified over years of Communist rule, affected how the agency presented the actor-cum-dentist in the toothpaste spot. "We picked someone who was very warm," Mr. Bielanski said, "who wasn't beating his chest, because people wouldn't believe that."
Another agency expectation not realized was a theory that "the American experience in product categories would be very relevant," he added -- for instance, emphasizing in advertising for, say, a soap, that it is the best-selling soap in America.
"It turned out that was too far from their daily experience," he continued. "They wanted something closer to their reality." As a result, the ads the agency has produced have focused specifically on the benefits the products being advertised are intended to deliver to Czechoslovaks, Hungarians and Poles.
D.M.B.& B.'s billings in the region for clients like Procter & Gamble, which makes Blend A Med -- the European version of Crest -- and Always, as well as Mars Inc. and Burger King, are expected to approach $10 million this year, Mr. Selkowitz said. That figure, which also includes billings at the agency's Moscow office, is around the level of billings of a D.M.B.& B. office in a country like Greece, India or Malaysia, he added.
But, he continued, the "hope is that growth will be exponential," noting that at this time last year, as the agency's efforts in Eastern Europe were beginning, billings there totaled $1 million to $2 million.
D.M.B.& B. is one of several giant American agencies now operating in Eastern Europe. Others include Backer Spielvogel Bates, Leo Burnett, Ogilvy & Mather and Young & Rubicam.

(D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles)

HEADLINE: BUSH IN JAPAN;
Europeans Ready to Protest if Trade Accord Leaves Them Out

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Time

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 9

 BODY:
European officials and auto executives here reacted with concern to a Japanese agreement to increase sharply purchases of American-made autos and auto parts, saying that the accord was unacceptable if it did not open the way for the purchase of more European-made products, too.
If the trade deal hammered out in a week of tough trade talks merely opens Japanese markets to all by removing barriers to imports, European officials said, they would then welcome the measures as an opportunity to compete on equal terms. 
 But some European officials insisted that if it turns out the Japanese offered targets for purchases of American-made goods, as seems to be the case, then European companies will insist on equal treatment for BMW's, Fiats, Volvos and other European autos.
 
Changing the Game
 "If the game we are playing changes from bridge to hockey, then we will want to have a hockey team," said Jean-Pierre Leng, the European Community's Ambassador to Japan.
Added Shunichi Itani, senior vice president with Mercedes-Benz Japan, "We welcome measures that expand the market for foreign-car imports, but we would have trouble accepting them if American auto imports are given any kind of advantage."
The trade deal the United States and Japan announced today, toward the close of President Bush's visit here, seems to have pleased few people, and many Europeans now appear to be in the ranks of the dissatisfied.
"In general terms, any discussions with the Japanese at any level which help improve access to Japanese markets are a good thing," Ambassador Leng said. "The United States is not the only one who has a trade deficit with Japan, however. Anything which would tend to bilateralize the problem is not going to be good. We are watching very carefully everything that is being done."
The European Community nations have a $28 billion trade deficit with Japan -- about 70 percent the size of the United States' $41 billion deficit with Japan. The community has been holding talks about removing barriers to various imports, and officials here said their aim in the negotiations had generally been to free Japan's markets, not seek special treatment.
 
Concerns About Consumers
 One problem created by the approach taken in the new American trade accord with Japan is that it pays little attention to the wishes of Japanese consumers.
"A discussion of the market situation is very helpful," said Siegfried Richter, president of the BMW Japan Corporation. "However, we can't imagine that governments and manufacturers can make consumers' decisions for them. We think the consumer cannot be spoken for."
But the ultimate risk of managed trade is that it could become a form of defense, used selectively by countries to reward their friends. That has been a special concern in Europe, where there is a tradition of greater government involvement in the economy than in the United States.
"Part of the great debate in Europe is over the question of how interventionist the government should be," said Kenneth Courtis, senior economist here with the securities unit of Deutsche Bank. "This agreement announced today sets an example that helps one side of the debate. The Europeans are watching carefully."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Potential Tragedy Of a Global Slump

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE agreement between President Bush and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan to try to accelerate world economic growth gives flesh to Mr. Bush's assertion that his mission to Japan was really about "jobs, jobs, jobs."
This bilateral macroeconomic commitment, if Germany and the rest of Europe can be brought aboard, makes far more sense than efforts by the President and his entourage of business executives to squeeze orders out of Japan for more American autos, auto parts, computers, glass, paper, financial services and other goods. 
 America's economic problems stem in part from the general slowdown in the world economy, and would be aggravated if the slump worsens. Last year, according to the World Economic Survey of the United Nations, the global economy's growth rate fell to zero from 1 percent in 1990, 3 percent in 1989 and 4.3 percent in 1988.
The developed market economies grew at a sluggish 1.4 percent in 1991 -- too slow to keep unemployment from rising and real per capita income from falling. The official figure is not yet in, but the United States economy sank by about one-half of 1 percent.
The third world grew at an average rate of 3.5 percent last year. China had the highest rate, 5.5 percent in 1991, after rising 4.8 percent in 1990; the world's worst growth record was in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, where output plunged 9.5 percent last year after dropping 6.3 percent the year before.
The contrast of rapid growth in hard-line China and depression in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, where people are struggling for democracy and economic freedom, could not have been lost on Chinese leaders. Last week China rudely expelled a group of Canadian legislators seeking to call world attention to the plight of China's dissidents and political prisoners.
Washington is not underestimating the historic importance of a successful move by Russia and the other ex-Communist states to democracy and market-oriented economies.
A world economic slump would not only aggravate the economic problems of the United States and the West but would threaten a tragedy for Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
With President Bush off on his mission to Australia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has been pushing ahead with plans for a conference in Washington to help Russia and the other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States. The date has been set for Jan. 22-23, but the list of countries that will attend has not yet been released.
The State Department's spokesman, Margaret Tutweiler, said this week that the conference aims to organize an effort to provide urgently needed "humanitarian" aid. It will not be an American-led effort to create a long-term multinational Marshall Plan for the ex-Communist countries.
The aid will include these elements: food, medicine, energy, shelter, technical assistance and logistics. The conference will not be a "pledging session," Miss Tutweiler said, but rather an effort to "help people help themselves" to prevent mass hunger and disease this winter. The intention is to keep working into the summer, to improve the situation for next winter as well.
The Administration sees this as the start of a continuing effort to help the republics create "democratic and market-based economic institutions." Despite its strong free-enterprise ideology, the Administration has no intention of trying to press for rapid privatization and "overnight" capitalism, for fear that if the republics move too fast, they could be courting disaster.
Small and newly established businesses can privatize quickly, but not the gargantuan state enterprises. And the bigger the state-owned industries, the more difficult they are to privatize, especially because of the huge imbedded real capital stock of plant and equipment, power systems, transportation, residential structures and transportation.
As Joseph Berliner, a research fellow at the Russian Research Center at Harvard University, writes in "Perspectives, 1992," just published by Brandeis University: "The capital stock built up under decades of non-market planning is grossly out of sync with the structure of capital that the market would call for.
"The massive size of enterprises, their location, their concentration in heavy industry and defense production, and their neglect of esthetic and environmental considerations, distinguishes the Soviet scene from that of capitalist countries. Because of the durability of capital, Soviet capitalism will bear the marks of its Communist past for a long time."
The conversion of the former Soviet economy into an effective, market-based system is likely to take 10 or 15 years, at least. The slower the growth of the world economy, the longer it will take.
Conversely, the stronger the global growth, the easier it will be for the United States and other Western countries to aid the reconstruction of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Sharply On Growing Recovery Hope

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed sharply higher yesterday on a bout of buying linked to rising hopes about the United States economy.
The dollar gained nearly 6 German pfennigs, closing at 1.5605 marks, against 1.5075 Wednesday. Most of the action occurred in a single round of buying at midday. 
 "I left my desk to pick up lunch when the dollar was at 1.5460 marks," said Betsy Reetz of the Union Bank of Switzerland. "When I came back 10 minutes later, it was at 1.5700 marks."
The dollar also rose to 125.80 Japanese yen, up from 124.45 Wednesday.
The dollar opened in New York on a strong note, helped by a report in the Japanese newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun that European nations would put pressure on the United States to push the dollar higher at the group's meeting Jan. 25 in New York.
Speculation that the American economy will soon recover, while Germany's weakens, helped the dollar, traders said. A rising United States economy would make American investments more attractive, raising the dollar's value.
The conflict between Russia and Ukraine over the Black Sea naval fleet added to the market's political jitters and helped the dollar, traders said. Many traders also said short-covering was a major factor, as dealers bought dollars in fear of being left out of a big jump.
"This is nothing more than dollar short-covering," said Charles Spence, corporate foreign exchange manager at the First Interstate Bank.
Some traders, including Mr. Spence, look for the dollar to drop back down today after the Labor Department releases employment figures for December. Economists on average forecast a rise in the jobless rate to 6.9 percent from 6.8 percent.
But others think the dollar has turned around and is ready for a sustained move upward. "I've turned bullish," Ms. Reetz of Union Bank said. "Bad employment numbers are largely factored in" to exchange rates already.
In other trading, the British pound closed at $1.8160, down from $1.8790 Wednesday.
The dollar ended at 1.3925 Swiss francs, up from 1.3450, and at 1.1490 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1425 Wednesday. It also ended at 5.3235 French francs, up from 5.1495 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Leads Precious Metals In a Rally Termed Technical

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Heavy buying of gold futures early yesterday set off what analysts called a technical rally that overwhelmed the influence of a stronger dollar and gave a sharp gain to precious metals in general.
The gold rally on the Commodity Exchange in New York resulted from the oversold condition of the market, said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments in New York. 
 "Generally a strong dollar smothers a gold rally," said an analyst, James Steel of Refco Inc. in New York. "Gold ignored the dollar move because the rally by the market was so technical in nature."
Gold futures for delivery in February settled $6 higher at $356.60 a troy ounce; March silver was 18.3 cents higher at $4.153 a troy ounce.
Silver edged higher on the gold increase, then took off when it hit several buy stops.
 
Drop in Producer Prices
 Traders also took solace from the drop in the Producer Price Index, with the idea that stagnant inflation might encourage investment and lead to greater industrial demand, Mr. Steel said.
Platinum futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange showed a modest gain, with prices held back by disappointment over trade talks in Tokyo. There is doubt the talks will result in increased sales of American autos, Mr. Steel said. Platinum is used to make catalytic converters used in cars.
A strike at the Impala platinum mine in South Africa had little effect on the market, with views expressed that the 10,000 striking miners will be back to work in a few days.
Platinum for delivery in January rose $2.70, to $339.50 a troy ounce.
Energy futures were mixed in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with oil prices fluctuating sharply as traders waited to see whether Iraq could get back into the market. Concerns over the possibility of a world oil glut continued to weigh on the market.
Light sweet crude for delivery in February was a cent lower at $17.86 a barrel. February heating oil was 0.49 cent higher at 49.85 cents a gallon. February unleaded gasoline was 0.65 cent lower at 50.34 cents a gallon and February natural gas was 3.1 cent lower at $1.259 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Wheat for delivery in March settled 3 3/4 cents lower at $4.00 3/4 a bushel. March corn was a 1/4 cent lower at $2.52 3/4 a bushel. March oats were 3/4 cent lower at $1.37 1/4 a bushel and January soybeans were a cent lower at $5.63 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Political Premonitions Born of 30's Despair

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
THE Archangel Gabriel is said to have foretold the birth of John the Baptist and, a little later, to have made the Annunciation to the Virgin Mary. It is the gospel according to Gregory LaCava, in his astonishing 1933 film, "Gabriel Over the White House," that, a couple of milleniums later, Gabriel takes command of the United States during the darkest months of the Great Depression.
The conceit of this woozily prescient neo-fascist Hollywood movie is that God, funneling His wishes through an off-screen Gabriel, transforms the fictitious Judd Hammond (Walter Huston), the party hack just elected President, into an iron-fisted if benevolent dictator who saves America from the worst economic crisis in its history. 
 You might say, "It can't happen here," which is what you're supposed to say. "It Can't Happen Here" is the title of the Lincoln Center Film Society's richly provocative films-of-the-Depression retrospective, which begins today at the Walter Reade Theater and runs through March 2.
Chief among the retrospective's odd-ball glories is "Gabriel Over the White House," which will be shown today, tomorrow and Monday.
The society will present a total of 29 programs of features, documentaries and short subjects, all made either during the Depression or, later, about the Depression. Three separate programs will be shown once each day. Each program will be screened at least twice, sometimes as many as four times, each day at a different hour.
This weekend's other selections, all equally important in their own way: Frank Capra's "American Madness" (1932), a buoyant forerunner of the terminally sentimental "It's a Wonderful Life"; Mervyn LeRoy's "Gold Diggers of 1933" (1933), in which chorus girls dressed in over-sized gold coins sing "We're in the Money," and King Vidor's "Our Daily Bread" (1934), in which collective action on a farm triumphs over drought and other adversities.
Scheduled for the weeks ahead: Mervyn LeRoy's "Hard to Handle" (1933), which features a smashingly funny James Cagney performance; LaCava's screwball take on Depression manners, "My Man Godfrey" (1936); Preston Sturges's "Sullivan's Travels" (1942), a satire of films like "Our Daily Bread" and of the people who make them, and Sydney Pollack's "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" (1969), an extraordinarily effective tale of existential despair, set in the depressed 1930's, though the sensibility is of the Vietnam era.
Good or bad, these films are never indifferent. They are history in the raw, history before the historians have squeezed the life out of it. They are unself-conscious reports from the winter of our heritage.
"Gabriel Over the White House," one of the retrospective's most significant artifacts, is not ineffective movie making. It is technically slick, and Huston is fine as both the initially bumbling President, a character seemingly inspired by Warren Harding, and as the born-again Judd Hammond, the demonic, undead White House presence whose will is that of his creator.
As politics, "Gabriel Over the White House" is an informed scream. It is hilarious in its naivete. At the same time, it is appalling for the casual way in which it glorifies Presidential death squads, the possibly permanent dismissal of Congress and the suspension of all Constitutionally guaranteed civil liberties.
"Gabriel Over the White House" was no fringe movie. It was a mass-market entertainment, produced by William Randolph Heart's Cosmopolitan Pictures and released by M-G-M. It was even a hit. As much as any film in the retrospective, "Gabriel Over the White House" reflects the degree of American bewilderment at the time it was made.
After the 1929 stock market crash, and after one brief bull market in 1930, the business of this country, which Calvin Coolidge so sagely said was business, had slipped into chaos. Wall Street was discredited. Brokers were seen to be crooks.
By the middle of 1932, American industry was operating at less than half of its 1929 volume. The market economy was stalled. Banks were failing. Hobo jungles and so-called "Hoovervilles" sheltered a huge floating population of the economically disenfranchised. The number of unemployed, which had been 5 million in 1931, rose to 13.7 million in 1932, about one-quarter of the work force. The pop anthem of the day: E. Y. Harburg's "Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?"
The desperate measures required in desperate times were frontally addressed by "Gabriel Over the White House." Though it opened at the Capitol Theater here on March 31, 1933, less than four weeks after Franklin D. Roosevelt had been inaugurated as this country's 32d President, the movie seems to predict the kind of programs Roosevelt would push through Congress in his first 100 days in office.
Huston's President Hammond starts a Federally sponsored work corps called the Constructionist Army, and anticipates the repeal of Prohibition by opening Government-run liquor stores. When bootleggers object by staging a drive-by shoot-out at the White House, the President has them lined up against a wall and shot.
At the time of its release, the movie fulfilled a lot of dreams. It also confirmed the worst nightmares of those who saw Roosevelt as a would-be dictator, the sort of President who, a few years later, would brazenly attempt to "pack" the Supreme Court, that is, to enlarge it with additional appointees to ensure approval of his legislation.
The "It Can't Happen Here" show is clearly intended to draw parallels between yesterday's Depression and today's recession and, one supposes, to sound a warning. Yet parallels are often superficial. They are deceiving.
Though angry, most of the characters in these films are remarkably trusting. They are idealists. They exalt the possibilities of the future even in retrospect, as in "Union Maids" (1976). In this fine Julia Reichert-James Klein documentary, three women look back with satisfaction and pride at their activities as militant trade-union organizers. The times, being grim, gave their lives brilliant focus.
As in the documentaries, the people in the fiction films earnestly want to believe in something, which is usually collective action. The men who organize the farm cooperative in "Our Daily Bread" agree to form a socialist government. Says one man, "The Government must control everything, even the profits."
William Wellman's "Wild Boys of the Road" (1933) is about three "nice" teen-agers who run away from home to spare their hard-pressed familiies the cost of their upkeep. They become hobos, bums. They see life in the raw: a young woman is raped in a box car, a young man loses his leg under the wheels of a freight train. At the end, the kids are arrested and brought into court on charges of attempting a holdup.
The judge turns out to be a Roosevelt surrogate. Robert Barratt, the actor who plays the judge, wears Rooseveltian pince-nez, talks in Roosevelt's cadences and promises them, in effect, a New Deal.
Roosevelt's first inaugural address ("The only thing we have to fear is fear itself") is quoted in the final sequence of a second 1933 Wellman movie, "Heroes for Sale." This is a crazy mixture of bitterness and hope about a man unjustly deprived of his war medals, falsely accused of being "a Red," whose wife is killed in a labor demonstration and whose invention (a combined washing machine and mangle) is stolen by a Communist agitator, who then becomes a rich capitalistic pig.
One can't go too fast in synopsizing this plot. The story makes no sense except for the desperation of its politics. In 1933, people wanted a savior and Roosevelt was their man. No other American President has ever been so quickly beatified.
For all of their talk of joint action, the 1930's films are never very militant in their liberalism. With the exception of the right-wing "Gabriel," none of the films seek to change the system. In Capra's "American Madness," Walter Huston plays an idealistic bank president who alienates his board of directors by making loans to people without collateral. The profit motive is not questioned.
"We've got to get the money back in circulation," he tells the stingy directors. He says that "a man's character is his collateral," which turns out to be true when there is a run on his bank and all of the little guys he ever helped rush over to deposit their money with him. Sound familiar?
The retrospective does have its moments of deadly uplift and pre-fabricated social conscience, especially in William Wyler's "Dead End" (1937), whose faults lie not in Wyler's direction but in the stylized source material (the Sidney Kingsley play adapted by Lillian Hellman) that doesn't fit easily on the screen.
There is also something sort of phony about John Ford's adaptation of John Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" (1940). Though beautifully photographed, the movie reeks of self-importance, which Frank Galatti managed to avoid in his recent Broadway stage adaptation.
The most successful films in this show are either insistently downbeat or comic. "Gold Diggers of 1933," with its kaleidescopic Busby Berkeley production numbers, is a nonstop delight. The seldom-seen "Hard to Handle," in which Cagney plays a hustling public-relations genius, is laugh-out-loud funny. Like Cagney, the film has immense spirit. In "Sullivan's Travels," Sturges acknowledges the realities of the Depression while sending himself and Hollywood sky-high.
Also worth seeing are Robert Altman's "Thieves Like Us" (1974) and Nicholas Ray's "They Live by Night" (1949), both adapted from the same Edward Anderson novel. The Altman has the tougher edge. The Ray is more romantic. "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?" remains a stunner. The dance marathon, which is a joke as viewed in the 1933 "Hard to Handle," becomes a bleak, merciless evocation of Depression America in the Pollack movie.
Equally clear-eyed is Ken Burns's "Huey Long" (1985), a superior documentary about the assassinated Louisiana politician. In this retrospective, Huey Long represents all of the fast-talking, panacea-promoting hustlers who enriched the 1930's landscape.
The Depression is said to have begun with the market crash of 1929. Though conditions improved somewhat as the 30's went on, the Depression was never really conquered. Instead, World War II came along and magically removed the conditions that had paralyzed the economy. That may be the grimmest lesson to be learned from "It Can't Happen Here."
 
When to See the Films in the Lincoln Center Series

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 3; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 1090 words

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Big Deal for Nichols
Whenever Mike Nichols is back in town working on a show, all anyone can talk about is his paycheck. Superstar directors are rare commodities in the theater, especially in the non-musical theater. No star is bigger than Mr. Nichols, and no deal is sweeter than his. He is now directing "Death and the Maiden," a new play by Ariel Dorfman, starring Glenn Close, Gene Hackman and Richard Dreyfuss, which is to open in late March. And the deal helps to explain the ticket price of $50, the premium for non-musicals on Broadway. 
 Not that Mr. Nichols alone is expensive. The three stars don't come cheap either. Here are the figures circulating among producers and potential investors and confirmed by Roger Berlind, the show's co-producer: The production will cost $1.3 million and will have to run for 16 weeks making a minimum of $325,000 each of those weeks (out of a potential $388,000) to pay back that investment. The 3 stars are signed for 26 weeks. While the show is still recouping, Mr. Nichols will be paid 6 points, or roughly one-third, of the royalty pool, which is the percentage of the weekly profits allotted to the creative team, which also includes the playwright, the designers and the producers. If we use the hypothetical gross figure of $300,000 a week, his share will come to about $13,000 a week. After recoupment, Mr. Nichols will receive a clean 20 percent of profits off the top in addition to his points. Using the $300,000 figure, expected profits would be $100,000 a week, which makes his share $20,000, plus $13,000 for a total of $33,000 a week. Ever feel like you're in the wrong business?
Just for some perspective, consider two other front-rank directors, Gene Saks and Jerry Zaks. Producers who have worked on shows with both men verify that they are paid roughly 3 points of the royalty pool, which may then increase half a point after recoupment. Neither gets a share of profits. That, says one producer, makes Mr. Nichols the highest-paid director in the history of the American theater.
But every theater executive canvassed agrees that Mr. Nichols is worth it. "Look at the cast he put together," says the producer James B. Freydberg. "Where do you ever see Gene Hackman on the stage? And this is a play by a serious writer going to Broadway. If the public pre-buys it based on the names and makes it critic-proof, it takes the risk out. And if the show doesn't bring in big money, then he doesn't get very much, does he?"
Phone sales began on Sunday when the first ad ran and already total more than $300,000. And even when these stars leave, producers say, with Mr. Nichols's connections in Hollywood, their replacements should be just as interesting, which insures its future life. "We could make better deals with lesser directors," Mr. Berlind says. "But in the end, you get what you pay for."
 
'Secret' vs. 'Will Rogers'

With the January attendance slump in full swing, senses of humor are a bit short, judging from the sniping going on between "The Secret Garden" and "The Will Rogers Follies." For months, "The Secret Garden" has been using the slogan "It Won the Awards. It Will Win Your Heart" in its ads. That's true, since the Broadway show won 3 of the 10 Tonys it was nominated for -- best supporting actress, best scenic design and best book of a musical, but it did not win best musical, as the ad seems to imply. "Will Rogers" did, and members of its creative staff say they have not been happy with the "Secret Garden" campaign.
Recently, the "Secret Garden" ads have also included the claim "Best American Musical of the Season," which is a quote from William A. Henry 3d in Time magazine. "Will Rogers" retaliated with an ad proclaiming "The Best Musical of the Year Is No Secret." Nancy Coyne, the president of Serino, Coyne Inc., the advertising agency for "Will Rogers," says: "It was meant to be tongue in cheek. There was no animosity intended."
Heidi Landesman, a co-producer of "The Secret Garden," says: "We're trying to sell tickets, not disparage anyone else. The whole thing is silly."
 
Unabashed Discount
 The ad that ran in last Sunday's New York Times for "Lost in Yonkers" has raised quite a few eyebrows among Broadway producers. It was taken by American Express and offered its card members the exclusive opportunity to save 25 percent off the regular ticket price for performances through Feb. 13.
What's so unusual? Well, Broadway has its little idiosyncrasies just like any other business, and one of them is to never offer discounts directly to the public, even in bad times, or you risk looking as if you're selling damaged goods. But, like any other business in a recession, some little idiosyncrasies are best left unindulged until times get better.
Gail Wasserman, a spokeswoman for American Express, says the company is sponsoring the national tour of "Lost in Yonkers" "so this particular offer is an outgrowth of our relationship with them." Sponsoring the tour means that the company assumes a lot of advertising and promotion costs, and in return promotes itself successfully in its major markets. That's why it's willing to extend itself in tough times back in New York.
Michael David, a veteran Broadway producer and general manager who is among the more progressive in the business, is currently represented on Broadway with "The Secret Garden." He says: "Everyone discounts their shows in bad months, just in a more private way, through mailings, groups and parties. Unlike a normal discount, those which are selective are better, and this is the Rolls-Royce of public discounting. It doesn't feed the big fear that twofers for your show will end up on every dry cleaners' counter in New York."
Emanuel Azenberg, the producer of "Lost in Yonkers," refused to comment.
 
Time Out for 'Forbidden'
 "Forbidden Broadway" will close on Sunday at Theater East, says its producer, Jonathan Scharer. But after what he calls a "vacation," the musical spoof of Broadway shows that changes periodically to incorporate new material is to re-open on March 17. "Even though the show's Christmas edition went well, I didn't want to put the 'Forbidden Broadway 1991 1/2' back on in 1992 since there had been a lack of business. These editions usually last about nine months. But in March, we will open our big 10th anniversary edition, which will be a 'best of' everything, plus material on new shows. So we have the luxury of being able to take the break, keep the theater and recast the new show."


GRAPHIC: Bo Diddley, above, will appear in "Return to the Forbidden Planet" on Jan. 18, kicking off a series of weekend guest appearances by pop stars that is to include Lesley Gore, Chubby Checker, the Shirelles, Platters, Drifters, Chiffons and Marvelettes. They will perform at the finale of the show, which is loosely based on Shakespeare's "Tempest" and has a score of golden oldies.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Just Why Do People Like to Feel Good?

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

The Pursuit of Pleasure
By Lionel Tiger
330 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $22.95.
Pleasure -- the subject of the latest book by the anthropologist and social critic Lionel Tiger -- is one of those huge, sprawling topics that can easily elude systematic examination. Indeed, "The Pursuit of Pleasure" bounces erratically around the map of human experience like a ball in a pinball machine, touching, fleetingly, on such varied phenomena as sex, food, drugs, art, music, sports, conversation and the enjoyment people get from gardening, pets, cooking and travel. "I have tried to find a link," writes Mr. Tiger, "between campfires, Judy Garland, the Place Vendome, playing patty-cake with a baby, the scent of gardenias, kisses and a good read. I've sought a law of pleasure that might unite such an array of phenomena and more besides." 
 A result of this vague but grandiose ambition is a messy hodgepodge of a book, a book filled with both insightful observations and hackneyed statements of the obvious, interesting facts and self-indulgent prattling, provocative questions and unsatisfying answers.
It is Mr. Tiger's contention that the things people find pleasurable today are rooted in the evolutionary history of the human species and our prehistoric past: "the behavior that yielded survival advantages in the past was translated into forms of pleasure: from sex, food, warmth, comfortable sleep, conviviality and so on." Because of social and economic changes, some of these old pleasures and preferences now result in problems.
People's taste for animal fat, for instance, was once a healthy survival mechanism. Our hunter-gatherer ancestors who lived some 10,000 years ago worked hard to catch their supper, and fat provided a rich source of energy in times of uncertain food supply. Nowadays, in rich countries where food is readily available and many people live sedentary lives, heart disease and other cholesterol-related problems are a major cause of premature death. People consequently worry about indulging in the pleasures of rich, fatty foods, even as they subject themselves to rigorous exercise routines to maintain their bodies and ease their guilt.
While this example of Mr. Tiger's thesis seems plausible enough, his eagerness to use biological determinism as an explanation for human behavior leads to some other highly questionable assertions. He argues that many contemporary Americans have chosen to live in suburbs, rather than in cities, because these "near rural" communities "are sensually more like the savanna in Africa in which we evolved and in which we developed the sensorium that appreciated a certain landscape, temperature, sense of place, access to potential resources, and scent and movement of air." He suggests that the color of the most popular prepared drinks -- the light brown of tea, coffee, colas, beer, whisky, brandy, rum and cocoa -- might reflect "a prehistoric enthusiasm for the liquid in small and precious bodies of water found in the sere tan savannas of our mother Africa." And he says modern man's penchant for travel and tourism "recaptures and reminds us of our ability to master interesting and unusual places to live," the ability of human beings to migrate nearly all over the world.
Such bizarre examples -- which selectively ignore whole sections of the population and their tastes -- make Mr. Tiger's thesis seem strained and precarious; in fact, much of this volume feels arbitrary in nature. Although Mr. Tiger goes on at great length about the conflict human beings feel between pleasure and austerity (Dionysus and Apollo), he ignores Freud's writings about the id and superego, ignores the psychology of desire. The question of the attempts by churches and governments to control people's private pleasures is raised but never explored in a rigorous manner. Instead Mr. Tiger simply states his own views: on one hand, he believes that drugs should not be legalized (he argues that "expanding the range of legal drugs available to consumers will also expand the market and the corps of victims"); on the other hand, he makes an impassioned argument for a sexuality unconstrained by old-fashioned morality.
His other suggestions for increasing the pleasure quotient in modern life tend to be obvious, sentimental or unrealistic. He exhorts people to take more pleasure in their work (something difficult for individuals trapped in dead-end, menial jobs), and encourages everyone to achieve a "daily celebration" by savoring the little things in life (like pulling the cork from a bottle of Champagne). He seems to feel that modern man perversely denies himself many of the pleasures to which he is entitled, and that "an emerging agenda of human rights must expand to include pleasure more explicitly than heretofore."
Such statements fail to take into account the more implacable facts of human existence like death, illness and poverty, and at a time when many people around the world are finding it difficult to make ends meet, they sound callous and Pollyanna-ish at the same time.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 569 words

HEADLINE: Lost in Tokyo

 BODY:
Personal diplomacy is one of George Bush's great strengths as President. Car salesmanship obviously is not. His three-and-a-half-day visit to Japan, interrupted by a frightening bout of stomach flu, was a fiasco.
For domestic political reasons, Mr. Bush recast the goals of this trip from designing a new "global partnership" to demanding that the Japanese quickly lower import barriers to bring America "jobs, jobs, jobs." 
 Lowering protectionist barriers is a worthy exercise. But the President sometimes blurred the distinction between artificial barriers and legitimate consumer preferences. More fundamentally, he refused to recognize that America's current economic problems weren't made in Japan and cannot be cured there.
Not even the auto executives Mr. Bush brought along with him were much impressed with the "voluntary" import targets he persuaded the Japanese Government to extort in their behalf. And the agreement on coordinating the two countries' fiscal policies to speed global growth contained little new or specific.
The main thing lost in Tokyo was a chance to lay strong personal foundations for a more equitable relationship. Japan now possesses the world's second-largest and most dynamic economy. With the cold war no longer defining world politics, Washington and Tokyo urgently need to reapportion their contributions to international security and development.
Japan's new Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, was eager to cooperate with his old friend in the White House. But Mr. Bush unwisely asked him for high-profile concessions he had no power to deliver. And the President soft-pedaled important issues on which Mr. Miyazawa might have been able to offer constructive responses.
To take one obvious example, Japan has benefited mightily from the reduction of global trading barriers since World War II, negotiated mainly through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Tokyo is now honor-bound to give other countries the same opportunity by helping to lower barriers in agriculture and services.
Instead, Japan continues to hold out against imports of foreign-grown rice, jeopardizing the nearly completed Uruguay Round trade talks. Japan's rice-growing lobby is small but powerful. There's reason to think Mr. Miyazawa would have been willing to risk some political capital by standing up to the rice farmers. Mr. Bush's focus on autos, however, gave him little incentive to try.
Mr. Bush also lost an opportunity to help shape Japan's plans to assume a more active international role. The Persian Gulf war last year dramatically underscored the imbalance between Japan the economic superpower and Japan the geopolitical featherweight. Tokyo contributed $13 billion to allied efforts, but avoided significant diplomatic or military involvement.
Secretary of State Baker recently made headlines in Tokyo by declaring that Japan owed the new international order more than just "checkbook diplomacy." Many Japanese agree, Prime Minister Miyazawa among them.
But there's sharp debate about what form Japan's new global role should take. Asian neighbors fear a return to the militarism of the 1930's and 1940's. The U.S. is well placed to help design an appropriate international division of labor.
As it turned out, the only Bush who gained anything from the trip was Barbara, who impressed Japanese and Americans alike with her extemporaneous good grace.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
10 Choices, 10 Errors

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
One year ago next week George Bush took one of the most important, risk-filled and courageous steps ever ventured by a President of the United States -- to do battle against an aggressor who had not directly attacked the United States.
In the last half-century two other Presidents had gone to war against marauding dictatorships -- President Roosevelt against Japan and President Truman against North Korea. But in both cases American armed forces or a dependent ally had already been attacked. And at the time there were few who mounted protest. 
 President Bush welded together agreement from a country and Congress that had deep misgivings. He had to convince both that moving against a powerful dictatorship in support of a weak dictatorship was in this case worth risking the lives of American men and women. He had to make the country understand that the aggressor was armed not only with a potent arsenal but a concept and intent of combining military and political power into domination of a region essential to American interests.
He did. And five days after he ordered the beginning of the ground war it was all over, Saddam Hussein defeated. No leader stood higher in the esteem of the world and his countrymen than George Bush.
Then, at the moment of victory, began the slide -- that sad series of errors, misjudgments, switches and distancing from friendship and principle, around the world.
1. President Bush permitted Saddam Hussein to remain in power, his killer squads around him. If he was a Hitler, as Mr. Bush said, it was like permitting Hitler to remain in command of Germany -- also Goebbels, Goring, Himmler, the Nazi Party and the Wehrmacht high command.
2. President Bush permitted Saddam Hussein to use the substantial air and ground forces that the coalition left him. He used them well -- to drive hundreds of thousands of Kurds and other Iraqis who had trusted America into the cold and death of mountain refuge.
3. President Bush thought he could help Mikhail Gorbachev patch together a free-market economy within the Soviet system. That was like trying to marry a hedgehog and a garden snake. The man who was to say that was treated scornfully by the Bush Administration -- until he became President of Russia and handed Mr. Gorbachev his pension papers.
4. President Bush hedged on the American pledge of support to Baltic independence and stalled almost to the point of -- what's a more respectful word than betrayal?
5. President Bush in Kiev delivered a lecture on the dangers of independence when that was what Ukrainians and all other inmates of the Soviet system so plainly lusted for.
6. President Bush presides over the American Government while political leadership in Europe goes rapidly to Germany, and says not a word.
7. President Bush has made the free, democratic United States the main supporter of the Syrian dictator, discernible from the Iraqi variety only by the difference in mustaches.
8. President Bush weakens the Mideast peace talks. He permits the Administration to show stunning contempt for Israel by voting for viciously strong language denouncing the deportation of 12 Palestinians -- stronger than the condemnation of Iraq for conquering Kuwait.
What else does he have in mind for Israel to break its will and destroy the name of the nation the U.S. once called its only and cherished Mideast democratic ally? When was that -- yesterday?
9. President Bush clings to his peculiar taste for Chinese Communist leaders, using his power to block minimal Congressional economic steps to protest the brutality of the world's biggest gulag.
10. And now President Bush leads a sales pitch to Japan -- surely one of the most embarrassing expeditions in the history of either country. Great salesmanship: buy or else.
What happened to George Bush? Nothing much, I suspect. Time and again after the gulf fighting he had his choice between consistent democratic idealism, which from the Baltics to Beijing has proved itself the most powerful political instrument in the world, and opportunism -- which looks smart, for a minute, and then turns out to be too smart by half.
President Bush just made his choices for opportunism, is all. That's sad. But he did rise to the moment, that once a year ago.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Look at the City;
Call Me Juror

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Two thousand two hundred twenty-four potential jurors trudged into the courthouses of lower Manhattan on Monday. I, armed with bagel and low expectations, was one of them.
There was no disappointment for those who expected filth in every room (part of the city's master plan to cut working hours without reducing costs), three armed guards dozing in each courtroom (part of the state's employment plan), and endless hours of waiting (a specialty of all governments). 
 For at least 12 of us, however, something extraordinary was in store as we entered the courtroom of Judge Michael Corriero of New York State's Supreme Court to hear The People v. a young man accused of selling cocaine to an undercover policeman. Called upon to sit in judgment, we were touched by that divine spark of common sense and decency.
But before partaking of that spark, we had to be selected -- which was harder than getting into Harvard. Of the 45 who sought admission, only 12, plus 3 alternates, could be accepted.
The judge, prosecutor and defense attorney took longer to pick the jury than to try the case. The process is termed "voir dire," French for speaking the truth. It should be called "oy vay," Yiddish for oh, pain.
The first batch of 16 prospects looked and sounded the same as the second and third batches -- and as the final jury. But with all three court officers exercising a veto, heads rolled. Those who said "I love New York" were dismissed, apparently on grounds of insanity. So were any who admitted ever having talked to a lawyer.
When the judge said "Tell me about yourself," life histories poured out, as if unplugged. One Wall Street type hanged himself by saying he worked for "a world-renowned economist." But a lady who tossed in that she had spent a year as an "intern at the Harvard School of Nutrition" passed muster. The prosecutor, a 24-year-old Asian-American, bounced all Asian-Americans. The defense attorney, who might have been Hispanic, cashiered the Hispanics.
Hope surged in me. I was going to get into Harvard -- I mean, on the jury.
My turn. Number 40. I was ready. "I'm a native New Yorker who left and returned and now lives on the West Side, who's never knowingly talked to a lawyer, who likes New York" (all the picked jurors actually loved New York, but had figured out the code), "who would be impartial and even Solomonic, but who never gets chosen for juries because I'm a journalist."
The court officers were on the defensive. The crowd was on my side. Oppressed journalist. Always rejected. But not this time.
The trial was on. The accused, a young Hispanic, did not speak English and required a translator. The Egyptian-born lab technician who testified that the powder allegedly sold to the undercover cop was cocaine didn't speak English very well, but loved to speak it. One detective did not know right from left.
The issue came down to the undercover cop's credibility. He had no "ghost" or "shadow" on the street with him the day of the arrest, so no one else saw the supposed sale. The 10-plus officers in the arresting-backup team apparently weren't qualified to be ghosts. The marked money was not found on the accused. The cops either forgot to take a picture of the accused at the station house right after the arrest, or lost it.
And so on.
Judge Corriero, a man of considerable civility and disciplined intelligence, spelled out the law with superb clarity and sensitivity, and sent us to deliberate.
Never in my life have I seen a group of people so attentive for two days. Never have I seen people put aside self-absorption so completely. Never more respect for one another -- the bus driver, the banker, the security guard, Nancy, Larry, Sabrina, Lauren, all.
To each, the accused was more important than any of us and all of us.
With pain, with doubt about sloppy police work but not with "reasonable doubt," we found the man who never looked at us guilty.
Our jury experience, I am told, was not unusual. Something in our government actually works. People can be called to public responsibility. For a fleeting moment, I couldn't help but feel that perhaps one day a political leader would summon that spark.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Bush Returns, Hailing Gains in Japan Agreement

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
From the moment President Bush stepped off Air Force One this morning, he and his advisers plunged into an effort to put an optimistic gloss on what automobile industry officials and Democratic Congressmen were calling a disastrous trade meeting with Japan's leaders.
In a speech at Andrews Air Force Base, Mr. Bush promised that his four-day visit to Japan would produce "clear and measurable" gains in American exports and the jobs they create. 
 But Mr. Bush's main claim, that the trip would create more jobs, was quickly overshadowed by the Government's announcement that unemployment rose to 7.1 percent in December, the highest rate in six years.
Mr. Bush's chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, said the figures were "not good news," and added, "That's why this trip was more important than ever."
Lee A. Iacocca, the outspoken chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, was more blunt on the trip's importance. In an address today before Detroit's business elite, he unleashed his most vitriolic attack yet on Japan, and predicted that President Bush's trade mission would not budge the trade deficit or salve the auto industry's wounds.
And while the Japanese told the American delegation more boldly than ever that they should look within their own society for ways to revive a sagging industrial base, Mr. Iacocca would have none of that. "I for one am fed up hearing from the Japanese, and I might say some Americans, too, that all our problems in this industry, all our problems, are our own damn fault," he told a gathering of about 5,000 business executives at the Detroit Economic Club. "We do not have idiots running General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler, or our suppliers. And our workers are not lazy and stupid." [Page 33]
Earlier, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One, Mr. Bush contended that the most visible fruits of his trip, a Japanese pledge to buy an additional $10 billion in American auto parts each year by 1995, would create 200,000 new jobs over that period.
The new unemployment data showed that the economy lost 300,000 jobs in December alone. With the 275,000 jobs lost in November, that makes a total of 2.3 million jobs that have vanished since the recession began in May 1990.
 
Bracing for Criticism
 As Mr. Bush returned, White House officials seemed to be bracing for a flood of criticism at home about their roles in a trip that sometimes had Mr. Bush looking more like a Chamber of Commerce official on an unsuccessful trade mission than a world leader.
Much of the criticism was directed at Mr. Bush's new re-election campaign chairman, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, and Mr. Skinner, who conceived or approved some of the most flawed aspects of the 12-day journey to Asia and Australia.
Chief among the charges was that Mr. Mosbacher, the departing Commerce Secretary, had erred by recruiting the heads of Detroit's three major auto makers to accompany Mr. Bush to Tokyo to press for Japanese concessions on automobile imports.
Auto-related goods comprise three-fourths of Japan's $41 billion annual trade surplus with the United States, and a primary goal of Mr. Bush's mission was to pry open Japan's domestic markets to American automobiles and and auto parts.
But the decision to bring Detroit executives was questioned on the first day of Mr. Bush's trip. For instance, The Wall Street Journal published a front-page article contrasting the seven-figure salaries and the miserable sales records of Detroit's auto executives with the smaller salaries and sparkling performance of their counterparts in Japan.
The Administration contends that Japan has employed that country's safety regulations, and technical specifications and restrictions on auto dealerships to keep out American cars. But many auto industry experts say American cars sell poorly in Japan because they are less well made than those of Japan and are not designed for the needs of Japanese drivers.
As Mr. Bush moved majestically through Australia and Southeast Asia, accounts piled up of the Detroit executives' efforts to restrict Japanese auto sales in the United States, and their refusal to make even the most obvious changes -- like moving the steering wheel from the left side to the right -- to make their cars more appealing to Japanese drivers.
By the time Mr. Bush reached Tokyo, the auto makers' salaries and the design and quality of their cars had long supplanted Japan's trade practices as the focus of debate in Tokyo.
 
'Careful of Company'
 "The lesson here," a Republican strategist said, "is that you've got to be careful of the company you keep."
Mr. Skinner and the President's political advisers were faulted by others for recasting the theme of the President's Pacific trip along political lines, scuttling its diplomatic aspects in favor of the one issue that could threaten Mr. Bush's re-election chances: "jobs, jobs, jobs."
The object was to quiet Democratic criticism that Mr. Bush was neglecting the economy in concentrating on foreign affairs. But the effect was to make the President look like a salesman, not a statesman, and to deeply offend Japanese leaders. They saw Mr. Mosbacher and Mr. Bush effectively blame them for the recession and unemployment woes in the United States only days before the trade mission began.
"The themes just didn't sell," a Republican Congressional strategist said. "The whole rearrangement was for political reasons, and it was transparent, and it didn't work."
Mr. Skinner said he was "concerned" about negative accounts of Mr. Bush's trip, the first major international undertaking since he took over as chief of staff. At Andrews today he tried to persuade reporters that they were holding Mr. Bush's trade mission to unrealistically high standards of success. But the President himself said the trip had accelerated the opening of Japan's markets to American exports.
Mr. Skinner said in an interview this evening that news organizations' "overcoverage" of the Detroit executives had overshadowed the 15 other executives on the trip, most of whom had high praise for its accomplishments. "I do think we got some significant commitments on auto parts, and that got overshadowed too," he said. Mr. Skinner also said he believed most Americans saw Mr. Bush's journey as a sincere effort to help American industry and the economy. But he agreed that American concerns must improve their quality if they are to triumph in Japan's competitive markets.
"It's obvious that if we get access to a market, we're going to have to make products that meet the market needs," he said. "That's why we've made progress on paper, on purchases by their government of computers, and on glass" -- three areas where Japan agreed this week to allow more competition from American-made goods.
Even so, he said, "This is a long-term effort; it's not a short-term effort."
Yet other Republican political strategists said today that from a political standpoint, that is precisely why Mr. Bush's trip should never have been cast as a political event. The new unemployment figures, they said, underscore the fact that whatever successes Mr. Bush scored in Tokyo this week, they will be too meager and too slow in arriving to help the President in his re-election campaign.
On Capitol Hill, Democrats pointed out on the juxtaposition of the mixed success of Mr. Bush's trade mission and the rise in unemployment.
"The surge in unemployment shows why the President cannot pose for photo-opportunities with the Japanese and cut the capital gains tax for the rich if he wants to get the economy moving again," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
By contrast, Republicans on Capitol Hill were largely silent about Mr. Bush's Japan visit.
"The feeling up here," said an adviser to a leading Republican Senator, who spoke on condition of anonymity, "is that this is best put behind us."

RUSSIA GUARDS ITS GOODS
Russia introduced border embargoes on most basic consumer goods to prevent a raid on its retail supplies by neighboring republics. 1 

PRESSURE FROM LENDERS
Despite a rise in prices and protests by angry shoppers, the International Monetary Fund wants Russia to adopt a sharp increase in oil prices. The fund argues that higher oil revenue would help balance the budget and boost the ruble's value. 1
 
Americans have trouble getting food to the Russians who need it. 5
 
Russia cuts gas deliveries to Poland in half. 5
 
A NEW VOLGA REPUBLIC?
Germany wants Russia to create an autonomous republic for ethnic Germans that would be similar to the old Volga republic, which was abolished in 1941. Bonn's goal is to discourage migration to Germany. 4
 
KOHL DEFENDS GERMAN VIGOR
Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought to defuse accusations of a new assertiveness by Germany, arguing that it has had to shoulder fresh responsibilities as a leading economic power in the heart of central Europe. 4
 
I.R.A. BOMBING IN LONDON
A bomb planted by the Irish Republican Army exploded in the heart of the Government quarter in London, disrupting traffic but causing no injuries. After six weeks of I.R.A. blasts that have disrupted the routines of hundreds of thousands of people, many were outraged. 3
 
12 KILLED IN ISRAELI ATTACK
Twelve people were killed and scores were wounded in an Israeli air raid on a Lebanese village. The Israeli Army said the target was a Palestinian guerrilla base, but Lebanese officials said the guerrillas left 10 months ago. 3
 
A CAMPAIGN AGAINST LIBYA
The United States, France and Britain circulated a draft resolution at the United Nations asking the world to press Libya to hand over agents accused of blowing up two airliners and to pay compensation. 3
 
HAITI'S WOULD-BE PREMIER
Rene Theodore, who has been chosen to form a Haitian government in a compromise with the country's ousted President, is described as a level-headed moderate. But many conservatives and soldiers cannot understand why a Communist politician was selected as a counterweight to a radical priest. 2
 
UPROAR IN CHILE OVER ARMS SALE
The interception of a shipment of Chilean arms bound for Croatia in violation of a United Nations ban has led to a scandal that officials say could involve some of Chile's highest-ranking military officers. 2

HEADLINE: New Jersey Fair-Housing Plan Goes Awry

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J., Jan. 10

 BODY:
A bright idea flashed through this woodsy suburb in the Watchung Mountains four years ago, promising significant relief from the state-imposed obligation to provide affordable housing for low- and moderate-income people.
With the prospect of being forced to rezone a 50-acre tract for such housing, leaders of the Township Committee approached the property owner, a well-known developer in Union County, with what seemed to be a mutually beneficial deal.
 
Exporting Fair Housing
 The Township Committee would approve an office park with two 10-story towers, two five-story parking garages and a helicopter pad, changing the zoning to allow the larger project. In return, the developer would pick up the cost of half the township's obligation under the Mount Laurel housing doctrine: $3.8 million for 129 units. The money would be paid to Berkeley Heights, then transferred to Newark under a legal but much criticized arrangement that permits suburbs to export part of their "fair share" housing mandate to depressed urban areas. 
 That was more than two years ago. On Dec. 30, after 32 hearings, the Planning Board approved the project, but with conditions that the developer, Connell Realty and Development Company of Westfield, found onerous and costly. Exasperated, Connell accused the township of reneging on the deal and demanded a refund with interest: $4.6 million. The developer has set Monday as the deadline.
But repayment, if it happens, will not be easy. The money has been paid to Newark, and Newark has spent it to repair 39 apartments and build 90 three-bedroom town houses.
"I don't believe they have a leg to stand on," said Mayor John G. Regit, referring to Connell's complaints. But Mr. Regit, who became Mayor two weeks ago, said the Connell dispute had caused some hard feelings around town, with allegations that the original agreement failed to receive sufficient public hearing. As a result, he said, his adminstration would "go back to the people" with special Saturday meetings at the town hall.
 
Not One Housing Unit
 The outcome of what both sides say is certain to become a court battle is far from clear. But the demand for a refund marks a new phase in the struggle of this town of 11,000 to comply with a housing mandate that has affected all of New Jersey's 567 communities and for which there is little public enthusiasm.
In the five years since a lawsuit forced Berkeley Heights to confront rezoning for low-income housing, the township's political life has been dominated by Mount Laurel concerns. The doctrine, named after the Burlington County township that was the defendant in several major fair-housing cases, forbids municipalities to use their zoning laws to block low- and moderate-income housing. Control of the Township Committee has flip-flopped several times since 1988, with Mount Laurel, Connell and related zoning and development matters as the major campaign issues. But still not one unit of affordable housing has been built here. The recession makes it unlikely that any will be built soon.
"We acted very diligently to provide site plan reviews for all the developers so they could get started on it," said Eugene Allen, the Planning Board chairman. "But the simple fact is that because of the economic conditions, there's no market for this type of speculative housing."
Through the regional contribution agreement with Newark and by the act of rezoning, Berkeley Heights has met its legal obligation under Mount Laurel, as have other communities. But the relatively modest number of new or rehabilitated housing units generated under Mount Laurel is troubling to those who oversee the program, and they say it is hardly unique to Berkeley Heights.
According to the Council on Affordable Housing, an agency set up in 1987 to enforce the Mount Laurel doctrine and its later amendments, well over 200 communities have approved plans for low- and moderate-income housing. The council's goal is 145,707 units by 1993, said Douglas V. Opalski, the council's executive director, but realistically, he said, the most the market could have accommodated since 1987 was about 25,000 new units, and perhaps a quarter of that has been built.
 
Millions Spent on Park
 So far there has been no formal response from Berkeley Heights to the demand for a refund, said Robert Spalteholz, vice president of Connell Realty. He said Connell had already spent $3 million on plans for the office park, the former site of a geriatric center, which Connell bought from Union County for $13.5 million in 1985.
Connell's lawyer, Dean Gaver, of the firm of Hannoch Weisman in Roseland, said the issue for his client was fairly simple. Connell, he said, signed an agreement to help finance the township's Mount Laurel housing, and in return the town was obligated to accept Connell's plan for the office towers, the garages and the helipad. Connell also agreed to some road improvements to allow 3,700 more cars a day on one of the township's main avenues, Plainfield Avenue.
"In fact," he said, "the Planning Board asked for major improvements to ramps off I-78 and the redesign of an overpass entrance to the park. The developer's agreement contemplated no such thing.
"They came to us and said, 'Would you be willing to advance these moneys under certain terms and conditions?' and we would file an application. We never said the Planning Board couldn't carry out its function. But the agreement was approval without conditions, or else we get the money back."
Mr. Gaver said that while the dispute had held up the project, Connell could conceivably follow through on it, perhaps even with the improvements. But not without a refund first.
The town's lawyer, Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Union County Republican who is the incoming State Senate President, said: "It's obviously going to be litigated. It's an unreasonable request, after all. Even to collect that much woney would take some time."
"They gave us the money; we changed the zoning," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "They participated in the site plan process. If his position is correct, why did he participate?"
