HEADLINE: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT INCREASES TO 7.1%, WORST IN 5 1/2 YEARS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate climbed to a five-and-a-half-year high of 7.1 percent in December, with the bulk of the rise occurring among people discharged from their latest job with little prospect of recall, the Labor Department reported today.
Long-term unemployment also rose substantially as the ranks of those out of work swelled by 289,000, to 8.9 million, the highest in nearly eight years. 
 As discouraging as much of the report was, however, many private analysts said it did not point to significant fresh deterioration in the economy last month but mainly reflected a continued lack of growth.
"What it tells you is that the economy is stagnant," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist for the First Boston Corporation. "There's no sense of improvement."
 
Some Bright Spots
 One relative bright spot in the report was a modest but unexpected rise in payrolls, which grew 31,000 after being expected to shrink by more than twice that amount. All of the gain, however, was in government rather than private payrolls, which would more accurately reflect economic conditions.
Other pluses were a slight increase in the length of the average workweek, an increase in the proportion of industries adding workers rather than shedding them and a rise in the index of production working hours.
Over all, today's figures appear to have reduced pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates further, or at least not to have intensified the Fed's concern. In fact, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, told Congress this afternoon that he expected the steep cut in interest rates the Fed ordered last month to be sufficient to get an economic recovery started and that he did not foresee a need for further rate cuts or for budgetary stimulus. [Page 33.]
 
Democrats Ask Action
 President Bush, returning from his business-oriented trip to the Far East, called the December results disappointing, and Congressional Democrats pounced on the report to assert Administration mismanagement.
"It is alarming that joblessness is still rising so sharply in the second year of this Republican recession," said Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House majority leader. "The surge in unemployment shows why the President cannot pose for photo opportunities with the Japanese and cut the capital gains tax for the rich if he wants to get the economy moving again. We need a far-reaching program to revive the economy and help middle-income Americans."
Representative David R. Obey, a Democrat from Wisconsin, said the higher jobless rate showed that extended unemployment benefits should continue at least until autumn.
Today's was the first monthly labor-market tally taken since enactment of legislation under which benefits for about 3.1 million people who have exhausted them since last March have been extended for up to 20 weeks. Normally, the jobless are covered for no more than 26 weeks.
Thomas J. Plewes, an associate Labor Department commissioner, said he could find no visible effect, such as an increase in workers re-entering the work force or a decline in so-called discouraged workers, that could be traced to the extension. Although extending benefits may reduce pressure on the jobless to find a job, the existence of the benefits acts as a lure for people to collect them, which requires statements that one is looking for work. Those who are not searching for work are not counted as unemployed.
The new job hunters increased the labor force by 245,000 in December, while 44,000 workers lost their jobs or quit, raising the ranks of the unemployed by 289,000. At 8,891,000, the jobless total is the highest since January 1984, when it was 9,008,000.
Before last month, the unemployment rate had held at about 6.8 percent from May through September before edging up to a revised 6.9 percent in October and November. Various indicators show that a recovery from the recession that began in July 1990 has now stalled, despite rising gross domestic output for both the second and third quarters of 1991.
 
Number Out of Work
 Since the onset of the recession, the jobless rate has increased 1.7 points and the number of people out of work has risen by 2.1 million.
The December increase in the unemployment rate was the first clear rise since May, since changes of one-tenth of a percent are considered statistically insignificant.
As part of the usual annual recalculation at this time of year, November's rate was revised up to 6.9 percent from the 6.8 percent initially reported. The rates for September and October were also raised one-tenth of a point but there were offsetting one-tenth-point declines for March, May and June.
The number of people who were laid off or discharged from their last jobs -- as opposed to having quit them -- rose nearly 300,000 in December, to 4,990,000, the report showed. Layoffs accounted for only 20 percent of these. Those who left jobs voluntarily fell to 913,000 from 987,000.
Last month, 56.2 percent of idled workers were job "losers," compared with 50.4 percent a year earlier.
 
'Some Stabilization'
 The number of people jobless more than six months rose by 148,000, to 1,471,000, while the average duration of jobless spells rose to 15.3 weeks from 14.9 weeks. But the proportion -- though not the total -- of people out of work five weeks or less shrank to 37.1 percent, contracting for the fourth straight month.
This, according to Michael P. Niemira, economist at the Mitsubishi Bank, indicates that while it may be hard to find work quickly, "there appears to be some stabilization in the labor markets."
 
Ohio's Big Rise
 Geographically, Ohio had the worst performance of the 11 biggest states last month, its jobless rate rising to 6.6 percent from 5.6. The rate for Illinois rose to 9.3 percent from 8.5. New York and New Jersey had insignificant increases. New York rose to 8.1 percent from 8 percent and New Jersey increased to 7.4 percent from 7.1 percent.
Regionally, unadjusted figures showed the Northeast had the highest rate, at 7.4 percent, while the Midwest had the lowest, at 6.5 percent.
The 31,000-job increase uncovered by the payroll survey of workers fell far short of making up for November's 265,000 loss -- a revision that was worse than the initially reported 241,000 loss -- and was mainly the result of a probably unsustainable increase for local governments, many of which are experiencing severe budget problems.
Factory jobs dropped 32,000 last month after falling 39,000 in November while construction rebounded 13,000 from a weather-related dive in November. Retail trade lost a modest 16,000 -- after two months of decline totaling 140,000 -- but health services, one of the few robust fields, added an additional 45,000 jobs last month.
 
Fewer Holiday Jobs
 Retailers hired less than half as many holiday employees this season as in the preceding decade, William G. Barron Jr., Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee. Afterward, he described the current overall state of the labor market as "flat."
The transportation sector lost 13,000 jobs last month, mainly because of the shutdown of two airlines -- Pan American and Midway, the Labor Department reported.
The length of the workweek rose six minutes both over all (to 34.5 hours) and in factories (to 41.1). Factory overtime also rose by that amount.
The index of aggregate production hours -- a proxy for industrial production to be reported next Friday -- rose to 121.7 from 121.4, while the proportion of industries expanding payrolls rose to 47.2 from 44.5.

HEADLINE: To the Presidential Hopefuls, The Middle Class Is Royalty

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
The vast group of voters known as "middle-class America" is about to be courted with a vengeance as the 1992 Presidential campaign gets under way.
Both parties are trying to calibrate their language, their policy proposals and their messages to show their concern for the middle-income American with a family, a house in the suburbs, a sense of economic alarm and a feeling that the politicians don't care. 
 To be sure, the invocation of "middle-class values" and economic concerns is a standard feature of political campaigns; to paraphrase Willie Sutton's explanation of why he robbed banks, that is where the votes are. What is striking this year is the recognition, in both parties, that these voters feel an especially sharp sense of betrayal and anger.
 
Scramble Among Democrats
 Four years ago, strategists for Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, had to struggle to make the case for "a middle-class squeeze." The candidate hit that theme consistently only in the final weeks of the campaign, with the slogan, "We're on your side."
Today, as the recession drags on, the plight of "the middle class," a loosely defined term based partly on income and partly on attitudes, is the starting point for the Presidential campaign. And Democrats are campaigning for that support far more relentlessly and explicitly than they did in 1988.
The five major candidates for the Democratic nomination are scrambling to cast themselves as the candidates best able to restore the American dream to "the forgotten middle class," as Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas describes it in his new television commercial in New Hampshire.
The Democratic candidates are talking about national health care plans, tax cuts for the mid-income group, expanded college loan programs and a host of other measures aimed at a broad swath of people squeezed by the recession.
For his part, President Bush is apparently preparing a new budget that will offer tax credits to help people buy health insurance, tax benefits for first-time home buyers and a flurry of other measures aimed at showing his concern for working families.
Republican strategists say they will not make the mistakes their party made in losing last year's Pennsylvania Senate race, when the Democrats hammered at the health care issue, a principal concern of many voters, and the Republicans responded only in the final days.
Many Republicans say it would be dangerous for the White House to look disengaged on such issues in this campaign.
"Bush has a long way to go here domestically, and step one is to reconnect, to show that he understands reality here at home, to let people know that he's aware of what they're going through," said one Republican strategist close to the Bush campaign organization.
 
Other Issues Seen
 Still, that strategist argued: "If you look at the middle class as just this monolithic group driven by economic self-interest, I think that's wrong. And I think that's what the Democrats are doing right now, and I think they'll get blind-sided by a whole set of values and other issues that will appeal to these voters."
Many strategists shy away from defining the term middle class, noting that income guidelines fail to take into account such variables as the number of children in a family or the local cost of living. Moreover, part of the political magic of the term is that most Americans, black and white, consider themselves part of the middle class, according to some public opinion polls.
But Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee, speaks of a critical middle-class voter as a suburbanite, in a household with about $35,000 income, younger than 45, with a child or two, and in a marriage in which both partners work. James Carville, a Democratic strategist working for Mr. Clinton and an architect of the Democratic victory in Pennsylvania, talks of a "32-year-old with two kids in day care who works in some suburban office building."
Robert D. Reischauer, head of the Congressional Budget Office, views the middle class as the middle 60 percent of Americans by income, which for a family of four would be from $19,000 to $78,000. He adds, however, that attitudes can be as telling as income: "Most people think of the life style they can afford, the amount of discretionary income."
 
Baggage to Unload
 In this struggle for the middle-income voter, each party has some baggage to unload. The Republicans have to fight the perception that they care most about the rich; the Democrats have to make the case that they are ready to lead again, and counter a decade of charges that they are addicted to big-spending Government programs and care most about the poor.
In 1984, when the Democratic nominee, Walter F. Mondale, campaigned for "fairness," many middle-income voters heard it as a plea for the poor, not for them, says Stan Greenberg, a poll taker for Mr. Clinton.
Today, some poll takers say, the middle class feels neglected by the entire system.
"Probably the single biggest point of consensus among voters today is that the middle class is ignored by the political system and paying a steep economic price for it," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. Some Democratic strategists assert that this anger results from a fundamental reassessment of the Reagan years, about who prospered and who did not. As a result, they argue, the anger will outlive the recession.
 
'Something Wrong'
 "Even if we have 3 percent economic growth by Election Day, I still think the right Democrat with the right economic message can win," says Mr. Carville. "I think people understand there is something wrong with Republican leadership that goes beyond expansions and contractions."
Robert M. Teeter, the campaign chairman for Mr. Bush, says that middle-class voters will not simply respond to a laundry list of Government programs. "The reason we've done well with the middle class over the past 10 years is we've been for the things that helped them, whether it's on tax policies, family values or national security. We've been closer to them than the Democrats have, and I don't think that's changed."
Still, many Democratic strategists say they have learned from their mistakes in the 1980's, when middle-class voters defected in droves as Republicans portrayed the Democrats, again and again, as a party outside the American mainstream. Values were an important part of the Republicans' appeal to middle-income voters, many strategists say. This year, in addition to their economic promises, the Democratic candidates talk often of their party's commitment to the traditional values of hard work, personal responsibility and patriotism.
 
Small-Town Roots
 Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, for example, talks of his small-town roots and the values it gave him; Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska talks of the yearning of parents that their children surpass them. Mr. Clinton talks of the need for greater personal responsibility in welfare programs and corporate suites.
From a policy perspective, the Democrats are focusing on issues with similarly broad constituencies: better schools, affordable health care, middle-income tax cuts.
"A lot of Democratic policy thinking used to be directed toward lower-income people," said Mr. Garin. "Now, there's a recognition that we've got to be fighting for the middle-class people who are the backbone of the country and the heart of the electorate."
Tim Raftis, campaign manager for Mr. Harkin, says: "The Democrats need to do a much better job, and I think in this campaign they have, in communicating and talking to the ordinary concerns of working people. Most people have a deep and abiding concern for the homeless and the less fortunate in our society, but it's hard to lend a helping hand when your own footing is pretty slippery."
Many Democrats see this new middle-class politics as a striking change in their party. Mr. Greenberg said he used to encounter resistance from some of his fellow Democrats about explicit appeals to the middle class; they worried, Mr. Greenberg said, that it might seem to exclude the poor or lower-income groups. "But it's an inclusive concept," the poll taker said.
Still, Mr. Teeter asserts that the Democrats may be congratulating themselves too soon. "They can get up and say middle class four times in each paragraph, but if they enunciate policies that the middle class don't think will help them, it won't do any good."
Mr. Teeter argued that the middle class still worries about Government spending and still has doubts about the effectiveness of using Federal programs to solve many of the nation's problems, two concerns that hampered the Democrats throughout the 1980's.

HEADLINE: For Nonviolent Legacy, A Violent Rap Message

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Portraying violence against the only state not to honor the nonviolent legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. or civil rights, a rap music video has aroused anger and fascination here.
Depicting the assassination of local politicians, the video, "By the Time I Get to Arizona," by the rap group Public Enemy, has been played repeatedly on news programs here. Discussion of the video has appeared on the front pages and editorial columns of Arizona newspapers and on radio talk shows. 
 A spokesman for Grant Woods, the State Attorney General, said that the state would take no legal action and that the rappers have a right to express their views, no matter how repugnant.
 
Music as Shock Treatment
 The video's debut this week on MTV is the latest instance in which violent words or images in rap music have shocked audiences outside the culture of hip-hop music.
Momentarily, the video has united most Arizonans, who rejected the holiday in a vote last year and remain sharply divided over the issue, which will be on the ballot again in November.
The national holiday, the third Monday in January, will fall on Jan. 20 this year and will be observed in every state except New Hampshire and Arizona. New Hampshire will hold a civil rights holiday, but it is a "floating" day, and the measure creating the holiday does not mention Dr. King.
The Rev. Warren Stewart, a leading black campaigner for adoption of the King holiday, said Public Enemy's violent message "does a disservice to the legacy of Dr. King."
 
Comment by Ex-Governor
 Mr. Stewart's view was echoed by Evan Mecham, the former Governor who canceled a plan for a statewide holiday in 1987 before he was impeached on charges of corruption. "It sounds like someone trying to make money with trash," he said.
The video depicts the group's lead singer, Chuck D., leading a paramilitary charge, and ends with an actor portraying an Arizona senator dying from poisoned candy and another portraying an Arizona governor being killed by a car bomb.
These scenes are interspersed with depictions of civil rights marches and re-enactments of the assassination of Dr. King, who was slain in Memphis on April 4, 1968.
The song is part of an album entitled "Apocalypse 91: The Enemy Strikes Black," which is one of five nominees for a Grammy Award for best rap performance by a duo or group. The album was released last November, but its video had its first nationwide showing this week.
 
'Respect to the Black Fist'
 Violent rap lyrics most recently drew a shocked reaction in Los Angeles late last year in the song "Death Certificate," by the rapper Ice Cube, which threatens violence against Korean shopkeepers. "Pay respect to the black fist or we'll burn your store right down to a crisp," the song says.
In October 1990, the rap group 2-Live Crew was acquitted of an obscenity charge in a Florida court for music that contained images of violent sexual behavior. But in a separate trial the same month, a video store owner who sold their album was convicted of selling obscene material.
While its video images are strong, the lyrics of the Arizona rap song are vague and generally unremarkable. The strongest lines are:
Call me the trigger man
Looki-lookin' for the governor.
Another line goes:
I'm on the one mission
To get a politician.
At one point Chuck D. asks:
What's a smilin' face
When the whole state's racist?
At a news conference in New York earlier this week Chuck D. defended his composition, saying: "It's a trip into the fantasy world of Public Enemy. You know, the big payback."
 
It's Chuck D.'s Version
 In a telephone interview the group's publicist, Ursula Smith, said: "What Chuck D. was trying to get across was that Martin Luther King did not just die; he was brutally murdered. Public Enemy is saying, 'This is how it looks on the other foot.' "
She added: "Oliver Stone has his version in 'J.F.K.' Now Chuck D. has added his movie about Martin Luther King. And what his movie is saying is, if Martin Luther King could see himself after his assassination, he would have had a different view."
Or, as Chuck D. puts it in his song, referring to today's politicians:
He try to keep it yesteryear,
The good ol' days,
The same ol' ways
That keep us dyin' --
Yes, you-me-myself, and indeed
What he need is a nosebleed.
Ms. Smith said that like the director Oliver Stone, Chuck D. was intent on educating audiences that remained largely ignorant of essential moments in history. She said his music is just one part of his "black awareness program" in which he visits high schools to talk about black issues.
Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, said in Atlanta today that she had not seen the video, but added, "We do not subscribe to violence as a way to achieve any social or economic ends; we condemn violence in any form."
Long before Public Enemy's attack, Arizona has felt an economic and political backlash over its failure to adopt a statewide holiday honoring Dr. King.
The state has lost millions of dollars in canceled conventions, and lost both financially and in prestige last year when the National Football League canceled plans to hold the 1993 Superbowl in Phoenix.
Moreover, the shock aroused here by Public Enemy's message illustrates the gulf between the harsh world that has nurtured the rappers and the political establishment of this desert state.
Douglas Cole, a spokesman for Gov. Fife Symington, called the video "repugnant" and "extremely misinformed," noting that the Governor favors a King holiday.
And Mayor Paul Johnson of Phoenix, which will honor Dr. King with a cityholiday this month, said, "The violence in the video is contrary to everything Dr. King lived for and died for."
Mr. Stewart tried to find something positive in the video, saying, "The message is unfortunate, but it put the issue back on the front pages."
But few Arizonans seemed impressed by that notion. John Mathews, a 21-year-old college student, said the video amounted to "the wrong kind of pressure" and might even backfire in its effect on voters.
The Arizona Republic defended the state in an editorial that said: "No matter what view of Dr. King the Arizona public might take, there can be no doubt that his message was always one of peace and nonviolence. However, the message sent by the rappers is one of political bigotry, ignorance and hatred."

HEADLINE: In Spite of Hardship, I.M.F. Urges Russia To Raise Price of Oil

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 10

 BODY:
After a week of rising consumer prices and sporadic protests from angry shoppers, a team from the International Monetary Fund, acting with the endorsement of the United States, is pressing Russia for drastic additional steps, chief among them a sharp increase in oil prices.
The I.M.F. wants President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, where most of the commonwealth's oil is produced, to raise petroleum prices to 10 to 15 times their present level, and they have already quadrupled in the last week. 
 Such a rise would increase gasoline and heating-oil supplies by pricing them beyond the reach of many people -- a measure not tried in the old Soviet Union. Russians now pay the equivalent of 4 cents a gallon for gasoline.
 
Why Raise Prices?
 The I.M.F. insists that higher oil prices would increase the revenues of the Russian Government, helping to balance the budget and thus increase the value of the ruble, an I.M.F. goal. And with higher prices reducing consumption at home, more oil would be available for export, thus earning Russia hard currency to repay $65 billion in foreign debt, another I.M.F. goal.
The I.M.F., whose policies usually represent the views of the Western industrial powers, is also pressing the members of the Commonwealth of Independent States to accept Russia's ruble as their common currency.
The new pressure in effect undercuts Ukraine's move to create its own currency, and it gives Mr. Yeltsin a Western stamp of approval as the leader in shaping economic policy for the entire commonwealth.
"We are agnostic on the issue of separate national currencies, but establishing them is like a divorce," said an I.M.F. official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If people build something together, separation destroys that something and reduces the energy level."
The unfolding Western approach to resolving the commonwealth's economic crisis was evident in interviews this week with officials of the Bush Administration, Mr. Yeltsin's Government and the I.M.F.
 
A Week of Talks
 An eight-member I.M.F. team, the first to visit since the Soviet Union was dissolved last month, arrived on Tuesday night for a week of negotiations with Yegor T. Gaidar, Mr. Yeltsin's top economic adviser.
The I.M.F., established after World War II, serves the industrial nations as their arbiter of which nations are creditworthy, and deserving of foreign loans and investment, both now sought by the former Soviet republics.
Various republics are applying for I.M.F. membership. The Bush Administration recently endorsed membership for Russia and five other former Soviet republics, and said it was prepared to support applications by the rest. But even before the republics' formal entry, probably later this year, the I.M.F. is maneuvering to influence their economic policies, an influence exercised this week to press the Yeltsin Government to raise oil prices and also to cut Government spending, which would reduce employment and social programs in the process.
The Yeltsin team says oil prices will be raised again, but right now Mr. Yeltsin is holding out for a $6 billion stabilization fund, a sum he has formally requested from the industrial nations. Among other things, the money would pay for consumer imports to ease tensions.
"We want to go forward with the I.M.F. program and we will go forward, even without the stabilization fund," said Konstantin Kagalovsky, a Gaidar deputy leading the negotiations with the I.M.F. team. "But the program might not succeed without the money."
Robert S. Strauss, the United States Ambassador to Moscow, favors the stabilization fund, and also the I.M.F.'s various demands, including higher oil prices, but with the caveat that public unrest might change the strategy.
"What is happening here is all too new," Mr. Strauss said. "There is no model, no precedent for this kind of program in a country like this. But if you don't get me too specific, there is a general consensus that we need to do various things."
 
Pennies Per Barrel
 Above all, the West is pressuring the Russian Government, which owns and supplies 90 percent of the oil consumed in the commonwealth, to stop selling it under a huge subsidy at the equivalent of less than 70 cents a barrel in American currency, even after the fourfold price increase in the last week.
That makes the pump price of a gallon of gasoline about 5 rubles, or 4 cents in United States currency, up from one ruble, or about one cent, a week ago. Gasoline in the United States, by comparison, averages more than $1 a gallon at the pump, and the world price of crude oil is more than $18 a barrel.
Moving oil toward world price levels, I.M.F. officials acknowledge, would be a blow to thousands of commuters and truckers. Millions of families get a break on heating oil, but I.M.F. officials argue that once heating-oil prices rise, the various republic governments could provide subsidies for those most in need, rather than the entire population.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The U.S. unemployment rate climbed to a 5 1/2-year high of 7.1 percent in December, with the bulk of the rise among people discharged from their latest job with little prospect of recall, the Labor Dept. said. Long-term unemployment also rose substantially as the ranks of those out of work swelled by 289,000, to 8.9 million, the highest in nearly eight years. As discouraging as much of the report was, many private analysts said it did not point to significant fresh deterioration in the economy last month, but mainly reflected a continued lack of growth. [Page 1.] 
 Greenspan told Congress that he expected the steep cut in interest rates the Fed ordered last month to be sufficient to get an economic recovery started and that he did not foresee a need for further rate cuts or for budgetary stimulus. [33.]
 
International
On his return, President Bush tried to put an optimistic gloss on what critics called a disastrous trade meeting with Japan's leaders. [1.]
Lee Iacocca unleashed his most vitriolic attack yet on Japan, predicting that Bush's trade mission wouldn't budge the trade deficit or salve Detroit's wounds. But other executives said that although the trip may eventually help narrow the trade gap, Bush focused too much on the auto industry's relations with Japan. [33.]
A trade agreement reached during Bush's trip could result in as much as $2 billion a year in extra sales of American computers in Japan. [33.]
A Chinese negotiating team made a new proposal as a final round of talks began on patents, copyrights and trademarks, but a U.S. official said the proposal did not go far enough. [33.]

Companies
A plan to allow Federated and Allied Stores to emerge from bankruptcy next month will be confirmed. [33.]
Sears, Roebuck is promoting James M. Denny to the new position of vice chairman. The move is intended to give Edward A. Brennan more time to focus on retail operations. [35.]
Ratings were upgraded on Merrill Lynch's long-term debt and preferred stock by S.&P. [35.]
New York Woman ceased publication. The lively life-style magazine for young urban sophisticates fell victim to the decline in local retail advertising. [37.]

Borden said it would cut 1,300 salaried jobs worldwide, citing brisk competition in the food business. [35.]
 
Markets
Oil prices rose after Venezuela cut its production by about 2 percent and said it hoped others would follow. [33.]
Stock prices fell moderately. The Dow dropped 10.07, to 3,199.46, ending the week 2.02 short of where it began. [36.]
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates moved higher after the Government employment report. [36.]
The dollar extended its recent advance. Gold prices slipped after rising overseas. [42.]

The issue of deducting "points" on mortgages has been clarified by an I.R.S. ruling. Robert D. Hershey Jr.: Your Taxes. [34.]

HEADLINE: Kohl Seeks to Fend Off Criticism Of His Assertive German Policies

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl sought today to defuse accusations of a fresh assertiveness on the part of reunited Germany, arguing that Germany is now a nation of 80 million in the heart of Europe and its leading economic power, and has had to shoulder fresh responsibilities, particularly toward its neighbors in Eastern Europe.
He also dismissed suggestions that Bonn would seek changes in the United Nations structure allowing it a permanent Security Council seat. 
 The remarks come at a time of growing disquiet over the assertive style of German policy. On Tuesday, Mr. Kohl's close European ally, President Francois Mitterrand of France, chided Germany for offending the spirit of European unity by its vigorous support in December of recognition for Slovenia and Croatia, the breakaway Yugoslav republics, and by raising interest rates in a display of financial power and political independence that put pressure on Britain, France and Italy. American officials have expressed similar distress.
 
Disarming Critics
 Since Germany reunified in October 1990, Mr. Kohl has been at pains to emphasize Germany's continued commitment to its Atlantic allies and to deepening European economic and political unity. But the Chancellor declared that the "new Germany" could not overlook that it "plays a strong part in the fate of others."
But in seeking to disarm his critics, Mr. Kohl at times appeared to display the kind of righteousness that has prompted the criticism of Germany in the first place.
At a news conference in Bonn that addressed the full range of domestic and foreign policy isues, Mr. Kohl cited Germany's financial and humanitarian aid for Eastern European countries, most notably the old Soviet Union, and suggested that that newly expanded role stemmed from reunited Germany's size and its position as "No. 1 in Europe in economic might."
Mr. Kohl, who shows himself to be unusually unflappable in the face of outside criticism, has found himself nonetheless drawn into the debate. Showing no sign of irritation, he has sought to disarm critics by insisting that Germany's energies will be exhausted for the near future with the task of rebuilding its eastern territories and assisting the battered economies of its newly democratic neighbors to the east.
 
Security Council Seat
 Mr. Kohl vowed to press for changes in Germany's Constitution allowing its defense forces to take part in United Nations peacekeeping missions, a step that is opposed by the Social Democrats. But he dismissed suggestions that Bonn would seek a Security Council seat.
"We have enough to do at home," he said.
A close aide to Mr. Kohl, noting the absence of public debate on the issue in Germany, said Bonn was satisfied that Britain and France, who are permanent Security Council members, adequately represented European interests.
"If a seat did come free, we would be in favor of it going to the European Community," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Layoffs Are Seen For Chevron Unit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., Jan. 10

 BODY:
A union official said Chevron U.S.A. was considering laying off hundreds of workers at the local refinery because of the recession. "If we don't have a layoff, it's going to be a miracle," Keith Guidry, vice chairman of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers' workmen's committee, said. 
 Chevron officials in Houston did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. But published reports said Chevron was looking at all operations as it worked to become more efficient and meet tougher environmental standards. Mr. Guidry said it would be at least two months before any layoffs since the union had an agreement with management for a 60-day notice.

HEADLINE: In the End, Wilder Realized The Numbers All Fell Short

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHMOND, Jan. 10

 BODY:
As is almost always the case in failed Presidential campaigns, in the end the numbers were not there for Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia.
He did not have enough money. His staff was too small. And worst of all for a politician, he did not have enough votes. 
 So on Wednesday night, more than a month before votes are cast in New Hampshire, in the first primary of the 1992 Presidential election season, he cut his losses and became the first candidate to drop out of the Democratic field. The five remaining contestants were left to scramble for the pivotal black vote that Mr. Wilder had unsuccessfully tried to lock up.
 
Unaccustomed to Defeat
 Never before in more than 20 years of politics had Mr. Wilder suffered a campaign defeat. True, it was not a defeat at the polls for this descendant of slaves, who was born in segregation and poverty on Richmond's Church Hill and rose to become the first black ever elected governor of one of the states. But it was the next closest thing to defeat at the polls.
In his surprising retreat from the fray, Mr. Wilder, normally the most combative and unyielding of politicians, said he did not have the time to run for President and also to run the State of Virginia, which is struggling with the worst economic recession in more than half a century.
"He had to face that hard fact," Edward Elson, an Atlanta businessman who was the Governor's chief fund-raiser, said Thursday in analyzing the aborted Presidential quest. "The campaign was truly going well. The problem was that things just got so bad in the state that he was up against a huge budget deficit and he had to turn his attention away from the campaign."
But that was only part of the story.
"The other part is that he never got his campaign sea legs," said Thomas E. Donilon, a Democratic strategist who so far is sitting out the 1992 campaign. "He's a better candidate than his brief run indicated, and we haven't seen the last of him in American politics. But he never raised enough money to stay in this race all the way or, for that matter, long enough to overcome his inexperience in running at a national level -- how to avoid verbal gaffes, how to debate effectively, how to convey the message."
The Governor has refused to elaborate on his decision to pull out of the race. He told reporters who trailed him today to Williamsburg, Va., where he spoke to a gathering of prominent black students from colleges all over the country, that there was nothing to add.
Asked the morning after his withdrawal when he had first concluded he would have to pull out of the contest, he called back over his shoulder to pursuing reporters, "It was before last night."
But some of his campaign workers are more forthcoming in analyzing the aborted race.
As Mame Reiley, the Wilder campaign coordinator in New Hampshire, sees matters, the Governor's poor showing in the polls there was due in good measure to a slow start.
"I know he had problems back home," she said. "But we could have done a lot better if we could have gotten decisions sooner out of headquarters, if we could have gotten more commitment, gotten his story and his message out. It was hard to get headquarters to get the Governor on the phone to talk to potential contributors, little things like that."
In the end, the Governor's campaign message proved to be a particular problem. Many political professionals as well as potential voters believe that the message never crystallized.
A politician often enamored more of political process than political issues, Mr. Wilder spoke mainly in generalities while on the campaign trail, saying he was a "fiscal conservative with a social conscience" but not elaborating.
Asked what he would do about soaring health care costs, a hot campaign issue, he sometimes answered with a vignette about how shocked he was to learn that a little girl in Virginia had died because her family could not afford medical care.
"We can't afford that," he would say.
Once during a debate when the Governor used such language in reply to a question about how he would deal with health care problems, a campaign rival, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, quipped dismissively, "Doug, you're running for President now."
There was another problem with the message, too, as the Governor began learning shortly after declaring his candidacy in mid-September. In many ways, it was the most serious problem of all.
In his 1989 campaign for governor, Mr. Wilder was able to win over black voters and liberals by proclaiming social consciousness, and he won moderate white voters by promising fiscal conservatism. Then, he got the final winning edge -- the margin that overcame the drag of the racial issue, many political experts say -- by declaring himself in favor of abortion rights.
But when he tried to forge that combination on the national political stage, he failed.
 
Hesitation Among Blacks
 Black voters, and especially prominent blacks, have been hesitant so far to commit themselves to any candidate. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a powerful and influential Wilder rival, has suggested that black voters ponder long before choosing a candidate. Moreover, he has pointed out that Mr. Wilder is among the most conservative of the country's major black figures.
As for moderate white voters, Mr. Wilder had to compete for their support with, among others, the apparent front-runner in the young campaign, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Mr. Clinton also preaches fiscal responsibility and social consciousness, though in considerably more detail.
Finally, the abortion issue, for all its potential effect on the campaign, has not yet become a hot, exploitable topic.
By the time Mr. Wilder withdrew from the race, a decision even his campaign manager said he did not learn about until the final hour, he was primarily chasing black voters. He had given up attracting many white votes, in part because in-depth interviews in New Hampshire by his campaign consultants had found whites were not moved by his candidacy.
In particular, Mr. Wilder focused on the heavy black vote in the South. His hope was that a good showing there would give his flagging campaign a lift, or at least provide him with enough delegates to have some say at the Democratic National Convention in New York in July.
Some members of his campaign staff were upset by this approach, even after polls indicated the Governor might pull significant black votes in several Southern states. They argued that it would mark the Governor in any future political endeavors as solely a "black candidate" rather than as a "candidate who happens to be black," the latter being his approach in his successful, history-making Virginia campaigns.
What of Mr. Wilder's political future?
"I'm not running for anything -- now," the Governor replied Thursday.
That answer immediately touched off renewed speculation that Mr. Wilder, who cannot succeed himself under Virginia law, has his eye on a United States Senate seat. His chief Democratic political rival in the state, Senator Charles S. Robb, will be up for re-election in 1994, a year after Mr. Wilder leaves the Governor's office.
Mr. Wilder's popularity in Virginia slumped when he entered the Presidential contest, less than half way through his four-year term as Governor. Many state residents felt slighted and some sported "Wilder for Resident" buttons.
But now that he has withdrawn from the 1992 contest, there is a hint of a turnaround in his state standing.
State Senator Hunter B. Andrews of Hampton, the Senate Democratic leader, the Governor's principal antagonist in the Virginia General Assembly, was among the first to commend Mr. Wilder for pulling out.
"Now he'll be here," Mr. Andrews said, "working with us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who withdrew as a Democratic Presidential candidate, talking to reporters on Thursday in Richmond. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Greenspan Asks Pause In Stimulus

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that he expected the steep cut in interest rates that the Fed ordered last month to be sufficient to get an economic recovery started and that he did not foresee a need for further rate cuts or for budgetary stimulus.
"That is my expectation; that is my best judgment," Mr. Greenspan said in answer to questions from sharply critical Democratic senators. 
 But he said the economic circumstances today were extraordinary, unlike any he had witnessed in his four decades as an economist, so he could not be sure he would not have to change his mind as the year wore on.
 
Unusually Large Cuts
 This was the first time Mr. Greenspan was questioned in public since the Federal Reserve reduced the interest rates it controls on Dec. 20. The unusually large one-day steps pushed the rates to their lowest levels since the 1960's.
A one-percentage-point cut in the discount rate to 3 1/2 percent and a half-point drop in the Federal funds rate to 4 percent were possible, Mr. Greenspan said, because inflation was under control. The discount rate, largely symbolic, is what the Fed charges banks for loans. The Federal funds rate, the benchmark for other short-term rates, is what banks charge each other for overnight loans.
The Fed chairman said he believed the new low rates, as they worked their way through the economy -- "the pipeline," as he called it -- would lead to new stock offerings and lower bond rates. That would mean individuals and companies were working down their debts and should mean a sustained recovery this year, he added.
Mr. Greenspan testified before a joint session of the Senate Banking and Budget Committees. Congress is in recess, and only a few senators, mostly Democrats, showed up.
 
Attack White House Efforts
 But the Democrats who did -- Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Alan J. Dixon of Illinois -- used Mr. Greenspan as a prop for another public attack on the Bush Administration's economic policies.
The Democrats are advocating tax cuts and spending increases to give the economy a quick jolt. Mr. Greenspan said such steps would be unwise because once budgetary discipline was breached, it would be difficult to "rein in" and would "create problems for the economy over the longer term."
Mr. Greenspan is held in high regard in Congress because of his economic expertise and his patient and respectful temperament. But today, for one of the first times in his more than four years as head of the central bank, he was under fire from the lawmakers.
Senator Sasser blamed the Fed for causing the recession, saying it had kept interest rates too high for too long, and declared, "I think it's time for the Fed to be at least as forthright in fighting recession as it has been in fighting inflation."
Senator Riegle said that it was fine to worry about the long term but that "people have to survive in the short term."
And Senator Sarbanes declared, "The Fed has not moved quickly enough and far enough in monetary policy to address the short-term problem."
 
Bobs and Weaves
 In his characteristically pedagogic manner, Mr. Greenspan responded softly to each wave of attack, saying that there was "an awful lot of monetary stimulus in the pipeline," that stimulative fiscal measures were "premature" and that interest rates were already "down to the lowest level in a generation."
Repeatedly, as the senators tried to pin him down about whether further interest rate cuts would be necessary, Mr. Greenspan bobbed and weaved to avoid a direct response. "I try to be as oblique as possible," he said, grinning, at one point.
But eventually, he had this exchange with Senator Dixon:
Q. I take it that you believe that the modest drops in the rate of the discount window finally culminating in the 1 percent reduction you authorized in December of this year should bear fruit in the near future?
A. Yes, sir.
Q. In other words, I take it then that you are saying to us that you believe that that series of modest discounts ultimately culminating in the 1 percent drop will show fruit without any additional imposition of . . .?
A. No, I said should; I didn't say will.
Q. At least you expect it to?
A. I think that is my expectation at this point, but I wish to emphasize that these are very unusual circumstances, and one has to be very chary about one getting a conviction and locking it into cement at this stage because we do not have a rational capability of holding a conviction in this type of environment.
 
Economy Clearly 'Struggling'
 Mr. Greenspan's assessment of the economy was the same as the one he gave the House Ways and Means Committee three weeks ago. Basically it is that last spring the economy began pulling out of the recession, which began in the summer of 1990. But by last fall, the recovery had stalled, and now it is clearly "struggling."
The reason, he said, was that the economy was left so badly out of shape by the corporate mergers and buyouts, the overbuilding of commercial real estate and the household borrowing and spending boom of the 1980's that the recovery could not gain normal momentum.
Still, Mr. Greenspan added, the data today were not so bad compared with other recessions since World War II. But he said today, as he did three weeks ago, that consumer worries about the long-range health of the economy were the worst he had ever experienced.
 
Exchange Over Inflation
 An exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, was a prime illustration of how politicians and central bankers view the world differently.
Mr. Greenspan, whose contact with the public is minimal, said he was surprised that the mail the Federal Reserve received about interest rates was not so much from those who wanted further rate cuts as it was from retired people who live on the interest earned on savings and had seen their incomes pared by the lower rates. He said that he was sympathetic to their problem but that he hoped the slowing of the rate of inflation would help them retain their purchasing power.
Maybe so for some people, Senator Kassebaum said. But for her elderly constituents, medical costs are continuing to rise at an abnormal pace, and that offsets any other benefits from lower rates of inflation.

HEADLINE: Dow Off by 10.07 for Day and 2.02 in Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices fell moderately across the market yesterday, canceling out the small gains that had nudged blue chips to two records this week. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 10.07 points, to 3,199.46, ending the week 2.02 short of where it began.
The drop followed a stronger-than-expected rise in the non-farm payroll numbers for last month. This was seen by investors as bad for the market, because it dimmed hopes of further interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Low rates have done much to fuel the recent rally, because they give investors few good alternatives to putting their cash into equities. 
 Blue chips rallied briefly in the afternoon, as the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in Congressional testimony that the central bank stood ready to take whatever steps were necessary to keep the economy growing. But it fell back and then recovered only part of the earlier losses.
Action was heavy on the New York Stock Exchange, with 236.1 million shares traded, down from 292.4 million on Thursday. Losing issues outpaced gaining ones, 1,093 to 669, as the Big Board's composite index slipped 1.28, to 228.95.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.51, to 415.10, while the American Stock Exchange index slipped 1.93, to 405.64. Other barometers, which hit records all week, were also off. The Nasdaq composite declined by 4.10, to 615.70, while the Russell 2,000, an index of small-company issues, was off by 1.27, to 199.31.
Bernard Spilko, the senior vice president of the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer, said, "The unusual strength in the U.S. dollar frightened foreign investors," adding that the job data "did not provide stocks with the support it looks for from the credit market."
"This created temporary uncertainty in the market, and when investors are uncertain the market normally goes down," Mr. Spilko added.
Birinyi Associates, a research firm that tracks program trading, said that yesterday was fairly busy. It tracked four buying programs and six selling ones, whose combined effect pulled the Dow down by 8.91. But traders said strong underlying buying pressures helped to counter much of the selling pressures.
The stock of Employee Benefit Plans lost about 50 percent of its value after the health-care and management services company said it would report disappointing earnings for its fiscal second quarter. The stock closed down 30 1/8, to 30 3/8.
The big mover among the Dow and S.& P. indexes was Merck, which declined 3 1/2, to 163. International Paper and Philip Morris were each down 1, to 69 3/4 and 79 7/8, respectively.
Goodyear rose 1 1/4, to 55 1/2, as Wendy Needham of Smith Barney, Harris Upham began her coverage with a "buy" rating and a target price of $70 to $75 a share, traders said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Venezuela in Step to Raise Oil Price

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Reacting to the recent tumble in oil prices, Venezuela cut its production by about 2 percent yesterday and said it hoped others would follow.
The move pushed the price of oil up slightly on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but analysts said that the price in coming weeks would depend on two bigger factors: the outcome of negotiations between the United Nations and Iraq on conditions for Iraq to resume exports, and the position of Saudi Arabia at a meeting next month of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. 
 In New York trading, oil for delivery next month settled at $18.23 a barrel, up 37 cents. In contrast, the average price as recently as October was $23.23.
Announcing the cut, the Venezuelan Minister of Energy and Mines, Celestino Armas, said the intent was to send the market a signal, and added that it was likely other countries would take similar actions. If others follow it may create an atmosphere conducive to production when OPEC meets, on Feb. 12, experts said.
 
Unrestrained Oil Production
 Since Iraq invaded Kuwait 18 months ago, the other OPEC members have produced virtually without restraint. The cut by Venezuela brings that country's production back to about 2.3 million barrels a day, a level just above its old OPEC quota and about equal to two-tenths of 1 percent of total OPEC production.
Peter C. Beutel, a petroleum expert at Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J., said: "They're making this cut to send a message to the market, but it's not much of a message. What has gotten the market a little bit spooked is the feeling that maybe this is going to ignite a trend among all the other OPEC producers."
 But the big issue, he said, is what Saudi Arabia will do. The Venezuelan move, he said, "is like putting quarters in a church dish and hoping the big guy is going to drop a hundred dollar bill."
 The other question is when Iraq will return to the market. Representatives from Baghdad met with United Nations officials in Vienna on Thursday, and John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation said the meeting represented a step forward in that "it wasn't negative."
 If Iraqi exports are allowed to resume, they could reach a million barrels a day within weeks, Mr. Licht blau said. Iraq's prewar OPEC quota was 3.14 million barrels.
 In Mr. Lichtblau's view, Iraq may be becoming more flexible in its negotiations with the United Nations. "Iraq has seen they no longer have a bargaining position," he said. "The world doesn't need the oil." If the United Nations stands firm on precisely how it wants the oil exported and Iraq does not go along, "all of OPEC will say thank you very much to the U.N.," he added.
 The Oil Daily Energy Compass, a London-based faxed newsletter, said earlier this week that it had surveyed members of the Security Council and found the basis for a compromise with Iraq over exports. Issues include whether the oil would be exported to the Persian Gulf as well as to the Mediterranean, and who will control the distribution of food that is bought with the oil money.
 New Iraqi exports would add pressure on OPEC to cut back, but the war changed the political alignment within the organization. Mr. Lichtblau suggested that the Saudis would be willing to cut production, but probably only for commercial reasons, and not because of an OPEC agreement.

COCOA RISES SHARPLY
By The Associated Press
Cocoa futures were sharply higher yesterday, grains and soybean futures were mostly lower, and livestock and pork futures gained.
Cocoa futures rose sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. The gain was a response to data that indicate an increase in demand. The fourth-quarter grind report was released yesterday by the Chocolate Manufacturers Institute.
Cocoa for delivery in March was $22 higher at $1,205 a ton.
Grain and soybean futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as dealers squared positions in advance of quarterly crop reports.
After the close of trading, the Agriculture Department released data showing winter wheat seedings totaled 50.2 million acres, much lower than traders' estimates of 54.05 million acres.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, cattle futures advanced on strong cash prices, while pork futures were under pressure as a result of steep cash hog prices. Pork futures received some support from forecasts of severe winter weather.

HEADLINE: Views of Bush's Trip From Corner Offices

 BODY:
American executives from many areas of industry were asked yesterday what they thought President Bush's trip to Asia would accomplish. Following are excerpts from their interviews and statements:
 
Dexter F. Baker
 Chairman and chief executive, Air Products and Chemicals, an industrial-gas producer in Allentown, Pa., and one of the executives accompanying the President on the trip.
We didn't just go to Japan. The Pacific Basin is very important to America. It's our largest trading relationship, with two-way trade of about $300 billion. We are pretty close to balance or slightly positive with most of the countries. The economies in that part of the world, outside of Australia, are booming. It's a very strategically important part of the American economic scene.
Some market-opening initiatives were achieved. I think it was a very positive trip. This wasn't tokenism on the President's part. I think he performed magnificently. The key thing is that the President has created a really positive environment for American investment and trade to flow to Japan.
I'm convinced they genuinely want to improve the commercial relationships with the U.S. We talked about the tremendous opportunity to work together in dealing with markets opening up in Central and Eastern Europe. Now, American industry has got to get off its duff and start investing in those parts of the world. The President has done his job. The American business community now has to go to work to tranform that to the bottom line and jobs.
 
Fred W. Lyons Jr.
 President and chief executive, Marion Merrell Dow Inc., a pharmaceutical company in Kansas City, Mo.
We're a little different from the auto industry. We're very pleased with the relationship we have with the Japanese. We introduced our Seldane antihistamine over there a year and a half ago and we did $100 million of business in 1991.
We go through a similar process in terms of drug registration in any country and the same kinds of marketing challenges. The problems we deal with are not unique to Japan.
We are very strongly in favor of free trade.
 
Wilfred J. Corrigan
 Chairman and chief executive, LSI Logic Corporation, a semiconductor manufacturer in Milpitas, Calif:
I can see how they reached the conclusion that they should take predominantly the automobile guys, but I don't approve of it. Either the President should have gone on his own, or, if he was making it into a trade mission, I think there should have been more businesses represented.
The message that gives to Japan is "Aha! What America is concerned about is automobiles." As far as the Japanese are concerned the automobile battle is over. It's just a mopping-up operation. Their concern is more on the industries of the future. Electronics is going to be the manufacturing industry of the 21st century.
There should have been significant representation from the computer industry and the semiconductor industry, and I'm sure there's a dozen other strategic industries. The message to give is: "We're really interested in the strategic-industry balance of trade."
 
George Hatsopoulos
 Chairman and chief executive, Thermo Electron Corporation, a high-technology and industrial-products company in Waltham, Mass.
I think the trip was ill conceived. Looking at the trade deficit as a bilateral problem with Japan is inconsistent with a healthy world economy. They may need a surplus from us in cars if they buy oil from other countries that buy things from us.
We have an overall trade deficit, but the problem is primarily economic policy in the U.S. We do have problems with high-tech products, communications, and certain financial services in Japan. President Bush focused on the wrong industry. Focusing on autos is taking on Japan where they have a good story to tell.
I think the White House knows better. Outside of politics, the only justification for looking at things bilaterally is to put pressure on them to remove invisible barriers.
 
James S. Davis
 Chairman and chief Executive, New Balance Athletic Shoe Inc. of Boston.
Japan is our strongest trading partner so it was important for the President to go to maintain good political and personal relations. It's good for chief executives to get to know each other because we are so interdependent. Greater understanding comes from sitting down face to face. We just wanted to remind everybody with our ad thatyou can still compete effectively in foreign markets. I have got to feel that there were other people there who are doing reasonably well. We just didn't hear about it because it's not controversial.
 
Don L. Gevirtz
 Chairman and chief executive, the Foothill Group, a financial-services company in Agoura Hills, Calif.
As a Democrat, I think the handling of the Japan trip provides the first glimmer that someone like Bill Clinton could defeat Bush.
Bush is focusing on dying industries rather than focusing on newer entrepreneurial industries that are creating most of the new jobs and many of the new innovations. It was a disastrous trip to Japan in terms of where our emphasis should be.
The major problem we have is that industries like autos have become completely non-competitive and at the same time we have a banking industry that is illiquid and not able to provide credit to smaller companies that are still growing.
 
Reginald Lewis
 Chairman and chief executive, TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a food company based in New York.
I don't think it was the wrong thing to do. The trade imbalance with the Japanese can't be ignored. The auto industry wanted his help, and he can't be criticized for trying to give it. The American consumer is now more aware of the impact on the general economy of selecting a Japanese product over the American product. It might encourage them to examine whether there is a real difference rather than a perceived difference.
Some of the strident aspects of the dialogue might be unfortunate. The negatives probably couldn't be avoided because it was a media event. Some of these problems have been with us for a long time and defy easy solution.
 
James Koontz
 President and chief executive, Kingsbury Machine Tool Company of Keene, N.H., and chairman of the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences in Ann Arbor, Mich.
I think the trip created recognition that there is a problem. The fact that we focused on the Japanese trade problem may have gotten some of the Japanese transplants to realize that they have to work more with American vendors. Our company has been promised several orders in the near future.
On the other hand, our problems are not really with the Japanese. They are at home. The major companies and unions have to sit down and agree to make our plants more flexible and productive. The whole trip was a bit of an embarrassment. The Japanese are 90 percent right in saying our problems are here.
 
Richard B. Madden
 Chairman and chief executive, Potlatch Corporation, a forest-products company in San Francisco:
I believe he should have made the trip. The President and Prime Minister Miyazawa agreed the two nations would reach an agreement by the end of March that would substantially increase access to the Japanese paper market.
I don't know if this would have been achieved in anywhere near that time frame if the President hadn't made the trip. Potlatch is a major exporter of bleached paper board to Japan but we have been trying to break into the fine- coated paper market for some time and have had many difficulties. There are structural barriers.

HEADLINE: Blunt Talk by Iacocca, Just Back From Japan

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Lee A. Iacocca, the outspoken chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, in an address before Detroit's business elite, unleashed his most vitriolic attack yet on Japan yesterday, predicting that President Bush's trade mission would not budge the trade deficit or salve the auto industry's wounds.
Other executives said yesterday that while the President's trip might eventually help narrow the trade deficit, Mr. Bush focused too much attention on the conflict between Japan and America's auto makers, who, they said, have only themselves to blame for their woes. 
 Such views reflect the widespread belief outside Detroit that the industry's troubles result not so much from Japanese trade barriers as from the American auto makers' failure to match Japan's efficiency and reputation for quality.
"I know many companies do have problems with Japan, but focusing on autos is taking on the Japanese where they have a good story to tell," said George Hatsopoulos, the chairman and chief executive of the Thermo Electron Corporation, a high-technology and industrial-products company based in Waltham, Mass. "I think the trip was ill conceived."
Mr. Iacocca, however, would have none of that. "I for one am fed up hearing from the Japanese, and I might say some Americans, too, that all our problems in this industry, all our problems, are our own damn fault," he told a gathering of about 5,000 business executives at the Detroit Economic Club. "We do not have idiots running General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, or our suppliers. And our workers are not lazy and stupid."
He said that Japanese auto makers benefited from having "a closed sanctuary" in their home market; "a huge, wide-open market like the United States to sell into"; a friendly Japanese Government, and "company unions and sweetheart deals with banks and suppliers."
Still, Mr. Iacocca said that Mr. Bush's trip, with 18 American business executives in tow, made an important diplomatic point. "What's changed is that economics finally made it to the front of the plane along with the generals and the admirals and all the Foggy Bottom types from the State Department," he said.
"Their leaders have always taken business people on missions like this, because they've always put economics and business first," he said of the Japanese. "Now we're doing that."
He added: "Seeing American government and business arm in arm for the first time ever sent the Japanese a clear message; and I think -- I think -- the Japanese got it. They didn't like it. They fought it. Oh boy, did they fight it. And they made a start in dealing with it, but only a start. Frankly, from a Detroit perspective, it was weak, but it was a start."
The lunchtime speech was vintage Iacocca, crammed with hyberbole, statistics, his trademark expletives and folk wisdom: "I used to believe the Oriental long view was a great virtue and something we could learn from the Japanese. I was wrong. It's not a virtue at all, it's a weapon, and we have to disarm them. We need to use our own weapon: good old-fashioned American impatience. That means demanding a solution to the problem now."
 
Some Blunt Words
 Looking wan from having crossed the Pacific twice since Monday, Mr. Iacocca reiterated his preference for free trade, but accused the Japanese of exercising "predatory trade" and "insidious Japanese economic and political power within the United States."
He also rejected the notion that part of the reason for the large trade deficit is that American vehicles are unpopular in Japan. "They say it's because our stuff is junk," he said. "I wonder if there's another reason. Like maybe because my Jeep Cherokee costs $12,000 more in Japan than it does here because they don't accept our certification, and everything has to be inspected, and there's a maze of red tape not designed to protect the Japanese consumer, but to keep us out."
The business contingent with Mr. Bush included executives from financial-service and industrial companies who spent most of their time outside of Japan, visiting other trading partners. But the presence of the top executives of the Big Three auto companies and several makers of auto parts emphasized the auto industry's needs to the point that they overshadowed other topics.
 
A Different Perspective
 The talks in Japan actually put far less emphasis on the auto industry's concerns than the news reports suggested, said Dexter F. Baker, chief executive of Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown, Pa., and one of the executives on the Bush trip. He also said the visits to Australia, Singapore and South Korea would have long-range benefits for business that have been underestimated.
"I think it was a very positive trip," Mr. Baker said. "President Bush is the first President to focus for an extended period of time on the international trade issue, and he performed magnificently."
But other executives said yesterday that many Americans were probably misled about Japan's role in the challenges the economy faces and about which industries they should be counting on most for improving trade balances with Asia.
One company, New Balance Athletic Shoe Inc. of Boston, went so far as to run a pointed full-page advertisement in The New York Times yesterday saying that its running shoes were "one American-made vehicle that has had no problem competing in Japan" and concluding: "It only goes to prove, Mr. President, that when you build a product people really, truly need, something amazing happens. People buy it."

HEADLINE: Rates Move Up on U.S. Jobs Report

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates moved higher yesterday after the Government reported a modest improvement in payroll jobs in December.
The 31,000 increase in non-farm payrolls came as something of a surprise to most analysts. Many had expected a decline of about 75,000. 
 The nation's overall unemployment rate, which rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.1 percent, was largely ignored by participants in the credit market.
 
Interest-Rate Implications
 Traders and analysts said the negative reaction was not to the numbers themselves, but to the fact that they strongly implied that the Federal Reserve Board would not move soon to lower short-term interest rates again.
Others said the price drop was merely a correction after the recent strong run-up.
"This has nothing to do with fundamentals," said William Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc. "There has been a big run-up, and now people are just taking some profits."
Another Government securities trader, who insisted on anonymity, said that Thursday's selloff had created a lot of concern. "There has been a lot of buying over the last two weeks, and some of that had to come back out of the market," the trader said. "People were poised to sell no matter what the number was."
 
Fed Has Bought Bonds
 Comments by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, helped to lift the bond market off its lows late in the session.
In remarks before a joint meeting of the Senate Banking and Budget Committees, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had recently bought bonds as part of its open-market operations, and would consider doing so again if conditions warranted. He also lent his support to the Treasury Department's study of whether the department should alter its current financing strategy and sell fewer long-term bonds.
Some credit market participants have urged the Treasury to take advantage of the current wide differential between bond yields and yields on shorter-term securities by selling fewer bonds. Aside from lowering financing costs, a smaller supply of long-term bonds would probably help to bring down long-term interest rates, adherents of this position argue.
The Federal Reserve Board could help accomplish this latter objective by doing exactly what Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had been doing recently.
 
'Testimony Was Friendly'
 There was little reaction to Mr. Greenspan's remarks about the economy, but analysts said the gist of his comments was not surprising, or threatening, to the fixed-income market.
"On balance, his testimony was friendly," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "He clearly kept the door open for further accommodation on monetary policy."
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 10614/32, down 19/32, to yield 7.45 percent, compared with 7.41 percent late Thursday and 7.47 percent on Jan. 3.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 10422/32, down half a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, to yield 6.83 percent. The new 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.35 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 10010/32, down 7/32, to yield 4.83 percent.
 
 
Short-Term Rates Up
 The flickering chances of another quick reduction in short-term rates by the Fed caused short-term Treasury bill rates to rise.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.80 percent late yesterday, up 5 basis points. Rates on six-month bills rose by 6 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.86 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 10 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.92 percent.

HEADLINE: Ad Drop Forces Closing of New York Woman

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
New York Woman, a lively life-style magazine for young urban sophisticates, ceased publication yesterday, a victim of the decline in local retail advertising.
"It breaks my heart," said Thomas Ryder, president of the American Express Publishing Corporation, the magazine's parent. "It's one of the best magazines I have ever been associated with." 
 The magazine, which had a circulation of 90,000, had been for sale since November. Its advertising pages were down 34 percent for 1991, and in its five-and-a-half-year existence it never made a profit.
 
Appeal to Quirkiness
 New York Woman was the creation of its editor in chief, Betsy Carter, who thought up the idea as editorial director at Esquire. She saw the need for a magazine that would appeal to the quirkiness and urban survival qualities that she felt differentiated women in New York City from others.
"New York Woman was meant to be a type of woman; it was meant to suggest smart, urban, sophisticated women," Ms. Carter said yesterday. "The vision for this magazine and the voice of this magazine have always been very, very clear and have never changed."
But the very title that helped define the readership might have worked against the magazine, making it sound too local for national advertisers. It was left with an advertising base of local retail establishments that were among the hardest hit in the recession.
"It was originally to be sent to women trend-setters and influence brokers, but that concept dissipated pretty quickly," said Claude Fromm, executive vice president and media director for TBWA, the advertising agency. "It turned out to be a life-style publication, but it was never perceived as a service publication. There was too much other competition in the New York market."
The 18 staff members assembled in Ms. Carter's office yesterday morning for a tearful meeting with Mr. Ryder, who told them the company would absorb as many of them as possible in other positions.
Mr. Ryder said the magazine had been on "a good growth track" and came close to breaking even in 1989. He said that in the attempt to sell the magazine he had talked to "virtually everyone in the business" but could find no takers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Advance Continues, Helped by U.S. Jobs Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar extended its recent advance yesterday against other leading currencies after a report on December employment in the United States showed more strength than had been expected even though the unemployment rate rose.
Gold prices slipped in domestic trading after rising overseas. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $356.25 an ounce, down 75 cents from Thursday. 
 Dealers said the dollar got a lift from an unexpected rise in non-farm payrolls in December, even though the unemployment rate rose to 7.1 percent from a revised 6.9 percent in November.
Frank Pusateri, vice president of corporate foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston, said news of the growth in payrolls enabled the dollar to solidify the even bigger advance it had made on Thursday.
The dollar dipped at midafternoon when Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the Fed stood ready to take steps to stimulate the economy if necessary.
That kind of talk could suggest the Fed is ready to lower interest rates some more, a development that could hurt the dollar.
But Karen Gibbs, a senior financial analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago, said the dollar bounced back as traders examined Mr. Greenspan's remarks.
"He was being nebulous," she said. "He said there was room for easing, but he might not do anything right away. He said there was plenty of easing in the pipeline already."
Ms. Gibbs said the dollar resumed its climb amid growing expectations that European central bankers would express support for the dollar at a meeting of leading industrial nations later this month.
In addition, she said the dollar gained from buying by professional traders who needed the currency to complete earlier deals in which they promised to sell dollars they did not own, a situation called short-covering.
Mr. Pusateri of the Bank of Boston said demand for dollars was up because foreign money managers also appeared to be getting ready to buy American stocks and bonds in anticpation of further rises in those markets.
The dollar finished at 126.90 Japanese yen in New York, up from 125.80 late Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 125.85 yen, from 124.65 late Thursday, and it rose to 126.95 yen in London.
The dollar also gained ground against the British pound. In New York, the pound fell to $1.7885, from $1.8160 late Thursday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.7925, from $1.8130 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates in New York included: 1.5850 German marks, up from 1.5590; 1.4120 Swiss francs, up from 1.3945; 5.4090 French francs, up from 5.3325; 1,197 Italian lire, up from 1,181, and 1.15475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14865.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 40 cents an ounce, to $356.20. Earlier, gold rose in London to $357.60, from $351.75 late Thursday. Gold in Zurich climbed to $357.40 an ounce, from $351.85 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $4.42 to close at $357.29.
