SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1007 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Quick, Henry, the Fix

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
QUICK FIX STILL LIKELY to tempt Bush, Congress," headlined The Washington Times, despite the advice of sobersided pundits that went, "Don't just do something, stand there."
Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist of Bear, Stearns & Company, argued that "the wrong tax cut is a temporary quick fix that puts money into people's pockets." 
 In a diplomatic context, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Russians that "there are not quick fixes and there are no simple solutions."
And President Bush, commenting on indictments filed against Libyan terrorists, pointed out that the charges were not "some quick hit, quick fix on trying to find the answer."
Perhaps subconsciously, the President stumbled on the derivation of the phrase being used to decry a panacea for cure-alls. A hit, now widely used as slang for "assassination," has also been used since 1949 to describe the sensation of instant satisfaction experienced by the narcotics user; in "The Man With the Golden Arm," Nelson Algren wrote about the way an injection "hit the heart like a runaway locomotive, it hit like a falling wall." Long before that, a shot of dope was called a fix-up, a compound first used in 1867 by the British historian William Hepworth Dixon, who wrote in his book "New America" about an "eye-opener, fix-ups, or any other Yankee deception in the shape of liquor." To get a fix-up changed to get fixed in the 1930's, and reverted to a shortened noun -- to get a fix -- a generation later.
The first use of quick fix has not been located, but in the mid-1970's Newsweek began applying the drug term to tax cuts. Soon it lost its drug sense; in 1986, the Canadian Labor Congress denounced drug testing as "a quick-fix solution," apparently unaware of the aptness of its choice of words.
The sense of fix in quick fix meaning "cure-all that cures nothing" is in competition with the slang sense of the verb fix as "to influence the outcome corruptly," as in the race was fixed, or in noun form, the fix is in. Curious, how the standard verb fix, meaning "set, fasten, make firm or permanent," has been so often associated with corruption (Mr. Fix-it is an influence-peddler, and price fixers go to jail). The most voguish sense of quick fix is "any slapped-together solution doomed to failure." Word junkies pushing narco-derivations are freaked out because it's hard to get a quick fix on why.
 
 
PHRASEDICK ALERT

 
HERE'S A FLASH FROM THE campaign to find the origin of the classic if-by-whisky speech, a parody of a politician taking both sides of an issue. Coinage goes to Judge Noah S. (Soggy) Sweat Jr. of Corinth, Miss. (the nickname "Soggy" based not on his last name but on "Sorghum Top," referring to the way his hair resembled the tassel that grows atop sugar cane).
In 1952, as wets and drys were debating local prohibition of booze, Judge Sweat, now 69 years old, copyrighted his speech: "If when you say whisky you mean the Devil's brew . . . but if when you say whisky you mean the oil of conversation. . . ." His nephew Tom, a lawyer, informs me he sells copies suitable for framing out of his office at 612 1/2 Waldron Street, Corinth, Miss. 38834.
On another etymological front, it was reported here that the coiner of the now-ubiquitous phrase the peace process was Henry A. Kissinger, then Secretary of State, in the mid-1970's. To double-check, I sent a note with the citation to my old friend Henry in New York, who replies: "I honestly don't know if I coined the phrase peace process. But have I ever refused credit for anything?"
 
 
LYING LOW

 
TAR-BABY DID ME IN; I SHOULD have listened to Brer Fox.
Beginning a pusillanimous apology in a political harangue, I wrote, "Another reason I laid low was. . . ."
"You have committed the most common grammatical error in the English language," retorted Marian Mumford Brown of Orleans, Mass., "using laid as the past tense of the verb lie. The proper conjugation of lie, meaning 'recline,' is lie, lay, lain."
Elizabeth Baird Saenger of Mamaroneck, N.Y., picks it up from there: "You meant and should have said, 'Another reason I lay low. . . .' Lay is the simple past tense of lie, an intransitive verb (I lie low today, I lay low yesterday, I have lain low for weeks now)."
Lie, I am instructed, when it is a verb meaning "to recline," is intransitive; that is, when you lie in the weeds, you are not committing any action against the weeds. My recent prediction on television that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will "lay there in the weeds, and he'll try to make a comeback," was a repetition of my error -- he'll lie there in the weeds.
An entirely different verb is lay, meaning "to put, place," and it is transitive, as when you lay your hands on a villain, or lay odds on the unlikelihood that a language maven has a blind spot.
Now here's the point of confusion: as we have seen, when you change the present tense of lie to the past tense, you get lay ("I lay low yesterday"). But that same word lay is the present tense of the verb meaning "to put"; as Ms Saenger (I use no period) writes: "I lay down the newspaper now in order to write. I laid it down yesterday. I have laid it in the same place for weeks."
When I asked my grammatical aide, Jeffrey McQuain, how to get out of this without looking like a sap, he suggested, "If you were a hen, you could lay low in the nest, meaning lay the eggs low." I am not a hen. "Or you could say you were misled by Uncle Remus."
That's it: "Tar-Baby stay still, en Brer Fox, he lay low." The author, Joel Chandler Harris, misled generations of Americans with his dialect idiom; if the present tense for Tar-Baby was given as stay, then the present tense for Brer Fox should have been lie. Only if Tar-Baby stayed still -- past tense -- could Brer Fox lay low.
However, let's face it, "Brer Fox lay low" is the memorable phrase, and it is grammatically impeccable. The word I used, laid, can best be used in the past tense of lay, as in "I have just laid my cards on the table." And that's no lie.

PUB-DATE: January 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 5; Page 15; Column 3; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2075 words

HEADLINE: The State of the Art of Travel

BYLINE: By TERRY TRUCCO; TERRY TRUCCO writes about travel frequently.

 BODY:
IN "Dodsworth," Sinclair Lewis's novel about a retired automobile magnate, Samuel Dodsworth sails to Europe for a Grand Tour and is dazzled by the ship. It is state of the art, for the late 1920's, with a swimming pool, a wireless room and "ventilators like giant saxophones."
"I love this ship," Dodsworth tells his wife. "It's so -- Man certainly has put it over Nature for once!" 
 Dodsworth's miraculous ship has been a museum piece for decades. Today you can cruise on a ship that uses a computer to raise and lower its sails, or make a telephone call while flying over the Pacific. Come springtime, you'll be hearing live all-news radio broadcasts on planes flying over the United States (stay tuned for the '92 World Series). And before too long, you can expect voice mail in most hotel rooms, individual seatback or armrest video screens on most airplanes and airphones that promise to end forever the splendid isolation of air travel. (You'll be able to call anywhere in the world, take incoming calls, send and receive faxes, hold conference calls and even chat with passengers flying in other planes).
Cost, not surprisingly, is a big factor in the type of high-tech accouterments a hotel or transportation company chooses these days. Amtrak's plan to test armrest video screens on its Florida-bound trains this summer fell through for lack of funds. And a move to equip rooms at Hyatt hotels with elaborate Compact Disk stereo systems has been tabled, for now, because of expense.
"The guest rooms will evolve as technology brings costs down," said John Nicholls, Hyatt senior vice president for architecture and design. In the meantime, the company is replacing old-style clock radios with tabletop AM/FM stereo systems at selected hotels.
Traveler preference will also determine the kind of advances you'll see. A big surprise at Sheraton has been the tepid reception of its video checkout system, introduced more than five years ago. Fewer than 25 percent of the guests use it, according to Tom Faust, vice president in charge of rooms. "What happens, we believe, is a lot of people don't realize a receipt is available at the front desk when they leave," he said.
Sheraton plans to continue the system and, apparently undeterred, is experimenting with a roboticized vacuum cleaner for use in large hallways and ballrooms. (It has a mechanical eye so it won't bump into pillars or people.)
Just don't expect robots to replace porters or flight attendants soon. "From our point of view, the human element in our service is something we stress," said Richard Gomez, a Singapore Airlines vice president.
Unfortunately, what no one seems to have discovered yet is a cure for jet lag. But one way to avoid it in the not-too-foggy future may be to experience a faraway land without switching time zones, through the high-tech magic (or mischief, depending on your sentiments) of virtual reality. This eerie technology, still being developed, will allow you to experience the scenes, sounds and sensations of another place. The process promises to be cumbersome and costly, at least at first. Requisite equipment may include wrap-around screens, audio sensors, goggles with video display terminals and computerized gloves. Still, it's one way to try an afternoon in the Andes, have an evening in Paris, then spend midnight in Moscow.
Here's a look at some more likely innovations you can expect before too long.
 
Airplanes and Airports
 Airlines are experimenting with technology to improve in-flight entertainment, airplane telephones and on-the-ground services. Most have either introduced or tested individual video screens, usually in first class and business class cabins. British Airways and American have a library of films first-class passengers can insert into armrest videos. Japan Airlines offers movies on both big screen and armrest units in first class and business. But Virgin Atlantic, which flies from New York to London, has screens for every passenger -- three-inch diagonal seatback screens in economy, six-inch armrest screens for upper class. At present Virgin offers six entertainment channels. But as many as 100 choices may be available within the next 18 months, according to Christopher Moss, Virgin vice president for marketing and new product development. Among them may be a channel showing views of the ground, taken from cameras installed on wing or tail. "It's great if there aren't any clouds," Mr. Moss said.
Live radio is another possibility. Virgin is considering an FM radio system that would seek out the strongest station as the plane flies overhead. "You'll get a flavor of each place, from Newfoundland to Boston, as you fly into New York," Mr. Moss said.
Live radio broadcasts will begin on Delta's domestic flights sometime this spring -- and should be available on other American carriers within the year. USA Today Sky Radio, a new all-news station modeled after New York's WCBS-AM, will broadcast exclusively to airplanes flying over the United States, via satellite. Eventually, planes and cruise ships throughout the world could get the station, according to Richard Cooperman, president of USA Today Sky Radio. (The new airplane antenna was developed by Rantec, which built the Patriot Missile antenna. This is its first civilian project.) USA Today Sky Radio, featuring news, sports, business and weather reports from the Gannett News Service, will initially broadcast 18 hours a day, featuring two segments each hour, peppered with commercials. During evenings and weekends, passengers can tune into live sports events, from baseball and basketball to Olympic highlights. And yes, the service will broadcast Superbowl XXVII in 1993.
Trans-Pacific telephone service is now available, via Inmarsat, on selected flights by Singapore Airlines ($8.80 a minute) and Japan Airlines ($10 a minute). And before too long air-to-ground Airfones, first installed in 1984, may seem obsolete. G.T.E. Airfone's new generation of digital communications, called Genstar, will allow passengers the luxury of international two-way faxes and calls, including conference calls. Passengers will also be to communicate, via modem, from personal computers. The new system, which could eventually mean a telephone and screen at every seat, should also increase the types of on-screen entertainment and information services available. You could play video games with a passenger a few rows away, then check on your gate connections, make a hotel reservation and do a little shopping, all on your screen. Weather and stock market reports will also be available. All this it should begin coming your way by the spring of 1993.
The airlines are also refining check-in systems. British Airways recently introduced, at Newark International Airport in New Jersey, the Brick, a portable computer to check in passengers when lines are long. And high-tech touches are improving airport waiting rooms throughout the country, though these are usually limited to first and business class lounges. Lufthansa's new lounge at Kennedy Airport, for example, features televisions with individual headsets, fax machines, photocopiers and computers.
This brings us to the 21st century and a new generation of supersonic aircraft that, if all goes according to plan, will handily surpass Concorde. The new supersonics will be bigger, fly longer distances, be less costly to fly and go faster (you'll get from New York to Tokyo in just over four hours). Both Boeing and the team of British Aerospace and France's Aerospatiale, which designed Concorde, have competing designs on their drawing boards. The big aircraft companies are also working on a new plane to replace the 747. Boeing's N.L.A., or New Large Airplane, will seat 600 to 650.
What won't be coming anytime soon is the hypersonic plane, the much balleyhooed Star Trek contraption that would fly four or more times the speed of sound -- or more than 4,000 miles per hour. The hypersonic would simply fly too high and too fast for this planet, according to a Boeing spokesman. It would accelerate so quickly, passengers would need to wear space suits.
 
Trains
 American trains for years have lagged behind those in Europe and Japan, which can travel up to 200 miles an hour. Things won't change much in 1992. Still, Amtrak announced in November that it plans to test Sweden's X2000, a high-speed "tilt" train that can travel on existing track, later this year. If the 125-m.p.h. train successfully negotiates the winding Boston-New York run, passengers may be riding it by the end of the year. The new train would reduce the time of the fastest train between the two cities from four hours to just around three.
Discussion of faster, all-new trains continues elsewhere, notably in California and Florida where there's long been talk of building superfast magnetic levitation, or maglev, trains. Last May, a group of private investors launched the Texas T.G.V., a $2.1 billion project designed to link Houston and Dallas by 1998 with a version of France's high-speed T.G.V. But a United States Department of Transportation report in November said high-speed trains would be financially impractical for much of the country. And the Railway Technical Research Institute in Japan plans to develop a low-noise superexpress that can travel as fast at 219 miles an hour, according to a report about a week ago from the Kyodo News Service that was carried by The Associated Press. The report could not be immediately confirmed.
 
Hotels
 The big news for movie fans is a sophisticated new system that replaces the old Spectravision, with its limited selection of recent films. Guests can now choose from a menu of 75 movies, and they can watch any time they wish. The old-fashioned box that appeared on top of the hotel television set has also been eliminated. And the cost to watch is the same.
"Viewership is way up at our hotels that have it," said John Nicholls, Hyatt's senior vice president for architecture and design. Other improvements in room entertainment include CD systems and disks at hotels such as the new Hotel Nikko in Beverly Hills, with VCRs in the suites.
Voice mail is gradually replacing standard message-taking services at a number of hotels. And some hotel companies are looking into ways to maximize use of the television screen. "In the not too distant future, you may be able to reserve a ticket for the theater or order an in-room pizza from Domino's," according to Trevor Jones, Holiday Inn senior vice president for corporate development.
The Nikko in Beverly Hills, which opened last month, is the first hotel anywhere to have a special chandelier, in the Imperial Ballroom, programmed to present a 10-minute thunder-and-lightning show. The simulated dark-and-stormy-night was developed as a way to grab the attention of blase businesspeople, The new hotel, which goes out of its way to be high tech, also has a restaurant, called Matrixx, where waiters take orders on palm-size computers. Requests for food reach the kitchen in a twinkling.
The Nikko in Beverly Hills is also one of a sprinkling of new luxury hotels, including the Peninsula, Nikko Essex House and St. Regis in New York, equipped with sophisticated bedside control panels connected with the telephones. With a touch of a screen above the phone, which can be programmed in six languages, guests can control lighting, temperature, television and stereo. And the system notifies the front desk if a light bulb burns out. Still, America's most opulent hotels aren't routinely equipped with bedside buttons to open and close the curtains, a near-standard luxury feature in Asia.
For the big hotel chains, like Sheraton, Hyatt and Hilton International, new technology has made it possible to keep extensive records of customer preferences and speed up check-in. "It isn't meant to be intrusive," said Mr. Jones. "Rather, the information is on the kind of room you prefer, whether you like room service or not, or if you want a king-size bed." Beginning in February, Hyatt will have a nationwide 800 number, enabling customers to check-in and receive a room assignment over the phone; Sheraton is introducing a similar program for frequent guests. This will still entail a stop at the concierge's desk to pick up a key. But at some future date, your personal credit card may serve as your room key, according to Mr. Nicholls of Hyatt.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 11; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1862 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Filming Life, He Found His Own

BYLINE: By MICHAEL APTED; Michael Apted is the director, most recently, of the documentary "35 Up," opening on Wednesday at Film Forum 3.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"Thirty-five Up," the latest installment in the documentary series about the lives of 14 Britons, is the culmination of 28 years' work, and as far as I know is the longest-running project in the history of film. It started in 1964 with "7 Up," a documentary produced by Granada Television that looked at Britain through the eyes of these individuals as 7-year-olds. I was 22, had just left Cambridge University with a law degree and had been hired to find the children from as diverse backgrounds as possible and, with the director Paul Almond, to get their opinions on money, love, God, sex, race, school and one another. We also wanted to know what they had in mind for their futures. These were the politicians, managers, union leaders and parents of the year 2000, so what kind of England could we look forward to?
We used the Jesuit idea "give me a child until he is 7 and I will show you the man," but, frankly, our underlying concept was political. Granada was a left-wing company, and in the heady days of 1964 when England was the pop-cultural center of the world, we wanted to see whether the dynamics that gave fame and fortune to the Beatles, the Stones and other icons had permeated our class system. Did everybody have a fair chance, or did the accident of birth bring power, wealth and success? Were children made into winners or losers by class divisions, or was the old order changing forever? 
 The film became an instant classic, for out of the mouths of those babes came some fairly alarming truths about the inequality and unfairness that still existed at the very heart of our society. The arguments that emerged were so provocative that I decided to go back every seven years to record what was happening to these children as they grew up.
Over 28 years and five films, their lives have become a road map for a kind of social history of the last three decades. The series has also been a marker for me, as it has engaged my entire working life. I have married, had children and moved to America, and wondered whether the choices I have made have been as preordained as some of those in "7 Up." I've brought up my own children, mindful of those I have filmed growing up burdened by so much parental ambition that their lives have gone seriously awry. You can see the charm of a 7-year-old become stress at 14 and disappointment at 21. I look at Nick, at 7 a farmer's son from rural Yorkshire, at 35 an associate professor of physics at the University of Wisconsin, in the process of relocating his family to America, much as I did, homesick for England and trying to identify and hang on to those of his roots that would give him his strength.
Professionally, I don't know what I've learned from the films except maybe that truth is more extraordinary than fiction, that real-life stories can be more unbelievable, more daring and more vivid than invention. My best movies, "Agatha," "Coal Miner's Daughter" and "Gorillas in the Mist," were all the more powerful for being based on truth.
Back in 1971 with the second film, "14 Up," it seemed unlikely that the series would survive. The interviews were like a struggle (they lacked, you might say, a warm glow), but once we put it all together, we knew we were onto something. The politics were as strong as ever, but now we had the excitement of juxtaposing two generations. We had turned a page in the family album.
But there were shortcomings that I've never really surmounted. We didn't have enough women, and the four we had all left school and married early; so we missed out on one of the most powerful political upheavals of my lifetime -- the changing role of women in the home and workplace. I think I also shortchanged my own roots -- the lower middle class. In my generation that class overcame modest beginnings by luck and hard work, but in the "7 Up" generation it found a world where the economy was collapsing and jobs in the arts, teaching, medicine and the like, were in short supply.
By "21 Up" it was hard enough putting the film together without bemoaning what might have been if we'd had a crystal ball. The awkwardness of the 14-year-olds had evaporated and interviewing had become much easier. I was having to condense a life into 15 minutes or so and make value judgments as to what was important and what wasn't.
Sometimes I was way off, with Tony, for example. At 7 he was the playground fighter who wanted to be a jockey, but I felt he'd never had a real chance in life. High spirits and quick wit weren't going to be enough. So I filmed him at 21 driving around the hot crime spots of the East End of London in his taxicab, conducting a tour of underworld highlights past and present. I supposed I was planning ahead, second-guessing what was lying in wait for him, but I had misjudged him completely. As Tony would often say to me, "Michael, you can't judge a book by its cover." The wildness of his early years had softened, and the energy was channeled into his marriage and children. His working-class roots became a real source of strength, and by his 20's he'd begun to make something of himself.
Our process is hardly scientific, more a complicated and sometimes bewildering array of private moments set against the cultural and social background of the times. Every seven years I do an exhaustive interview with each person, with very little preparation, looking for the spontaneous rather than the prepared response. We use a fraction of what we shoot (the ratio of film shot to film used is 30:1), so we stockpile an enormous amount of footage. With each new edition of the series, we start from scratch and sometimes go back into unused interview footage if it has become unexpectedly relevant.
By 1984 and "28 Up," the series had changed dramatically -- the politics were now unspoken and the class distinctions self-evident. Individual drama moved to the foreground, and the human element began to dominate. I brought the film to America and showed it at the Los Angeles and New York Film Festivals, seriously doubting that people would make sense of it unless they were well versed in the English school and class systems.
I was wrong. It found a huge audience of people who were responding not to a thinly disguised political polemic but to something universal. Success, failure, promise and disappointment -- these had become the new currency of the film. Images would stay in the mind -- Neil, the bright-eyed Liverpudlian who at 7 wanted to be an astronaut, at 28 hitchhiking forlornly around Scotland, his life in pieces; Suzy, bitter and nervous at 21, blossoming into motherhood; Bruce teaching Bengali children, the ambition of a 7-year-old to be a missionary realized; Tony, alone with his jockey pictures, a dream abandoned.
I doubt that "28 Up" achieved the magical quality of the original -- maybe that's the prerogative of 7-year-old children -- but according to the critics, it had power and resonance. Commitments had been made at the work place and at home, the decisions we all have to make at some time or another. This is what caught the audience's imagination, making it possible to identify with and relate to the people in the film. The public's response was as gratifying to me as anything in my professional life.
The major difficulty in mounting "35 Up" has been to keep as many of the subjects as possible. For most of them, the whole enterprise has become a major invasion of privacy, and three have dropped out. Inevitably the piece is weakened if it doesn't have a full cast -- you lose the contrasts and comparisons, and there's a feeling of extended family. Also, some of us have become close, though I'm sure they all dread the seven-yearly knock at the door.
Without giving away what has happened over the last seven years, what seems unique this time is the strong sense of mortality that pervades the film. Many of the subjects have recently lost parents; a number now have children around 7 years old. They are teaching their children what I filmed them learning, so you see knowledge and wisdom handed on from generation to generation -- a circle being closed.
There are as many surprises now as there were with "28 Up," and I'm hopeful that the films get richer as the people get older. Someone wrote of "35 Up" that it contained the heartening message that age makes people nicer, which bodes well for "42 Up," "49 Up" and on, but the excitement of each step is not knowing what to expect. I fear for the participants' safety, as with family and friends; and although life is hard for most of them, it is reassuring to observe the resilience and enterprise of the human spirit.
Other films have come out of my project. Last year CBS and Granada produced Phil Joanou's American "7 Up" (as yet not broadcast), and Granada financed Sergei Miroshnichenko's Russian version, and maybe there will be more. The new films have a great advantage over the original -- they know they're in for the long haul, whereas "7 Up" was only supposed to be a one-shot.
So, as I served as a producer on the American film and consultant on the Russian one, we were able to plan ahead, to anticipate what may be important in America over the next decades -- the breakdown of the inner cities, the widening of the gap between rich and poor and the redrawing of the ethnic map -- and respond to that in our choice of children. We filmed in the Soviet Union last autumn, just before the Baltic states broke away and well before the whole country fell apart. If we can keep track of our Russian 7-year-olds, their lives could provide astonishing insight into the future of the new commonwealth.
I suppose my greatest contribution to the whole project has been to hang in and give it continuity. I remember sitting with Mike Scott, then Granada's head of programming, in Los Angeles and saying wasn't it about time for "28 Up," and him responding that it would never happen because I wouldn't leave Hollywood.
He couldn't guess the power the films have in my life and how I doubt whether I'll ever have the chance to do anything as original as this again.
 
 
 
APTED BY APTED
 AGE 7 (1948): At local state school. Quiet, very shy. Greatest joys were listening to the radio, chocolate (still rationed) and going to soccer games with my father.
AGE 14: Scholarship to private school in center of London. Easy access to West End theaters and cinemas. Still too shy to be in school plays.
AGE 21: Second year at Cambridge University. Consumed by interest in theater -- in plays with Trevor Nunn, John Cleese, Stephen Frears and Jonathan Lynn. Had fallen in love with movies after seeing Ingmar Bergman's "Wild Strawberries" at age 17, A career in show business still seemed an idle dream.
AGE 28: Married with a son. Living in Manchester, climbing the ladder at Granada Television. Making the decision to go freelance and try my luck in London.
AGE 35: Had second son. Trying to build a career in movies. Had made two -- "Triple Echo," with Glenda Jackson, and "Stardust," produced by David Puttnam. Still paying the rent by working in television and theater. Looking enviously toward America.

HEADLINE: IN THIS CORNER

 BODY:
Michael Specter's article "In This Corner" (Dec. 15) portrayed Lowell Weicker as a tough, independent leader, trying to do the right thing, but it failed to express Connecticut's worst fears -- namely, that Weicker is simply using the state's desperate problems to further his ambition to repackage himself as a leader of national prominence. Weicker worked hard during his campaign to create the impression that he was against an income tax. When elected, he used strong-arm tactics on legislators to swing their votes to gain a huge tax increase.
Weicker wants a quick Connecticut miracle that can propel him to renewed national prestige. It's too late. The depression and economic collapse that started in New England is spreading, and so is the fury of the middle class, who have nothing left to give.
 
JAY BUETTNER
Avon, Conn.

LENGTH: 1461 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Developing in Brooklyn;
Putting the Cleveland Connection in Play

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
DEVELOPMENT has its ups and downs. The 42-year-old Bruce Ratner, who has become the chief developer of major projects in Brooklyn, has had some of both.
The ups are to be found at Metrotech, the office center on a 16-acre site adjoining Polytechnic University, which contributed the land and is getting major building and grounds improvements. With four completed office buildings, a fifth far advanced in construction and two or three more in prospect, Metrotech is easily New York City's leading phased office development project, second in scale only to Olympia & York's World Financial Center at Battery Park City. 
 But now Mr. Ratner finds it necessary to digest a reverse. He and his company -- Forest City Enterprises of Cleveland, whose New York City affiliates, Forest City Ratner Companies, he heads -- have been obliged to withdraw as developer of the ambitious Arverne waterfront redevelopment plan for 308 acres of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens.
The intention was to build 7,000 to 10,000 housing units on a platform above covered parking, with Park Tower Realty as joint-venture partner. The downturn in the market has made the economic planning obsolete.
None of which leaves Mr. Ratner discouraged. On the contrary, he buzzes with enthusiasm about Brooklyn and his company's decision to make it the base of its development activities. That gave the city in the late 80's an essential assist in its efforts to hold large office tenants who were relocating with thousands of jobs to newly built lower-cost space across the Hudson River. Through Forest City, a counterattack was mounted.
"Brooklyn is different," said Mr. Ratner, notably in the lengths to which its officials go to support office growth. A supportive attitude by borough officials in the face of local resistance to the dislocations of urban redevelopment is not the norm in New York City. But that and more came at crucial times from the office of Borough President Howard Golden when Mr. Ratner and the city's Economic Development Administration were seeking to clear land in time to capture New Jersey-minded tenants.
Metrotech lies between Jay Street and Flatbush Avenue, off Willoughby Street, near Brooklyn's major civic buildings. Myrtle Avenue, now closed within the area, is becoming a grand pedestrian walkway between the offices and the revived Polytechnic campus.
Through the project Forest City Enterprises has become involved as developer, builder or co-venturer in a widening spectrum of projects. Mr. Ratner's older cousin, Albert, is the chief executive officer of Forest City, one of the country's largest publicly owned development companies. With their backing, Mr. Ratner has been able to bring millions of dollars of private risk capital to bear in Brooklyn.
The Arverne reversal was not surprising, given the decline in the housing market. The notion of putting so large a tract in the hands of a single developer -- even one who agreed to pay $90 million -- never appealed to top housing officials of Mayor David N. Dinkins. And with the decline in the housing market, there was no realistic prospect of a sales success that would justify the costs.
"We went through the land-use review process for the first 7,500 units," said Mr. Ratner. "It was a lovely plan for market-rate housing. But with the economy as it is, it's not possible to build it." Condominiums would have been offered at an average price of $170,000. "Even at $150,000 we couldn't have sold it," Mr. Ratner said.
IN the new approach to Arverne foreseen by Felice Michetti, New York City's Housing Commissioner, the city will parcel out sites to developers as the Battery Park City Authority does in its long-term land-development program. The development must be able to span real-estate cycles, Commissioner Michetti said. "We don't want to be stuck with a cash bid made at the height of a real-estate market," she said.
"We never fight with the city," Mr. Ratner said. "We said, 'What would you like us to do?' " The answer was yes.
Now the question is when and whether the city will be able or willing to undertake the initial infrastructure costs that its current approach implies. Then the city would sell buildable parcels in stages. The administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch had looked to a long-term developer to pay the infrastructure costs, getting in return the benefit of the increased land value it was creating.
With that setback behind it, Forest City is continuing to undertake new development projects in Brooklyn. It has become a joint-venture partner with Rose Associates in the Atlantic Terminal urban renewal project, where 440 units of housing and 4.5 million square feet of office and retail space is envisioned. It has bought the 155,000-square-foot Albee Square Mall along the Fulton Street mall at Gold Street with a view toward improving it. It still has additional sites for Metrotech buildings.
Mr. Ratner's route to real-estate development led through public service. He worked in the Consumer Affairs Department for former Mayor John V. Lindsay after finishing at Columbia Law School in 1970. Later he served for four years as Mayor Koch's Consumer Affairs Commissioner.
He left in 1982 to start investing -- with the purchase of the former Herald-Tribune building, at 230 West 41st Street, which was 85 percent occupied by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.
"We could buy buildings at $50 or $60 a square foot that had rents of about $6 a square foot," he said. "We thought that rents would go up to about $18 a square foot." They did. Another purchase was the 550,000-square-foot 80 Maiden Lane, former home of Continental Insurance. It was leased from 1985 to 1987 after a $20 million renovation.
In time, Mr. Ratner was shown Polytechnic's blighted Brooklyn land by another former city official, Michael Bailkin, who was representing the university. The Metrotech concept had been promoted for years by Polytechnic's administrators as a 1.7-million-square-foot "technology park." It was an idea in search of a deep-pockets development partner.
FOREST CITY was interested but the density was deemed too low. After a two-year land-use review that began in 1984, the property was rezoned to accommodate 3.7 million square feet on six large sites. Forest City saw the potential mainly as back-office space for financial firms. The Koch administration used tax abatements and other financial devices to keep occupancy costs for the initial prime tenants competitive with developments in New Jersey.
Credibility on Wall Street for both Brooklyn and Forest City was won by the successful completion of One Pierrepont Plaza, a 650,000-square-foot building mainly occupied by the operations group and data center of Morgan-Stanley, at Pierrepont Street and Cadman Plaza West.
The breakthrough for Metrotech came with the city's ability, working with Forest City, to clear a site for a Securities Industry Automation Corporation building. It took a marathon session with holdout business and residential tenants and their lawyers, and a $29 million commitment for relocation costs.
"We would have lost S.I.A.C. -- even Brooklyn Union -- if we hadn't moved fast," Mr. Ratner said.
No less dramatic was the last-ditch campaign to hold Chase Manhattan Bank's back-office operations in New york City. An economic package concocted by Deputy Mayor Alair Ane Townsend was decisive.
Now the term "Metrotech" is omnipresent in the emerging campus-like office community, which blends into the also-emerging landscaped courtyard of the Polytechnic campus. Completed are One Metrotech Center (900,000 square feet) for Brooklyn Union Gas (with Bear Stearns & Company as a major tenant); Two Metrotech Center (550,000 square feet) for the Securities Industry Automation Corporation; and Three Metrotech Center, part of the Chase Financial Services Center (500,000 square feet); and 10 Metrotech Center (400,000 square feet), a gut rehabilitation of 625 Fulton Street.
Back at the center, Four Metrotech Center (one million square feet), another section of Chase's project, is well advanced in construction. Chase is handling the construction of its buildings and will own its site. Forest City built the other Metrotech office buildings, and continues to own them.
Other projects named "Metrotech" have come along independent of Forest City: Five Metrotech Center is the name given to a new library for the university. Six Metrotech Center is a New York Telephone Company learning center. Seven Metrotech Center is another phone company building.
At the height of its Metrotech activity, Forest City Ratner employed 80 people. Today it is down to 40. But it began in 1985 with three people. Its stamp on Brooklyn is indelible.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: New Hotels;
Staying the Course, Despite the Gloom of Recession

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THE FUTURE envisioned by the builders of the Regent New York Hotel at 57 East 57th Street is one that stretches well into the coming decades. It is the coming months that may pose the greatest challenge.
The 54-story, limestone-clad hotel -- soaring over the neighboring Fuller Building -- is being finished at a time when the real-estate empire of its developer, Harunori Takahashi, is being restructured by Japanese banks. 
 It is also being built into a market that has changed since the late 80's, when the Regent was conceived. There may no longer be quite so much of an appetite for the kind of luxury that the hotel plans to offer, at prices in the neighborhood of $400 a night.
Undaunted, however, executives in the hotel's ownership and management said the $370 million, 372-room project will stay the course and open, as planned, next January.
The Mercer, another new hotel in which Japanese and Hong Kong investors figure, is scheduled to open in SoHo this summer. And a downtown hotel project, by a group from Hong Kong, is now under city review.
But the Regent cuts the highest profile; one that is not going to be lowered. "The hotel, from the beginning, was planned as a five-star luxury hotel," said Wilfried N. Wagner, the general manager. "And it is going to be opened as a five-star luxury hotel.
"The valley that the whole hotel business is going through has not given us any reason to make a change in our approach," he added.
The hotel is owned through a partnership that is ultimately controlled by Mr. Takahashi's EIE International Corporation, whose headquarters are in Tokyo. It is to be managed by Regent International Hotels of Hong Kong, in which EIE International has a 30 percent interest. (Robert H. Burns, the chairman of Regent, owns 65 percent of the company and the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation owns 5 percent.)
Construction is being financed by a loan from a consortium of six Japanese banks, led by the Long-Term Credit Bank. The others are the Ashikaga Bank, Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation, Mitsui Trust and Banking Company, Nippon Credit Bank and Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company.
Five of those six banks have formed a separate consortium, also led by the Long-Term Credit Bank, to "select and evaluate all projects" undertaken by Mr. Takahashi, said Toru Ogahara, president of EIE Regent Avenue Corporation, a subsidiary of EIE International, based in Manhattan.
"EIE is no exception in the suddenly changing financial situation surrounding real estate and development projects," Mr. Ogahara said. "Mr. Takahashi is discussing with lenders how best to realistically adapt EIE to these changes." Those discussions, he said, began early last year.
"Some projects are on the list to sell off," Mr. Ogahara said. "Some projects are on the 'go-ahead' list.
"From the very beginning," he continued, "the New York project has been given top priority on the 'go-ahead' list. We have consumed more than 50 percent of the budget. We are sure there will be no change in the policy of our headquarters, as well as by the consortium, to keep going."
FUMIYO OKUDA, the manager of EIE Regent Avenue, said: "Maybe the operation of EIE International will be affected. But as far as each project is concerned, they shouldn't be affected. We have to make sure -- even more than before -- that it comes in under budget. But what has happened in Tokyo has not affected our budget."
Because five of the lenders are also involved in restructuring EIE International, Mr. Ogahara noted, "the distinction between construction financing and equity financing is becoming more and more fluid."
That is not the only complicated aspect of the project, whose complexity runs from the ground up. For one thing, the L-shaped development site between Park and Madison Avenues, from 57th to 58th Street, is composed of five parcels. Two are owned outright by 57-57th Associates, a partnership controlled by EIE Regent Avenue. The other three parcels are leased to 57-57th Associates on terms ranging from 50 to 200 years. The owners were identified by Ms. Okuda as Blackstone Holdings, successor to the Blackstone Hotel, a 200-room structure that once stood at 50 East 58th Street; the Baccarat crystal firm, whose showroom occupied the base of the five-story town house that once stood at 55 East 57th Street and the Rubin family.
The assemblage was bought in January 1989 from William Zeckendorf Jr., who remains connected to the Regent as a "development adviser," Ms. Okuda said, with no "active financial interest" in the property.
When the hotel was announced in January 1989, it was to have a main tower of 46 stories and a smaller tower of some 20 stories, with a total of 400 rooms. Completion was planned for late 1991. The architects -- then and now -- were I. M. Pei & Partners (whose practice continues as Pei, Cobb, Freed & Partners) and Frank Williams & Associates, both of Manhattan. The interiors were to be designed by John F. Saladino, who has been replaced by Chhada, Siembieda & Associates. The Tishman Construction Corporation was and is the construction manager.
Before building could start, the developers eliminated the smaller tower and increased the larger one to 54 stories. The structure, with some 530,000 square feet of space, was built as of right under zoning rules, the developers said.
Since then, construction has stayed on track, the EIE and Regent executives said. So has the decision to keep the Regent in its stratospheric category. "From a design and construction point of view, we reached the point of no return long before the slump started," Mr. Wagner said. "You can't switch the theory in the middle."
"The economic condition of New York has not affected the hotel," he said. "We're building a hotel for the next 30, 40, 50 years."
GUESTS can expect to find rooms ranging from 570 to 1,200 square feet, with ceilings more than 10 feet high. In the 120-square-foot bathrooms are sunken tubs, separate shower stalls and color television sets. There are to be stewards on every floor.
The Regent, Mr. Wagner said, is meant for a clientele that is "not so rate-sensitive." And, he added, "If there is a shortage, we'll have to adjust our marketing accordingly."
The Mercer Hotel, at Mercer and Prince Streets, is being created out of a 104-year-old commercial structure. It is to have 78 guest rooms, costing an average of more than $200 a night; a health club, restaurant, pharmacy and florist. The developers are Andre T. Balazs and Campion A. Platt. The architectural and design team is composed of Harman Jablin Architects, Serge Becker and Tsao & McKown Architects.
Financing for the $33 million project has come from a Japanese bank called F.A.D., Mr. Balazs said, as well as investments by the developers themselves and a group they described as a Japanese real estate developer and financier, a Japanese retail and clothing executive, a Japanese architect and a Hong Kong hotelier.
Mr. Platt said that even in today's distressed market, the Mercer had several things going for it: the weekend business in SoHo, the absence of nearby competition, an intimate scale and competitive rates.
Another hotel is being planned at Platt and Gold Streets in lower Manhattan. This is being developed by a group of Hong Kong investors through the Barleda Development Corporation, whose location is given in city records as Livingston, N.J. The design is by Alan Lapidus Architects of Manhattan.
According to an application at the Buildings Department, the hotel would have 19 stories, with a restaurant on the ground floor and a meeting room on the second floor. There would be a total of 144 guest rooms.
Nelson Yeung, the president of Barleda, said the hotel would cater to domestic and Asian business travelers. But nothing is going to happen in the immediate future. The owners, he said, will wait for signs of a healthier market before they begin.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Office of the Astor Estate;
A 'Frankly Modern' Addition

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
ONCE the administrative center for the greatest of New York's family fortunes, the jewel-like, two-story Office of the Astor Estate at 21 West 26th Street is not a landmark and is ignored by guidebooks and New York histories.
Miraculously, the exterior of the Victorian Gothic building has survived unchanged since 1881 -- but now construction is proceeding on a "frankly modern" rooftop addition. 
 John Jacob Astor, who arrived in the United States from London in 1784, amassed a fortune of $20 million, most of it in real estate, by his death in 1848. His son, William Backhouse Astor, retained his father's Doric style, temple-fronted office at 81 Prince Street.
By the time William died in 1875, the fortune exceeded $100 million and it went to his two sons, John Jacob Astor 3d and William Astor. In 1881, they demolished the Prince Street office for the present 575 Broadway and the two brothers built a pair of matching buildings at 21 and 23 West 26th Street.
Thomas Stent, the family's regular architect at the time, designed two-story buildings as close as New York ever got to the work of the great Philadelphia architect Frank Furness. Above the ground floor -- barred like a treasure house -- rises a facade of brick, granite and terra cotta.
In approved Victorian fashion, materials, colors and finishes fight and strain against each other: polished gray granite, raw orange terra cotta and curved red brick. Above this the cornice is corbeled out on brick work, but the attic pediment slopes back in ribbons of granite. Heavy lintels, like droopy eyebrows, weigh down the second-floor windows and ostensibly protect a richly carved terra cotta panel -- which needs no protection at all.
Some carved ornament seems to imitate Chinese sculpture, but most is patterned after the naturalistic designs of William Morris. The whole building has the blocky, brusque quality of Frank Furness's 1879 masterpiece, the Provident Life and Trust Company in Philadelphia.
John Jacob Astor 3d occupied No. 21 and William occupied No. 23; from these buildings issued the most sustained record of private architectural patronage ever seen in New York.
From 21 West 26th Street, the John Jacob Astor 3d line built the old Waldorf, Netherland and Astor Hotels (all now demolished) and the Graham Court and Apthorp apartments. From 23 West 26th, the William Astor line built the St. Regis and Knickerbocker Hotels and, under Vincent Astor, the Astor Court apartments at 90th Street and Broadway, the old Astor Market at 95th Street and Broadway and 120 East End Avenue.
Along with these came scores of other works -- rowhouses, commercial buildings, apartments -- all by leading architects of the day, among them Henry Hardenbergh, Trowbridge & Livingston, Clinton & Russell and Charles Platt.
A 1905 account in McClure's Magazine estimated the estate's income at $10 million a year.
In 1922, Vincent Astor hired Peabody, Wilson & Brown to redo the facade of No. 23 in a chaste, neo-Federal style, but No. 21 has remained untouched. Both were sold by the Astors after 1940, by which time their real estate interests were winding down. Today the buildings are surrounded by tall loft buildings.
Albert Zuckerman, a literary agent, bought No. 21 in 1979 for his firm, Writers House, and he has stripped and restored the interior. Its Minton-style tiled floors, Japonesque iron stair, paneled walls and office dividers and Aesthetic Movement fireplaces and even door hardware are all intact.
DESPITE the troubled economy, the building is chock-a-block with agents negotiating deals and newly published books, so Mr. Zuckerman hired Peter Moore, a designer, and David Mandl, an architect, to design a roof addition that is now almost complete.
After discarding various plans for a more historical look, Mr. Zuckerman says, "we're making a frankly modern addition, without masking the fact."
Indeed, no one will ever think the extra floor will "look as if it's always been there" -- an oft-stated goal of architects these days.
Whereas a Victorian architect would probably have kept the addition low and covered it in multicolored slate around tiny dormers, the new design has tall plate-glass windows topped by a big, sloping copper roof, with a square, off-center window.
Nothing of the original front is being changed and the finished work will speak to two quite different business successes, over a century apart.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Style of a Men's Club in a Hotel Setting

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
WHEN we reviewed the stylish restaurant in the new Hotel Sheraton Stamford in the summer of 1986, it was called Magnificent J's, after a class of sailboats that raced across the Atlantic in the 1930's. The restaurant featured seafood, prepared with a panache that rated a Very Good, in a setting that resembled a ship's cabin. Following a trend of the time, the hotel seemed to be making its restaurant a culinary flagship instead of the ordinary and predictable hotel dining room of decades past.
Alas, much that distinguished the small, handsome Stamford restaurant has disappeared, including most of its name, menu and wine cellar. The new name, J's Bar and Grill, says it all. The small menu, which is printed daily (though only a small category called "captain's choice" changes), offers several types of steak, a few seafood and chicken dishes and several currently popular appetizers. 
 J's dining areas are essentially the same -- small and intimate, more like a men's club than a bar and grill, with only a few tables, regally spaced for privacy. The two very cozy areas are separated into smoking and nonsmoking sections and are on either side of a serving well. A roomy bar, with ship motif, has been carved out of a portion of the former dining space.
One can only speculate as to why the hotel has jettisoned its notable restaurant. Was it the economy, the business-oriented clientele, the somewhat hard-to-find location, all or none of the above? What remains is a fine place physically and decent if not memorable food. The stunning all-American wine list, which included wines from more than 20 states, is also gone, replaced by a limited list, mostly California and French vintages. The one noticeable improvement is the service, smooth, professional and extremely accommodating.
The food is good but not pace setting. Best of the limited number of appetizers offered were the Cajun swordfish medallions -- two small blackened steaks with no-holds-barred spicing accompanied by a freshly made marinara sauce spiked with green pepper strips and chunks of fresh tomatoes. Buffalo mozzarella, another commendable first course, was almost a light meal -- four large slabs of soft cheese and sliced tomatoes. Smoked salmon with dill cream was a generous serving of high-quality salmon, enhanced by aromatic dill cream.
Less satisfactory was a skimpy serving of fried calamari, though its marinara sauce was light, sassy and fresh. Also a letdown were the crab cakes with tartar sauce. The crab meat was fresh-flavored, but the two little cakes, flecked with bits of green and red pepper, were smooshed and compressed into flat patties, lacking the loose texture and lightness that is usually preferable in a crab cake.
A stir-fry dish of Gulf shrimp and sea scallops contained a wide variety of crisp, fresh vegetables -- cauliflower, zucchini, celery, scallions, cabbage, broccoli and red and green peppers -- which added a panoply of flavors, though there was barely a whisper of sesame-ginger sauce. An enormous blackened New York strip steak was a fine value at $14.95, though it could have been more richly spiced.
A tender broiled filet mignon, topped with Burgundy butter, would have been perfect, except it was medium-rare instead of rare as ordered. Swordfish steak, grilled with Burgundy butter, was moist in parts, dry in others, with minimal butter.
The fresh vegetables served with each entree change from night to night. One night we had a delicious broiled tomato provencal and corn on the cob, another night sauteed red and yellow pepper strips.
We ran through the dessert list but found each item, from the New York cheesecake and apple pie to carrot cake and four-layer chocolate cake, unexcitingly commercial.
In converting Magnificent J's to J's Bar and Grill, the management has controlled the prices (no mean achievement), which are as low or lower than they once were, though the dishes are less ambitious now. A three-course dinner for two came to $53 before tax, tip and drinks. The bar at J's has a taco bar buffet between 4:30 and 7 P.M., with garlicky guacamole, a respectably spicy red salsa, ground beef, melted cheese, crunchy chips and other accouterments. If you dine early, the taco bar makes a first course unnecessary. This can slice $11 off your tab, making J's Bar and Grill an even better value.
 
J's Bar and Grill
Good
Hotel Sheraton Stamford, 240 Fairfield Avenue (off Exit 7 northbound from Interstate 95), Stamford. 967-2222.
Atmosphere: Oak panels and wainscoting, beige wing chairs, padded couches, carpet and wallpaper, sailing etchings; comfortable men's club ambience.
Service: Efficient, smooth and caring.
Recommended dishes: Taco bar buffet, buffalo mozzarella, Cajun swordfish medallions, smoked salmon with dill cream, Gulf shrimp and scallops stir fry, blackened New York strip steak.
Price range: lunch entrees $6.25 to $18.95, dinner entrees $13.50 to $18.95.
Credit cards: All major cards.

Reservations: Accepted.
Wheelchair accessibility: Ground-level access, ramp to restaurant level.

HEADLINE: Recession Tempers Casino Revenue

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
THE recession tempered gross gaming revenue growth in the casino industry last year to 1.35 percent, according to recently released unofficial figures.
But analysts said the gambling halls had improved their profitability by cutting costs and renegotiating debt. The 12 casinos reported gross gambling revenue of $2.99 billion, compared with $2.95 billion for 1990. 
 "Considering all the economic news, it's not bad," said Al Glasgow, publisher and editor of Atlantic City Action, a gaming newsletter.
He said that revenues were flat, but that casinos were improving their bottom lines by spending less. For example, he said, in the third quarter of 1991, the casinos cut expenses by $4 million.
 
Legislative Changes
 The gaming halls benefited last year from legislative changes that permitted 24-hour gambling on weekends and holidays, more floor space devoted to slot machines and the introduction of new games.
The city's largest casino, the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort, generated the most gross revenue -- $383.7 million, Mr. Glasgow said. The casino recorded 1990 revenue of $304.9 million but was not open until April 1990.
The biggest gainers last year were Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, up 7.4 percent, to $220.1 million from $205 million, and Caesars Hotel and Casino, up 6.4 percent, to $309.1 million from $290.4 million.
The biggest declines occurred with the Trump Castle Casino Resort, down 16 percent, to $196.5 million from $233.9 million, and the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, down 15.7 percent, to $235 million from $278.7 million.
Marvin Roffman, a casino analyst with Roffman Miller Associates in Philadelphia, said industry revenue would remain level as long as the recession lingered.
"Consumers have less disposable income to spend and put in those slot machines," Mr. Roffman said. "I see sluggish growth for the economy. I don't think 1992 will be a banner year for Atlantic City from the standpoint of revenue growth. The bottom line numbers should get better."
He attributed his optimism on profitability to debt-heavy casinos' refinancing hundreds of millions of dollars in bonds, which have absorbed much of their revenue.
 
Changes at Trump Casinos
 Last year, the Taj Mahal restructured its debt as part of a bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The Trump Castle is planning a similar restructuring, and the Trump Plaza is pursuing a bond exchange.
The other casinos, their 1991 results, their 1990 figures and the percentage change are as follows:
*TropWorld Casino and Entertainment Resort, $287.1 million, $278.5 million, up 3.1 percent.
*Harrah's Casino Hotel, $283.9 million, $279.7 million, up 1.5 percent.
*Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel, $267.1 million, $268.0 million, down 0.3 percent.
*Sands Hotel and Casino, $242 million, $230.4 million, up 5 percent.
*Showboat Hotel and Casino, $239.8 million, $247.8 million, down 3.2 percent.
*Bally's Grand Hotel and Casino, $191.5 million, $199.6 million, down 4.1 percent.
*Claridge Hotel and Casino, $135.4 million, $134.7 million, up 0.5 percent.
For December, the 12 casinos recorded revenue of $203.8 million, a 3.1 percent decline compared with $210.4 million in December 1990.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

DOMESTIC WORKSHOP
 Wives and mothers going back to school, back to work -- or both -- often leave behind a trail of mismatched socks, burned dinners, abused appliances, hostile husbands and confused children. 
 Dr. Barbara Smukler, a teacher, writer and director of academic recources at Mount St. Vincent College in Riverdale, went through it when she returned to school as a wife and mother of two children. What she learned she now teaches in workshops designed to make life easier by forestalling domestic calamities with advanced planning. The next session, which is free, is Tuesday at 7 P.M. in the college's administration building.
She focuses on things that cookbooks leave out -- like how to turn on the oven. Detailed instructions for house cleaning, laundry sorting and spending time with each family member to explain his or her chores are spelled out. She also includes some tips on readjusting to the academic world, like taking notes and tests, understanding the difference between studying and reading and taking emergency measures when there is no tutor to rely on.
The college is at 263d Street and Riverdale Avenue. The phone number for more information is (212) 549-8000.
 
WORLD TRADE CLUB LUNCH
 "Doing Business With the 'New' U.S.S.R." is the subject of a talk to be delivered Wednesday in White Plains by Vladimir N. Checklin, deputy president of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council in Manhattan.
Mr. Checklin is a graduate of the Moscow State Institute of International Relations, and he once headed a division of the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Trade. He has written many books and articles on Soviet economic relations with the West, published in the Soviet Union and in the international press.
His talk will follow a reception at 11:30 A.M. and luncheon at 12:15 P.M., held by the World Trade Club of Westchester at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza, 66 Hale Avenue. Reservations at $40 may be made by calling 948-6444.
 
PHOTOS LIKE PAINTINGS
 Betsy Imershein's photographs have the look of paintings in the school of photorealism. Minutely detailed, colored, focused and composed, the picture-perfect subjects are super-real. Capturing them on film is what she considers her challenge -- to find the ideal subject under ideal photographic conditions.
Her pictures are in a two-artist show called "Double Vision" at the Upstream Gallery in Hastings-on-Hudson through Feb. 2. Sharing the spotlight with her is Amelia de Neergard, who works in oil stick and pastels on handmade paper. She uses signs, symbols, abstract shapes and color in provocative combinations for the viewer to interpret.
The gallery, at 495 Warburton Avenue, is open Wednesdays through Sundays from 1 to 6 P.M. and Thursdays from 3 to 8 P.M. Call 478-0407 for more information.
 
ADIRONDACK CENTENNIAL
 The official area kickoff for the centennial celebration of the Adirondack State Park will take place from 4 to 6 P.M. today at the Katonah Museum of Art, where an exhibition of Adirondack-inspired furniture, fine art, decorative arts, architecture and utilitarian objects is on display through Jan. 26.
Among those attending today's event will be Barbara McMartin, chairwoman of the park's Centennial Committee; Craig Gilborn, director of the Adirondack Museum, and John Cronin, Keeper of the Hudson River. Christopher Shaw will entertain with folk songs.
A weekend at the Point, one of the Adirondack Great Camps, formerly owned by the Rockefeller family, will be raffled off at $100 a ticket. A limit of 200 tickets will be sold.
Establishment of the park 100 years ago in a constitutional amendment was an unusual legislative step at that time. More than twice the size of Yellowstone National Park and half the size of Switzerland, the park has six million acres that are supposed to remain "forever wild."
Admission and refreshments are free. [A review of the exhibition appears on page 22.]
 
HONEGGER'S 'KING DAVID'
 Arthur Honegger's "King David" will be performed today at 3 P.M. in the Ossining High School Auditorium by the Choral Arts Society of Briarcliff Manor and the Westchester Boys' Choir, accompanied by a full orchestra.
The Swiss-born composer wrote the work in Paris in 1921 as a dramatic psalm for the theater, but it will be presented today in concert form, conducted by Timothy Vernon, who is the year-round director of both the adult and boys' choral groups.
The boys will sing the parts of angels. Barrett Clark will be the narrator, and the chorus will take the roles of warriors, priests, seers and Israelites. Soloists include Mary Kay McGarvey, soprano; Kathleen Shimeta, mezzo-soprano, and Vincent DiBenedetto, tenor.
Tickets are $12, $6 for students and people 65 and older. For more information, call 962-3218 or 723-2336.
 
PLAY ON FITZGERALD
 Before it moves to Manhattan in February, "The Other Side of Paradise" will have a limited run at the Westport Country Playhouse this month. Written by John Kane of the Royal Shakespeare Company in London and directed by Susie Fuller, a British actress and director, the play is about a famous American: F. Scott Fitzgerald.
Keir Dullea has the leading role of the writer during his promising years in Hollywood, when he was in his early 30's and his fame was on the rise but his wife's mental illness was beginning to undermine the marriage. The work had its premiere last summer at Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater in Westport.
Performances, which begin this Wednesday and run through Jan. 26, are Wednesdays at 2 and 8 P.M, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M., Saturdays at 5 and 9 P.M. and Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets are $17 and $19 and can be charged by calling (203) 227-1072. The theater is at 25 Powers Court, off Route 1.
 
ENVIRONMENT LECTURES
 A five-part lecture series titled "Earth in Rebellion: New Visions for a Fragile Planet" is scheduled by the New York Botanical Garden of the Bronx, beginning Thursday at 6 P.M. at 270 Park Avenue (47th Street) in Manhattan. At each session, a leading activist will present his or her view of solutions to environmental problems.
Dr. Wes Jackson, president of the Land Institute in Salina, Kan., will lead off the series with a talk on "Agriculture That Respects the Land." On Jan. 23 Dr. Christine Padoch's topic will be "The Forest Is the Garden." Dr. Padoch is a botanical scientist at the New York Botanical Garden.
"Making Peace With the Planet" is to be discussed on Jan. 30 by Dr. Barry Commoner, founder and director of the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College.
The final sessions on Feb. 13 and 27 will be conducted, respectively, by Dr. Carolyn Merchant, professor of environmental history at the University of California at Berkeley, and Dr. David Ehrenfeld, professor of biology at Rutgers University. Dr. Merchant will speak about "The Death of Nature" and Dr. Ehrenfeld's talk is titled "Losing Our Way: Conservation in a World Without Landmarks." Admission to each session will be $14. For more information or to make reservations, call (212) 220-8747.

HEADLINE: Bedford School Plans Program on Parenting

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: BEDFORD

 BODY:
BLAME the recession or the stresses felt by working couples. Whatever the reason, parenting seems to have hit hard times. "People have forgotten how to enjoy their children," a psychologist was overheard saying at a recent holiday party in Scarsdale. A local school administrator agreed. "Parents today feel a lot of insecurity," she said.
In a recent report stating that many American 5-year-olds were not ready for kindergarten, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching recommended parent-education programs as one way to help get families on track. The Rippowam Cisqua School, an independent day school here for prekindergarten through ninth grade, was ahead of the game in planning just such a program to help celebrate its 75th anniversary. 
 "Getting Through the Thicket: How Schools and Families Can Nurture Children in the 90's" will be held Jan. 25 from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. at the Rippowam campus of the school on Route 22 and Bedford Center Road. The fee for the morning is $35 a person and includes lunch.
The program will offer workshops on such topics as disciplining and motivating children, helping children through a divorce, handling anger constructively, recognizing childhood stress, charting a healthy course through adolescence and evaluating testing.
A group of 19 psychiatrists, counselors, teachers and authors of books about parenting will lead the workshops. State Senator Mary B. Goodhue, a member of Governor Cuomo's Early Childhood Task Force and head of the Senate Standing Committee on Child Care, will also lead a workshop on Early Childhood Education and Day Care.
 
A Talk and Q&A Session Planned
 Before tackling these issues in individual workshops, conference participants will hear a talk by the psychologist and author Dr. Lee Salk, who will also conduct a question and answer session.
Dr. Salk is a clinical professor of psychology at the Cornell University Medical College in Manhattan. He is an attending psychologist at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in White Plains and also serves as both a consulting psychologist at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan and as an adjunct professor of child development at Brown University.
Dr. Salk's best-selling books, including "What Every Child Would Like His Parents to Know," "How to Raise a Human Being" and "Dear Dr. Salk," have been published worldwide in many languages.
In a reassuring way, the 65-year-old psychologist delivers a pointed message to parents. As providers of the primary environment in which children live, parents -- and educators and pediatricians -- have the greatest impact on children's lives, despite the prevalence of television, media advertising and peer group pressures, he said in an interview.
Speaking in a spacious Manhattan apartment, Dr. Salk named what are for him the three most important human needs: to be loved, to feel some control over our lives and to feel accepted because of our individuality. Parents should respect virtues that are often overlooked, he suggested, like a child's ability to relate to his grandparents. Such qualities are often not appreciated, he said, yet they reflect values that should be nurtured to instill a sense of confidence and caring in children.
 
'Indulge Babies in Their First Year'
 The psychologist said his own philosophy of child-rearing was to "indulge babies in the first year of life." This makes them happy children who want "to learn, to love and be loved," he said. He said he discourages the idea of "showing the child who's boss" or an "I have rights, too" attitude.
"That's like ignoring the foundation of the building and worrying about what it's going to look like on top, then discovering it has some structural weakness because no one was around," Dr. Salk said.
Economic hardship is not an excuse for poor parenting, because children can "learn to build on adversity," the psychologist said. Families with homes and enough to eat "can pull together and do some really wonderful things in tough times," Dr. Salk said. "Re-examine your values -- learn that money isn't everything. This is no time to be competitive but to be humble."
Dr. Salk said he often speaks of his own adversities -- like not being accepted into the high school or college of his choice as well as becoming ill with a usually fatal form of cancer -- in his talks to school groups. He ascribes his own positive attitude -- "If it has never been done before, that's all I have to hear" -- to a mother who "never took no for an answer."
Schools can also play a positive role in children's lives by responding to youngsters' talents and interests, focusing on what students do right rather than on learning disabilities, Dr. Salk said. In fact, Dr. Salk doesn't like the term "learning disabilities." He would rather ask whether the teacher has "a teaching disability."
 
'Remediation Can Knock Confidence'
 Schools should also "help identify problems and be flexible in how they are dealt with," because "remediation can knock confidence," Dr. Salk said.
The psychologist added that in his talk he would stress the family "as a functional rather than a structural thing -- the function is more important than the structure." He speaks freely of his own family: his mother, a Russian immigrant, his father, who was in the garment business, and the two brothers with whom he grew up in Manhattan.
The oldest, Dr. Jonas Salk, discovered the vaccine for polio and conducts research at his Salk Institute in La Jolla, Calif. His other brother, Dr. Herman Salk, is a veterinarian whose projects include teaching cattle-raising techniques in third-world countries.
Dr. Lee Salk's wife, Mary Jane, is a writer whose first novel will soon be published by Ballantine Books. His son is a medical student, and his daughter is doing graduate work in psychology, Dr. Salk said.
For more information about the Rippowam Cisqua conference or to register, call the school at 234-3674.
