LENGTH: 2886 words

HEADLINE: A Crusade to Save the Soul of Arlington

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex.

 BODY:
A master at civic boosterism, Tom Vandergriff lured the Senators baseball team, now the Texas Rangers, away from Washington in 1971 and coaxed millions of dollars from voters for a stadium, a convention center, libraries, schools, lakes and roads.
But no triumph during his 26 years as Mayor here, until 1977, compares with the surprise choice by the General Motors Corporation 41 years ago to pass up Dallas and Fort Worth to build an assembly plant in Arlington, then a small farm town of 7,800 people and four square miles. 
 "It's been a Rock of Gibraltar for us that gave us the confidence to do some great things," said Mr. Vandergriff, whose family has sold thousands of General Motors cars since 1926 through its Buick and Chevrolet dealerships. "You simply couldn't imagine in your worst nightmare losing an entity like General Motors."
Yet, suddenly and unexpectedly, Arlington is in exactly that predicament -- confronting the prospect of losing its largest private employer and local tax provider as G.M. considers it for closure as part of a sweeping cost-cutting plan. The soul-searching and campaigns to save the plant that have preoccupied Arlington, now the seventh-largest city in Texas, are not unlike those in scores of cities and towns whose own factories have been threatened by America's stagnating industrial power.
But as many towns, including Arlington, fight to keep manufacturers, some economists worry that the tax concessions they are offering are unfairly benefiting business at a growing cost to other taxpayers. "It might be a good deal for Texas if they end up winning the plant, but collectively for the nation it doesn't do a thing," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "We end up with a distorted tax system for financing unemployment insurance benefits. It just continues this very warped taxing system we have in this country."
In Arlington, city and state officials are in a frenzied, secretive competition with Ypsilanti, Mich., to keep their G.M. plant open. The auto giant's chief executive, Robert C. Stempel, said last month that, as part of a plan to shed 74,000 jobs and close 21 plants, G.M. would soon choose where to consolidate production of its two rear-wheel car plants: in Arlington or at the Willow Run plant in Ypsilanti.
For Arlington, success could mean keeping nearly 3,800 plant jobs, plus at least 4,000 jobs of local suppliers, retailers and others that economists say depend on General Motors and its local work force.
Arlington would also retain what until now has been a crucial taxpayer. The G.M. plant contributed nearly $4 million in local taxes last year, including $2.1 million for schools. Already this year, the district has had to increase class sizes because it lost $16 million in state and local money, mostly to poorer districts, even as 1,700 new students pushed enrollments to 47,000. The threat of losing G.M. from the tax rolls "is probably the most challenging situation the school district has faced," said Rick Berry, superintendent.
Invariably, a plant closing would also lower property values, further depleting property-tax receipts, as the houses of furloughed or transferred workers flood a glutted housing market and businesses close. Some 1,100 G.M. employees live in Arlington.
It is a scenario being played out in dozens of communities across the country. The post-World War II industrial and military buildup that turned towns into cities in the 50's and 60's fizzled in the 80's and 90's as the economy weakened, the Pentagon budget narrowed and companies struggled to compete with stronger foreign rivals, while at the same time having to pay down the heavy debt taken on for acquisitions, stock buybacks and other financial maneuverings in the 1980's.
Robert B. Reich, who teaches political economy at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, said prospects for workers and communities are worse than in previous decades. Since the 80's, executives have come under increasing pressure from raiders and shareholder activists to bolster short-term profits. But all too often, said Professor Reich, they have relied on cutting jobs rather than looking for other ways to pare costs.
 
Sharing the Burdens
 "The great benefits that were achieved in the golden age of mass production in this factory were the direct results of investments made by the public as well as by G.M. and its shareholders," he said. "Now that times are tough, what is the appropriate allocation of burdens?"
Part of Professor Reich's answer, developed in his recent book, "The Work of Nations," is that American corporations and big labor unions must do more to preserve jobs -- following the example of competitors in Germany, Japan and elsewhere -- by reducing wages, if necessary, training workers in more modern and efficient techniques and investing in advanced production equipment. Workers and communities, as well as creditors, shareholders and management, would share in a recovery.
Like hundreds of manufacturers, General Motors spent heavily on new technology and acquisitions during the 80's, but lagged other auto makers in training workers, he said. Making matters worse, the United Automobile Workers union has blocked attempts, most recently by G.M., to reduce wages as a measure to cushion workers against layoffs, effectively preserving the jobs and pay of older workers at the expense of younger ones, Professor Reich said.
In this Presidential election year, the White House and Congress prefer fixing the blame for the auto makers's troubles on their Japanese rivals, Professor Reich said. President Bush's trip to Japan last week, he added, was "a clever political ploy" that obscured how productive the more than 50,000 Americans have become at the Japanese auto factories in the United States. "Japan has absolutely nothing to do with this recession," he asserted.
Other analysts, especially on Wall Street, believe G.M. delayed far too long in paring its work force as its share of domestic auto sales fell below 35 percent and its production capacity held at 45 percent. Along the way, it became the producer with the steepest costs in the auto industry, a recipe for disaster.
The cutbacks that could ensnare Arlington are "part of the transformation of our industrial enterprise," said David E. Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. "In the long term, it's a lot worse to fail to make these changes. We have to do these things to preserve the integrity of our manufacturing capability in America."
Yet since Mr. Stempel's announcement, schoolchildren in Arlington have hoisted banners praising their local plant and workers have cruised the streets here in cars bearing bumper stickers saying, "Keep GM: The Heartbeat of Arlington." Elected leaders of the city and state have been huddling almost daily to decide how best to save the plant. Lloyd Reuss, G.M.'s president, told reporters last week in Detroit that the company could make a decision before the end of March.
Under pressure from debt-rating agencies and investors shocked by losses of $15 million a day at G.M. late in the year, Mr. Stempel told reporters last month that he revealed details of the retrenchment to quell rumors about plant closings. He said he did not delay a verdict on the Arlington and Ypsilanti plants as a ploy to wring concessions from each side.
Yet some plant workers believe G.M. has already made a decision. "I don't know if they have or not," said Fred Rattan, 63. "I've always said that trying to predict what G.M. is going to do is like predicting the weather."
 
Holding Out Incentives
 Yet Arlington officials plan to complete an incentive package by Wednesday that includes a smorgasbord of tax breaks and investment incentives. The tax breaks would amount to between $7 million and $10 million over 10 years, depending on the level of G.M.'s investment in the plant.
The creation of an enterprise zone, approved last week by the Texas Department of Commerce and including the plant and businesses within a three-mile radius, could potentially save G.M. millions in state and county tax dollars when money is spent to expand or upgrade production, said Mr. Vandergriff, now the chief administrator of Tarrant County, which includes Arlington and Fort Worth.
"G.M. has taken a very solid position that they are not going to whipsaw the communities or the two states," said Richard Greene, Arlington's Republican mayor. "They are not asking for any concessions. We're telling them what it would be worth."
But Arlington and Texas officials say they do not expect these incentives to be much different from proposals by Ypsilanti and Michigan officials. "These sorts of incentives are generally the lay of the land throughout the country" Mr. Greene said.
Governor Ann Richards's office declined to elaborate on her strategy for keeping G.M. in Texas. "The first people to see it will be General Motors," said Cathy Bonner, executive director of the Texas Commerce Department.
But disclosing one detail at a Friday news conference in the Arlington city council chamber, the Governor pledged that the state would buy from G.M. all of the natural-gas powered vehicles for its fleet if the Arlington plant remained open. A Texas law passed two years ago ordered the state, local governments and owners of private fleets to convert 30 percent of their vehicles to compressed natural gas by 1994. Texas state agencies must have 11,400 such vehicles by then.
Flanked by two dozen local politicians and union officials, Governor Richards said, "I'm real serious about the Texas commitment" to the Arlington plant. "The only automobile company we have in Texas is G.M. And I firmly believe that compressed natural gas is the fuel of the future."
A Democratic Representative, Martin Frost, whose recently redrawn district will soon include the Arlington plant, said he thought G.M. would favor the site over Ypsilanti if only to preserve its influence with powerful Texas lawmakers in Washington. "I don't believe that General Motors, if they go back to Congress, can rely solely on the Michigan delegation, so it would make some sense politically for them to actively involve the Texas delegation," he said.
 
The Washington Card
 Texans now head powerful rule-making panels in Congress, including the House banking committee and the Senate finance and judicial committees, each of which might be in a position to aid General Motors in the years ahead on tax, antitrust and other issues, Mr. Frost said.
Governor Richards met informally with some high-level G.M. executives a week ago during the Dallas Cowboys-Detroit Lions football game in Pontiac, Mich., and said Friday that she intended to meet with Mr. Stempel, along with other state officials and plant executives.
The manager of the Arlington plant, Art Hester, is the arbiter of what G.M. executives in Detroit hear about the Texas plant. A spokeswoman in Detroit, Nettie Seabrooks, said Mr. Hester is not speaking with reporters, and another spokesman, John Mueller, said he was unaware of any meetings that Mr. Stempel would hold with delegations from either Texas or Ypsilanti.
Mr. Stempel has said that the damage to the Texas economy of closing the state's lone car-assembly plant would be a factor in the decision. The state estimates that the plant, with a payroll of $121.5 million, last year contributed more than $1 billion in total economic activity in Texas.
For the county, closing Arlington "would make a bad situation that much worse," said Bernard L. Weinstein, an economist who is preparing a report on Arlington for G.M. and is director of the Center for Economic Development at the University of North Texas, in Denton.
The flush years of the roaring Texas economy disappeared when oil prices collapsed in 1986 and depressions in banking and real estate followed. That year was also the last time G.M. laid off Arlington workers; more than 1,000 people left the payroll.
The harshest setback for the area since then came last year, when cuts in military spending and manufacturing slashed more than 15,000 jobs in Tarrant County, which includes Fort Worth and is the weakest region in the slowly growing Texas economy. The cutbacks, at General Dynamics, Carswell Air Force Base, Bell Helicopter and LTV Aerospace, have made it nearly impossible to find jobs that pay as well as those at the G.M. plant, where hourly wages are $15 to $20 or more.
 
Chasing G.M.
 Many Arlington workers said, provided the choice, they would move to Ypsilanti if assembly work for the Chevrolet Caprice, Cadillac Brougham and Buick Roadmaster were shifted to the larger Michigan plant. Offers go first to workers with the most seniority.
But the assembly work added in Willow Run probably would not provide work for all the Arlington employees, and hundreds, if not thousands could be furloughed, with uncertain severance benefits. The current U.A.W. contract with G.M. assures laid-off workers unemployment benefits, from both government and company funds, of about 65 percent of pay for 36 weeks, according to the U.A.W. But the contract expires Sept. 14, 1993, or within a few months of when local officials expect that the Arlington plant would close.
Randy Philpot, a worker with 20 years at the Arlington plant, has already decided to move to Ypsilanti if Arlington loses. "I'd have to go," he said. Mr. Philpot, 44, said he needs to stay with the auto maker 10 more years to qualify for a full pension and early retirement. His wife, Debby, a nurse, and two high-school-aged children would remain in Arlington, where the mortgage on their house has been retired and expenses are low, he said.
"I could be laid off in a year at Ypsilanti and the whole family would be disrupted," he said. "So it would be a lot easier if I just went by myself."
 
The Halcyon Days
 Birthplace of more than five million cars under nameplates like Pontiac Chieftain, Oldsmobile Starfire, Chevrolet Monte Carlo and Cadillac Brougham, the G.M. plant propeled Arlington into a storybook era that, while it lasted, showed off the rising prosperity and optimism of postwar America.
A suburban "city" today of 96 square miles that has expanded beyond two interstate highways spanning the 34 miles between Dallas and Fort Worth, Arlington now has a population of 261,000. It beat back Dallas's bid last year to capture the Texas Rangers, but Mr. Greene cautioned that even if the city succeeds again with General Motors, it will not secure the plant's future.
"Great corporate citizens and benefactors of this community don't come with a guarantee to stay forever," he said. "Whether it's here or Ypsilanti, whoever is chosen, we'd all better keep hoping for a better car market."
Mr. Vandergriff, who sold his stake in Arlington's Vandergriff Chevrolet GEO dealership three years ago to a partnership including his son, Victor, and Mr. Greene, said he no longer owns General Motors stock. Yet he and his father had rejected offers from Japanese companies during the 1970's to add other dealerships.
Now 65, Mr. Vandergriff said he is shaken as much by the corporation's financial troubles as by its threat to pull up stakes. "I would agree that dramatic steps have to be taken," he said. "But it's hard medicine to take. When I think about it, I just shudder."
"Their people are just interwoven into the fabric of the community," he said. "The taxes that plant has paid have been enough to build city hall, libraries, parks and schools. If the plant closes, it will be devastating."
 
 
 
YPSILANTI PLANS TO RESIST A WAR OF INCENTIVES
 In Ypsilanti, Mich., 20 miles west of Detroit, the community's stake in the auto industry is far bigger than in Arlington. General Motors has a parts plant in addition to the Willow Run assembly plant and Ford Motor operates two parts plants.
Still, losing Willow Run would inflict deep wounds. The annual payroll of $178.8 million, when two shifts operated during 1990, slipped last year when the plant slowed to one shift, with 2,400 hourly workers and an additional 200 salaried employees. The plant makes Chevrolet Caprice sedans and station wagons, Oldsmobile Custom Cruiser wagons and Buick Roadmaster Estate wagons.
The Michigan Department of Commerce estimates that another 10,000 workers in the state could lose their jobs if Willow Run were closed. Personal income in Ypsilanti would fall by $50 million and retail sales by $35 million, according to estimates by the Ypsilanti Chamber of Commerce.
Since 1982, the township has granted G.M. 11 tax breaks through tax abatements, earned by spending for new equipment and other improvements at Willow Run. Township officials said the abatements save G.M. $1.9 million a year.
Unlike their competitors in Arlington, Ypsilanti's town leaders have not framed any potential new tax breaks before G.M.'s verdict. At the state Capitol in Lansing, the posture is also reserved.
"We are committed to fighting for jobs at Willow Run," said Rusty Hills, a spokesman for John Engler, the Republican Governor. "What we are not going to do is get into an incentives war to pay them to work here."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Year of the Foreign Bond

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Bonds were generally more friendly than stocks for Americans investing abroad last year. High interest rates in some countries, like Italy, and strong capital gains combined with high interest rates in others, like Australia, all helped to outpace average foreign stock returns by more than six percentage points.
Overall, bonds in the 11 foreign markets included in the J. P. Morgan government bond index were up 15.9 percent for 1991, compared to a 9.4 percent return for the stock markets in the same countries, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. The 1991 return for foreign bonds matched that of 1990, when bond markets far outpaced stock markets, which tumbled because of the threat of the Persian Gulf war. 
 But still, to do well, it was necessary to pick the right bond market. The total returns ranged from 24.3 percent in Australia to 9.6 percent in the Netherlands.
Australian bonds ended the year in such spectacular form because all the pieces came together. In the bond market, capital gains were up 13.1 percent as interest rates fell. But the rates still remained high enough to produce a return of 11.7 percent, according to the J. P. Morgan index. So with only a slight fall in the Australian dollar, the total return topped 24 percent for the year.
As a bonus for those in both Australian stocks and bonds, the stock market was up 27.8 percent in dollar terms, finishing first in the same group of countries in the Financial Times index. The rest of the top five bond markets were Japan, up 23.4 percent; Canada, up 21.5 percent; Spain up 16.6 percent, and Italy, up 15.1 percent. In all four, the bond markets outperformed the stock markets. Japan and Canada, where interest rates were falling, had strong capital gains and interest rate returns. But in Italy and Spain, most of the return was from interest rates because rates in Europe have been kept high by Germany's monetary policy.
The United States was the sixth-best bond market performer, with a return of 14.8 percent. It was followed by Denmark, 13.5 percent; France, 13.4 percent; Britain, 12.8 percent; Belgium, 12.0 percent; Germany, 9.8 percent; and the Netherlands, 9.6 percent.
Among these markets, the stock market outperformed the bond market in the United States, where it rose 27.4 percent, and the Netherlands, where the stock market was up 14 percent. In Germany, the bond market performance was weak, but still better than the 4.8 percent rise in the stock market.
In the remaining markets the performance of bonds and stocks was even: in Denmark, bonds rose 13.5 percent, stocks 14.8 percent; in France, bonds were up 13.4 percent, stocks 14.2 percent; in Britain, bonds 12.8 percent, stocks 11.9 percent; and in Belgium, bonds 9.6 percent, stocks 9.2 percent. In Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands and Britain, interest return was much higher than capital gains. In France and Denmark, there was a close balance between returns on capital gains and interest.
Investing in foreign stock and bond markets was further complicated by a volatile dollar. By the end of the year, the dollar was back close to where it started. But there were several points during the year when dollar-based investors making trades were caught short. The sudden rally in the dollar at the end of last week should remind investors that the dollar is fickle, unpredictable and can quickly wipe out unhedged investments
During the two-day rally, the dollar jumped 5.1 percent against the German mark and 2.2 percent against the Japanese yen. Currency traders were leery of predicting a continued rally because they have yet to see real signs that the United States economy is recovering or that interest rates in Germany are going to fall soon. But several traders said that they detected a change in sentiment about the dollar and economic recovery that could keep the dollar at these new levels for a little while.
The impact of the dollar on foreign investments can easily be seen in movement of the J. P. Morgan index through the year. Last January, with the dollar still falling and adding to foreign bond returns, total return from non-United States bond markets was up 3.8 percent. Then in February, the dollar began to rally. And it quickly wiped out all the bond market returns.
By the end of March, investors who hadn't put hedges in place ended up with the poorest foreign bond market performance since November 1978, with non-United States bond returns off 7.5 percent. After six months, with the dollar still rising, non-United States bond markets were off 2.96 percent since the beginning of the year.
The dollar peaked on July 2, and by September the tumble provided most of the 5.8 percent return for foreign bonds. The pattern was repeated again in December.
According to the J. P. Morgan calculations, the dollar rally against the German mark cut 18.9 percent from returns before the peak on July 2. The subsequent fall gave almost all of that loss back. The dollar ended the year just 1.2 percent higher against the mark. While not identical, this same pattern held in the other European bond markets.
As for the yen, the dollar story was even better. At its peak June 10, the dollar rally cut 4.6 percent from Japanese bond returns. But in the decline that ensued, all this, and more, was given back. The dollar ended the year down 8.5 percent against the yen.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Waiting for the Capital Gains Shoe to Drop

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Nothing, it is wrongly said, is certain except death and taxes. In reality, taxes are not a sure thing, and in that fact may lie a partial explanation for the soaring stock market.
Just now, chances seem better that the Government's desperate effort to revive the economy will produce a cut in the capital gains tax rate, a move that would be a boon to shareholders. 
 "As long as things are going well, who will take a gain if there is a possibility of a cut in the capital gains tax?" asks C. Fraser Evans, senior economist at Colonial Mutual Funds, arguing that hopes for such a cut have caused potential sellers to wait.
Perhaps even better for stocks would be an end to the double taxation of dividends, as was suggested by a Treasury study last week. Companies now get tax deductions when they pay interest on borrowing, but do not save on taxes when they pay dividends, which is one reason that corporations went deeply into debt in the 1980's, a miscalculation that is still damaging the economy. It remains hard to see how that idea could get through Congress, but even the talk may be helping.
But what will happen when the tax situation eventually is clarified? A decision to cut the capital gains rate would provide a reason for nervous investors to take profits, but it might also encourage buyers. On the other hand, if it becomes clear that capital gains taxes will not be cut, that fact could promote a sell off. The Oct. 13, 1989, mini-crash came in the same week it became clear that that year's campaign to cut capital gains taxes, which had seemed promising, was doomed to failure.
One new tax development is unfavorable for stocks. Foreign pension funds that own American stocks have long found ways around the withholding tax on dividend income that is normally paid by foreigners. But Bob Gordon, the president of Twenty-First Securities, notes that the Internal Revenue Service last week proposed regulations to close one loophole, involving the lending of stocks around the time of the dividend, and said it was thinking about trying to close another, a wonderfully complicated strategy involving what are known as equity swap contracts. If the I.R.S. succeeds, foreign pension funds will find owning American stocks less profitable and less desirable.
While some big stocks slipped last week, the explosive rise in smaller stocks continued. The Nasdaq composite, up 3.9 percent last week, has gained 13.2 percent over the last three weeks. More and more individuals are concluding they have to find alternatives to the low interest rates offered by banks.
That kind of soaring market rarely dies quickly, but share prices are almost certainly closer to a top than a bottom. "People who have never been in the U.S. stock market are pouring money into it," says Jorg H. Schwarzenbach, who runs private banking for Credit Suisse in New York. "This is a very dangerous sign."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Dubious California Play

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
As an investment concept, CleanAir Transit is pure California, right up there with wind chimes and chardonnay. Based in Santa Barbara, this newly hatched company aims to design and sell nonpolluting electric buses to environmentally correct towns and cities everywhere. No more diesel fumes, just a benign trace or two from the natural-gas generator that runs the air conditioner and heater.
This ahead-of-the-curve idea is outlined in a private placement memorandum now making the rounds among the very wealthy set out West. (The minimum outlay is $25,000, so none but the wealthy need apply.) By privately selling $2 million worth of preferred and common shares, CleanAir Transit hopes to grow enough to sell more shares to the general public in a year or so. 
 But the financial wizard behind CleanAir is Larry H. Welch -- a wealthy Santa Barbara resident who is either the company's former chief executive and chairman, or simply a director, depending on which documents you inspect. And, as many people across the country have already discovered, doing business with Mr. Welch can sometimes become a very disagreeable experience.
Mr. Welch is a newcomer to the antipollution scene. But he is known in the limited partnership world, which is still buzzing over the recent bankruptcy court filing by Alert Holdings, a Denver-based security alarm monitoring service founded by Mr. Welch. Nor is Alert the first company on Mr. Welch's resume to have stumbled into bankruptcy.
David Vallone, a spokesman for CleanAir, said on Friday that Mr. Welch does not take questions from the press. And although CleanAir identified Mr. Welch in early November as its chief executive, and discloses in more recent documents that it will pay him a substantial royalty on future sales, Mr. Vallone said that Mr. Welch "is just one of six directors." He continued, "As far as his past activities are concerned, he has invested in approximately 30 companies over the years. Some did well and some did not."
And the Alert bankruptcy? "That story is just unfolding," Mr. Vallone said, "so it is inappropriate to pass judgment on that."
Alert Holdings, founded by Mr. Welch in 1985, is in the business of electronically monitoring the security alarm systems installed in homes and businesses around the country and calling the appropriate emergency services when necessary.
Under Mr. Welch's chairmanship, Alert raised more than $250 million through the sale of limited partnerships and used the money to finance the purchase of new business accounts from smaller rivals across the company. Alert would identify an acquisition and the partnerships would buy it, with Alert getting a hefty up-front fee for arranging the deal. Alert would also collect continuing fees from the partnerships for providing security monitoring services to the new accounts. The revenue left over went to the partnership investors, who had been promised annual returns as high as 15 percent.
But despite those handsome promises, some of the leading figures in the partnership marketplace avoided the Alert Holdings deals. "We never liked what we saw there," said Brent Donaldson, president of the Liquidity Fund in Emeryville, Calif., which invests in limited partnerships across the country. "We just had fundamental problems with the underlying economics. We could never figure out how they could be sustained long-term."
As it happened, "long-term" didn't last very long. With the company's business faltering and both the Rocky Mountain News in Denver and Forbes magazine poking into its problems, a major investor forced Mr. Welch out last summer. In November, a new management informed Alert's limited partners that quarterly payments due in September would not be made. Since then, a host of investor lawsuits have been filed against the company and its former management, charging mismanagement and fraud in the sale of the limited partnerships.
"There are literally thousands of investors affected," said David J. Bershad, the New York lawyer who is heading the legal team representing the plaintiffs in those lawsuits. The defendants include Mr. Welch and most of his management team, including Roy A. Webley, who is now listed as executive vice president at CleanAir.
Dana Woodbury, the vice president for compliance at Multi-Financial Securities Corporation in Englewood, Colo., was an early critic of the Alert partnerships and refused to approve them for his firm's clients. Why? "The management," Mr. Woodbury said last week. "Larry Welch was very key. When we looked at his prior business dealings, we found that several of the firms for whom he raised money, and for whom he was a director, had gone bankrupt. That reflects poorly on his judgment and his management."
Before the Alert saga began, Mr. Welch's previous experience had been in consumer home-electronics stores. In the early 1980's, he built up one chain, sold it at a considerable premium and was promptly fired by the new owner. He sued for wrongful dismissal and lost the case in 1984. In 1985, he landed in yet another legal squabble arising from his investment in Schaak Electronics, an electronics retailing chain in St. Paul. He served briefly as Schaak's chairman, promising to find new capital for the struggling company. The financing never materialized, and he was ousted by the chain's founder. More lawsuits followed, and Schaak wound up in bankruptcy court -- as did Connecting Point, another electronics retailing chain he founded and attempted to merge with Schaak during his brief tenure there.
But Mr. Vallone in Santa Barbara said that Mr. Welch's background has so far not been a problem for CleanAir Transit. "Investors who are looking at putting money into the company, or who had already put money in, have asked those questions and have had their questions answered," he said. "It simply is not an issue."

HEADLINE: MAKING A DIFFERENCE;
A Believer in Liberal Arts Tackles Worker Education

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Since 1983, when the Government released a stinging critique of the nation's schools, educational reform has been high on corporate America's list of priorities. But even before that report, titled "A Nation at Risk," the National Alliance of Business, a coalition of some 3,500 businesses, was intent on raising the quality of the country's work force by improving education and employment opportunities.
Recently, the organization, founded in 1968, appointed Joseph A. Pichler, president and chief executive of the Kroger Company, a Cincinnati-based supermarket chain, as its chairman. 
 Mr. Pichler is a former labor economist and business school dean who once helped organize a conference on the morality of capitalism. He was lured away from academia in 1980 after serving on the board of Dillon, a supermarket company that subsequently merged with Kroger. He became Kroger's chief in 1990.
"Teaching students, working with young people, has to be the most intrinsically satisfying thing you could do," he said during a break from an N.A.B. meeting in Washington.
Mr. Pichler, 52 years old, said that like most executives, he believes the country is dependent on the quality of the work force and its ability to produce goods and services. "The welfare of the nation depends on improved schools," he said. The N.A.B. sponsors several types of job-training and school programs.
Despite his advanced degree in economics and his years teaching business, Mr. Pichler is a hard-shell believer in the liberal arts as training for a life at work, an attitude that began with his Jesuit education in high school. "Two years of Latin, two years of Greek," he said. "At the end, you either have a liberal education or you're dead."
The work force, he says, needs people literate in geography, history and cultural diversity: "We need people with esthetic and social interests. We need good citizens."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/January 5-10

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
In Tokyo, Just Squabbling Among the Motorcar Moguls 

President Bush did not get much from the trade talks in Tokyo other than a case of the flu. So when America's Big Three automakers met their Japanese counterparts for a breakfast chat in Tokyo, the atmosphere was stormy, to say the least. The Americans were miffed at the vagueness of Japanese buying pledges. Somehow, 20,000 more cars "did not sound like a lot," said an angry Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation. And who would they buy from, anyway? Detroit or Japanese transplants? They never said. "There is no agreement," said Harold Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, calling the pledges "inadequate." For their part, the Japanese lectured the Americans, telling them to improve the quality of their products and reform their industry. "We haven't done anything wrong," said Yutake Kume, president of Nissan. "We don't need to rectify our conduct or our deeds."
 
The Candidates Slip Away
 
In an election year, when the economy is in a slump, it usually signals trouble for the incumbent. Sure enough, last week's New York Times/CBS News Poll showed President Bush's approval rating slipping to just 48 percent because of the weakness of the economy. But the sluggish economy also seems to be working against the challengers. First, the effects of the slump caused Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York -- the Democratic front-runner -- to renounce his Presidential aspirations and concentrate on New York's economic woes. And last week, Virginia's Governor, L. Douglas Wilder, said he would drop out of the race to work on Virginia's economy. If the economy turned around, would they run?
 
First the Good News
 
In economics, all blessings are mixed. The Labor Department said last week its producer price index, which charts inflation at the producer level, had fallen by 0.2 percent in December. Such a tumble means inflation is virtually licked. "Inflation at the producer level is likely to be about 2 percent or so overall for the year, with consumer prices rising only about 4 percent for the year," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. But the reason for the decline in prices "is decreased demand," he said.
 
The Fall-Off's No Fallacy
 
For individuals, its best to pinch pennies in a recession since job prospects are uncertain. But to get the economy going, the country needs people who spend. That is the problem economists call the "fallacy of composition." According to the Federal Reserve, that's what the country is facing now. The Fed reported that consumer credit expanded by a minuscule $27 million in November -- about 25 cents a worker. The reason for the fall-off in borrowing is Detroit. More people are paying off auto loans than taking out new ones.
 
Another Prod for Washington?
 
There was more gloomy news on unemployment last week. According to the Labor Department, 300,000 more people became unemployed in December. That brought the unemployment rate to 7.1 percent, two-tenths of 1 percent higher than the month before. "Seven percent is an important political number," said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. "If the Administration isn't galvanized already into acting, this will do it." Such actions could include tax cuts and further drops in the discount rate, he said.
 
Selling Health-Care to Doctors
 
Last week, the White House chief of staff, Samuel K. Skinner, invited a group of doctors to the White House (they still make White House calls) to sound them out on President Bush's plans for fixing the nation's health-care crisis. America spends more than any country on medical care -- 14 percent of gross national product -- yet 34 million Americans have no coverage at all. President Bush wants more than a Band-Aid, Mr. Skinner told the doctors, including Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association. The Administration wants to provide incentives for enrolling in prepaid group plans which buy group care at a discount from providers. It also wants to include tax credits for purchasing medical insurance and, for the doctors, it wants to limit awards in malpractice lawsuits. The doctors seemed pleased. Tax credits alone, said Dr. Todd, won't solve the crisis.
 
Bristol-Myers Squibb said it would reduce its prices to the Government by $80 million.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Woolworth's Pulling Back
 
America has been sipping sodas at Woolworth's fountains since 1879. But lately, the fountains -- and the stores -- haven't been doing so well. The Woolworth Corporation, which operates 6,500 stores in the United States and had sales of $9.8 billion in 1991, said last week it would close or reformat 900 stores that lost about $50 million from January last year through October. About half of the 10,000 employees at those stores would lose their jobs. The closings will lead to a charge of $250 million.
 
A Sand Trap for the Japanese
 
Minoru Isutani, the reclusive Japanese golf entrepreneur, paid $840 million for the Pebble Beach Company and its golf links on the California coast in Monterey. His plan was to sell memberships for as much as $1 million, the way they do in Japan. That would would help him pay off the $450 million he borrowed to buy the resort. But last week the Monterey County supervisors drove his plans into the rough. They rescinded an agreement permitting the sale of memberships guarantying tee times and room reservations at the resort because it would limit the public's access to the course. "Even though it costs about $200 a round, it's the only one of the top three courses the public can play," said Chris Hodenfield, senior editor of Golf Digest magazine. Two hundred dollars? "Its an awe-inspiring course," he said. "There's the spray off the ocean, sea lions on the rocks. Playing it is like opium."
 
More Service in the Skies
 
Last week, American Airlines said it would offer business-class service on its flights between New York and Los Angeles. For an extra $200, you'll get wider seats, better service and meals you can both identify and eat.
 
A Detroit-Style Solution
 
When Detroit's manufacturing moguls touched down in Tokyo last week with President Bush, they arrived complaining about Japan's reluctance to buy American cars and car parts. They had a case when it came to car parts, but cars? Japan drives on the left, after all, and no American manufacturer produces a domestically built right-hand-drive car. Last week, the Ford Motor Company said it would solve that problem, building a right-hand version of its sporty Probe in Flint Rock, Mich. -- in about 20 months. Not only is that an inordinate amount of time to make the changes, but Flint Rock is run by Japan's Mazda Motor Corporation, in which Ford owns a stake. The new Probe should feel at home in Japan. That's where its engine, transmission and drive-train are made.
 
A Surprise Downgrading
 
While Lee A. Iacocco, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, and Robert Stempel, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, were in Japan trying to drum up business, $100 billion worth of their debt was downgraded. Moody's Investor's Service knocked $75 billion worth of G.M.'s debt to A2 from A1 while Standard & Poor's pushed about $20 billion of Chrysler's debt to B+, from BB-. The downgrading will make it more costly for them to borrow. "We didn't expect it," said Robert Lutz, Chrysler's president. It's back to the drawing boards for the financial planners.
 
Overtrading
 
Paine Webber Inc. was ordered by the New York Stock Echange last week to pay $900,000 in fines for recommending investments to its retail customers that were often too risky and for buying and selling stocks merely to generate fees. In one case, the exchange said, trading was so excessive that $300,000 in commissions was generated in two and half years on five accounts with a combined value of less than $1 million.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
British Rate Rise Likely
 
The snake (the European system of relatively fixed exchange rates) is wrapping itself around Britain, python-style. Since Germany's central bank raised its key interest rates point last month, other European central banks have been forced to follow suit. France made its moves last month. Now the problem is Britain. Its currency is falling against the Spanish peseta. "There is a trend toward high rates in Spain, versus a perception of lower rates in Britain," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist of High Frequency Economics. That suggests British rates may move up.
 
The dollar, meanwhile, is doing just fine, thank you. It's at its highest level in two months. "Technical factors are moving the market," said Madis Senner, of Sunray Securities. "With the mark a high-yield currency,it climbs then viciously corrects," he said.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
On the Road With Oldsmobile's Tourer

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
I REMEMBER, once, trying to rent a summer place in Nantasket, Mass. This was in the mid-60's, and the prospective landlord was a nasty guy. But I wanted the place, and my family was counting on me, no matter that this grouch thought us too inferior to spend a week in his rental house.
He didn't like my name. Didn't like that I had two little kids. But, most of all, I remember that in the middle of my stammering interview, he asked imperiously what kind of car I drove "over the road." It was a test. 
 His wife said, "Oh, Har-old," or some such thing to indicate that she, too, thought the question a bit odd, that maybe he'd gone too far, and to hint that she was on my side.
Even then, though, I thought his phrasing as weird as the timing of his question. I mean, how does a regular car differ from one that you use to go "over the road?"
It happened that I owned an almost-new Cadillac, so he was mollified on that score at least, but the notion of a "road car" has puzzled me ever since. Not that it is something I dwell on, but it does come to mind now and then, as it did this week when I was driving Oldsmobile's new 98 "Touring Sedan."
I mean, how does a touring sedan differ from a regular sedan? Is it a road car, or what?
Surprisingly, Webster's New World Dictionary has a few thoughts on the matter, noting that "touring car" is an Americanism that refers to "an early type of open automobile, often with a folding top, seating five or more passengers."
Other than the seating, though, those words seem to have little to do with 1992's Touring Sedan, a giant four-door Olds that possesses a supercharged V6 engine, gobs of leather and real wood trim, and a stiff suspension that is indeed fine for touring -- as long as you stay off potholed city streets.
The tester was dark blue, almost black, with vinyl cladding on the lower body, gray pinstriping, a sleek profile, alloy wheels carrying fat 16-inch tires, and most of the comforts known to Detroit and points far east. Antilock brakes are standard, as is an automatic transmission with its shifter in the console.
As befits its size, the car weighs in at 3,700 pounds, but fuel economy is reasonable, with a rating of 17, city, and 27, highway. All the same, economy is not what this behemoth is about, and the sedan is one of the pricier Oldsmobiles, with a base of $28,995 and a delivered sticker of $31,083.
Luxury, heft and size are all part of this road-car thing, of course, and the buckets up front add a nice sporting touch, while the roomy back bench offers comfort for three fellow tourers.
For the driver, there is full analog instrumentation, along with more gadgetry than can be dealt with safely at speed. The upper center of the dash is incredibly confusing, with (by actual count) 55 buttons to control such things as interior temperature, the sound system and an information display.
To compensate slightly for all that complexity, the leather-wrapped steering wheel offers simple remote rocker switches for climate control and the radio. The hub also incorporates a standard air bag for safety, but tiny buttons in the top two of the four spokes have to suffice for the horn.
The tester had a compact-disk player neatly hidden under the radio where it would be less likely to be stolen, and the rest of the front compartment showed similar thought. Below the CD player, dual cupholders fold into the dash, and controls for the power seats and windows are in both front armrests, where they are easy to use.
The ashtray is tiny and impossible, however, and it is unlighted at night. Like cigarette packs, it should carry a warning. And another unfortunate example of thoughtlessness can be found in the back seat, where the windows go down less than half way, an unforgiveable lapse of design in a car this large.
Out back, there is a trunk that is the biggest thing this side of a '59 Lincoln, and its power pulldown is a welcome addition. The central locking system also can be operated remotely from the driver's keychain, a particularly neat idea that Olds shares with some other General Motors cars.
On the road (remember the road?) the Touring Sedan is smooth and quick, and the supercharger helps to pull 205 horsepower out of the 3.8-liter V6, which is mounted crossways under the hood and drives the front wheels.
Acceleration from zero to 60 takes a mere 8.7 seconds, and the Olds cruises so effortlessly at high speed that you need at least three eyes, one for the gauge, one for the rearview mirror, and a third for the road. This thing is as fast as it is big.
Up there in Nantasket, Harold would have been impressed. We didn't take his house, by the way. We rented a place right on the beach and it rained all week.
 
 
 
SECURITY AT THE PUSH OF A BUTTON
 One of the things you get with Oldsmobile's Touring Sedan is the remote-control keychain that is now common to a lot of General Motors vehicles. Push a button and you lock all the doors. Push another, the locks pop up. And still a third will open the trunk's power lid. Neat, particularly at night.
But you don't have to shell out big bucks for a keychain that works magic. Kraco Enterprises of Compton, Calif., is marketing a remote fob and add-on domelight for $29.95. It will illuminate your car from as far as 50 feet away.
The light draws its power from the automobile's cigarette lighter, and it needs no installation. You simply plug it in, turn the switch to "remote" and mount it on the dash or sun visor. The light turns itself off 60 seconds after the keychain button is pushed, allowing adequate time to get into the car.
The unit also has an on-off switch for use as a flashlight or reading lamp.

HEADLINE: Quayle Fills Bush's Irregular Regulation Shoes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I must disagree with a statement in "Mr. Quayle's Irregular Regulation" (editorial, Dec. 15): "The Task Force on Regulatory Relief didn't amount to much when George Bush headed it as Vice President." All of the criticisms made of Vice President Quayle's Council on Competitiveness -- it is a "powerful force for watering down regulation," it operates "in secrecy," and it has a "pro-business slant" -- apply with equal force to Mr. Bush's task force. 
 Environmentalists and other public-interest groups complained throughout the 1980's about Mr. Bush's role in delaying, diluting and quashing health and safety rules. For some reason, they just could not get the press interested in the story.
In an effort to bring President Bush's role in sabotaging health and safety regulations to the attention of the public during the 1988 Presidential campaign, Public Citizen published a report ("Risking America's Health and Safety: George Bush and the Task Force on Regulatory Relief"), of which I was principal author, detailing 20 incidents of the task force in action.
These included its interference with Food and Drug Administration rules to protect children from the dangers of Reye's Syndrome and unsafe infant formula; its meddling with Occupational Safety and Health Administration rules to protect workers from the severe hazards of ethylene oxide, grain dust and other highly toxic substances; its delay of Department of Transportation standards for air bags and bumpers, and its interference with Environmental Protection Agency regulations to reduce lead in gasoline and asbestos in a range of consumer products.
In each case, the task force or the Office of Management and Budget -- whose regulatory functions it supervised -- countermanded the scientific judgments made by the expert agencies entrusted by Congress to protect the public and did so at the behest of the regulated industries that were unsuccessful in making their arguments to the agencies. In each case, like Mr. Quayle's Competitiveness Council, Mr. Bush's task force operated behind closed doors with no public accountability.
Though task force interference was widely complained of for years, and though Public Citizen's report was released by Senators Albert Gore Jr. and Edward M. Kennedy at a well-attended press conference in October 1988, there was little coverage of the issue in the news media. The lack of press attention was particularly baffling because President Reagan hailed leadership of the task force as Mr. Bush's "greatest service to the nation" while Vice President.
The public was entitled to know that under the guise of "eliminating needless government regulations," George Bush consistently placed the profits and interests of big business above the health and safety of the country and its children.
It's not too late. George Bush is running for re-election. The public is still entitled to know about his role in preventing health and safety regulations from taking effect. This effort may be helped by a recent court ruling that task force records are subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. Perhaps now that you have highlighted Mr. Quayle's irregular regulation, you will next insure the public's right to know about President Bush's similar activities.
 
KATHERINE A. MEYER
Washington, Dec. 28, 1991
 
The writer is a lawyer.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1931 words

HEADLINE: SLOW BURN;
The Middle Class Feels Betrayed, But Maybe Not Enough to Rebel

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF the 150-or-so million people who are loosely called the middle class are so steamed up about stagnant wages and big debts, about rising taxes and medical bills, about the bosses of floundering corporations who collect multimillion-dollar salaries while firing thousands of workers, will they take it any more?
Indeed they might. 
 In America's unpedigreed, denim-and-sneaker society, most people say they're middle class. In terms economists use, the middle class is about 60 percent of the population. It is people who have high school diplomas and sometimes some college, family incomes of $20,000 to $60,000, a little more in cities like New York and Los Angeles, and in recent years, an equivalent amount of consumer debt. They have a house in a suburb, two vehicles, and one or two family members who work full time.
"Middle class is where you can live in a decent neighborhood, drive a decent car and can get all your necessities," said Carolyn Milini, 37 years old, of Canton, Ohio, a home health aide whose husband, Tony, is a steelworker. For the middle class, a living room carpet is a sizable expense and a family boat is a 12-foot skiff with an outboard motor. In the three-bedroom house where she and her husband have been raising five children from two marriages, there is a microwave oven. "But that's a luxury," she said.
Michael S. Dukakis tried with some success too late in 1988 to court the middle class as an economic bloc, but Democratic Presidential candidates usually fear alienating the affluent voters who vote in greater proportions and contribute more to campaigns. For the five top Democrats in the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18, the issue is more tempting. The economic condition of the middle class has deteriorated throughout two decades of four Republican Presidents and one Democrat, and today's teetering economy, with the highest unemployment rate in more than four years, has made it worse.
Over nearly two decades, nonsupervisory workers enjoyed handsomely rising wages, from an average of $136 a week in 1972 to $359 by late last year. But it was all an illusion because prices rose much more. Real wages, adjusted for inflation, have actually fallen 19 percent, so workers can buy that much less with what they earn. They've kept abreast of prices only because so many wives have gone to work.
Harp on that hard enough, advises Victor Fingerhut, a pollster and political consultant to labor unions, and Mr. Bush is out: "When working and middle-income people vote against poor people and blacks, Republicans win. When they vote against the super-rich and big corporations, the Democrats win." But even on economic issues, it might be harder for the Democrats to capture middle-class votes than people like Mr. Fingerhut presume. American voters may be miffed now, but the patterns of previous election years show they have short memories and are easily seduced.
The Federal Reserve Board's giant pre-Christmas cut in interest rates, making it easier for everyone to borrow and buy, driving rates for home mortgages to the lowest levels in almost two decades, could help to revive the economy by early summer. If the past is a precedent and the bullish stock market an oracle, that's time enough for voters to think kindly again of incumbent politicians.
And to reinforce the Fed's help, Mr. Bush is expected to offer middle-class voters tax breaks. That could drive this year's record $350 billion budget deficit higher, spelling more economic woe later and sticking future taxpayers with even bigger payments on the national debt. But as President Ronald Reagan demonstrated, there's no surer election-year aphrodisiac than a promise to cut taxes.
There are indications, too, that the middle class may not feel as rebellious as polls and the state of its incomes suggest. Although wages of individual workers have plunged, the surge of women into the work force has raised family living standards, if just a bit. The Census Bureau reports that after taking account of inflation, the median family in 1990 earned $35,353, about $2,000 more than in 1970.
Going back another decade, family incomes are also 23 percent higher than the average of the 1960's, belying the view that today's middle-class family cannot live as well as its middle-class parents. And even though they save less and borrow more, today's families seem no more strapped than those of the 1960's and 1970's in how they spend their money.
A Bureau of Labor Statistics study shows that at the start of those decades, a family whose principal breadwinner was 35 to 44 years old spent about 20 percent of its income after taxes on housing and utilities. In 1987 and 1988, a family of the same age spent considerably more -- 26 percent. But partly because today's family has fewer children, spending for food and clothing dropped from 34 percent of its income 30 years ago to 19 percent. As a result, the family of the late 1980's spent considerably less on the necessities of food, clothing and shelter.
And because most middle-class families still have employer health insurance, their own spending for medical care, while rising lately, is only about 5 percent of their incomes.
For the money-strapped family, recreation would seem a likely target of cutbacks. But the family of the late 1980's spent more for recreation than the family of the 1960's. "In their spending," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, "it doesn't look like people are suffering."
Americans, more than most nationalities, also live on escalators, accepting the risk of moving down in the economy with the opportunity to move up. Much as people might worry about a stagnant standard of living, they support a system that makes room for their sons and daughters to become richly paid executives, doctors and lawyers.
"What's interesting about our society is that we are, in our perceptions if not reality, a classless society," said Fabian Linden, consumer economist at the Conference Board in New York. "There's no resentment of the guy at the bottom of the totem pole toward the guy at the top."
 
Suffering in Silence
 If the middle class is hurting, it has not been showing it in some other ways. Even as their incomes have stalled, middle-class Americans have become more reluctant to join unions, which were strongest in the 1950's and 1960's when real wages jumped almost 50 percent and helped insure their members a place in the middle class.
Voting patterns imply that much of the middle class is alienated, apathetic or content with Government policies. Only 57 percent of all adults voted for President four years ago -- fewer than in the elections of the prior two decades. The economy's losers voted even less. Only 39 percent of the unemployed voted four years ago, compared with 44 percent in 1984. Among skilled factory workers, core members of the middle class, 47 percent voted in 1988.
The heaviest voters -- people who gave Mr. Bush his edge over Mr. Dukakis, people whose incomes actually rose -- were big winners in the 80's. Seventy-two percent of all executives and 78 percent of all professionals voted four years ago. Among retirees, whose Social Security benefits rose in the decade and whose poverty rate fell, 69 percent voted. Of those 64 to 75 years old with incomes over $50,000, 89 percent voted.
In this election, the Democrats' opportunity may lie in perceptions, fanned by the recession, that someone is not playing fair with the middle class. Business Week magazine calculated that in the 1980's, chief executives gave themselves four times more in pay increases than they gave their average factory worker. Executives who preside over ailing industries typically take generous pension or severance payments when their jobs fold, but their workers fare worse. F. Ross Johnson left the chairmanship of RJR Nabisco three years ago with a $53 million personal "golden parachute" after losing a takeover battle for the company. Because of the debt incurred in the battle, 2,600 employees were dumped.
Last August, Roger B. Smith, the chairman of General Motors who presided over the company's decline in the 1980's, rode into retirement with an annual pension of $1.2 million that the company raised four months earlier from an originally scheduled $700,000. Last month, the company announced the layoffs of 74,000 workers over the next four years and canceled the $600 Christmas bonuses of 100,000 middle-level managers.
The old compact that workers made with G.M., A.T.& T., DuPont or Sears -- the promise of a lifetime of loyal labor in exchange for ever-rising wages, a pension and medical care -- is breaking down. Companies that long provided free health insurance now demand that workers share the cost. In this recession, unlike those of the past, many lost jobs will not return when the economy rebounds. In past recessions, blue-collar factory workers suffered most, and now there is the additional stress of some of their jobs going south of the border. But this time around layoffs are reaching well into the ranks of white-collar workers -- auditors, analysts, executive assistants, computer technicians and supervisors.
 
The Social Escalator Shifts
 People feel betrayed. Gary Castellan, 41, lost his job in an LTV Corporation steel mill in the early 1980's, a few months before he would have qualified for a pension. "They made sure we didn't get it," said Mr. Castellan, who now earns $9.65 an hour as a supermarket baker in Pittsburgh, about $2 less than he earned at LTV. "And there was nothing I could do about it."
Alan Machado, a 44-year-old computer technician and college graduate in New Bedford, Mass., said that there used to be an inviolate understanding: "They'd take care of you, you'd take care of them. And you'd be all set." But Mr. Machado's employer, A.T.& T., closed his plant last year and let him go after seven years with the company. He is left with $307 a week in unemployment benefits, about $220 less than he earned.
The middle class also has reason to fear that the American social escalator is running against it. Greg Duncan, an economist at the Survey Research Center at the University of Michigan, said that from 1968 to 1980, 6.3 percent of middle-income workers moved into the upper-income levels and 6.2 percent moved down. But from 1980 to 1987, the escalator accelerated, and 7.5 percent moved up while more, 8.5 percent, moved down.
Inequities show up in family finances. The Census Bureau reported last year that the 20 percent of families with the highest incomes captured 44 percent of all family income in 1990, up from 42 percent in 1980. The top 5 percent, with an average income in 1990 of nearly $150,000, raised its share from 15 percent to 17 percent. Everyone else, 80 percent of families, lost ground.
The search is on for whom to blame. In Mr. Machado's view, "It's American industry's fault for not being competitive, for not investing in new plants." Many others see a political problem. One old Republican ally, the 1.5 million-member Teamsters union, will oppose Mr. Bush's re-election. "This time you're going to see a strong, strong swing completely in the other direction," said Larry F. Landwehr, president of a big teamsters local in Wichita.
Some others doubt that politicians have all that much to do with the condition of the middle class. Lawrence Kline, a psychiatrist in white-collar, middle-class Bethesda, Md., picks up some of the frustration. "But the people I see are more likely to blame themselves," he said.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
It's Not Just Some Cars, It's the Future

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
NOBORU HATAKEYAMA, Japan's vice minister for international trade and industry, emerged from the bruising negotiations over auto imports that dominated President Bush's visit last week in an uncharacteristically reflective mood. Now that the President had finally followed Japan's example and put economics at the top of his international agenda, Mr. Hatakeyama admitted to a certain ambivalence.
A United States focused on competing economically with Japan as vigorously as it once waged the cold war is not a prospect the Japanese relish. On the other hand, a weak United States could be just as troublesome. And what ails America, Mr. Hatakeyama said, is not too few Jeep Cherokees in Japanese showrooms or even the recession, but America's industrial future. 
 If there is one thing the legendary bureaucrats of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry understand it is how to build a successful auto industry. And Mr. Hatakeyama said that what he heard on the subject from President Bush and his entourage of auto company executives was not encouraging. "They have not faced reality yet," he said.
His remarks underscored the sharp differences in how many Japanese and Americans viewed the purposes of this messy summit. While Japan seemed to be taking an unwelcome interest in America's decline as a world industrial power, some American critics, perhaps nostalgic for the days when superpower encounters meant debating the arcana of nuclear annihilation, seemed more worried about how it looked to have the President of the United States traveling around with Lee Iacocca and the other chairmen of the Big Three trying to get people to buy more Chryslers, Fords and Chevrolets.
 
A New Kind of President
 President Bush seemed to feel that it was important to show the Japanese that trade issues were now too important to be left to trade negotiators alone, that they were now a Presidential priority. But he may have more difficulty convincing his own people that they have to get used to a new kind of President -- and perhaps a new self-image -- in this era of diminishing expectations and battered industrial competitiveness.
In the long run, that may have been the importance of this summit -- showing in its shortcomings that America needs a better balance in designing policies to cope with its industrial ills. It is important to tackle at the highest levels Japan's many remaining barriers to trade, but not to use them as scapegoats, while ignoring the work that can only be done at home.
The summit demonstrated that the balance has not been struck. While some critics complained that the President was using the Japanese trade surplus as a smoke screen for America's troubles at home, others, led by the bellicose auto executives Mr. Bush had in tow, complained that the President settled for too few concessions. By contradicting Mr. Bush's assertions that he had accomplished much here, they created a level of discord within the President's party that was more embarrassing than his sudden illness at a formal dinner.
"I really don't want Mr. Miyazawa's sympathy," said Robert C. Stempel, chairman of General Motors, referring to Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's comment that Japan ought to offer concessions out of compassion for the American automakers. "The reason that we could come to Japan this time is not because we come from a position of weakness, but because we come from a position of strength." Coming from a leader of an industry that is losing billions of dollars and laying off tens of thousands of workers, these expressions of resentment were hard for Japanese competitors to understand.
Just as puzzling was President Bush's willingness to abandon under election year pressure his professed commitment to free trade and effectively demand that Japan set targets for the purchase of American-made autos and auto parts. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady attempted to refute this interpretation by insisting that the Japanese companies offered the targets voluntarily. But not everyone found the argument convincing. "This agreement amounted to the world's biggest and second biggest economic powers formally approving government-managed trade," Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading business newspaper, said in an editorial. "It is sure to set a bad precedent."
The President and his policymakers devoted little time to the other side of the coin -- preparing measures that might be taken to rebuild the crumbling structure of the auto industry back in Detroit.
 
Declaring Victory
 One faction within the Bush Administration that has been struggling to get these issues on the President's agenda did declare victory in the summit. "We are approaching the Japan issue in a much more comprehensive way than ever before," a senior Administration official said. "Remember that just 18 months ago MITI wouldn't even agree to have Japanese companies come up with a plan to increase purchases of American auto parts." However, when asked what measures the Administration was taking to insure that American companies take advantage of the opening, or to insure that they invest more to improve their quality and efficiency, the official said, "I don't have an answer to that."
Some Japanese remember all too well a similar exercise a decade ago. The Reagan Administration fought for and received what were known as "voluntary export restraints." The agreement capped the number of autos the Japanese could ship to the American market. In Detroit, profits soared, but a decade later the Big Three are struggling again.
Mr. Hatakeyama offered his own quick list of the kinds of policies a Japanese bureaucrat would think of instituting. He mentioned changing the reporting period for the big American auto companies from a quarterly to an annual basis, so they could focus on longer-term planning. He suggested that a special tax incentive might encourage investments in new equipment and technology, and that a gasoline tax might encourage the design of more fuel-efficient cars.
Some frustrated American government officials respond that it may take a crisis in the relationship with Japan to achieve those objectives, rather than policy initiatives by President Bush. "A real crisis makes people act, it galvanizes people, and that is what we need to get corporate America out of the gate," a senior Administration official said. "People need to feel some emotion."
Japanese officials dismiss this idea as a poor substitute for a real policy. "By definition, a crisis is something out of control, and that is too big a risk," said Makoto Utsumi, a former vice minister of international affairs at the Finance Ministry. "It is better to work with the things we can control, to make wise policies."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
The Rules Change, the Problems Don't

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IN last year's State of the City speech, Mayor David N. Dinkins promised "a new beginning." This year he invoked the poet Georgia Douglas Johnson as he wistfully envisioned a city government that would allow New Yorkers "to call our dreams." Instead, his beleaguered constituents seem more likely to get a jarring wake-up call shortly, as escalating financial and political pressures converge.
Next week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is scheduled to unveil a $52 billion state budget, in which he promised no new taxes. He held out no such hope regarding new pain, which the recession is likely to inflict on consumers of state services and on recipients of state aid -- including New York City. Mr. Dinkins's own financial plan was due this week, but he asked the City Council for a delay until Jan. 30 so he can factor the precise dimensions of that pain in projecting the city's own budget deficit. 
 Acquiescence from the reconstituted Council inaugurated last week cannot be taken for granted by the Mayor anymore. Speaker Peter F. Vallone appears likely to press his own agenda even more vigorously than he did last year.
 
The New Minority
 At the same time, the lopsided majorities to which he has guided virtually every measure before the Council can no longer be guaranteed. The minority of two who routinely dissented on the old 35-member Council has grown on the new 51-member body to a core of 16 -- 15 of whom, led by Ronnie M. Eldridge of Manhattan, declared victory after Mr. Vallone agreed last week to modestly relax the rules allowing the Speaker and the committee chairmen he appoints to control legislation.
The potential for more spontaneity within the Council and in its dealings with Mr. Dinkins still pale compared with the contentiousness between Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature, which has already led to costly delay in bridging a projected deficit in the fiscal year ending March 31. Common to both Albany and City Hall, though, is the skepticism of private credit-rating agencies whose verdict on the budget can vastly increase the cost of borrowing. Last week one agency reduced its rating on most New York State debt to the second-lowest rating among the 50 states.
Also peering over Mr. Dinkins's shoulder will be state watchdogs who hold the city to a higher accounting standard than the state imposes on itself. The four-year plan, including a $30 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, is expected to be unusually specific in an effort to meet the monitors' demands for significant reductions in the city's work force, for the shift of some services to private industry and for other economies -- including, perhaps, the shuttering of some superfluous jail cells. City officials also hope to win approval for a complicated debt refinancing and are even holding out hope for concessions from organized labor.
But if Mr. Dinkins's "new beginning" never got off the ground last year, the Mayor, at mid-term, is being forced to confront grim fiscal reality as never before. "This," said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, "is show time."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Soviet Aftershocks Include a Global Commodities Glut

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
WHEN your chief competitor goes out of business, that is supposed to be good news for your bottom line. But when the Soviet Union died, a lot of the commercial victors around the world caught a bad cold at the funeral.
The reason is a flood of exports from the former union that has severely depressed commodity prices. From over there, the export activity of the last few months probably looked like a desperate effort to keep bread on the table. But for competitors in uranium, aluminum, platinum, fertilizer and gold, it was an ironic reprise of the cold war threat of Nikita Khrushchev, to "bury you." Bruce L. Kaplan, who owns a precious metals consulting firm in Santa Monica, Calif., called it "dis-hoarding." The effects, which have been felt each year since 1989, have been dramatic, with the major exception to the pattern being oil, which Russia produces in abundance but is difficult to stockpile. 
 Reliable statistics about commodity exports were hard enough to assemble in the good old days of Communism, when the transactions were centrally controlled by Soviet authorities. In recent months, as the number of players has multiplied, tracking it has become even more complicated. So the clearest indication of the new activity is the effect on prices.
Platinum, for example, fell from $500 an ounce in 1989 to about $340 on Friday -- less even than gold. "It's an enormous problem," said Nina Lipton, vice president of the Platinum Guild International, a trade association in New York. The Soviets -- the Russians, mainly -- were the world's second-largest producers, after the South Africans, and centralized their sales, she said, but now new entities have popped up in the former union to sell platinum and they sometimes undercut each other.
Gold, meanwhile, was at about $358 on Friday, down from $500 in 1987. Because of a glut of Russian exports, the world scares that used to push up the price of gold, like the Persian Gulf war, now seem only to raise the blood pressure.
Aluminum ended 1992 at 51 cents a pound, down from 70 cents a year earlier. Robert Regan, an aluminum expert at American Metal Markets, a New York-based daily newspaper, said no one knows when the flood will abate, but without a Red Army to soak up production, it may be quite a while.
Urea fertilizer seems to have become even more chaotic. At Sovlink American Corporation, a company with American, British and former Soviet concerns as shareholders, the president, Terry English, described the situation as the union declined last year: "You'd be out there negotiating for $150 a ton, and out of nowhere, you'd get an offer for $120. They didn't know the value and they didn't care; they just wanted to make sure they were paid in dollars."
American uranium producers filed an anti-dumping complaint against the Soviets on Nov. 8, after watching the price of a pound of yellowcake, a lightly processed ore, drop to $7. It was nearly $12 in the summer of 1990.
 
Immense Stockpiles of Uranium
 "They have immense stockpiles they have built up since the end of World War II," said James C. Cornell of the Stamford, Conn., office of Nukem, a German trading firm. The price the Russians get now, he said, is far below cost for even the most efficient producer.
For nearly all these commodities, several other factors were at work. The international market for cars, which use platinum in catalytic converters, is down. Aluminum demand is down because of the recession and a slump in construction. Gold demand is down because inflation is dormant.
While exact numbers with which to measure the influence from the former Soviet Union are hard to come by, Mr. Regan put the increase at nearly 700,000 tons last year, meaning that total exports tripled. In gold, James R. Steel, a metals analyst with Refco Inc., a commodities trading firm in New York, said that exports had been holding steady at about 210 tons a year in the early 90's, and 1989 exports were 285 tons, with another 260 tons last year. Platinum exports probably hit 1 million ounces last year, up from 400,000 in normal times, Ms. Lipton said.
This is not the first episode of a surge in exports from what had been the Soviet Union. Mr. Regan pointed out that aluminum exports surged in the late 1950's and again in the early 60's, after wheat crop failures. John Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said that the Russians did the same thing with oil at the time, raising fears that a rising tide of "Red oil" would threaten American producers at a time when "anything the Soviet Union did that could hurt Western companies was viewed as a hostile act."
The latest surge of exports has not included oil, the volume of which has actually declined lately because of production problems. Mr. Lichtblau and others say the rate of oil exports will depend on a race between declining production and declining consumption, the latter dragged down by general economic decline.
Although the short-term cause of the surge is sales of stockpiled material, another difference from the late 50's and early 60's is that this time the Soviet collapse could lead to a sustained increase in the level of exports. The republics want to integrate their economies with the West, a step that will require hard currency, and the likely source is exports of raw materials. Now, however, those exports can be mined, drilled, smelted and refined with Western capital and technology.
"This is imperialism at its best for American capitalists," said Ms. Lipton. The largest country on earth, rich in all manner of natural resources, is being opened to the world.
